The company declared an interim dividend of 0.503 Singapore cent per share, down from the year-ago payout. Revenue increased 5% to S$98.4 million, while gross profit rose 18% to S$19.5 million. The company's net asset value increased to 39.41 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Insurer AXA to distribute products through Alibaba
summary: AXA, a French insurer, partnered with Alibaba and Ant Financial Services Group to distribute insurance products and services globally. The partnership aims to co-innovate and develop value-added products, explore new markets, and accelerate AXA's business growth in China. This global partnership will enable AXA to expand its customer base and increase its presence in the Chinese market.

site_title: Canada rebound set to survive wildfires that ruined May GDP
summary: Canada's GDP contracted 0.6% in May, the fastest pace in over seven years, due to record wildfires in Alberta that cut oil production by 22%. However, analysts predict the losses will be fully recovered in the second half. The Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz maintained the key lending rate at 0.5%, citing signs of oil production resuming. The economy is expected to rebound with annualized growth of 3.5% in the third quarter, according to analysts.

site_title: Baidu delivers more bad news to investors as China tightens ads
summary: Baidu, China's largest internet search service, has warned investors that government curbs on online advertising will hurt revenue growth for the next two to three quarters. The company forecast lower-than-expected sales of 18.04-18.58 billion yuan, citing stricter regulations and a decline of 1.9% in revenue. Analysts predict it may take 12 months for revenue and profits to return to normal growth pace. Baidu is diversifying into media, artificial intelligence, and cloud services, but faces intensifying competition and regulatory policy changes.

images.alt_text: DISAPPOINTING OUTLOOK: Baidu forecast lower-than-expected sales of 18.04 billion to 18.58 billion yuan this quarter.

site_title: Wall St banks face more lending scrutiny
summary: Wall Street banks are facing increased scrutiny from federal regulators regarding their lending standards for high-risk corporate loans. Regulators are questioning how these loans would perform under adverse conditions, seeking clarification on monitoring procedures and addressing potential risks. Despite the 2013 guidelines, regulators are concerned that many "pass deals" are on the line, and banks' withdrawal from the market has not eliminated risky deals, which are now being taken on by private equity firms and direct lenders.

site_title: MGCCT's Q1 DPU rises 9.1% to 1.85 cents
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a 9.1% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.85 Singapore cents for its fiscal first quarter ended June 30, driven by an enlarged portfolio and higher revenue. Gross revenue rose 11.9% to S$84.96 million, while net property income jumped 11.2% to S$69.42 million. The increase was mainly due to the acquisition of Sandhill Plaza in Shanghai and higher revenue from Festival Walk in Hong Kong.

site_title: Torchbearers
summary: Tennis players, including Louis Oosthuizen, Charl Schwartzel, Marc Leishman, and Vijay Singh, have cited Zika virus as a reason for dropping out of tournaments due to concerns over its potential impact on childbearing years. Other notable news includes the US seeing a drop in weekly jobless claims and China unveiling steps to aid employment amid trade tensions, while Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, owned by Ambani, has also delayed its India IPO beyond this year.

site_title: Starhill Reit FY16 DPU up 1.4%
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 1.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the financial year ended June 30, to 5.18 Singapore cents. Revenue rose 11.4% to S$219.7 million, with income distributed to unitholders reaching S$113 million, a 2.4% increase year-on-year. The fourth-quarter DPU remained stable at 1.29 Singapore cents, with income distributed to unitholders at S$28.1 million, unchanged from the previous quarter.

site_title: Brazil hedge-fund manager who called real rally sees more gains
summary: Brazil's hedge fund manager Luiz Fernando Figueiredo predicts the real will climb 9% to 3 reais per US dollar by year-end, contradicting a Bloomberg survey that expects a weaker real. Figueiredo, a former central bank director, attributes the rally to growing foreign investment due to easing concerns over the government's deficits. His flagship fund has returned 16% so far in 2016, beating 98% of peers, after years of sub-par returns.

images.alt_text: OPTIMISTIC: Despite outsize rallies this year across Brazilian financial markets, hedge fund manager Luiz Fernando Figueiredo argues that there are more profits to be made.

site_title: Beef bonanza for Brazil as Chinese dine on more foreign steak
summary: Brazil has surpassed Australia as the largest supplier of beef to China, with exports increasing by 65% in the first half of 2016 due to a production deficit and low prices. China's per capita beef consumption is expected to reach a record 3.864 kg this year, but production has not kept pace, leading to a 22% jump in imports to 1.225 million tonnes. This shift has created a sales bonanza for Brazilian exporters, particularly JBS SA, Minerva SA, and Marfrig Global Foods SA, with shipments to China and Hong Kong rising to 265,800 tonnes in the first six months of the year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine's Q2 2016 profit after tax and minority interests (Patmi) of $11.5 million missed expectations, dragged by a $35 million forex loss and $8 million impairment for Cosco. The company's interim DPS was lower than expected, and analysts cut their FY16-18E EPS estimates. SembCorp Marine's Brazil yard is still at risk, and rigbuilding is expected to be among the last to benefit in a cyclical recovery.

site_title: Champagne on ice is this summer's hot drink
summary: Champagne sales have surged this summer, with producers like Moet and Veuve Clicquot releasing new lines designed to be mixed with ice. Inspired by jet-setters in the south of France, Moet introduced Moet Ice Impérial, a champagne specifically made to be consumed over ice, in 2016. This summer, other brands have followed suit, including Veuve Clicquot's Rich and Moet's Ice Impérial Rosé. The trend is driven by a desire for a more casual approach to drinking champagne, with many consumers adding ice to their drinks to beat the heat.

site_title: Aggressive car loan schemes now target private-hire drivers
summary: Aggressive car loan schemes targeting private-hire drivers have emerged, with Cycle & Carriage partnering Goldbell Financial Services to offer a 90% financing option repayable over 10 years. This is the highest in the market, with most private-hire loans capped at 80% and a maximum tenure of seven years. The scheme aims to support retrenched workers and small businesses, while also catering to the growing number of new private-hire drivers seeking self-employment opportunities. The interest rate is 3.98% for seven years, compared to 2.78% for normal car loans.

site_title: Britain to review EDF's Hinkley Point nuclear energy plan
summary: Britain is reviewing EDF's $24 billion Hinkley Point nuclear energy plan, just weeks after the Brexit vote. The decision was made despite the board of French state-controlled EDF voting to proceed with the project. The review is the latest development in the project's uncertain future, with the UK government casting doubt on the plan. The review will likely delay a final decision on the project, which has been a contentious issue in British politics since its inception.

images.alt_text: UNDER REVIEW: The two new reactors at Hinkley Point, in south-west England, were targeted to provide around 7 per cent of Britain's electricity.

site_title: Brewer SABMiller accepts AB InBev final offer
summary: Brewer SABMiller has accepted a final takeover offer from Anheuser-Busch InBev, raising its cash offer to £45 per share. The decision comes after the value of the pound slumped following Britain's Brexit vote, affecting the initial £44 per share offer. The deal, expected to be the third largest in history, has already gained approval from regulatory authorities in the US, EU, and South Africa. SABMiller's takeover is expected to boost AB InBev's prospects in developing markets in Africa and China.

site_title: More needed to recharge Nintendo
summary: Nintendo's mobile game Pokémon Go has become a blockbuster, breaking records and drawing investor interest, with its shares soaring to US$42.1 billion. Despite the game's popularity, Nintendo has downplayed its impact on profits, and its stock has fluctuated. The game's success marks a potential revival for Nintendo, but the company still needs to utilize its valuable intellectual property to create long-term sustainable value. With plans to release four more mobile games, Nintendo may have seen the light in venturing into mobile gaming, but competition in the space remains intense.

site_title: Japan's top steelmakers boost output
summary: Japan's top steelmakers, Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal and JFE Steel, boosted output over April to June, with Nippon Steel posting its first increase in seven quarters. However, both firms swung to quarterly losses due to oversupply, a firmer yen, and lower demand. Despite higher steel prices, China's overcapacity and exports remain a drag, and Japanese steelmakers expect a 35% drop in annual profit. The yen's surge also affects customers, such as automakers, and may lead to price negotiations or output cuts.

site_title: S'porean detained under ISA for promoting violence and ISIS
summary: A Singaporean national, Zulfikar Mohamad Shariff, 44, has been detained under the Internal Security Act for promoting violence and ISIS ideology online. He made numerous Facebook posts glorifying ISIS and encouraging Muslims to take up arms, radicalising at least two other Singaporeans. Shariff's radicalisation began in 2001 and he had maintained contact with radical preachers in Australia and the UK. He was issued with a two-year detention order and two other individuals, including a security guard and a businessman, have been dealt with under the ISA for similar activities.

site_title: Captivating combo concepts
summary: Multi-concept spaces are emerging as a new form of experience-centric retail, offering variety to consumers and encouraging them to stay and explore. Examples include Mahota Commune, a restaurant, cafe, supermarket, TCM clinic, and studio, and Yoga Movement and Common Man Coffee Roasters' cafe-yoga studio space. These spaces aim to create a lifestyle experience, combining services and products to promote sustainability, wellness, and health. They also encourage customers to engage with the space in various ways, such as through free classes, workshops, and activities. Hotel Jen Tanglin's incorporation of experiences like yoga, mindfulness, and local lifestyle events is another example of this trend.

site_title: London's black cabs bet their future on technology over a century old
summary: London Taxi Co is investing $400 million to build electric cabs, with plans to start production in 2018, as the UK capital's smog problems worsen. The company, owned by China's Geely Automobile Holdings, aims to boost UK manufacturing and bring better air quality to London's streets. The move follows the UK government's plans to require all new taxis to be zero-emissions capable by 2018, with electric or hybrid motors. The transition could help eliminate 10,000 early deaths a year caused by smog, and is seen as a step towards cleaner air in the city.

site_title: CDLHT says hotel rates will stay competitive amid supply (Amended)
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 0.9% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.23 Singapore cents for the three months ended June 30, 2016. The trust attributed the drop to lower net property income, primarily due to soft trading environments in Singapore, Maldives, and Australia. Despite this, room rates are expected to remain competitive as new hotels enter the market, increasing room stock by 4.7%. The trust's average occupancy rate fell to 83.5%, and revenue per available room declined 9.2%.

site_title: Controlling shareholder Rawabi voices support for Vallianz
summary: Rawabi Holding, a controlling shareholder of Vallianz, has reaffirmed its "strong commitment" to the offshore services provider following recent announcements by major shareholder Swiber Holdings. Rawabi owns an 18.7% stake in Vallianz and is a strategic joint venture partner in the company's Middle East operations. The statement aims to inject confidence in Vallianz's business prospects, providing a boost to the company amid recent market uncertainty.

site_title: Consumer sentiment fell in July on dim economic prospects
summary: Consumer confidence in the US declined to 90 in July, down from 93.5 in June, due to dimmer views of the economy and lingering concerns about global market conditions. A record share of higher-income households cited the UK's Brexit decision as a factor. The economy expanded at a 1.2% rate in the second quarter, less than projected. Consumers' year-ahead prospects for the economy dropped to the lowest level in two years, with slower growth expected to translate into rising unemployment.

site_title: Brexit hits profits in London property agency Foxtons
summary: London property agency Foxtons' profits plummeted 42% in the first half of 2016 due to uncertainty surrounding the UK's EU membership referendum. Pre-tax profits fell to £18.1 million, and property sales in London were down substantially. The company attributes the decline to slow residential markets and expects a prolonged period of uncertainty, delaying a recovery in London's property sales markets. Revenue also fell 3% to £68.6 million, prompting Foxtons to review branch expansion plans.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariff salvo from Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating loss as H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. An Indonesian court detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC agreed to deepen green and transition finance cooperation.

site_title: Swiber to rescind wind-up application and go under judicial management; claims now at US$50.5m
summary: Swiber Holdings has withdrawn its winding-up application and will instead place the group under judicial management, following a discussion with its major financial creditor. The group received additional claims of US$24.6 million, increasing the total claims to approximately US$50.5 million. The decision comes after Swiber announced a winding-up petition two days earlier, which had caused market volatility. The company will apply to discharge the provisional liquidation order and withdraw the winding-up application.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust appoints new CEO for its subsidiary, City Gas
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust appointed Kenny Tan Chuan Huat as CEO of City Gas Pte Ltd, effective August 1, 2016. Tan, a former head of energy and feedstock at Linde Gas Asia, succeeds Teo Kwan Hai. Tan brings over 15 years of experience in the energy sector, including senior roles at SP PowerGrid and Gas Supply Pte Ltd. Teo will move to a new role within City Gas, also starting August 1.

site_title: India's ICICI Bank Q1 profit falls 25%, bad loans tick up
summary: India's ICICI Bank reported a 25% decline in quarterly profit to 22.32 billion rupees due to higher bad loans. The bank's gross bad loans rose to 5.87% in the June quarter, compared to 5.82% in the previous quarter. This was smaller than expected, with analysts anticipating a 21.99 billion rupee profit.

images.alt_text: ICICI Bank Ltd, India's top private sector lender by assets, said quarterly profit fell 25 per cent as its bad loans ticked up, although the decline was smaller than expected.

site_title: SBI Offshore warns of H1 loss amid tough market conditions
summary: SBI Offshore, an oil and gas contractor, expects to report a half-year loss due to lower revenue amid challenging market conditions. The company, which has diversified into the solar energy sector, will disclose more details on August 8. SBI Offshore also posted a US$4.0 million loss in 2015, citing scaled-back spending by oil majors and order deferrals. The company is seeking additional revenue through solar energy projects. Meanwhile, minority shareholders are challenging the existing board, including CEO Chan Lai Thong, over proposed new directors.

site_title: US economy grows 1.2 % in Q2 as inventories fall
summary: The US economy grew 1.2% in Q2, below forecast, due to a decline in inventories for the first time since 2011, but consumer spending drove growth. Inventories fell $8.1 billion, weighing on GDP growth, but a surge in consumer spending pointed to underlying strength. The Federal Reserve sees near-term risks to the economic outlook diminishing, and economists expect a tightening labor market and rising house prices to support spending for the rest of 2016.

images.alt_text: The US economy grew far less than expected in the second quarter as inventories fell for the first time since 2011, but a surge in consumer spending pointed to underlying strength.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q2 profit rises 53% on fair value gains; to pay 0.503 cent per share
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' Q2 net profit rose 53% to S$19.9 million, driven by a 53% increase in fair value gains from its Sydney investment property. On a per-share basis, net profit increased to 1.67 Singapore cents. The company also reported a 5% increase in revenue to S$98.4 million. As a result, Roxy-Pacific is declaring an interim dividend of 0.503 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Industrial Bank seeking 26 billion yuan in private share sale
summary: China's Industrial Bank Co plans to raise up to 26 billion yuan (S$5.3 billion) in a private stock placement to replenish core Tier-1 capital. The lender will sell 1.72 billion shares at 15.1 yuan each to six investors, including the Fujian province's finance bureau and China National Tobacco Corp. The company's Shanghai-traded stock will resume trading on August 1.

site_title: Pacific Radiance says it might not recover US$10.1m from Swiber (Amended)
summary: Pacific Radiance estimates it may not recover approximately US$10.1 million from Swiber due to services rendered to Swiber's subsidiaries, despite serving letters of demand. The company's net tangible assets and earnings per share are expected to be negatively impacted. Pacific Radiance joins other companies hit by Swiber's surprise winding-up announcement, sparking fears of contagion.

site_title: UIC Q2 profit soars 89.8% to S$112m
summary: UIC Industrial Corporation's second quarter profit surged 89.8% to S$112 million, driven by higher trading property sales and residential project sales. Revenue climbed 22.9% to S$236 million, with Q2 earnings per share rising to 4.3 Singapore cents. No dividend was proposed, and shares closed 0.727% down to S$2.73.

site_title: Myanmar govt launches thin economic policy
summary: Myanmar's government released a three-page economic policy, eight months after Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy won the election. The policy outlines 12 broad policies, including prioritizing labor-intensive enterprises and privatizing state-owned companies, but lacks specific details on how to achieve these goals. The government claims it is an "overview" with more detailed plans to follow, but no release date has been set. Businesses and international aid groups expressed disappointment over the lack of specifics, amid concerns that the government's focus on the peace process has hindered economic development.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's government released a long-awaited economic policy on Friday, but the document was noticeably light on specifics and will likely do little to ease the concern of businesses that have grown frustrated with the lack of a detailed plan.

site_title: Sanofi poised for swift Medivation move as earnings drop
summary: Sanofi is poised to swiftly reach a deal with US biotechnology company Medivation Inc as the pharmaceutical company's profit and sales declined. Sanofi's profit fell 8.7% last quarter due to cheaper copies of its best-selling insulin Lantus and slower-than-expected starts for new products. Medivation would bring tumor-fighting drug Xtandi and two experimental cancer products, potentially revitalizing Sanofi's struggling cancer business. Sanofi's CEO, Olivier Brandicourt, stated that the company is ready to move quickly and remain financially disciplined in the latest round of talks with Medivation.

site_title: Far East Orchard Q2 profit surges 575.2% to S$37m
summary: Far East Orchard's Q2 profit surged 575.2% to S$37m, driven by recognition of profits from its SBF Center joint venture property development project. Revenue fell 21% to S$44.7m, and earnings per share jumped to 9.01 cents. The company's net asset value per share edged up to S$2.88. No dividend was proposed, and shares closed 1.28% lower at S$1.54.

site_title: Japan's Tokai Tokyo Financial to buy 30 % of Ace Securities-sources
summary: Tokai Tokyo Financial Holdings plans to acquire a 30% stake in Ace Securities Co, a smaller Japanese brokerage firm, from large shareholders for several billion yen. The move is part of a consolidation effort by brokers to boost assets and reduce dependence on commissions from short-term trading. The acquisition will add Ace's 600 billion yen in assets to Tokai Tokyo Securities' 4 trillion yen, enhancing its competitiveness in the industry. This rare consolidation comes as brokers face declining profitability due to sluggish market conditions and individual investors' reluctance to trade stocks.

site_title: Non-trading items bolster Jardine Strategic earnings
summary: Jardine Strategic Holdings (JSH) reported a 46% increase in net profit to US$1.09 billion for the first half of the year, driven by non-trading gains and revaluations of investment properties. Revenue slid 4.6% to US$14.33 billion. Earnings per share rose to US$1.84, and the net asset value per share climbed to US$55.46. The company declared an interim dividend of nine US cents per share, up from 8.5 cents previously, and its shares closed US$0.75 higher at US$30.60.

site_title: US: Shares open lower
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Friday due to weak second-quarter growth figures, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% at 18,423.44. The Nasdaq, however, was boosted by strong earnings from Amazon and Google parent Alphabet. The US growth rate came in at 1.2%, below the 2.6% analyst estimate, described as "extremely disappointing" by Briefing.com analyst Patrick O'Hare.
