summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev raised its bid for SABMiller to £79 billion, responding to investor concerns following the UK's Brexit vote. The new offer includes £45 per share, a £1 increase from the previous offer, and an additional £4.66 in cash for those choosing a cash-and-stock alternative, valued at £51.14 per share. SABMiller shareholders will receive the increased offer.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals fall to 15-month low in June: BBA
summary: UK mortgage approvals fell to a 15-month low in June, with British banks approving 40,103 mortgages, down from May's revised 41,842. Business borrowing also decreased, with a 526 million pound drop in non-financial business lending in June. The British Bankers' Association attributed the decline to nerves before the June 23 referendum on European Union membership, with business confidence fragile in anticipation of the outcome. The results are not seen as a verdict on the economy post-Brexit.

site_title: Divestment gains lift SIA Engineering's Q1 bottom line
summary: SIA Engineering's Q1 net profit surged to S$198.40 million, driven by a S$141.6 million gain from divesting its stake in Hong Kong Aero Engine Services. The divestment, along with a special dividend of S$36.4 million, resulted in a total gain of S$178 million. Revenue decreased 2.1% to S$271.6 million, but earnings per share rose 17.67% to 17.67 Singapore cents. The company's net asset value per share increased to 137.9 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: DIVESTMENT gains boosted results for Singapore Airlines Engineering (SIA Engg) for its first quarter.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Luye Medical to develop healthcare capabilities, services in Chongqing with local government
summary: Singapore-based Luye Medical Group signed a strategic cooperation pact with Jiangbei District Government in Chongqing, China, to develop healthcare capabilities and services in the city. The group will invest $400 million over the next few years, introducing expertise from Australia, Singapore, South Korea, and the US, and partner with the Chongqing government to develop high-quality private healthcare services and facilities.

site_title: BP logs US$1.4b loss, draws line under oil disaster
summary: BP has posted a net loss of US$1.4 billion in the second quarter, drawing a line under the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill disaster. The company has also booked a net post-tax non-operating charge of US$2.8 billion for costs linked to the disaster. BP's CEO, Bob Dudley, expressed relief that the material liabilities for the spill are now behind the company, and stated that BP is a stronger, more focused and more disciplined company.

site_title: Post-Brexit vote rise in hate crimes prompts Britain to review policing
summary: Britain has announced a review of policing after a 6,200% increase in reported hate crimes following the Brexit vote. The majority of incidents targeted Muslims and Eastern Europeans, with harassment, assault, and verbal abuse being common. Interior Minister Amber Rudd stated that hatred has no place in 21st-century Britain and plans to commission a review of police understanding and response to hate crimes. The government will also provide funding for security measures and equipment for places of worship, and work with schools to tackle hatred and prejudice.

site_title: China: Stocks close up over 1% on broad rally
summary: China's stocks rose 1.2% to 3,269.59 points on the CSI300 index, and 1.1% to 3,050.17 points on the Shanghai Composite Index, driven by a broad-based rally in financials and industrials.

site_title: India's Flipkart buys Rocket Internet-backed online fashion store for US$70m
summary: Flipkart, India's largest e-commerce firm, acquired Jabong, a domestic online fashion retailer backed by Rocket Internet and Sweden's Kinnevik, for US$70 million in cash. The deal combines the two sites, increasing their monthly active users to 15 million. The acquisition comes as e-commerce players face increased competition from domestic rivals and Amazon. The move is part of Flipkart's efforts to expand its fashion segment and boost its market share in the competitive Indian e-commerce sector.

site_title: MCT's Q1 DPU up 1% at 2.03 Singapore cents
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 1% increase in distribution per unit to 2.03 Singapore cents for the first quarter, driven by positive contributions from VivoCity, Mapletree Anson, and PSA Building. Gross revenue rose 5.2% to S$73.38 million, with net property income increasing 3.7% to S$56.28 million. Despite market weaknesses, the Reit manager attributed the results to active asset management, with the NPI margin sustained at 76.7%. Unitholders will receive the distribution on Aug 29.

site_title: AGO report: HDB delayed final payments to contractors by up to 3.3 years
summary: The Auditor-General's Office (AGO) report found that the Housing & Development Board (HDB) delayed final payments to contractors by up to 3.3 years, contravening contractual requirements and potentially affecting contractors' cash flows. This occurred on 36 construction and upgrading contracts worth S$37.62 million. The AGO described this as "laxity" in project management.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts higher Q1 DPU, distributable amount
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) posted a 6.8% year-over-year rise in distributable amount for Q1 to S$51.5 million, driven by higher rental income. Distribution per unit (DPU) rose to 2.85 cents from 2.73 cents, and revenue grew 3% to S$84.1 million due to higher rental rates and occupancies.

site_title: Ecclestone's mother-in-law kidnapped in Brazil: reports
summary: Formula One chief Bernie Ecclestone's mother-in-law, Aparecida Schunck, was kidnapped in Sao Paulo, Brazil, on Friday night. Criminals are demanding 120 million reais (S$49.8 million) in ransom. The incident was reported by a Brazilian news magazine, but local police could not be confirmed. The motive and further details are not provided.

images.alt_text: The mother-in-law of Formula One chief Bernie Ecclestone has been kidnapped in Sao Paulo and criminals are demanding 120 million reais (S$49.8 million) in ransom, according to reports in a leading Brazilian news magazine.

site_title: AGO report: Nanyang Polytechnic gave $8.38m in 'hidden subsidies, excess funds' to subsidiary
summary: The Auditor-General's Office (AGO) reported that Nanyang Polytechnic (NYP) gave its subsidiary $8.38 million in 'hidden subsidies and excess funds' for the 2015/16 financial year. The AGO stated that NYP's transaction management with the subsidiary reflects a disregard for financial controls and proper governance. This is part of an audit of 11 statutory boards, including 16 ministries and eight organs of state, for the same period. The AGO's findings highlight concerns over financial management and governance within NYP.

site_title: Oil falls towards US$44, lowest since May, on glut worries
summary: Oil prices have fallen to their lowest since May, reaching US$44.49 a barrel, due to concerns about a persistent supply glut and weak refining margins. Global benchmark Brent crude is up over 60% from a 12-year low, but the rally has stalled. Analysts cite a delay in rebalancing the market, with US drillers adding oil rigs for a fourth consecutive week. Hedge funds have cut their bets on rising prices, further dampening sentiment, and US inventory reports are expected to show a fall in crude stocks but a rise in gasoline supplies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise, index closes at 8-month high on foreign buying
summary: South Korean shares reached an 8-month high on Tuesday, closing at 2,027.34 points, driven by foreign investors' buying spree for a 14th consecutive session, netting 190 billion won. The South Korean won also edged up, quoted at 1,134.9 to the dollar, as foreign monetary income increased the greenback supply.

site_title: Yuan firms against US dollar but weakens against currency basket
summary: China's yuan firmed against the US dollar, reaching 6.6778 per dollar, following the central bank's firmer guidance rate setting and a weaker dollar index. However, it weakened against a basket of currencies, falling to 95.97 on the Thomson Reuters/HKEX Global CNH index. The offshore yuan traded at 6.6867 per dollar, while one-year non-deliverable forwards contracts traded at 6.841, -2.39% away from the midpoint. The People's Bank of China intervenes in the market to keep the onshore spot rate stable, traders say.

site_title: Porsche to create more than 1,400 jobs for electric car
summary: Porsche has increased the number of jobs it will create for its first all-electric sports car, the Mission E, to over 1,400, up from the initial 1,000. The majority of these positions will be at the Zuffenhausen base, where a new paint shop and assembly line will be built. Additionally, the company will increase apprenticeships to 220 from 150. This expansion aims to support the production of the battery-powered car, set to be completed by the end of the decade.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stable at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets, including London's FTSE 100, Frankfurt's DAX 30, and Paris's CAC 40, steadied at the start of trading on Tuesday, awaiting interest rate decisions in Japan and the US. London's FTSE 100 added 0.2% to 6,720.94 points, while the eurozone markets were essentially flat. The markets await clues about policy from the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan, which conclude their meetings this week, amidst strong data fueling speculation of an interest rate rise.

site_title: MOE to tighten processes to prevent bond-breaking by foreign students
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) in Singapore has tightened processes to monitor and enforce scholarship bonds for foreign students, following a report by the Auditor-General's Office that criticized the lack of oversight. Despite a 1% intentional default rate and 4% of students still being contacted, the majority of foreign students are fulfilling their bonds. The MOE reports that the default rates have fallen significantly over the last three years, with a small group seeking deferment or unable to fulfill due to medical reasons.

images.alt_text: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said on Tuesday it has worked with the universities in Singapore to tighten processes to monitor and enforce scholarship bonds, following a report from the Auditor-General's Office Singapore (AGO) that ticked off MOE for a lack of oversight over these bonds.

site_title: Pound slides after report BOE's Weale favours immediate stimulus
summary: The pound dropped 0.4% to US$1.3089 after a report that Bank of England policy maker Martin Weale favors immediate stimulus for the UK economy, citing weaker-than-expected purchasing managers' indexes. Weale's shift in stance, considered hawkish, affected sterling's value, which has been under pressure since the UK's Brexit vote. The Bank of England sets policy on August 4, with expectations of no easing at the July meeting. The pound touched its lowest since 1985.

site_title: Hyundai Motor Q2 profit hit by slow emerging market sales
summary: Hyundai Motor reported a 1.5% drop in Q2 net profit to 1.76 trillion won (S$2.1 billion), citing slow emerging market sales and currency swings. The firm sold 2.39 million cars in the first half of 2016, down 1.0% from a year ago. Hyundai faces challenges from Brexit uncertainty, growing competition in global markets, and diplomatic tensions with China over the deployment of the Thaad system. The company warned of more difficulties in the latter half of the year.

site_title: Philippine Abu Sayyaf kidnapped five sailors, Malaysia says
summary: Malaysia's police chief confirmed that five tugboat crew members, kidnapped from their vessel off the coast of Sabah, Borneo island, were abducted by the Philippine militant group Abu Sayyaf. The group, notorious for repeated kidnappings, has been blamed for recent abductions, including beheading Canadian tourists and releasing Indonesian sailors. The incident occurred in the region where government authority is weak and banditry is common, and marks the latest in a series of high-seas kidnappings by the Abu Sayyaf.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Stocks end flat
summary: Australian and New Zealand share markets ended flat on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index up 0.07% to 5537.50 and New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index down 0.9% to 7310.39. Initial movements were driven by commodity prices and global markets, but markets rebounded to close slightly higher.

site_title: Update: Base salary of Employment Pass to be raised to S$3,600 from Jan 1; NTUC lauds move
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Manpower announced an update to the Employment Pass qualifying salary, increasing it to S$3,600 from S$3,300, effective January 1, 2017. The move aims to keep pace with rising local wages and maintain the quality of the foreign workforce. Only new applicants with a monthly salary of S$3,600 or more will be considered, with those with more years of experience required to command higher salaries. NTUC assistant secretary-general Patrick Tay praised the move, saying it will help level the playing field for local professionals and build a stronger Singaporean core.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: AGO report: MFA overpaid S$109,868 in telco bills
summary: The Auditor-General's Office (AGO) report revealed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MFA) overpaid S$109,868 in telco bills and wasted S$80,744 due to improper verification of invoices. The AGO found that MFA did not carry out proper verification of invoices to ensure correct rates and amounts billed and paid. This irregularity occurred in the 2015/16 financial year.

site_title: Dirty water stunts millions of Indian children: study
summary: A new study by WaterAid reveals that India has the world's largest number of stunted children due to dirty water, lack of toilets, and poor hygiene. With 48 million children under the age of five affected, this accounts for 30% of the global total. Stunting is a form of malnutrition that can lead to physical and intellectual weakness. The study highlights the need for improved sanitation and access to clean water, with 140,000 children dying annually from diarrhoea and 76 million lacking safe water access.

images.alt_text: India is home to the world's largest number of stunted children due to a lack of toilets, dirty water and poor hygiene, according to a new study published on Tuesday.

site_title: AGO report: National Arts Council paid consultants S$0.41m to build S$0.47m bin centre
summary: The Auditor-General's Office (AGO) report revealed that the National Arts Council paid a S$0.41 million consultancy fee for a S$0.47 million bin centre, with the fee being 87.2% of the construction cost. The report also highlighted delays in obtaining approvals for the Victoria Theatre and Victoria Concert Hall Redevelopment project, with 47 out of 164 variation works carried out before approvals were given, resulting in delays of up to 3.5 years. This indicated a breakdown in controls to justify and approve variation works.

site_title: Ooredoo said to consider sale of stake in StarHub
summary: Ooredoo QSC is considering selling its 14% stake in StarHub Pte Ltd, the Singapore-based phone company. The Qatari-owned carrier is working with HSBC Holdings to gauge interest in the sale, citing a desire to focus on its core Middle East market. This move comes as Singapore plans an auction of additional frequencies to enable the entry of a fourth mobile carrier, potentially boosting competition in the country. Ooredoo's sale of its StarHub stake would be a significant development for the Singaporean telecommunications industry.

site_title: AGO report: MinLaw failed to keep proper asset records of those who died at homes
summary: The Auditor-General's Office (AGO) report revealed that the Public Trustee's Office (PTO) under the Ministry of Law failed to maintain proper asset records of deceased individuals who received assets from nursing homes in 2015/16. The lack of adequate controls and independent checks increased the risk of asset misappropriation. Discrepancies were found in the recording of assets, raising concerns about the accurate accounting of trust assets.

site_title: Brexit rewrites UK budget rules as borrowing set for first big rise since 2010
summary: The UK government, under Finance Minister Philip Hammond, is expected to increase borrowing by nearly £65 billion over the next two years due to the post-Brexit economic shock. This marks the first significant rise in borrowing since 2010. Hammond plans to "reset" government budget policy to ease austerity, with economists predicting a material rise in borrowing next year. The government may consider a fiscal stimulus package, potentially including public investment or tax measures, to boost the economy. However, experts warn that higher borrowing could lead to extended austerity in the long run.

site_title: Australia dollar gains ahead of inflation nail-biter; kiwi rises
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.72% to US$0.7521 ahead of inflation data, which is forecast to dip to 1.4%, potentially leading to another rate cut as early as next week. The Aussie also gained against the British pound after dovish comments from Bank of England policymaker Martin Weale. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar rose 0.7% to US$0.7044. Market analysts expect the US Federal Reserve to stand pat on policy this week, but investors are bracing for possible signals about a tightening later this year.

site_title: Florida state judge rules bitcoin doesn't qualify as money
summary: A Florida judge ruled that bitcoin does not qualify as money, clearing a man of state money-laundering charges. Michell Espinoza was accused of selling over $1,500 in bitcoins to undercover detectives, but the judge found that virtual currencies like bitcoin are not tangible wealth and cannot be hidden like cash. The ruling is the first of its kind and may set a precedent for other bitcoin cases, with an appellate court likely to decide the issue sooner.

site_title: Singapore's June factory output disappoints with 0.3% year-on-year dip
summary: Singapore's factory output fell 0.3% year-on-year in June, marking a surprise dip after three months of growth. The decline was largely due to a 10.2% year-on-year contraction in biomedical output. Excluding biomedical, factory output grew 2.4% with support from electronics and precision-engineering clusters. This brings 2016's overall factory output growth to 1.2% year-on-year.

site_title: AGO finds 'inadequate financial controls' in agencies including HDB, LTA
summary: The Auditor-General's Office in Singapore has found "inadequate financial controls" in several government agencies, including the Housing & Development Board and the Land Transport Authority. Weak controls led to losses of revenue, with the LTA missing out on S$13.9 million in tolls in 2014/15. The AGO also noted inadequate oversight of external entities and lapses in contract management. The report highlights the need for improved governance and financial controls in government operations.

site_title: Asia: Markets move cautiously ahead of bank meetings
summary: Asian markets moved cautiously ahead of central bank meetings in Japan and the US, with Tokyo stocks sinking on a strong yen. The Federal Reserve concludes its meeting Wednesday, and the Bank of Japan is expected to announce a significant bond-buying scheme. Oil prices dropped, hitting investor confidence. Japanese stocks fell 1.6%, while Hong Kong rose 0.3%, and Shanghai added 0.6%. US traders took cash off the table after pushing multiple records on Wall Street, with the Dow and S&P 500 falling over 2% on Monday.

site_title: Australia: Shares track commodities lower, NZ stocks flat
summary: Australian shares declined 0.32% to 5,515.7, tracking lower commodity prices and global markets. Energy and mining stocks fell, with Santos down 4.71%, Origin Energy down 2.9%, and Newcrest Mining down 3%. Consumer goods retailers rose, led by electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi up 3.3%. New Zealand shares were flat, hovering around record highs.

site_title: Oil prices edge up but supply glut woes return
summary: Oil prices rose slightly in Asia, up 10-18 cents to $43.23-$44.90 per barrel, after a 2% drop the previous day. The supply glut worries are returning, with US inventories falling less than expected and petrol supplies rising during peak demand season. The US Energy Information Administration's report also showed an increase in rigs coming online, increasing production and denting prices. Market strategist Evan Lucas stated that fundamentals don't support a move up to $55-$60 per barrel, but prices may not plummet to near 13-year lows.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips on global oil price drop, stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won decreased by 0.2% to 1,139.4 as of 0203 GMT, pressured by a decline in global oil prices. Market expectations of a potential US Federal Reserve rate hike in September may further drag the won down to 1,150 won per dollar.

site_title: US dollar falls more than 1% on the day against yen
summary: The US dollar fell more than 1% against the yen on Tuesday, as investors expect Japan's stimulus steps to fall short of initial hopes. The dollar dropped to 104.71 yen, its lowest since July 14. The Japanese government's massive spending package, worth 20 trillion yen, is expected to be less than initially stated. This move is attributed to investors' growing concerns about the country's economy.

site_title: McDonald's said to plan US$400m Malaysia, Singapore sale
summary: McDonald's plans to sell 20-year franchise rights in Malaysia and Singapore for at least $400 million. Suitors are seeking funding for the deal, with one potential bidder in talks for up to $300 million. The move is part of McDonald's international turnaround plan, which aims to increase local ownership in Asia. The company currently owns most restaurants in the region and seeks to have 95% of its Asian restaurants under local ownership. This sale is the latest in McDonald's Asia revamp, following plans to sell operations in China, Hong Kong, and South Korea.

site_title: Hot stock: Katrina Group surges on trading debut
summary: Katrina Group, a food and beverage firm, made its trading debut with its shares surging 83% to S$0.385 on the Catalist-listed exchange. The company raised S$7.5 million from its initial public offering, which included 35.8 million new shares. Katrina Group, which started as a small stall, now owns and operates 32 restaurants in Singapore and two in China.

site_title: Solar plane completes historic round-the-world trip
summary: The Solar Impulse 2, a sun-powered airplane, completed its historic round-the-world trip, landing in Abu Dhabi, UAE, after a 48-hour flight from Cairo. The 42,000-kilometer journey, which began in March 2015, marked the first time a plane traveled the globe without fuel. Swiss explorer Bertrand Piccard and pilot Andre Borschberg took turns at the controls of the single-seat aircraft, relying on 17,000 solar cells to power the plane. The historic flight aims to promote renewable energy and has sparked hope for a cleaner future.

site_title: Shell Philippines files 29.7b peso IPO; may be country's largest in 2016
summary: Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corp plans to raise up to 29.7 billion pesos (S$855 million) through an initial public offering (IPO), potentially the Philippines' third and largest in 2016. The company will offer 330 million shares at up to 90 pesos per share. The IPO comes as the Philippine Stock Exchange shows signs of stability after months of volatility. The proceeds will be used for capital expenditures, working capital, and general corporate expenses, fulfilling the requirement to offer at least 10% of its equity to the public.

images.alt_text: Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corp is looking to raise up to 29.7 billion pesos (S$855 million) in what could be the Philippines' third and largest initial public offering (IPO) this year.

site_title: End of the road or new beginning for Yahoo?
summary: Yahoo is selling its core assets to Verizon for $4.8 billion, marking the end of the internet pioneer as a corporate entity. However, analysts believe the Yahoo brand may continue to live on and potentially grow under Verizon's ownership. The deal aims to create synergies between the two companies, with Verizon seeking to expand beyond its telecom roots and Yahoo needing help against online rivals. Verizon plans to maintain the Yahoo brand on its media properties and may give the new business unit autonomy to attract talent and innovate.

site_title: Singapore shares open 18.59 points lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 18.59 points lower on Tuesday, down 0.63% to 2,911.26, following a lower close on Wall Street overnight. UOB and DBS were among top losers, with 55.7 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 70 to 54. This marks a reversal of the 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, which was not mentioned in the article.

site_title: Broker's take: Nomura wary of higher costs at Raffles Medical in Q2 results
summary: Nomura expressed concerns over rising operational costs at Raffles Medical Group (RMG), despite a 19.8% revenue growth to S$118.95 million in the second quarter. The brokerage maintained a "buy" rating with a target price of S$1.77. RMG's net profit increased by 4.5% to S$16.67 million. Nomura attributed the strong revenue growth to all divisions' performance, but warned that rising costs could impact the company's profitability.

site_title: JTC launches Tampines Industrial Drive site for sale
summary: JTC has launched a 0.49-ha site at Tampines Industrial Drive (Plot 3) for sale under the second-half 2016 Industrial Government Land Sales programme. The 20-year-tenure site is zoned for Business-2 development with a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.4. Industrialists can apply for the site before the tender closes on September 20, 2016, at 11am. The move aims to offer more choices for industrial development, aligning with the Singapore government's efforts to encourage industrial growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Museum sketches bright future for art in Indonesia
summary: A new museum, the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art in Nusantara (Museum Macan), is set to open in Indonesia, aiming to boost the country's art scene. The 4,000 square meter venue, funded by businessman Haryanto Adikoesoemo, will feature a collection of 800 pieces by Indonesian, Asian, and Western artists, including works by notable artists such as Andy Warhol and Affandi. The museum's opening is seen as a response to Indonesia's lack of high-quality art institutions and its growing affluent middle class.

site_title: Australia probes 'shocking' youth detention abuse
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull ordered a Royal Commission into the mistreatment of teenage boys at the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre in the Northern Territory. Graphic evidence showed prison guards assaulting and tear-gassing the boys, with one being hooded and shackled to a restraint chair. The inquiry will investigate the culture that allowed the abuse to occur and expose the perpetrators. Human rights groups, including Amnesty International and Save the Children, have long urged the government to act on abuses in juvenile detention, calling for alternative approaches to rehabilitation.

site_title: AA Reit posts flat DPU growth in Q1
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) reported flat distribution per unit (DPU) growth in Q1, with a DPU of 2.75 Singapore cents, unchanged from the same period last year. Net property income increased 1% to S$20.4 million, while the unit base expanded slightly. The portfolio occupancy stood at 92.7% as of June 30, 2016.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip at open
summary: Hong Kong shares slipped 0.47% at the open on Tuesday, following losses on Wall Street and amid anticipation of policy meetings by the Japanese and US central banks. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,890.89, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also decreased marginally. Traders took profits after a two-week rally, awaiting central bank decisions.

site_title: Singapore Blue Circle approved for 40MW wind project in Vietnam
summary: Singapore-based wind energy developer Blue Circle has received an investment certificate from Vietnamese authorities for a 40-megawatt wind project in Ninh Thuan province. The project, in partnership with Vietnamese company TSV, is expected to start construction in 2017 with an estimated US$60 million investment. The site has potential for 70-100 megawatts of capacity, and a long-term lease and power purchase agreement with Vietnam's national power utility EVN is planned.

site_title: Michelle Obama delivers glowing endorsement of Clinton
summary: Michelle Obama delivered a glowing endorsement of Hillary Clinton at the Democratic National Convention, praising her as a strong leader who can shape the country's future for the next four years. In a passionate speech, Obama highlighted Clinton's commitment to her daughters and the nation, and urged Americans to reject "hateful language" and partisan battles. With her husband Barack Obama, she emphasized the importance of preserving his accomplishments, including healthcare reform and the Iran nuclear deal. Obama also reiterated that she has no plans to run for office, stating that she wants to stay involved in public service through other means.

images.alt_text: When her husband first ran for president in 2008, Michelle Obama cautiously entered the political arena, fully supportive of his candidacy yet wary of the country's partisan battles.

site_title: New Philippine leader Duterte sets out growth focus in first big speech
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte delivered his first state of the nation address, outlining his focus on economic growth and job creation. He pledged to relax economic restrictions, lower taxes, and attract foreign investment. Duterte also vowed to accelerate infrastructure spending, improve transportation links, and provide free contraceptives to the poor. He promised to combat corruption and illegal drugs, and announced a unilateral cease-fire with Maoist rebels. The address was seen as a boost to the stock market, with the Philippine Stock Exchange Index rising 0.3% at close.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.83 points to 1666.99. Losers outnumbered gainers 62 to 56, and volume was 40.37 million lots worth RM12.4 million.

site_title: SCMP CEO Robin Hu to join Temasek in December
summary: Singaporean Robin Hu, CEO of South China Morning Post, is stepping down to join investment company Temasek in December. He will become the joint head of Temasek's sustainability and stewardship group, effective December 1.

site_title: China internet regulator fines websites over reporting: media
summary: China's internet regulator has fined several websites for violating internet publication rules, ordering them to rectify pages that ran news stories based on their own reporting. This move appears to be part of President Xi Jinping's administration's efforts to strengthen the ruling Communist Party's grip on news and information. The enforcement of these rules comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The fines and rectification orders mark a significant step in China's efforts to control the flow of information online.

images.alt_text: China's internet regulator has fined several websites for violating internet publication rules and ordered them to "rectify" pages that ran news stories based on their own reporting, state media has reported.

site_title: Stocks to watch: PLife Reit, Yoma, Raffles Medical, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Joyas International
summary:
Singapore stocks to watch on July 26, 2026, include:

Parkway Life Reit, down 10.2% due to absence of one-off distribution gain.
Yoma Strategic Holdings fell 28.6% in fiscal Q1 due to lower gross profit.
Raffles Medical Group's second-quarter net profit rose 4.5% to S$16.67 million.
Mapletree Logistics Trust's total return dropped 57.9% in Q1 due to loss in financial hedging instruments.
Joyas International Holdings extended the rights issue period by one day after stock code error.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; techs, banks down
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.2% to 8,974.56 on Tuesday, following a one-year intraday high on Monday. Electronics and financial shares declined, with Hon Hai Precision and Cathay Financial Holdings slipping 0.2% and 0.4% respectively. The Taiwan dollar softened to T$32.170 per US dollar. The decline was attributed to cautious trading.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on stronger yen
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Tuesday, following a negative lead from Wall Street and a stronger yen, which hurt exporters. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.51% and the Topix index fell 0.63%. The decline was attributed to the yen's appreciation, which made exports less competitive.

site_title: Japan to miss FY2020 GDP target of 600t yen: govt forecast
summary: Japan's government forecasts its fiscal 2020 nominal GDP will be 551 trillion yen, missing the 600 trillion yen target, with sluggish growth expected to continue. This assumption is based on a mid- to long-term real economic growth rate of 1% or less. The forecast does not account for a massive stimulus package expected this autumn.

site_title: Japan pension fund with 11t yen hiring to boost region debt
summary: Japan's National Federation of Mutual Aid Association for Municipal Personnel is considering buying more regional government bonds and state-backed organizations' debt due to negative interest rates, which have pushed the benchmark Nomura-BPI index yield below zero. The pension fund, with 11 trillion yen in assets, is recruiting managers with more freedom to deviate from the benchmark, aiming to boost returns in the world's fastest-aging population. Regional government bonds have higher yields than sovereign bonds, and the fund is exploring alternative investment strategies to cope with low yields and negative returns.

site_title: Japan to double direct spending in stimulus package: Nikkei
summary: Japan's government is set to increase direct spending in its stimulus package to 6 trillion yen (S$77.8 billion), doubling the initial planned 3 trillion yen, according to a report by Nikkei. The package, which could exceed 20 trillion yen, aims to bolster the economy through direct spending, state subsidies, and lending programs. The government will compile a supplementary budget of around 2 trillion yen to fund part of the package, with the rest to be funded in the next fiscal year's budget, starting in April 2017.

site_title: Amazon gets permission from UK to explore drone deliveries
summary: Amazon has secured permission from the UK government to explore the use of small drones for deliveries, with the goal of starting such services by 2017. The partnership was facilitated by the UK Civil Aviation Authority and a cross-government team, following a video showcasing drone delivery capabilities released last year. This move marks a significant step forward for Amazon's plans to utilize drones for package delivery.

site_title: China asks US to support resumption of talks with Philippines
summary: China's foreign minister Wang Yi asked US Secretary of State John Kerry to support resuming talks with the Philippines over the South China Sea, following a UN-backed court ruling in favor of Manila. China refused to accept the ruling and has blamed the US for stoking tensions. Wang urged the US to take steps to support the resumption of talks, maintaining regional peace and stability. This comes after Southeast Asian nations dropped any reference to the court ruling in a joint statement, with Cambodia opposing it.

images.alt_text: China's foreign minister has asked the US secretary of state John Kerry to support the resumption of talks between China and the Philippines over the South China Sea, following a ruling against Beijing over the dispute earlier this month.

site_title: Pollution from commercial jets harms environment: US
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has concluded that commercial jets' greenhouse gas emissions contribute to global warming, endanger public health, and harm the environment. Aircraft are the single-largest GHG-emitting transportation source in the US, accounting for about 3% of total US emissions, and 29% globally. The EPA aims to regulate passenger planes to address climate change and public health concerns, excluding small tourist and military aircraft. The agency has already set GHG standards for cars and trucks, paving the way for future aircraft engine standards.

site_title: New Zealand posts monthly trade surplus of NZ$127m in June
summary: New Zealand posted a monthly trade surplus of NZ$127 million in June, exceeding forecasted NZ$150 million. The annual deficit was NZ$3.3 billion. Exports reached NZ$4.26 billion, while imports totaled NZ$4.13 billion.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip with oil near 3-month low while yen, gold jump
summary: Asian shares declined amid a near three-month low in oil prices, with Japan's Topix index falling over 1% due to a rebounding yen. Industrial metals and gold rallied, while copper and nickel rose for the first time in three days. Investors are awaiting central bank meetings in the US and Japan, which may impact commodity prices and markets.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands rises amid signs of turnaround in Macau
summary: Las Vegas Sands Corp rose in extended trading after reporting a rise in mass-market gaming revenue in Macau for the first time in two years. The company's president, Rob Goldstein, stated that gaming floors were busy, especially on weekends, and Macau is transforming into the world's greatest mass market. This positive sign suggests a turnaround in the two-year slump in betting in the Chinese enclave.

images.alt_text: Las Vegas Sands Corp, the world's largest casino company, rose in extended trading on signs a two-year slump in betting is easing in the Chinese enclave of Macau.

site_title: Google-backed Chinese smartwatch to go head to head with Apple's
summary: Mobvoi Inc, a Chinese AI startup backed by Google, plans to sell its smartwatch, the Ticwatch 2, in the US in September, competing with Apple's products. The $200 smartwatch features voice-activated natural language search and innovative scrolling features. Founder Li Zhifei aims to sell 50,000 devices within a year, reaching $100 million in revenue. The company's success in China, where its device was the third-best selling watch on JD.com, may lead to a US IPO next year if the device replicates its success.

images.alt_text: Mobvoi Inc, the Chinese AI startup backed by Google, intends to go toe-to-toe with Apple Inc when it begins selling its smartwatches in the US in September.

site_title: Panama Papers show Italian bribes' path to Algeria: ICIJ
summary: Italian company Saipem SpA allegedly paid $275 million in bribes to Algerian officials through offshore shell companies created by law firm Mossack Fonseca. The bribes were used to secure $10 billion in oil and gas deals. Prosecutors in Milan believe Franco-Algerian businessman Farid Bedjaoui used the shell companies to funnel the bribes. An Italian judge ordered Saipem and officials to stand trial, and Interpol has issued an international alert for Bedjaoui's arrest. This case is the latest in a series of corruption allegations against Saipem, which has faced similar allegations in the past.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge ahead led by Ryanair, William Hill; energy stocks down
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by a bullish outlook from Ryanair and a surge in William Hill shares amid bid interest from rival companies. Energy stocks fell 2.1% due to weaker crude prices. Germany's DAX rose 0.5% despite a decline in business morale, with economists citing the resilience of the country's economy. Shares in SEB rose to a record high after interim results, while Monte dei Paschi di Siena fell 8.3% amid concerns over a potential rights issue.

site_title: South Korea Q2 GDP growth marks 2-quarter high as capex, consumption rebound
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.7% in Q2, the fastest annual growth since 2014, driven by improved domestic consumption and capex. The country's GDP expanded 3.2% from a year earlier, exceeding forecasts. The central bank estimates annual growth at 2.7% and the government at 2.8%. The Bank of Korea is expected to cut interest rates again, with a majority of analysts predicting another rate cut by year-end. The government has submitted a $9.7 billion supplementary budget to create 68,000 new jobs.

site_title: Ringgit set for longest losing streak in more than a year on oil
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is set for its longest losing streak in almost 14 months, weakening 0.5% to 4.0875 per dollar amid concerns over the country's finances due to a decline in crude oil prices below $45 a barrel. The ringgit has declined 3.4% in the past seven days, surpassing the previous longest run of losses since June 2, 2015.

site_title: Cranes stand idle as Myanmar businesses bemoan economic policy drift
summary: Myanmar's ruling party, led by Aung San Suu Kyi, will announce its economic plans this week, aiming to reassure businesses and investors concerned about the lack of clear policy detail. Despite the country's 7-8% annual growth rate since 2011, businesses are scaling back expansion plans due to uncertainty. The government's economic strategy will focus on agricultural development and job creation in the private sector, but critics say it lacks detail and prioritizes other issues, such as the peace process. The announcement comes after the scrapping of approved construction projects and a review of high-rise developments, which has halted work on half-built sites.

site_title: Ship hits wall of Panama Canal, renews design concerns
summary: A Chinese container ship, the Xin Fei Zhou, hit a wall of the Panama Canal's new lane, the third incident since the canal's expansion in June, amid concerns over design safety. The ship, owned by China Shipping Container Lines, is undergoing repairs. The incidents follow previous collisions with the canal's fenders, raising questions about the safety of large vessels navigating the expanded waterway. The Panama Canal Authority is investigating the latest incident, which has sparked renewed concerns about the canal's design and safety.

site_title: Chow Tai Fook plans US wholesale business amid China slowdown
summary: Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group plans to launch a US wholesale business, selling polished and rough diamonds to retailers, to offset the effects of a slowdown in China's luxury market. The move aims to tap into the US market's 40% of global diamond sales. The business is expected to be launched within a year, with the company seeking to partner with local retailers. This strategic move reflects Chow Tai Fook's lack of confidence in the Greater China market, where profits have plummeted 46% due to Chinese tourists skipping the city for other shopping destinations.

images.alt_text: Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group Ltd plans to expand in the US market by selling diamonds to retailers there, as it seeks to offset effects of a slowdown in China that has hurt luxury sales and led profits to plunge.

site_title: Oil continues slide on inventory glut
summary: Oil futures slid on Monday, with West Texas Intermediate benchmark crude falling to $43.13, its lowest level in three months. The decline followed concerns about a supply glut and the strong dollar, which raises prices for holders of other currencies. Analysts attribute the drop to the less-than-expected decline in US crude inventory, as reported by the EIA, and the rise in gasoline supplies during peak driving season. The price drop brings relief to investors, but the overall market outlook remains bearish.

site_title: Yoma posts 28.6% fall in Q1 profit, sees progress in Myanmar under new government
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Myanmar-based company, reported a 28.6% drop in Q1 profit to S$1.83 million, primarily due to lower gross profit and weaker revenue. The decrease was attributed to the completion of buildings in StarCity Zone A and deferring property sales in Pun Hlaing Estate. Despite this, the company expects progress in Myanmar under the new government.

images.alt_text: Yoma Strategic Holdings, which has real estate and investment businesses in Myanmar, on Tuesday posted a 28.6 per cent drop in net profit for fiscal first quarter on lower gross profit.

site_title: 19 dead in knife attack on Japan disabled care centre
summary: At least 19 people were killed in a knife attack on a care centre for the mentally disabled in Sagamihara, Japan, on Tuesday. A 26-year-old man, Satoshi Uematsu, admitted to carrying out the attack, citing his desire to "make the disabled disappear." 25 people were wounded, 20 seriously. Japan has a low rate of violent crime, but has seen increasing cases of attacks on vulnerable individuals.

site_title: Greek PM proposes constitutional change for 'direct democracy'
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras proposes constitutional changes to give Greeks "direct democracy," allowing them to elect the president and hold referendums on laws. The proposed changes also include a maximum of two consecutive terms in parliament and a "religion-neutral" state. Tsipras plans to form discussion groups nationwide to deliver a report by April on public proposals for the constitution. The changes must be approved by a new legislative body after the next elections, which are due in 2019, and could be put to a referendum.

site_title: Disunity rules as US Democratic convention gets underway
summary: The US Democratic convention opened in chaotic scenes, with rival supporters of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders trading boos and jeers, reflecting the party's disunity. The convention comes as polls show Republican Donald Trump leading the presidential race. The party is reeling from leaked Democratic National Committee emails that showed staff undermining Sanders' campaign and questioning his Jewish faith. Sanders lost the primary but has angered his supporters, who believe the race was fixed. The convention will continue with prime-time addresses from Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Michelle Obama, but the party is seeking to project a unified message ahead of the presidential election.

site_title: US dollar, yen weaken as central banks to meet
summary: US and Japanese central banks are set to meet this week, influencing currency markets. The US dollar and euro weakened against the yen, with the euro falling to 116.32 yen and the dollar falling to 105.82 yen. The euro rose slightly against the dollar, and the British pound also rose. Analysts expect Japan to lend more monetary support, potentially boosting the yen. A failure to meet market expectations could lead to further yen depreciation.

site_title: Hammerson: UK property market facing uncertainty after Brexit vote
summary: Hammerson Plc, a UK shopping centre landlord, expressed uncertainty about the impact of Brexit on property valuations. The company's external valuers reported a reduced probability of valuations matching sale prices after the Brexit vote. This uncertainty affects the lettings and investment markets, leaving Hammerson and others to navigate a period of uncertainty.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Post's earnings may be impacted by integration headwinds and goodwill provisions in FY2017, but the company's transformation to an ecommerce and logistics outfit is deemed necessary. CapitaLand Mall Trust's redevelopment of Funan is expected to inject new life to the ageing mall, while Frasers Commercial Trust's occupancy rate improved to 93.3% in Q2 FY2016. Microsoft extended its lease at Alexandra Technopark for another five years, and Frasers Commercial Trust's fair value estimate was lifted to S$1.45 due to a lower risk-free rate assumption.

site_title: Diversification as a driving force
summary: Lian Beng Group, a Singapore-based construction company, has diversified its business to reduce dependence on a single industry sector. The firm operates four main segments: construction, property development, other construction-related business, and investment holding and dormitory business. Through its diversification efforts, Lian Beng Group has built a range of properties, including HDB flats, private condominiums, schools, and libraries. This diversification strategy has helped the company expand its business and reduce its reliance on the construction sector.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: ISCA's role in supporting the accountancy profession
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) plays a key role in promoting effective financial reporting in the accountancy profession. ISCA collaborates with stakeholders to enhance quality financial reporting, including CFO forums and sustainability reporting initiatives. The institute has set up a Corporate Reporting Committee to focus on sustainability reporting and provides technical support to its members. ISCA's president, Gerard Ee, stated that the institute identifies emerging accounting issues and addresses implementation challenges to keep the profession updated on latest developments.

site_title: Jokowi hits his stride in Indonesia with wins on policy, police
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo, known as Jokowi, has consolidated his position in the last year, achieving several policy wins and distancing himself from former President Megawati Soekarnoputri. He has passed key legislation, including a tax amnesty bill and a bill to increase national police chief Tito Karnavian, and taken a tough stance on terrorism and China's maritime claims. Despite economic challenges, including a slower-than-expected growth rate, Jokowi's approval ratings remain high, with over two-thirds of lawmakers supporting him. However, analysts warn that his success is contingent on the economy continuing to grow and infrastructure projects being completed on time.

site_title: Re-shaping the GOP into a voice for America's forgotten people
summary: Donald Trump's Republican National Convention speech marked a significant shift in the party's ideology, positioning itself as a voice for America's forgotten people. Trump blasted wealthy donors and powerful lobbyists, challenging the party's foreign and trade policy orthodoxies. He vowed to put "Americanism" before "globalism," including revoking international trade agreements and restructuring military alliances. Trump's speech electrified delegates and was watched by over 30 million viewers, electrifying the party's electoral base and potentially transforming American politics.

images.alt_text: In accepting the Republican presidential nomination, Mr Trump pledged to be a law-and-order president.

site_title: India's reforms of the last 25 years have paid off, despite setbacks
summary: India's 25-year-old economic reforms have yielded impressive results, with the country now the fastest-growing major economy, boasting a GDP of over $2 trillion. Poverty has decreased by more than half, and exports have risen 15-fold. Despite initial setbacks, the reforms have broadened constituencies in their favor, with all governments endorsing them. However, the benefits were not equally distributed, and subsequent governments have struggled with corruption and social inequality. Despite these challenges, the reforms have paid rich dividends, and India's story remains one of great promise and opportunity.

site_title: June CPI prompts confidence in MAS policy continuity but woes on Brexit impact
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), maintains confidence in its monetary policy continuity for October after releasing June's inflation data, which showed core inflation at 1.1% and headline inflation at -1 to 0% for 2016. However, economists are concerned about the impact of Brexit on price pressures, with MAS managing director Ravi Menon stating that there is no need to change the monetary policy stance unless there is a marked deterioration in the global economy. MAS is now forecasting core inflation to average around 1% for the year.

site_title: The long, final goodbye of the VCR
summary: The last company manufacturing VCRs, Funai Corp of Japan, announced it will stop production at the end of July due to difficulty acquiring parts. This marks the end of an era for the videocassette recorder, a technology that was once a staple in homes. The decision is largely attributed to the decline of VCRs in the face of newer technologies like digital streaming services. The demise of the VCR serves as a reminder of the fleeting nature of technological advancements.

images.alt_text: The world's last VCR is set to roll off the factory line at Funai Electric as it ends production of the once booming home-theatre technology.

site_title: US: Markets tumble on sinking crude prices
summary: US stocks declined on Monday after oil prices dropped to a three-month low, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.4% and the S&P 500 losing 0.3%. Energy stocks, including ExxonMobil and Chevron, plummeted due to the sharp decline in crude prices. Yahoo shares also tumbled 2.7% after Verizon announced its $4.8 billion purchase of Yahoo's web properties. The market is now focused on the Federal Reserve meeting, with investors speculating about potential rate hikes later this year.

site_title: PLife DPU falls 10.2% in Q2 in absence of distribution gains
summary: PARKWAY Life Real Estate Investment Trust (PLife Reit) reported a 10.2% fall in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter, due to the absence of a one-off distribution of divestment gain. Excluding the gain, DPU from recurring operations rose 1.2% from a year ago. The Reit manager attributed the decline to market volatility affecting acquisition opportunities in the short to medium term. Despite this, the long-term prospects of the regional healthcare industry remain driven by rising demand for better quality private healthcare services.

site_title: Brexit a danger to US financial stability: Treasury
summary: The US Treasury Department has raised concerns about the impact of Brexit on US financial stability, citing medium-level risks. The report notes that the UK's exit from the EU could lead to recession, hurting US trade and currency markets. A shock victory by the "leave" campaign has exacerbated these risks, with asset prices and economic growth forecasts tumbling. The report also warns of indirect linkages and the potential for self-perpetuating losses of confidence.

site_title: Strengthening the financial reporting value chain (Amended)
summary: Finance professionals must improve company reporting quality to meet growing investor demands. As business becomes more complex and borderless, investors are seeking more relevant and timely financial information, particularly on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues. Companies, auditors, and regulatory agencies must work together to provide reliable and quality financial information to investors, who use it to make informed decisions that drive capital markets.

site_title: Duterte defends crime crackdown in national address
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte defended his anti-narcotics crackdown, saying drugs were "drowning" the country and human rights should not protect criminals. In his State of the Nation Address, he vowed to reform the economy and tackle chronic flaws, promising new infrastructure projects and technological advancements. Despite criticism over a surge in suspected drug traffickers' killings, Duterte said he would not relent in his campaign, warning that "there will be no let-up." The address marked a month into his presidency, with Duterte having won 91% approval rating.

site_title: Rio Olympic village unfit for occupancy; athletes refuse to move in
summary: The Rio Olympic village, intended to be the home of thousands of athletes during the Summer Games, has been deemed unfit for occupancy due to issues such as blocked toilets, leaking pipes, and exposed wiring. Australian athletes have been staying in hotels instead, while other countries' delegations have also refused to move in. Organizers claim the problems will be resolved within a few days, but the issues have added to the setbacks and stumbles for the Rio Olympics, which are set to open on August 5.

site_title: How the rich hurt the museums they fund
summary: The wealthy are increasingly funding their own museums, leaving traditional institutions to compete for donations. This has led to an emphasis on flashy new projects to attract patrons, rather than maintaining existing collections. Despite the growth of museums, many face financial difficulties and declining attendance. The US$5 billion spent on new expansions between 2007 and 2014 is a significant portion of the overall funding, with private philanthropy playing a major role. A shift towards more public funding is needed to correct for the biases of the wealthy and support smaller, underfunded institutions.

site_title: India's Mytrah eyes infrastructure fund listing
summary: India's Mytrah Energy Ltd is considering listing an infrastructure investment trust (InvIT) to tap rising demand for green power. The company may raise up to $400 million, with half for growth and the rest for early-stage investors to exit. The move aims to boost India's renewable energy capacity to 175 GW by 2022. Mytrah has 920 MW of installed wind capacity and plans to expand, but needs fresh capital to achieve its growth goals. Listing an InvIT could provide an alternate exit medium for early-stage investors in Indian renewable energy platforms.

site_title: Google playing catch-up with Amazon and Microsoft in cloud computing
summary: Google is playing catch-up with Amazon and Microsoft in the cloud computing market, with a focus on faster networks, lower prices, and artificial intelligence. Despite being behind, Google is rapidly moving to change its position, with recent announcements on energy efficiency, speech recognition, and cloud services. Analysts predict that Google's ability to find energy efficiency and offer businesses insights gained from years of watching people online could give it an edge in the market. However, Amazon's lead in cloud technology and its ability to develop hundreds of new cloud features annually may keep Google from surpassing its competitors in the near future.

site_title: Zapping your brain at home is here to stay
summary: DIY brain stimulation devices, which use low levels of electricity to stimulate the brain, have become a growing trend, despite warnings from neuroscientists about potential risks. The devices, which can be purchased online, are often used to improve memory and learning ability, but some users also self-treat depression and anxiety. A recent open letter from neuroscientists calls for users to exercise caution, but acknowledges that DIY practitioners are unlikely to stop using the devices. Despite concerns, research suggests that many DIY users are astute and adhere to scientific protocols, but the long-term effects of home use are still unknown.

site_title: Property cooling measures to stay amid lower-for-longer rates
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has decided to maintain property cooling measures, citing risks of a renewed surge in property prices despite lower interest rates. Since 2013, property prices have fallen 9.4% cumulatively, but the MAS believes more time is needed to stabilize the market and restore household debt sustainability. The measures include tighter loan-to-value ratios, loan tenure limits, and duties to discourage property flipping. The MAS distinguishes between property and car financing measures, relaxing car loan curbs to ease inflation pressures.

site_title: S'pore manufacturing gets boost from 3M's S$135m Tuas expansion
summary: 3M has announced a S$135 million expansion plan for its Tuas facility in Singapore, set to be completed by the end of 2018. The expansion will increase the facility's size to 100,000 square meters and enhance its capabilities in adhesive and bonding products. The project will also allow 3M to implement its state-of-the-art technologies and manufacturing processes in Singapore, marking the country's first application of these technologies in Asia. The expansion is expected to create 100 new jobs, bringing the total workforce to 1,600.

site_title: US action on 1MDB could put a time limit on Malaysia's political chaos
summary: The US government's move to seize assets allegedly stolen from 1MDB may put a "time limit" on Malaysia's political chaos, with the US Justice Department filing a 136-page complaint alleging $731 million of funds were routed to a private bank account held by "Malaysian Official 1". The US is expected to follow up with civil action and potential indictments of those close to Prime Minister Najib Razak, including Malaysian tycoon Jho Low, which could pressure the ruling party to act. The move may crack the support circle around Najib, but domestic pressure to resign remains low.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Nintendo slumps most since '90 on dashed Pokemon Go hopes
summary: Nintendo's stock plunged 18% to 23,220 yen, wiping out $9 billion in market value, after saying the financial impact from Pokémon Go will be limited. The game's release nearly doubled Nintendo's stock, adding $17.6 billion in market capitalization, but the company is now revising expectations. Analysts say the correction is due to the game's popularity and the company's limited stake in the app, which is only 13%. Nintendo is set to report first-quarter earnings on Wednesday, which may provide further clarity on the situation.

site_title: Paradise lost - and found?
summary: The US is experiencing a "revolution of rising expectations" similar to the French Revolution, where prosperity was not enough to prevent a backlash. The economic and political expectations of the late 1990s were dashed, leading to widespread discontent and a power vacuum. This has created an intellectual void that outsiders like Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders can fill with their own solutions. Americans are now seeking change, but what they really want is to revert to a more tranquil past, rather than accepting the reality of the present. Trump's "America First" slogan is a simplistic attempt to restore the glory days, but it is unlikely to address the underlying issues.

site_title: Joyas extends rights deadline following stock code error
summary: Joyas International Holdings has extended the deadline for accepting its rights issue by one day due to an error in the stock code. The original deadline was July 28, but it has now been set for July 29. The company's non-renounceable and non-underwritten rights issue involves issuing up to 2.43 billion new shares at S$0.0035 per rights share. Joyas expects the revised timetable to be unchanged, and the net proceeds will be used for financing and general working capital to strengthen the balance sheet and support growth strategies.

site_title: China bank to sell securities backed by bad debt
summary: China's Agricultural Bank of China Ltd plans to sell securities backed by 10.7 billion yuan (S$2.2 billion) of non-performing loans on the interbank bond market, marking China's largest sale under a trial program. The sale price will be 29% of the loans' face value, with a forecasted recovery rate of 41%. The move aims to address China's rising bad loan crisis, with the Ministry of Finance expected to eventually inject capital into the banking system. The sale is part of China's efforts to tackle its credit woes through debt swaps and asset-backed securities.

site_title: ST Index ends 0.5% lower in cautious session
summary: Singapore stocks ended 0.5% lower in a cautious session ahead of two major central bank meetings, with local banks leading the decline. The Straits Times Index dropped 15.5 points to 2,929.85, with blue-chips under pressure. The two central bank meetings, including the Bank of England's interest rate decision, are expected to impact markets.

site_title: Deutsche Bank set for investor scrutiny as short sellers circle
summary: Deutsche Bank faces investor scrutiny as its stock has lost over half its value in the past year. The bank's CEO, John Cryan, will present a quarterly update, but analysts are concerned about its capital strength and the impact of Brexit on its revenue. Hedge funds have increased their short positions, betting on a further decline in shares. The bank's fixed income and currency trading business is expected to falter, and its common equity tier 1 ratio, a key measure of financial strength, is below the regulatory minimum.

site_title: Collectors' items: inspirational, delightful, poignant
summary: The New York Times' exhibition "The Keeper" at The New Museum explores the complex relationships people have with their collected items, featuring over 4,000 items and artworks from 30 "keepers". Readers submitted stories and photos of their own collections, showcasing a wide range of unusual and often poignant items, including Absolut Vodka ads, avocado seeds, and Soviet watches. The exhibition highlights the emotional and social significance of collecting, with some respondents expressing regret, joy, and befuddlement about their own collections. The show runs through September 25.

site_title: Alibaba Pictures tie-up lifts Spackman shares
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group shares surged in Singapore morning trading after Alibaba Pictures Group purchased distribution rights to the film "Life Risking Romance" in China. The stock reached an intraday high of S$0.095, up from a previous close of S$0.86. Executive chairman Charles Spackman said the partnership will provide exposure for the film in China, leveraging a combined platform of traditional theatres and the Internet. The deal is not expected to impact the company's financials.

site_title: More inquiries received from Chinese buyers after Brexit vote
summary: Chinese buyers' interest in UK property has surged since the Brexit vote, with enquiries 30-40% higher than average from June 20 to July 11. The pound's slide has created opportunities to buy at a discount, with sterling losing 8% against the dollar and 6% against the yuan. This contrasts with a decline in British commercial property investment demand, with over £18 billion of retail investor cash frozen in July. The UK looks like a "safe haven" at a cheaper price, according to juwai.com's president Bernie Morris.

images.alt_text: The number of such enquiries for British residential and commercial property has been 30-40 per cent higher than average in each week from June 20 to July 11, said juwai.com.

site_title: Juno's trip to Jupiter holds lessons for S'pore
summary: Singapore aims to become an international hub for debt restructuring, following the success of NASA's Juno mission, which navigated turbulent space conditions. The Committee for the Future Economy has recommended updates to Singapore's insolvency laws, including specialist insolvency benches, increased use of alternative dispute resolution, and a restructuring-friendly ecosystem. The government has accepted the recommendations, aiming to capitalize on growing demand for debt restructuring services in Asia.

site_title: Clinton's vision for US foreign policy shared by many globally
summary: US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has received widespread global support, with a landslide victory in a hypothetical contest against Donald Trump. Clinton's strong foreign policy vision, championing a smart power strategy, has resonated with many international audiences. Her experience as secretary of state under Barack Obama has helped restore the US reputation worldwide, and her approach to diplomacy is seen as a welcome change from Trump's rhetoric and policy proposals, which have sparked concerns among foreign leaders and populations.

site_title: Property cooling measures: Why cautionary stance still needed
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority has reiterated its caution against unwinding property cooling measures despite signs of a market bottoming out. The Urban Redevelopment Authority reported a 0.4% decline in private residential prices in Q2, with sales transactions rising 10.9% year-over-year. However, the MAS remains concerned about the economic slowdown, sluggish growth, and high household debts. With interest rates at historical lows, the MAS prefers to maintain cooling measures to prevent a wrong market signal, despite developers' calls for easing measures.

site_title: Bursa Malaysia turns in flat performance for Q2
summary: Bursa Malaysia, Malaysia's stock exchange operator, reported a flat performance for the second quarter, with a profit after tax and minority interest of RM49.5 million, little changed from the previous year. Revenue remained stagnant at RM130 million, attributed to lower equity trading values. The company attributed the reversal of foreign funds in the second quarter after a strong inflow in the preceding quarter. Despite challenging market conditions, Bursa remains cautiously optimistic about its performance for the year and has proposed a dividend of 17 sen per share.

site_title: Sluggish growth amid Brexit; financial services gains to ease
summary: Singapore's economic growth remains sluggish due to Brexit and weak US investments. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expects financial services to ease in growth this year, but notes tentative signs of stabilisation in the trade-related cluster. Healthcare, education, and public infrastructure construction are expected to fare better, with sequential growth in April and May from the electronics industry. MAS managing director Ravi Menon cites these segments as potential relief from the economic slowdown.

site_title: Transgenders transform into goddesses at Hindu festival
summary: In a unique Hindu festival, transgender women in southern India's Tamil Nadu transform into goddesses through intense preparation and trance-like states. The Mayana Kollai festival in Devanampattinam village features dancers who, with reverent concentration, shed their identities and become goddesses. The experience is marked by a somber atmosphere, with participants losing themselves in their roles, leaving behind their everyday lives. This annual celebration showcases the community's strong cultural heritage and spiritual connection.

site_title: China builds massive seaplane: state media
summary: China has completed production of the world's largest amphibious aircraft, the AG600, according to state media. The state-owned Aviation Industry Corporation of China unveiled the first plane in the southern port city of Zhuhai, marking the country's effort to wean itself off foreign aviation firms. The AG600 is part of China's ambitious aviation program, which aims to reduce dependence on foreign aviation companies.

images.alt_text: The AG600, which was unveiled on Saturday in the southern port city of Zhuhai has a maximum range of 4,500 km. The aircraft is intended for fighting forest fires and performing marine rescues, according to Xinhua.

site_title: Australian PM says no clues from FBI report on MH370 pilot
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has dismissed a reported FBI investigation into the pilot of missing Flight MH370, stating it's a matter for Malaysian investigators. The investigation, revealed in a New York magazine, found that the pilot used a flight simulator to chart a route similar to the plane's believed path. However, Turnbull said the simulator information doesn't shed light on the plane's location, and the search will be suspended if nothing turns up within the designated 120,000-square-kilometre zone.

site_title: Asia Pacific's first-half hotel transaction volume rises 13.2%
summary: Asia Pacific hotel transaction volume rose 13.2% in the first half of 2016, with 14,000 keys traded, compared to 11,000 in the same period last year. The region's hotel investment volumes reached US$3.8 billion. Japan was the top contributor, with 59 transactions across 11 countries. The top 10 single-asset transactions collectively totaled almost US$1.7 billion, with Australasia attracting the highest capital inflows.

site_title: QT Vascular wins US appeal against US$20m award
summary: A US appeals court has reversed a US$20 million damages award against Singapore-listed QT Vascular, which was ordered to pay AngioScore Inc. for patent infringement in angioplasty balloons. The patent infringement battle, dating back to 2012, was related to angioplasty balloons used to widen obstructed blood vessels. The appeals court ruling reverses the district court's decision, allowing QT Vascular to avoid the significant damages.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Sponsored content takes larger role in media companies
summary: Sponsored content has become increasingly important for media companies as traditional advertising declines. Publishers have invested in teams to create sponsored content, such as written stories, videos, and podcasts, which has provided relief. The shift towards social platforms has also led to a change in the way sponsored content is consumed. While some publishers have seen success, the changing online advertising business remains a challenge for the industry.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp denies allegations of involvement in Lava Jato investigations, reaffirming its zero-tolerance stance on bribery and corruption. Otto Marine's shipyard subsidiary arrested a vessel for unpaid ship repair charges. Singtel's Optus Business signed a new 3-year ICT services agreement with QBE Australia. Technics Oil & Gas placed under judicial management, with two judicial managers appointed to manage its affairs. Trading of its shares suspended since June 1.

site_title: 'Brain training' cuts dementia risk in healthy adults: US study
summary: A 10-year US study found that a computerised brain training programme reduced dementia risk in healthy adults by 48% among those who received speed-of-processing training, with those completing 11 or more sessions showing a 48% lower risk. This contradicts previous research that rejected the effectiveness of "brain games" in delaying dementia development. The study's findings are promising but need to be peer-reviewed and published to confirm their validity.

site_title: Australia grocer Woolworths to cut jobs, close stores in overhaul
summary: Woolworths, Australia's top grocer, is undergoing a major overhaul to regain its competitive edge. The company will cut up to 500 jobs, close 30 stores, and consider selling its online retailer Ezibuy. This restructuring aims to reduce costs of up to A$1 billion and boost customer service. The move comes after Woolworths posted its first loss in 23 years in February due to increased competition from foreign entrants, including Aldi. The company's CEO, Brad Banducci, plans a three to five-year transformation.

site_title: Copper signals resilience despite eventful weeks
summary: Hedge funds are betting on copper despite recent market turmoil, with the metal's price rising 4.7% this year. China's copper imports reached an all-time high in the first half of the year, driving optimism among investors. Global copper demand is expected to increase 2.1% this year, outpacing supply, which is expected to trail consumption by 80,000 metric tons in 2020. The surge in copper's net-long position is seen as a turnaround from recent net-short positions, with analysts citing China's growing real-estate sector and increasing demand for the metal.

site_title: HDT S'pore Taxi to launch electric fleet in 8-year trial
summary: HDT Singapore Taxi, a subsidiary of China-based electric car maker BYD, will launch a fleet of 100 fully-electric taxis in Singapore as part of an 8-year trial by Q1 2017. The trial aims to study the feasibility of e-taxi fleets in Singapore's land transport network. BYD will provide the electric vehicles, and HDT will establish charging facilities for normal and semi-fast charging. The company plans to operate its drivers as full-time employees with benefits, departing from the typical leasing model. The trial is supported by the government's technology innovation and development scheme.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Tougher MAS action against tainted money amid 1MDB scandal
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has pledged tougher action against financial institutions that fail to meet anti-money laundering standards amid the 1MDB scandal. MAS will increase supervision and make public sanctions against institutions that persistently or egregiously breach rules. The move aims to protect Singapore's reputation, which has been hurt by the scandal. The regulator's managing director, Ravi Menon, emphasized the need for stricter measures to prevent tainted money from entering the financial system. MAS will also be more transparent in its sanctions, aiming to deter institutions from violating anti-money laundering rules.

site_title: Amid oil rout, MAS seeks prudent provisioning by banks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is questioning banks on their provisioning practices amid volatile oil prices and banks' exposure to oil-related companies. MAS does not prescribe provisioning but encourages conservative standards through continuous questioning. The banking system in Singapore has set aside provisions to cover more than one time of bad loans, with a non-performing loan ratio of 1.7% in the first quarter. MAS considers a bad loan to be one in arrears for three months or more.

site_title: EU working with consumer groups to pressure VW for compensation
summary: The European Union is working with consumer groups to pressure Volkswagen to compensate European clients for the diesel emissions scandal. The German carmaker has pledged up to $15.3 billion to US owners, but has rejected similar calls for European owners due to weaker legal rules. Instead, VW is implementing a technical fix to remove illicit software, claiming this won't affect car values. EU officials are urging VW to reconsider, but so far, no compensation has been offered to European owners.

site_title: Prospective borrowing by Indian Railways exceeds GDP of some nations
summary: Indian Railways plans to borrow 2.5 trillion rupees ($50 billion) over five years to fund modernization efforts, exceeding the GDP of some nations. The network aims to upgrade tracks, trains, and stations with a 8.6 trillion rupee investment. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration will rely on government spending and debt for most of the funding, with a private sector contribution of around one trillion rupees. The network faces challenges in raising passenger fares and increasing freight revenues, and must manage investment projects better to meet its goals.

site_title: Greenback buoyant before Fed, BOJ meetings
