summary: The US dollar remained strong ahead of meetings of the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan, with investors expecting positive news for the greenback. Improved US economic data and jobs numbers signal a possible interest rate hike by the Fed, while the BOJ is expected to ease monetary policy. The yen is likely to weaken, with some strategists warning that a disappointing move may disappoint those betting against it. The dollar traded at 106.25 yen and US$1.0955 against the euro.

site_title: GM re-evaluates planned US$1b investment in India
summary: GM re-evaluates its $1 billion investment in India, putting on hold plans to launch a new car platform. The company's sales have fallen nearly 40% and its share of the domestic market is below 1%. GM's original plan included launching a multi-purpose vehicle and a new modular platform, but the company is now conducting a review of its product portfolio. GM still plans to launch small cars in 2017, including the Beat Activ hatchback and Essentia compact sedan.

site_title: Florida club shooting 'not an act of terror:' police
summary: A shooting outside a Florida nightclub on July 25, 2016, killed 14-year-old Shawn Achilles and 18-year-old Ste'fan Strawder, and injured 16 people. Police in Fort Myers stated that the incident was not an act of terror, and no motive has been determined. The victims were described by local media as a star high school basketball player and a student.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine restarts Sokor project operations
summary: CNMC Goldmine has restarted operations at its Sokor project in Kelantan, Malaysia, after a stop-work order was lifted on July 25. The order, issued on July 19, was part of the Kelantan government's review of CNMC's application to mine unlimited amounts of ore from Sokor. The company's shares rose 3.5% to 44 cents following the announcement. CNMC is also planning to acquire a controlling stake in Pulai Mining, a concession with 11 licenses to explore and mine for various minerals.

site_title: More paperwork, less playtime for bankers in Singapore
summary: Singapore's banking industry is facing increased regulatory scrutiny, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) investigating several banks for alleged breaches of anti-money-laundering regulations. The probes are linked to the 1MDB scandal, with assets worth S$240 million seized and banks including DBS, UBS, and Standard Chartered put on notice for "control failings". The move is expected to lead to increased paperwork and compliance costs for banks, potentially deterring sophisticated trades and impacting the city-state's reputation as a hub for private banking.

site_title: Democrats kick off convention as a more progressive party
summary: Democrats have adopted a more progressive stance ahead of their 2016 convention in Philadelphia, driven by Hillary Clinton's leftward policy shifts and prodding from Senator Bernie Sanders. The party is shifting towards a more liberal stance on issues, reflecting a changing US population. This marks a significant shift from the party's center-right stance in the 1990s. The changes aim to appeal to a younger, more diverse electorate and hold onto the presidency.

images.alt_text: Mrs Clinton, running as the natural heir to President Barack Obama, is campaigning on a promise to fortify and expand upon his accomplishments.

site_title: Air France expects 35% srike rate among French cabin crew for Wednesday
summary: Air France expects a 35% strike rate among French cabin crew for Wednesday, with 40% on long-haul flights and 25% on short-haul flights. The strike, called by two unions, will affect over 90% of long-haul flights and about 70% of short- and medium-haul flights, with reduced passenger numbers. The strike is set to run from July 27 to August 2.

site_title: Markets unclear about likely outcome of this week's BOJ meeting
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy board is set to meet this week, with markets anticipating fresh monetary-easing initiatives following a sharp cut in government economic growth and inflation forecasts. The BOJ may also downgrade its forecasts. Tokyo stock prices have risen for six weeks, and the yen has fallen to a six-week low, driven by these expected BOJ actions. The BOJ's QQE (quantitative and qualitative easing) launch is uncertain, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Dinner, movies and colonoscopy at a mall in future
summary: Healthcare companies are increasingly moving into retail malls, seeking to capitalize on the demographic shift towards older consumers and growing family needs. With softening retail markets, landlords are offering favorable leases, including improvement allowances. Examples include Cedars-Sinai's 32,000-sq-ft doctors' office at The Runway at Playa Vista in Los Angeles and Vanderbilt University Medical Group's entire second level at the 100 Oaks Mall in Nashville, Tennessee. This trend is expected to continue, with the healthcare industry absorbing more retail space as a result.

site_title: Britain's timetable for regaining control
summary: European Union leaders urge British Prime Minister Theresa May to expedite the UK's exit plans, as the UK does not wish to be a part of the single market. The UK will comply with EU rules and regulations when exporting to EU countries, and the EU should do the same for the UK's exports. The UK will not impose new tariffs or barriers on EU exports, and the EU should not impose new tariffs on the UK's exports. A swift negotiation is in the EU's and UK's interests, and it is not a difficult process.

site_title: Asean avoids mention of South China Sea ruling
summary: Asean avoids criticizing China over a UN-backed tribunal's ruling that rejected Beijing's claims to the South China Sea, instead calling for "self-restraint" in the strategic waterway. The statement, issued after days of disagreement, gives China a diplomatic victory, despite Beijing's anger over the ruling. The move is seen as a compromise, with some countries wanting to pressure China while others are wary of stoking a vital trading partner. The Asean meeting in Vientiane is also expected to address tensions on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Crowdo gets full securities crowdfunding licence
summary: Crowdo, a Singapore-based crowdfunding platform, has received the full securities crowdfunding licence from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). This makes Crowdo the first and only operator in South-east Asia to achieve "multi-jurisdiction licensing". The platform will facilitate peer-to-peer lending and equity crowdfunding in Singapore, with a dedicated P2P-lending platform. Crowdo aims to protect investors with a proprietary credit scoring engine and praises the new MAS rules, but notes that maintaining a productive dialogue with regulators will be key to Singapore's fintech growth.

site_title: Aviva Singapore launches new FA firm
summary: Aviva Singapore has launched a new financial advisory (FA) firm, Aviva Financial Advisers, which offers multiple products from different insurers, including Aviva and three other providers. The firm, comprising 280 agents, aims to dominate the future of insurance and increase its market share. The move follows declining tied agency channel sales and growing demand for more choices from consumers. Aviva expects the FA channel to grow faster and become more competitive, with similar adviser compensation for selling products from different insurers.

images.alt_text: Mr Majmudar: "Our view is that the FA industry has been growing; at end-2015 its market share was 20 per cent, and at some stage it is going to grow much faster."

site_title: Verizon buys Yahoo's core business for US$4.8b
summary: Verizon has acquired Yahoo's core Internet properties for $4.83 billion, expanding its digital advertising and media business. The deal boosts Verizon's AOL Internet business, gaining access to Yahoo's ad technology tools, search, mail, and messenger assets. Verizon Chairman and CEO Lowell McAdam said the acquisition will put the company in a highly competitive position as a top global mobile media company. Yahoo's leadership team, led by Marissa Mayer, will stay on until the deal closes in early 2017, with Mayer due to receive a severance package of approximately $57 million.

site_title: UK ban on onshore wind subsidies could cost Scotland £3 billion
summary: The UK's decision to ban onshore wind subsidies could cost Scotland up to £3 billion and jeopardize its clean energy targets. The ban, announced by former Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative government, was made without consulting the Scottish government. Scotland relies heavily on onshore wind, hosting 60% of the UK's capacity, and its fast wind speeds and long coastlines support 21,000 jobs and £1 billion in annual investment. Lawmakers are urging the UK government to review the decision and improve consultations with Scotland to ensure a supportive policy framework for the renewable energy sector.

site_title: Indonesian tax amnesty could spark outflow from Singapore
summary: Singapore's wealth management industry may suffer due to a tax amnesty in Indonesia, where around $200 billion of undeclared assets are being repatriated. This amount, roughly 42% of Indonesia's total assets under management, is expected to be a significant blow to the industry. However, the exodus of funds is not as predicted, with estimates suggesting it will be a smaller portion than initially thought. The repatriation of funds may have a limited impact on Singapore's financial hub.

site_title: Higher revenues across the board lift Raffles Medical's Q2 profit
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 4.5% year-on-year increase in Q2 net profit to S$16.67 million, driven by higher revenues across all divisions. Revenue grew 19.8% to S$118.95 million, with contributions from healthcare and hospital services increasing 42.2% and 7.9% respectively. The group declared an interim dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per share and maintained a strong cash position of S$123.6 million. Despite higher staff costs, the company expects further growth in revenue for the rest of the year.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics' Q1 DPU stays at 1.85 cents
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's (MLT) Q1 DPU remains unchanged at 1.85 cents, despite a 57.9% decline in total return attributable to unitholders due to a loss in the fair value of financial hedging instruments. The Reit posted a 5.7% increase in net property income to S$75.2 million, driven by new acquisitions and revenue growth from existing properties. The trust expects a challenging leasing environment, but its diversified portfolio is expected to mitigate this.

site_title: Scottish first minister warns against 'hard' Brexit
summary: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon warned that Britain is heading for a "hard" Brexit, which could lead to Scotland's independence. Sturgeon emphasized the importance of maintaining access to the EU single market and freedom of movement for Scotland's economic interests. Unlike England and Wales, most Scottish voters chose to remain in the EU. Sturgeon stated that she would fight to protect Scotland's interests and keep options open, including the possibility of Scotland staying in the EU while England, Wales, and Northern Ireland leave, a concept described as "Reverse Greenland".

site_title: Julius Baer could afford bank with assets of up to US$15b: CEO
summary: Julius Baer CEO Boris Collardi stated the bank can afford to buy a rival with assets under management of up to $20.61 billion without seeking additional funding, citing price sensitivity. Baer has used acquisitions to keep pace with larger rivals and is exploring further cost-cutting measures. The bank's new regional structure is expected to help reduce costs, with synergies in the front office potentially leading to cost savings.

site_title: Bonding with diners through quality food and service
summary: Jumbo Group, a Singaporean restaurant business, has grown from its humble beginnings to become one of the country's most recognizable brands. The company attributes its success to holistic staff management and operational excellence, as well as its development of employees through various training programs. Jumbo has implemented a range of initiatives, including a central kitchen, point-of-sale systems, and an Enterprise Resource Planning system, to enhance productivity and operational efficiency. The company plans to expand in Singapore and China, leveraging its brand to capture the growing Chinese middle class.

site_title: Daily FX volumes edge up 1% in April vs year-ago: Fed
summary: US currency trading volume averaged $893.2 billion in April 2016, up 1% from the year-ago period and 10% higher than October 2015. The increase in trading volume was largely driven by a 23% growth in swap turnover since the previous survey.

site_title: P2P lending in South Korea spurs rush for regulation
summary: South Korea's P2P lending market has rapidly expanded to 72.4 billion won in the first three months of 2016, driven by investors seeking high returns due to low government bond yields. The industry offers average rates of 9-10% but lacks transparency on where investment money goes, prompting concerns of potential fraud. The government is drafting industry guidelines to protect investors, following China's crackdown on similar platforms last year. P2P lenders such as 8Percent, Funda, and Midrate have been accused of wrongdoing, but none have been proven guilty.

site_title: G20's deference for China's economic policies irks Japan
summary: China successfully dodged criticism of its economic management at a G20 meeting it hosted, with finance ministers and central bank chiefs praising the yuan's transparency. In contrast, Japanese officials expressed frustration, calling for more reforms from Beijing. Japan's concerns about China's economic performance, particularly the yuan's decline, were largely ignored. The US, a long-time critic of China's currency policies, appeared satisfied with Beijing's handling of the yuan, while expressing concerns about industrial overcapacity.

site_title: Yahoo confirms sale of core assets for US$4.8b to Verizon
summary: Yahoo has agreed to sell its core assets to Verizon for US$4.8 billion, marking the end of the internet pioneer's 20-year run as an independent company. Verizon will integrate Yahoo into its AOL unit, creating a top global mobile media company and accelerating its digital advertising revenue. The deal will help Verizon expand its digital presence and enhance its advertising capabilities. The sale is expected to be completed later this year.

images.alt_text: Yahoo agreed to sell its core assets to telecom giant Verizon for US$4.8 billion, ending a 20-year run by the internet pioneer as an independent company, the firms announced Monday.

site_title: LH Group warns of Q2 loss
summary: LH Group Limited, a Singapore-listed investment holding company, expects to incur a loss for Q2 2016 after a preliminary assessment of its draft unaudited financial results. The company will disclose further details on August 15, 2016.

site_title: Indonesia's tax chief says US$30m has been declared under tax amnesty so far
summary: Indonesia's tax chief reported nearly $41.38 million in previously concealed assets declared under the country's tax amnesty programme, with $30 million expected to leave Singapore for Indonesia. The programme, launched on July 18, has seen taxpayers declare 400 billion rupiah (approximately $41.38 million) and 6 billion rupiah in penalty fees from 20 taxpayers. The expected outflow of funds from Singapore is roughly $30 billion, according to consultants and industry experts.

site_title: Aztech issues profit warning for Q2, H1 2016
summary: Aztech Group issued a profit warning for Q2 and H1 2016, stating it will record a loss due to impairment charges from marine-related assets, weakness in the marine market, and excess capacity. The company cited a downward revision in valuation and fair value impairment assessment. Further details will be released when Aztech announces its financial results.

site_title: Europe's first regulated bitcoin product launches in Gibraltar
summary: Europe's first regulated bitcoin product, BitcoinETI, launches on the Gibraltar Stock Exchange and Deutsche Boerse, offering investors a regulated asset-backed exchange-traded instrument investing exclusively in bitcoin. The product, which can be used for instant, worldwide transactions, has seen its value stabilize after a highly volatile past, trading at around $655. This move comes as a result of talks between stakeholders, including the Financial Services Commission and the British Overseas Territory's government, and is seen as a step towards increased transparency and liquidity for investors.

images.alt_text: Europe's first regulated bitcoin product - an asset-backed exchange-traded instrument that will invest exclusively in the digital currency - begins trading this week on the Gibraltar Stock Exchange and Germany's Deutsche Boerse.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends lower on firm dollar; shares edge up
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.2% to 1,137.0 per dollar against a firm US dollar, despite solid economic data. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.1% to 2,012.32 points, with foreign investors buying a net 198.4 billion won worth of shares. Shares of Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp rallied due to cheaper valuations.

site_title: China to massively increase oil storage capacity
summary: China plans to construct 70 million cubic meters of storage for its strategic petroleum reserve, equivalent to 60 days of its current crude imports. The government aims to build 44.6 million cubic meters by 2020, adding to its existing 28.6 million cubic meter capacity. China also plans to improve its pipeline network and build natural gas storage tanks to hold 10% of its total gas consumption by 2020, aiming to reduce its reliance on crude imports and promote cleaner energy resources.

images.alt_text: China plans to construct a total of 70 million cubic meters of storage for its strategic petroleum reserve (SPR) in three construction phases, a state-run newspaper said on Monday.

site_title: Chinasing's board proposes winding up business
summary: Chinasing Investment Holdings' board proposes winding up the business due to inability to secure an exit offer for potential delisting. The company has incurred substantial losses since 2011, with the exception of 2012. Controlling shareholder Huang Quan and substantial shareholder Hong Yuexiong will vote in favor of the winding up proposal. A special general meeting will be convened to allow shareholders to decide on the proposal. The company will send a circular with details to shareholders in due course.

site_title: Billionaire Li drops bid for Baidu's Netflix-like video unit
summary: Billionaire Li, Chairman of Baidu Inc, has dropped his bid to buy control of the company's streaming video service iQiyi after failing to reach an agreement on its price and structure. The deal, valued at US$2.8 billion, was met with criticism from shareholder Acacia Partners LP, citing a price deemed "far too low". The collapse of talks comes as Baidu seeks to whittle down rising expenses, including losses from the streaming business, which may be difficult to go public in China.

site_title: Joyas extends rights shares acceptance, applications and payment to July 29
summary: JOYAS International Holdings Limited has extended the deadline for accepting, applying for, and paying for rights shares to July 29, 2016, due to an error in the stock code for electronic applications via ATMs. The original deadline was July 28. The error has been rectified, and the company does not expect further modifications to the revised timetable.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.84 points to close at 1,668.26 on Monday, driven by 415 gainers and 364 losers. The index saw significant trading volume of 1.6 billion lots, valued at RM1.57 billion.

site_title: UK manufacturing order books fell in July, order expectations hit by Brexit: CBI
summary: British manufacturing order books fell in July, with a -4 balance, as Brexit uncertainty hit business confidence. Order expectations for the next three months were at their lowest since December, while quarterly numbers showed total orders rose to +9 from -4 in April. The quarterly business optimism balance plummeted to -47, the lowest since 2009. This suggests that Britain's vote to leave the EU is already hurting confidence among businesses, with weak expectations for new orders and a scaling back of investment plans.

site_title: Malaria drug may help in cancer fight, early research finds
summary: Researchers have found that an off-patent malaria drug, atovaquone, can make cancer cells more susceptible to radiotherapy by boosting oxygen levels, making it easier to treat cancer. This has prompted a clinical trial to test its effectiveness in cancer patients. The study, led by Gillies McKenna, aims to re-sensitize resistant tumors to radiotherapy, potentially providing a low-cost solution to combat cancer.

site_title: US: Wall St lower as earnings roll in; Fed meet eyed
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting, despite robust economic data and strong corporate earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.28%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The Fed is considering a rate hike, with traders pricing in a 14.7% chance in September and 38.5% in December. The market is now focused on corporate earnings, with earnings expected to fall 3% in the second quarter.

site_title: At least two dead, 14 wounded in Florida nightclub shooting: media
summary: At least two people are dead and 14 others wounded in a shooting at a nightclub in Fort Myers, Florida. The incident occurred during a teen party at Club Blu, with one person detained. This marks the month after a deadly mass shooting at a nightclub in Orlando, where a lone gunman killed 49 people.

site_title: Mapletree Log Trust Q1 profit drops 58% as hedges' fair values fall; DPU stays at S$0.0185
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's Q1 net return for unitholders dropped 57.9% to S$21.5 million due to a loss in the fair value of financial hedging instruments, primarily interest rate swaps. Despite this, the trust posted a 5.7% increase in net property income to S$75.2 million and maintained its distribution per unit at 1.85 cents.

site_title: UK-based currency trading fell 9% y/y in April: BoE
summary: The Bank of England reported that foreign exchange trading in London fell 9% in April to $2.2 trillion, the lowest level in three years. This decline is attributed to changes in regulations aimed at reducing bank risk and the market-rigging scandal that led to the suspension or firing of dozens of traders. The decrease is part of a broader trend, with currency trading in London experiencing a decline over the past three years.

site_title: Update: At least two dead in Florida nightclub shooting: TV
summary: A shooting at a Florida nightclub, Club Blu in Fort Myers, has left at least two people dead and 14 others wounded. The incident occurred on Monday at approximately 12:30 am, and police have detained a "person of interest." A nearby home and vehicles were also targeted, resulting in one minor injury. This incident comes just six weeks after an attack on a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida, which left 49 dead.

site_title: Food Empire wins legal fight in Lithuania to use MacCoffee 3-in-1 brand
summary: Food Empire Holdings has won a legal battle in Lithuania to continue using its MacCoffee 3-in-1 brand, as the Supreme Court ruled that the brand is not "confusingly similar" to McDonald's McCAFE. The court's decision will allow Food Empire to continue building on the success of its brand, established in Lithuania over a decade ago. Food Empire executive chairman Tan Wang Cheow stated that the ruling is a basis for the company in one of the European Union's member states. The company's shares closed 2.9% lower following the announcement.

site_title: Private transport firm to roll out electric taxi fleet in Singapore from September
summary: HDT Singapore Taxi will launch a fleet of 100 fully-electric taxis in Singapore by September, as part of a trial by the Land Transport Authority and the Economic Development Board. The fleet, provided by BYD, will operate for eight years to study the feasibility of new EV business models. The trial aims to explore fleet-based operations such as EV car-sharing and electric taxi fleets, marking a significant step towards Singapore's goal of becoming a hub for electric vehicle adoption.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Judicial managers appointed for Technics Oil & Gas
summary: Singapore's High Court has appointed Tam Chee Chong and Andrew Grimmett as judicial managers of Technics Oil & Gas and its subsidiary, Technics Offshore Engineering. The group has been placed under judicial management, and the two managers will oversee the company's affairs, business, and property. This move is a result of the company's financial difficulties, with the judicial managers taking over from the boards of directors. The appointment aims to manage the company's affairs until a more permanent solution is found.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5% down on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 15.5 points to 2,929.85. The decline was largely due to caution ahead of central bank meetings in Japan and the US this week. About 923.6 million shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 229 to 172. The most actively traded counter was Annica Holdings, which remained flat at S$0.001.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine's stop-work order lifted, resumes operations at Sokor
summary: CNMC Goldmine's stop-work order at its Sokor mine in Malaysia has been lifted, allowing the company to resume operations. The order was issued on July 19 in connection with the Kelantan government's review of CNMC's application for unlimited ore mining. The company has restarted its operations and will make further announcements on the progress of its application. The stop-work order had caused the stock to fall nearly 8% on July 22.

site_title: Asean breaks deadlock on South China Sea, Beijing thanks Cambodia for support
summary: Asean has reached a consensus on the South China Sea, dropping a reference to a landmark legal ruling that favored the Philippines. The decision came after Cambodia opposed the mention of the ruling, allowing Beijing to express gratitude for its support. The Asean communique emphasized the need for peaceful resolutions to disputes in the sea, in accordance with international law, and urged the maintenance of freedom of navigation. The move is seen as a compromise, with Beijing criticizing the US for its role in raising tensions in the region.

site_title: German business morale falls slightly after Brexit vote
summary: German business morale fell slightly in July, with the Ifo economic institute's business climate index decreasing to 108.3 from 108.7 in June. Company executives became less optimistic, but assessments of the current business situation improved. Ifo head Clemens Fuest attributed the decline to reduced business expectations, while noting the German economy's resilience.

images.alt_text: German business morale fell in July, a survey showed on Monday, suggesting company executives in Europe's largest economy have become less optimistic since Britain voted to leave the European Union.

site_title: Australian dollar steadies ahead of inflation; kiwi slips again
summary: The Australian dollar steadied ahead of inflation data, with investors awaiting a potential rate cut in August. Underlying inflation is expected to dip to 1.4% on July 27, supporting the case for a rate cut. The New Zealand dollar, however, slipped further, falling 0.3% to 0.6977, as investors expect further rate cuts to combat low inflation and a high dollar.

site_title: China sets up South China Sea environment protection fund
summary: China has established a 15 million yuan (S$3 million) environmental protection fund for the South China Sea, following criticism from the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague. The fund will support scientific research and development of new methods and equipment for environmental protection over the next three years. China has spent double the amount of the new fund in the past four years, including 30 million yuan to protect reefs and islets, and has released fish and sea turtles into the sea six times. The move comes after the tribunal criticized China's large-scale land reclamation and construction of artificial islands.

site_title: LVMH to sell Donna Karan to G-III Apparel for US$650m
summary: LVMH agreed to sell Donna Karan International Inc to G-III Apparel Group Ltd for $650 million. The deal follows a year after Donna Karan's departure as founder and chief designer. G-III will gain the Donna Karan and DKNY brands and expects the acquisition to weigh on profit initially, but boost earnings from next fiscal year. The transaction is expected to be completed by early next year.

images.alt_text: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE agreed to sell Donna Karan International Inc to G-III Apparel Group Ltd for an enterprise value of $650 million, a year after the founder of the women's clothing brand departed.

site_title: Ericsson CEO Vestberg resigns as company accelerates cost-cuts
summary: Ericsson CEO Hans Vestberg stepped down after six and a half years, amid a turbulent period marked by declining stock price, intense competition, and investigations into business dealings. The company is accelerating cost cuts and has cut jobs, battling fierce competition from Huawei and Nokia. Vestberg's departure follows a report that Ericsson may be inflating sales, and he had vowed to improve profitability but failed to do so. CFO Jan Frykhammar will be interim CEO until a replacement is found.

site_title: In China's quest to conquer world soccer, fans feel left behind
summary: Chinese soccer fans feel left behind as the country's top league prioritizes commercial sponsorships over grassroots development, despite investing heavily in European clubs. The Chinese Football Association's top-down approach has led to constant changes in team names and locations, irritating fans. The country's ambition to become a soccer superpower under President Xi Jinping is at odds with the need to nurture a genuine grass-roots sporting culture and homegrown talent. China's ranking of 81st in the world highlights the need for a more organic approach to football development.

images.alt_text: Big money signings and investments in storied European clubs, and the backing of a president who is an avid soccer fan: things should be looking up for millions of Chinese supporting the 'beautiful game'.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end marginally lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day marginally lower, shedding 0.07% to 21,948.94, as investors took profits from recent gains ahead of key central bank policy meetings in Japan and the US. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.01%.

site_title: Fortune Reit posts higher DPU of 24.78 HK cents for six months ended June
summary: Fortune Reit's distribution per unit rose 6% to 24.78 HK cents for the six months ended June, driven by a 6.7% increase in income available for distribution to HK$470.0 million. Revenue and net property income also increased by 6.1% and 7.9%, respectively. The interim DPU will be paid on August 29, 2016, to registered unitholders.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Europe: Stocks firm at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.1% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 adding 0.4% and 0.01% respectively. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were in focus. The rally was despite ongoing US trade uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Singapore inflation eases for 20th month in June, projected to rise in coming months
summary: Singapore's inflation fell by 0.7% in June, its 20th consecutive month of decline, due to a smaller drop in accommodation costs and falling actual and imputed rental costs. Service inflation rose to 1.6% due to higher holiday expenses and telecommunication fees, while food inflation edged down to 2.1%. MAS core inflation is projected to average around 1% for 2016, and CPI-All Items inflation is forecast to come in at negative 1.0-0.0% for the year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) warned that the 1MDB probe poses a risk to its reputation, prompting a plan to increase supervision. Keppel Corp refuted allegations in the Operation Car Wash investigation. Singapore's inflation fell 0.7% in June, the 20th consecutive month, but is expected to rise in the coming months. Alibaba acquired distribution rights for Spackman's film "Life Risking Romance". A private transport firm will launch an electric taxi fleet in Singapore from September. Singapore shares closed 0.5% down on Monday due to caution ahead of central bank meetings.

images.alt_text: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon. MAS said on Monday it will sharpen its supervision on anti-money laundering and countering financing of terrorism control (AML/CFT) in the financial industry.

site_title: Indonesian tax amnesty could spark outflow from Singapore wealth industry
summary: Singapore's wealth management industry is expected to face an outflow of funds from rich Indonesians taking advantage of a tax amnesty, with around $30 billion potentially moving back to Indonesia. This is below projected amounts by the Indonesian government and central bank, but still significant, considering it could generate three times more government revenue than a previous tax amnesty in 2008. The amnesty's rules, including a three-year investment requirement and limited investment options, may deter some individuals from participating, despite the potential for reduced tax liabilities.

site_title: HSBC in talks with Blom over Lebanese unit sale amid cost cuts
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc is in talks with Blom Bank SAL to sell its Lebanese banking business, amid efforts to cut costs. The move is part of HSBC's three-year strategy to reduce annual costs by $5 billion, with 25,000 employees set to be cut. HSBC operates in 71 countries, including Lebanon, where it has three branches and employs around 200 people. A sale of its unprofitable Turkish unit was scrapped earlier this year, following a failed attempt to find a buyer. Details of the potential sale are yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends flat as investors take profits, Nintendo poked lower
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average ended flat on Monday, moving away from seven-week intraday highs, as investors took profits after a Wall Street-inspired rise. The Nikkei stock index closed 0.04% lower at 16,620.29, despite early gains supported by hopes of further Bank of Japan stimulus later this week.

site_title: China: Stock indexes edge up in sluggish trading
summary: China's stock indexes edged up 0.2% and 0.1% at 3,230.89 and 3,015.83 points respectively, in sluggish trading due to a lack of fresh market cues. Analysts predict a continued sideways trend in coming days.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte ditches the glitz for frugal national address
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte will deliver a six-year term outline in his inaugural national address, marking a shift from the event's traditional opulence. Duterte has scaled back the budget and instructed guests to dress down, following his election largely on his anti-crime platform. The speech, authored by Duterte, is expected to focus on law and order and will be a departure from his usual unscripted remarks.

site_title: Property cooling measures to remain: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that property cooling measures will remain unchanged. Managing director Ravi Menon stated that the measures are necessary to stabilize the property market and restore household debt sustainability. The measures were introduced to curb the 60% surge in property prices between 2009 and 2013, which outpaced nominal income growth.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said on Monday property cooling measures will remain.

site_title: Stimulus speculation drags on yen
summary: The Japanese yen slipped against the US dollar due to speculation that the Bank of Japan will increase its stimulus program following its policy meeting this week. Over 75% of economists polled by Bloomberg News expect the BoJ to make a policy move. The US Federal Reserve is also set to meet, with markets awaiting any clues about future policy moves. The yen rose to 106.31 from 106.19 yen, while the euro gained to 116.65 yen.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines may announce Boeing order this week: report
summary: Malaysia Airlines is reportedly set to announce a plane order of Boeing B737 MAX jets as early as Wednesday, with the airline aiming to expand its fleet by adding long-range narrowbody aircraft. The potential order could be up to half the size of a similar deal by Vietjet Air, valued at $11.3 billion. Malaysia Airlines' CEO, Peter Bellew, confirmed talks with Boeing, Airbus, and Bombardier, and the airline has called a press conference for Wednesday. The move is seen as part of the airline's strategy to serve more Asian routes out of Malaysia and recover from past disasters.

site_title: MAS: S$5.2b investment gain in FY15/16 official foreign reserves
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported a S$5.2 billion investment gain in official foreign reserves for FY2015/16, lower than the previous year's S$10.4 billion gain. The decrease was due to higher valuation provisions on equity investments, with global equity markets declining in FY2015/16. The official foreign reserves stood at S$332 billion as of March 31, 2016. MAS stated that currency movements do not impact the OFR's international purchasing power or its ability to conduct exchange rate policy.

site_title: China's yuan edges up in wake of G20 talks; doubts on outlook remain
summary: China's yuan edged higher against the dollar, staying near a six-year low, despite improved economic activity in the second quarter. The yuan traded at 6.6774 per dollar, 0.12% above the midpoint of 6.6860. Analysts warn that economic growth is likely to decelerate in the second half as credit and fiscal support wanes, with risks tilted towards lower policy rates and further yuan depreciation. The conclusion of the G20 finance ministers' meeting also saw yuan weakness bets rise, as countries pledged to support global growth and refrain from competitive currency devaluations.

site_title: Vanke battle peers into shadows of China banks' risky lending
summary: Chinese banks are increasingly using shadow lending products to mask worsening asset quality, with some banks investing depositors' money in asset management plans (AMPs) backed by shares as collateral. JPMorgan estimates AMP funds stood at 32 trillion yuan at the end of March, double a year earlier. This has raised concerns about regulatory arbitrage and the lack of effective oversight, potentially sacrificing proper risk management in pursuit of profit.

site_title: Mastercard holders can use cards to pay for trains, bus rides in year-end pilot
summary: Mastercard holders in Singapore will be able to pay for train and bus journeys using their contactless cards in a year-end pilot program. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Mastercard have partnered to launch an account-based ticketing system, eliminating the need for separate transit cards and fare top-ups. The pilot aims to attract 100,000 users and will also enable mobile phone contactless use on public transit, allowing commuters to track their journey and fare history through a mobile app or web portal. The program is set to launch at the end of this year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by positive leads from Wall Street and Europe, ahead of policy meetings by US and Japanese central banks. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.49% to 22,071.77, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.16%. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Nintendo shares plunge on Pokemon Go warning
summary: Nintendo's shares plummeted 17% to 23,405 yen after the company warned that the success of Pokémon Go, a popular mobile game, would not significantly impact its profits. Analysts had previously expressed concerns that the game's global success would be limited, and Nintendo confirmed this on Friday. The company owns a significant stake in the Pokémon franchise and will receive licensing fees, but the income from Pokémon Go is expected to be moderate. The stock had previously soared after the game's release, briefly surpassing Sony's value.

site_title: QT Vascular says US appeals court overturns US$20m payment to AngioScore
summary: QT Vascular said the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has overturned a US$20m payment to AngioScore, finding the district court lacked jurisdiction to hear the breach of fiduciary duty claim. A unanimous three-judge panel reversed the ruling, which had found Dr. Eitan Konstantino breached his duties to AngioScore, awarded damages, and found QT Vascular liable. Dr. Konstantino, CEO of QT Vascular, called the decision "delighted", validating the company's stance since the start of the litigation.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: MAS sees dent in reputation, to raise supervision amid 1MDB probe
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will sharpen its supervision on anti-money laundering and countering financing of terrorism control in the financial industry amid the ongoing 1MDB probe. MAS managing director Ravi Menon said the recent findings have made a dent in the country's reputation, with the financial sector being particularly vulnerable to money-laundering risks. MAS has already taken "decisive actions" against three major banks and will investigate other financial institutions. The probe into 1MDB has led to allegations of over $3 billion being misappropriated and laundered through US financial institutions.

site_title: Philippines' ex-leader Arroyo: 'I was persecuted'
summary: Former Philippine President Gloria Arroyo has declared herself a victim of political persecution after being released from nearly five years in detention over a corruption case. The Supreme Court dismissed plunder charges against her, finding "insufficient evidence" to accuse her of misusing state lottery funds. Arroyo, who suffered a spinal illness and was jailed under the administration of President Benigno Aquino, said she plans to seek medical treatment abroad. She criticized the prosecution process, stating that she is not saying political figures should be immune from prosecution, but rather that the process should be fair and even-handed.

site_title: MAS, MTI to review 1-3% growth forecast for 2016
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) are reviewing the 1-3% growth forecast for Singapore's economy in 2016. MAS managing director Ravi Menon noted a modest ascent in inflation, keeping the forecast for consumer price index (all-items inflation) at -1% to 0%. This review aims to reassess the economic outlook amid changing global conditions.

site_title: Ringgit heads for longest losing streak since November pre-FOMC
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell for a sixth consecutive day, its longest losing streak since November, amid speculation of a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase. The currency weakened 0.6% to 4.0830 per dollar, driven by US retail sales and housing data, and ongoing probes into 1Malaysia Development Bhd. Analysts predict the Fed will be "hawkish" and shift market pricing in the upcoming meeting, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.22 points to 1657.64. Volume was 20.67 million lots worth RM5.9 million, with 66 gainers and 27 losers.

site_title: China should increase government investment: state planner official
summary: China's deputy chair of the state planner, Zhang Yong, has called for increased government investment to boost the economy. Zhang stated that government investment should not compete with private investment, acknowledging that private investment has shrunk to a record low. He attributed the slowdown to the economy, saying it's impossible for private investment to continue growing rapidly.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks retreat from over 1-year high; TSMC down
summary: Taiwan's main stock index fell 0.6% on Monday, retreating from a one-year high, as investors took profits on recent winners such as TSMC, the world's top contract chip maker. TSMC dropped nearly 1% in the session. The electronics and financial subindices also declined 0.7%. The main index reached a level not seen since July 2015 earlier in the session.

site_title: Hot stock: Spackman shares gain 8.1% in early trading
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group shares rose 8.1% in early trading, reaching S$0.093, following the announcement that Alibaba Pictures Group has purchased the rights to distribute its film "Life Risking Romance" in China. The film, starring Ha Ji-won and Chen Bolin, is set to be released in South Korea in the fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter co-operated with Brazil probe of alleged militants
summary: Brazil's Operation Hashtag probe, targeting suspected Islamist militants, received cooperation from Facebook and Twitter, providing information about suspects' social media activities. The probe, which began last week, involves 12 suspects linked to the Islamic State group, discussing potential attacks on the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. Judge Marcos Josegrei da Silva stated that the companies' data helped investigators understand the nature of discussions and that there is no anonymity for such activities on the internet. The judge's comments come amid growing debate on privacy issues and law enforcement cooperation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks dip despite foreign buying spree, won slips
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.1% on Monday as local investors remained cautious ahead of US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan policy meetings. Foreigners, however, continued their buying spree for the 13th straight session, purchasing a net 49.3 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The won slipped 0.2% against the US dollar, and major carmakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors rose near 4%. Market analysts expect stocks to remain unchanged until uncertainties surrounding central bank decisions pass.

site_title: Has Wall Street been tamed? Fines, job cuts and anger take toll
summary: Wall Street is experiencing a period of significant change, marked by increased regulation, fines, and job cuts. The industry has seen a record $284 billion in fines over the past eight years and has lost over half a million jobs since the 2008 financial crisis. Profitability and compensation are falling as the industry adapts to new rules and faces challenges from fintech startups. The Republican Party platform and Democratic proposals call for the reinstatement of the Glass-Steagall Act, which could break up major banks. The industry is shifting towards smaller, specialized providers and embracing technology to stay competitive, but some experts warn that this could lead to a decrease in innovation and risk-taking.

images.alt_text: Chris Hentemann has two pieces of art on the walls of his corner office in midtown Manhattan. One is an oversize photograph of the cockpit of his twin-engine Beechcraft Baron. The other is an Andy Warhol print of Muhammad Ali with his fists cocked.

site_title: Japan's monthly economic assessment unchanged, but business sentiment worsens
summary: Japan's government maintained its unchanged assessment of the economy, citing a moderate recovery despite a worsening business sentiment. The Cabinet Office reported stagnant corporate mood due to a strengthening yen, with declining exports. The government is drafting fiscal stimulus spending to boost growth, while expectations for further monetary easing to increase inflation rates remain. Overall, the report suggests that the economy is facing weakness in some areas, leaving uncertainty about its future trajectory.

site_title: Aviva launches financial advisory firm
summary: Aviva has launched a financial advisory firm in Singapore with 280 licensed advisers, offering life, health, general insurance, and investment products. The move aims to shift the insurance industry towards more mature markets like the UK and Australia. The FA channel has grown consistently over the decade, now accounting for 20% of the market share, surpassing the tied agency channel. The launch follows Aviva's compareFirst Web aggregator, allowing consumers to compare life insurance products. The firm signals Aviva's conviction that the FA channel will dominate the future of insurance.

site_title: China says South Korea's Thaad anti-missile decision harms foundation of trust
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi criticized South Korea's decision to deploy a US anti-missile defense system, Thaad, as harming the foundation of trust between the two countries. China opposes the deployment, citing concerns that the system's radar could track its military capabilities. The decision has drawn protests from Beijing, which also worries about regional security. South Korea and the US claim Thaad is only for defense against North Korean ballistic missiles. The move has sparked tensions between China and South Korea, with China calling for a reevaluation of the deployment.

site_title: Suspected bomber killed in German bar blast: police
summary: A bomb blast at a bar in Ansbach, southern Germany, killed the suspected bomber and injured at least 12 people, with three seriously hurt. The explosion occurred near a city centre, where approximately 2,500 people were gathered for an open-air music festival, which local media reported may have been the intended target. Authorities have confirmed that the blast was set off deliberately and are investigating the cause.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses on supply worries
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, extending losses from last week, amid fresh worries about a global supply glut. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped six cents to US$44.13 a barrel, while Brent fell six cents to US$45.63 a barrel. The increase in US oil production, driven by reopened rigs, adds to the oversupply crisis. The dollar's strength also weighs on the market, with prices fluctuating between US$43 and US$52 per barrel since early June. The oversupply crisis is expected to continue, with oil supplies growing despite a decrease in crude supplies.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dipped on Monday, extending last week's losses on fresh worries about a global supply glut as more US rigs come back online and the dollar strengthens.

site_title: Japan's June exports fall less than expected, offer hope of recovery
summary: Japan's exports fell 7.4% annually in June, less than expected, indicating a possible recovery from a persistent decline. This decline is attributed to a slowing drop in exports, particularly in car and steel shipments. Exports to China and the US also decreased, but at a slower rate than forecast. The trade balance turned into a surplus, and imports fell 18.8% year-over-year. The Japanese government is considering a massive spending package to boost economic growth, and the BOJ is expected to ease monetary policy to boost inflation.

site_title: China's Huawei plans to ramp up R&D as first-half sales quicken
summary: Huawei reported a 40% revenue growth to 245.5 billion yuan (S$50 billion) in the first half of 2016, driven by upgraded smartphones and network gear. The company plans to sustain its investment in research and development as it prepares to build fifth-generation broadband networks. Despite a narrowing operating margin to 12%, Huawei aims to maintain its momentum and eventually displace Apple and Samsung from the top spots in global smartphones. The company's Consumer Business Group is scheduled to announce results on Tuesday, with revenue growth projected at 50% this year.

site_title: Vietnam warns South China Sea is a 'test' of Asean
summary: Vietnam has warned that the inability of South-east Asian nations to unify against China's militarization of the South China Sea is a "test" of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean). This comes after a UN-backed tribunal debunked Beijing's legal claim to the strategically vital sea. The warning was issued as diplomats met in Laos, highlighting the bloc's central role in addressing the security challenge. Vietnam's Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated that the South China Sea has become a "test case" for Asean's unity.

site_title: Australia says no clues from FBI report on MH370 pilot
summary: Australia has dismissed an FBI report on the missing MH370 pilot, stating it does not shed light on the plane's location. The report, cited in a New York magazine, revealed that the captain, Zaharie Ahmad Shah, used a flight simulator to chart a route similar to the one believed taken by the plane. This has reignited speculation in the Australian media that the mystery could be a murder/suicide. Australia maintains that the matter is for Malaysia to investigate.

site_title: Otto Marine unit effects vessel's arrest for outstanding ship-repair claims
summary: A Singaporean court has arrested the vessel Ratina Blessing for outstanding ship repair-related charges owed by RS Marine Investments Pte Ltd. The arrest was initiated by PT Batamec, a subsidiary of Otto Marine, which provided repair services to the vessel in 2015-2016. The company received partial payments but the remaining charges remained unpaid. Otto Marine's lawyers are working to enforce PT Batamec's rights and protect the group's interests and assets.

site_title: Australia plans indefinite detention of convicted extremists
summary: Australia plans to indefinitely detain individuals convicted of terrorism-related charges if they pose a danger to society upon release. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced the measures to deter terrorism, prevent attacks, and ensure public safety. The decision will be made by a court-supervised process, including medical and psychological assessments, and periodic reviews. The scheme will be reviewed annually and after several years. This move comes after a growing number of attacks, including the recent Bastille Day attack in Nice, France, and amid concerns about home-grown radicals in Australia.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday after Wall Street's Friday rebound
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.29% to 2,953.96 on Monday, following a Wall Street rebound on Friday. US stocks rebounded after dipping on Thursday, with the telecom and utilities sectors leading the gains. US crude fell 1.2% to $44.18, while Brent fell 1.1% to $45.69. Trading volume was 64 million shares worth S$85 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 102 to 56.

site_title: US dollar buoyant vs euro, yen as risk-on mood prevails
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen due to a risk-on mood, with the dollar up 0.1% against the euro at US$1.0969 and 0.1% against the yen at 106.30. The euro fell to a one-month low following shootings in Munich, while the yen has been on the defensive amid expectations of a Bank of Japan interest rate cut. A near-term Federal Reserve interest rate hike is also expected to support the dollar. Central bank meetings this week, including the Fed's policy conclave, will be closely watched for market direction.

site_title: Bulls thrive in low-volatility environment
summary: The US stock market reached all-time highs last week despite a low-volatility environment, with major indexes finishing the week at record highs. Strong earnings from tech and bank companies, including Microsoft and Bank of America, led the market. The low-volatility environment has allowed bulls to thrive, with strategists suggesting investors are committing to stocks after two years of hedging in "bond-like" sectors. The US economy is expected to show potential for growth, but second-quarter earnings need to justify the bounce since the "Brexit" vote.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on BoJ stimulus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by hopes of a fresh Bank of Japan stimulus later this week. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.17% to 16,655.81, and the Topix index gained 0.23% to 1,330.59. Investors are optimistic about the potential stimulus, which could boost economic growth and stabilize the market. The move follows a solid lead from Wall Street, where stocks rose to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: More Chinese buyers enquire about UK property after Brexit vote
summary: Chinese buyers have increased their inquiries about UK property by 30-40% since the Brexit vote, with the pound's decline creating opportunities to buy at a discount. The surge in interest comes as half of Chinese investors paused their plans to invest in the UK before the vote, citing a crisis at home and uncertainty in Britain. The value of sterling has lost 8% against the dollar and 6% against the yuan, effectively bringing down prices across the market.

site_title: China state firms help offset outflows with overseas debt
summary: China's state-owned enterprises are raising money offshore and bringing it back home through dollar bonds, offsetting capital outflows. In the April-June period, sales of dollar bonds by state-run firms rose to a record $18.7 billion, 80% higher than the previous four quarters. The government encourages companies to bring in foreign-currency debt to convert into yuan, aiming to counterbalance capital outflow pressures. This move is seen as a policy effort to boost capital inflows and prevent panic capital outflows.

images.alt_text: After stepping into the currency and equity markets repeatedly over the past year to stem declines, government-linked entities are now spurring capital inflows by raising money offshore and bringing it home.

site_title: Brexit chaos may erase US$1.6t from global M&A, study says
summary: A new study by Baker & McKenzie predicts that the UK's potential exit from the European Union could erase up to $1.6 trillion from future mergers and acquisitions. The uncertainty surrounding Brexit may lead to a cycle of market and political uncertainty, halving the UK's economic growth forecast to 1.1% for 2017. Merger volumes are expected to dip by at least $240 billion over the next five years. However, the study notes that London will retain its financial and economic talent, and global merger activity is only moderately down for the next two years before recovering.

site_title: Changjiang Fertiliser narrows Q2 loss to 5.64m yuan
summary: Changjiang Fertiliser reported a narrowed second-quarter net loss of 5.64 million yuan, down from 5.91 million yuan in the same period last year. The loss per share was 1.57 renminbi cents, lower than 1.64 renminbi cents in Q2 2015. The company's first-half loss was 10.73 million yuan, compared to 12.59 million yuan last year. Changjiang Fertiliser plans to dispose of its subsidiaries in China within the next 12 months.

site_title: Keppel refutes Operation Car Wash allegations (Amended)
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore-listed conglomerate, has denied allegations of involvement in bribery and corruption related to Operation Car Wash, an anti-corruption probe in Brazil. The allegations were made by Zwi Skornicki, who admitted to making illegal payments to publicists of Dilma Rousseff's 2010 presidential campaign. Keppel reiterated its zero-tolerance stance against such activities and will take necessary steps to eradicate them if discovered. The company is currently unable to comment further due to ongoing investigations.

site_title: Deutsche Bank set for investor scrutiny as short sellers circle
summary: Deutsche Bank's CEO John Cryan is set to present a quarterly update, but investors are skeptical about his efforts to turn around the struggling bank. Despite job cuts and asset sales, the bank's stock has lost over half its value in the past year. Hedge funds, including Marshall Wace, have bet on further declines. Analysts warn about the bank's capital strength, citing a low common equity tier 1 ratio and a drop in fixed-income trading revenue. Short interest has declined, but sell ratings outnumber buy ratings, raising concerns about the bank's future.

site_title: Gold slumps as stronger dollar, share market gains cut demand
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $1,317.26 an ounce, extending a two-week drop, due to a stronger dollar and gains in the US stock market, which cut demand for the metal as a store of value. The US Federal Reserve is set to meet on July 26-27, with traders pricing in a 10% chance of a rate rise, while the Bank of Japan is expected to step up stimulus. The S&P 500 ended at a record on Friday, further weakening gold's rally this year.

site_title: Alibaba buys distribution rights for Spackman's film 'Life Risking Romance'
summary: ALIBABA Pictures Group acquired distribution rights for Spackman Entertainment Group's film "Life Risking Romance" in China, set to be released in the fourth quarter of 2016. The film, starring Ha Ji-won and Chun Jung-myung, will be distributed through a combination of traditional theaters and online platforms. The partnership aims to expand the film's reach and exposure in China. The deal is expected to have minimal financial impact on Spackman's financial year ending December 31, 2016.

images.alt_text: ALIBABA Pictures Group has purchased the rights to distribute Spackman Entertainment Group's film "Life Risking Romance" in movie theatres and on online platforms in China.

site_title: Singtel's Optus Business in ICT deal with QBE Australia
summary: Singtel's Optus Business has announced a three-year ICT services agreement with QBE Australia, delivering voice, mobile, and data network services to over 4,000 QBE end-users across 42 locations in Australia using the Optus network.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths to cut jobs, close stores in restructure
summary: Woolworths, Australia's top grocer, announced a restructuring plan to regain its competitive edge, resulting in up to A$1 billion in costs, 500 job cuts, and the closure of stores. The company will also shift 1,000 head office positions to stores. The overhaul follows the company's first loss in 23 years, amid increasing competition from foreign entrants such as Aldi. The restructuring is expected to take three to five years to complete.

site_title: Oil near a two-month low as US drillers ramp up operations
summary: US oil producers are reviving drilling operations in the shale patch, adding rigs for the fourth consecutive week. Oil futures fell 0.4% near a two-month low, with West Texas Intermediate for September delivery at $44.03 a barrel. US crude and gasoline supplies are at their highest seasonal levels in at least two decades. The rally in oil prices, sparked by supply disruptions in Nigeria and Canada, has lost momentum. Oil prices remain up about 68% from a 12-year low in February.

site_title: Asia: Shares near 9-month peak, US dollar shines
summary: Asian shares near a 9-month peak as Brexit worries ease, while the US dollar rises amid solid economic data. The dollar's index hit a 4-1/2-month high, boosting its relative attractiveness. The euro and British pound also fell, while oil prices hovered near 2-1/2-month lows. US stock prices marked four straight weeks of gains, with the S&P 500 setting a record closing high. Policymakers from the Group of 20 agreed to support global growth and better share trade benefits.

site_title: Olympics: WADA 'disappointed' by IOC decision on Russia
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) rejected calls to ban all Russian competitors from the Rio Olympics, despite the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) recommending such a move. WADA expressed disappointment and concern that the IOC decision may lead to "lesser protection for clean athletes" and undermine the principles of clean sport. The agency had previously recommended a blanket ban on Russian competitors, citing a state-run doping program exposed by the McLaren Investigation. WADA will continue its investigative work into doping and strengthen the anti-doping system, while the IPC will make its own decision on Russian athletes in the Paralympics.

site_title: One dead, 10 injured in explosion near Nuremberg, Germany
summary: A person was killed and 10 injured in an explosion in Ansbach, Germany, near Nuremberg. The cause of the blast is unclear, with officials suspecting a gas leak and authorities investigating whether it was intentional. The incident occurred late on Sunday, following a shooting that killed nine people in Munich on Friday.

site_title: Teenage friend of Munich gunman arrested: police
summary: German police have arrested a 16-year-old Afghan teenager, a friend of the Munich gunman, David Ali Sonboly, who killed 9 people in a shopping center rampage. The teenager handed himself in after the incident and had been questioned about his relationship with Sonboly. However, police found contradictions in his statements, leading to his arrest for withholding information about a crime. The teenager is suspected of posting a similar message on Facebook after the killings, which may have been an attempt to lure victims.

site_title: Munich gunman 'planned shooting for a year'
summary: A 19-year-old German man, David Ali Sonboly, killed 9 people and injured 35 others at a Munich shopping mall, planning the attack for a year. He selected victims at random and had a history of depression and mental health issues, but no link to extremist groups. Sonboly, who had bought the gun online, killed himself after the attack, which has sparked debate about Germany's gun laws and tightened security measures.

site_title: Business as usual for Malaysia premier amid latest graft drama
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak appears unfazed by US allegations of massive fraud at a state fund, continuing with his usual routine despite the controversy. Najib attended various events and meetings, focusing on domestic issues, including the economy and supporting ethnic Malays. The US Department of Justice seeks to seize over $1 billion in assets, but Najib denies wrongdoing and has maintained his grip on power. Analysts believe he remains "fairly secure" and the impact of the scandal on financial markets has diminished, with investors focusing on stability rather than potential political risk.

site_title: Australian treasurer says credit agency points to post-election risks
summary: Australian Federal Treasurer Scott Morrison stated that a ratings agency's assessment of the country's debt reiterated the risks posed by a fractious senate following the double dissolution election. Fitch Ratings has affirmed Australia's AAA sovereign credit rating with a stable outlook, but Moody's and S&P have expressed concerns about the consequences of the election result on fiscal reform. Morrison emphasized the importance of maintaining confidence in the economy by living within means and avoiding higher debt and deficits. A negative change to the nation's credit rating could have flow-on effects for state and territory governments and the financial sector.

site_title: Yahoo appears near deal to sell core assets
summary: Yahoo is near a deal to sell its core online assets to Verizon for $5 billion, ending its 20-year run as an independent company. The sale would allow Yahoo to separate its main assets from its holdings in Alibaba, which accounts for most of its market value. The deal would also integrate Yahoo with AOL, a move seen as a way to monetize its audience through advertising. The sale comes after Yahoo reported a $440 million quarterly loss and has been under pressure from shareholders to break up the company.

site_title: Australia on sale: Retail price war raises spectre of deflation
summary: Australia's retail sector is experiencing a price war, with widespread discounting and a near 50% slump in sales revenue between January and June. This trend suggests the country is at risk of deflation, with falling inflation rates and stagnant wages growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia has cut interest rates to 1.75% to combat the low inflation, but experts warn that the central bank may need to lower rates further to prevent an activity-sapping rise in real interest rates.

site_title: Bet on reflation: SocGen analyst
summary: SocGen analyst Alain Bokobza recommends betting on reflation in Japan and emerging markets despite a deflationary environment. He suggests selling the Japanese yen until it reaches $1.10 and buying the Nikkei stock market index to benefit from cheaper exports. Additionally, Bokobza recommends buying Japanese banks for a higher-risk, higher-reward bet.

site_title: Policewoman claims French interior ministry pressured her on Nice attack
summary: A French policewoman claims the interior ministry pressured her to alter a report on security at the Nice fireworks display where 84 people were killed in a 2016 attack. Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve denies the allegations, saying the policewoman was trying to discredit him. Cazeneuve's office also denies that he sent a representative to the local police, contradicting the policewoman's testimony. The claims have fueled an escalating row over security failures in Nice, with local authorities and opposition politicians criticizing the government's handling of the attack.

images.alt_text: Sandra Bertin (pictured), who is in charge of Nice's system of security cameras, told the Journal du Dimanche newspaper she had been "harassed for an hour" by an unnamed interior ministry official on the phone after a "commissioner" came to see her the day after the attack.

site_title: US moves to block massive health insurer deals led by Anthem, Aetna
summary: The US Department of Justice has filed a lawsuit to block two massive mergers in the health insurance market: Anthem Inc's acquisition of Cigna Corp and Aetna Inc's planned acquisition of Humana Inc. The DOJ claims these mergers would reduce competition, raise prices for consumers, and stifle innovation, ultimately reducing the number of large national insurers from five to three.

images.alt_text: Antitrust officials have filed a lawsuit against Anthem Inc's proposed purchase of Cigna Corp (above) and Aetna Inc's planned acquisition of Humana Inc.
Antitrust officials have filed a lawsuit against Anthem Inc's proposed purchase of Cigna Corp and Aetna Inc's planned acquisition of Humana Inc (above).

site_title: Hamilton wins in Hungary to take overall lead
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Hungarian Grand Prix, taking the championship lead from teammate Nico Rosberg for the first time this season. Hamilton, now 48 wins away from a record, leads Rosberg by six points after 11 of 21 races. The Briton's fifth win of the season came after a strong start, and he praised his team for the victory. The race marked a significant shift in the championship standings, with Rosberg set to face a tough task to regain the lead in the German Grand Prix next week.

site_title: Dollar hits 4-month high on strong US data
summary: The US dollar index rose to a four-month high on Friday, driven by positive US data and weak overseas readings, prompting investors to reassess the likelihood of a US Federal Reserve rate increase. This led to the dollar's fifth consecutive weekly gain. The dollar's value is also boosted by the prospect of monetary policy divergence between the Fed and global central banks.

site_title: Trump says US could pull out of WTO
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump suggested the US could pull out of the World Trade Organization if elected, citing trade deals as a "disaster." He proposed punitive import taxes of up to 30% on firms moving manufacturing abroad, and expressed concern over the impact on the world economy, but dismissed potential backlash. Trump also reiterated his intention to force NATO allies to shoulder defense costs and proposed "extreme vetting" for French and German citizens at US borders.

images.alt_text: US Republican White House nominee Donald Trump suggested Sunday that the United States could pull out of the World Trade Organization if he is elected president.

site_title: Can't find a room at the Rio Olympics? Try the luxury sex suite
summary: Rio de Janeiro is experiencing severe hotel shortages ahead of the Olympics, with only 56,500 rooms available despite the city's goal of 62,000. To address the issue, luxury hotels are offering alternative accommodations, including sex suites and Airbnb rentals. The city's infamous "love hotels" are also making rooms available at discounted rates, with some offering seductive deals of up to 70% less than traditional establishments.

site_title: BNP's First Hawaiian IPO said to value bank up to US$4b
summary: BNP Paribas SA's First Hawaiian Inc, a Honolulu-based bank, plans to set terms and sell shares in the next couple of weeks, with a potential market value of US$3 billion to US$4 billion. The bank's value is comparable to that of Honolulu-based Bank of Hawaii Corp, and its IPO filing shows US$19.1 billion in total assets. First Hawaiian posted net income of US$213.8 million last year, and the bank is expected to list on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol FHB.

site_title: UK warns of Brexit 'shadow' on world economy
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond warns that Brexit will cast a "shadow" over the world economy, citing uncertainty about the outcome for the next couple of years. However, he also sees opportunities in free trade deals with countries like China, Australia, and India. Hammond says he could see a free trade deal with China, citing the UK's existing strategic partnership. G20 finance ministers also express concern about the Brexit impact, vowing to use all policy tools to boost growth.

site_title: Obama decries Trump's 'lack of preparedness'
summary: US President Barack Obama criticized Republican nominee Donald Trump's readiness to be commander-in-chief, stating Trump's suggestion that the US might not meet its NATO defense obligations highlighted a "lack of preparedness." Obama emphasized the importance of European allies boosting defense spending, particularly amid Russia's aggression. In contrast, Trump's comments were seen as contradicting the NATO treaty's Article Five, which commits members to defend each other in case of an attack. Obama's comments underscored his concerns about Trump's foreign policy approach.

site_title: Adaptive's upcoming film will put its unusual business model to the test
summary: Adaptive Studios, a new film studio with an unusual business model, is set to release its first big test with the upcoming film "Coin Heist". The studio acquires abandoned scripts from other studios, adapts them into novels, and then produces films or TV shows based on the books. With 50 acquired scripts, including "Coin Heist", which has been in development for 18 years, Adaptive aims to prove its approach gives it an advantage over bigger studios competing for fresh scripts. The studio has already released a dozen books and plans to publish 18 more, with eight in development for film and television.

site_title: Better guidelines needed for lifting of trading halts
summary: Indonesian coal miner Resources Prima Group and digital satellite firm AddValue Technologies experienced inconsistent trading halt liftoffs, with the latter taking 14 minutes and the former just 7 minutes. The lack of guidelines and consistency raises concerns about fairness and market uncertainty. Experts suggest introducing clearer guidelines, such as fixed liftoff times or requiring companies to state when halts will be lifted, to provide greater certainty for traders and investors.

site_title: Can company indemnities and D&O really protect directors?
summary: Directors of companies face increasing risks of personal liability due to shareholder activism and regulatory scrutiny. To mitigate these risks, companies offer contractual indemnities and directors and officers (D&O) liability insurance. However, these protections have limitations, including restrictions under the Companies Act and market norms. Certain risks, such as fraudulent conduct and environmental claims, are uninsurable. Directors must review and update their indemnities and D&O policies to ensure adequate protection, considering changes in the law and regulatory requirements.

site_title: Scandal rocks US Democratic Party truce on eve of confab
summary: US Democratic Party Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigned on the eve of the party convention, amid a scandal involving leaked emails that suggested an insider effort to hobble Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign. The emails, which included messages suggesting Sanders be presented as an atheist in deeply religious states, sparked widespread outrage and calls for Wasserman Schultz's resignation. Sanders endorsed Hillary Clinton as the party's nominee, but many of his supporters are planning protests in Philadelphia, fueling concerns about the party's unity. The scandal threatens to undermine an uneasy truce within the party, just as Clinton is set to face Republican nominee Donald Trump in the November election.

site_title: Markets to look at Fed and BOJ meetings
summary: The Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan are set to hold meetings this week, with no interest rate changes or money printing expected. This inaction is expected to support stock markets, which have been boosted by the "Brexit" rally. The chance of the Fed raising rates this week is low, at 8%, rising to 24.6% for the September meeting. A rate hike this year is unlikely, with most observers expecting a December meeting to be the next opportunity for a rate increase.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group posts 4.5% rise in Q2 profit, buoyed by higher revenue
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 4.5% year-on-year rise in Q2 net profit to S$16.7 million, driven by 19.8% revenue growth across all divisions. Revenue was boosted by higher patient load, expanding clinic networks, and newly acquired International SOS. Staff costs and operating expenses offset the gains, with the group maintaining a strong cash position of S$123.6 million. The company declared an interim dividend and expects further growth in revenue for the rest of the year.

images.alt_text: Singapore-listed Raffles Medical Group (RMG) on Monday reported a 4.5 per cent year-on-year rise in second-quarter net profit to S$16.7 million, buoyed by higher revenue from all divisions.
