summary: Business confidence in the Asia-Pacific region has picked up in the second quarter, driven by a stronger sentiment in China, but Singapore businesses remain nervous due to the volatile global economy. Despite a slight improvement, 55% of Asia-Pacific businesses are less confident about their Q2 prospects, with 47% reporting cuts to capital expenditure and 42% declining orders. Global business confidence has also improved, but remains below the global average due to uncertainty surrounding Brexit and its potential impact on global markets.

site_title: Shooting star
summary: The Mercedes-Benz CLA Shooting Brake boasts unique styling, combining sporty coupe and estate-like features. With five doors, it defies traditional automotive logic, but its proportions are deemed beautiful. The Shooting Brake concept was first introduced on the CLS model, featuring a long bonnet, steeply raked windshield, and sensuous bulges. Despite its unconventional design, the CLA Shooting Brake is visually appealing, making it a standout in the automotive world.

site_title: American Airlines quarterly profit plunges 44%
summary: American Airlines reported a 44% plunge in quarterly profit to $950 million, or $1.68 per share, due to a large provision for income tax. This is a significant decrease from the same period last year, when the company earned $1.70 billion, or $2.41 per share. The company's earnings per share, excluding items, were $2.81. The large tax provision was a major contributor to the decline in earnings.

site_title: PayPal ties up with Visa to extend reach
summary: PayPal has partnered with Visa to expand its reach, allowing customers to use Visa credit and debit cards in PayPal transactions and enabling shoppers to use PayPal in brick-and-mortar retail locations. The deal is expected to boost revenue and growth, with PayPal raising its full-year 2016 revenue guidance to $10.75-10.85 billion, projecting 16% growth. PayPal's second-quarter earnings rose to 36 cents per share, with year-over-year revenue growth of 15%. The partnership is seen as a significant move to increase convenience and accessibility for PayPal users.

images.alt_text: Paypal Holdings Inc on Thursday showed strong growth in its online payments business, meeting Wall Street earnings expectations and announcing a partnership with Visa Inc that is expected to boost the reach and revenue of the money-moving service.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde to stand trial over Tapie affair: French court
summary: French court orders IMF chief Christine Lagarde to stand trial over a massive state payout to tycoon Bernard Tapie when she was economy minister in 2008. The payout of 404 million euros was criticized for being too generous. Lagarde's appeal against trial was dismissed, with the court ruling she should face charges for negligence. This is the latest development in a long-standing controversy surrounding the affair.

site_title: Trump casts himself as US saviour with forceful acceptance speech
summary: Donald Trump accepted the Republican presidential nomination, delivering a forceful speech to Americans who feel their country is spiralling out of control. The 70-year-old New York real estate developer and reality television star appealed to voters who yearn for a leader who will take aggressive actions to protect them. Trump drew cheers from delegates as he accepted the nomination, positioning himself as the US saviour with his unconventional campaign.

site_title: Sabana Reit Q2 DPU falls 32%
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 32% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.23 Singapore cents in Q2 2016, driven by a 31% drop in distributable income and 24% decrease in net property income. Gross revenue fell 11% due to negative rental revisions. Despite an 88.8% overall portfolio occupancy level, the trust's units closed unchanged at 54.5 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Lian Beng Group granted options to acquire four properties for S$151m
summary: Lian Beng Group has been granted options to acquire four properties in Singapore for S$151 million. The subsidiaries have until August 11 to exercise the options granted by Heartland Retail Holdings. The acquisition is expected to be funded through bank borrowings and internal resources, providing rental returns. The deal's completion is subject to approval from the Housing and Development Board.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Chinese scientists plan first human test with gene editing tool
summary: Chinese scientists are conducting the first human trials with the Crispr gene editing tool, a potential therapy for lung cancer. Led by oncologist Lu You, the trial involves activating immune cells using Crispr and infusing them back into patients. The initial group of three patients will be treated one at a time due to potential risks. This breakthrough marks a significant step in mastering the technology, which could lead to therapies worldwide.

site_title: Don't fight a losing battle at work
summary: Experts advise against openly confronting and opposing every issue at work, as it may be a losing battle. Knowing when to charge and when to back off is crucial. While it's essential to air views and voice disagreements, it's not necessary to pursue every issue. Effective communication and strategic decision-making are key to resolving workplace conflicts and achieving goals. By recognizing when to take a stand and when to yield, individuals can maintain a positive work environment and avoid unnecessary stress. This approach can lead to better outcomes and a more productive workplace.

images.alt_text: In the office, it seems that there is no end to the number of people or things that irk you.

site_title: Thai TMB Bank aims to triple online customers by 2021
summary: Thai TMB Bank plans to triple its online customers to 1 million by 2021, allowing customers to open deposit accounts via smartphones or other devices. This service, set to launch in the third quarter, will be the first of its kind in Thailand, requiring customers to physically verify their identity at bank branches to open a savings account.

site_title: China Vanke and top shareholder face questioning from securities watchdog
summary: China Vanke Co and its top shareholder, Baoneng, are facing scrutiny from China's securities regulator for violating disclosure regulations on shareholding changes. The regulator requires executives to meet to discuss the matter, condemning Vanke's management for disregarding small investors' interests. The dispute stems from a corporate battle between Vanke and Baoneng, which holds a 25% stake in the property development company. Vanke recently unveiled a $6.9 billion deal to dilute Baoneng's stake, but the shareholder has tried to oust the Vanke board.

site_title: Lum Chang unit scores S$60.8m tender for industrial building
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' wholly owned subsidiary, Lum Chang Building Contractors, has secured a S$60.8 million contract to build a 14-storey industrial building in Singapore. The 19-month contract includes upgrading works to three existing buildings. This contract does not impact the group's current year profits and brings the total outstanding value of construction projects to S$558 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Up, up and away! Hot-air balloonist set to beat world record
summary: A Russian hot-air balloonist, Fedor Konyukhov, is set to break the world record for a round-the-world trip in a hot-air balloon, landing in Australia on July 23. Konyukhov, who previously conquered the north and south poles solo, departed Western Australia on July 12 and is expected to complete the record-breaking journey. His crew predicts he will land in the afternoon, marking a successful final leg of his adventure.

site_title: US: Wall St flat; GE leads industrials lower
summary: US stocks were flat on Friday, with the Dow and S&P 500 trading at record highs, despite disappointing results from industrials, including GE, which dropped 2.2% after its report. GE led the industrials sector down 0.8% and was the biggest loser on the Dow. Analysts now expect smaller profit declines and more companies to top earnings estimates, but the market is digesting a strong post-Brexit rally and may need time to reassess.

site_title: CDL to dispose controlling stake in HK-listed City e-Solutions for HK$566.4m
summary: CDL agrees to sell its 52.52% stake in Hong Kong-listed City e-Solutions Limited to China Tian Yuan Manganese for HK$566.4 million (S$98.2 million). The sale price is a 119% premium over the audited net asset value per share, and follows discussions announced in April. CDL will cease to have any interest in CES after the transaction. The disposal is not expected to impact CDL's net tangible assets or earnings for the 2016 financial year.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closing at 1,657.42, down 0.12 points. A total of 1.38 billion lots worth RM1.41 billion were traded, with 397 gainers and 340 losers.

site_title: Euro zone business growing at weakest rate since start of 2015: PMI
summary: Euro zone business growth has slowed to its weakest rate since 2015, according to a survey by Markit. The composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 52.9, down from 53.1 in June, as stronger performances in Germany and France offset weakness in smaller countries. A Reuters poll had predicted a steeper fall, but the slight loss of momentum may be of concern to the European Central Bank. Despite this, the PMI still indicates third-quarter economic growth of 0.3%.

site_title: PBOC official says tax cuts more effective than rate cuts: media
summary: A Chinese central bank official, Sheng Songcheng, stated that tax cuts are more effective than interest rate cuts in stimulating the economy, as companies are reluctant to invest. This is due to a liquidity trap, where enterprises lack the willingness to invest. Sheng also suggested increasing the fiscal deficit ratio to 4-5% of GDP to boost the economy more effectively, reiterating remarks made last weekend. This move could provide policymakers with an alternative to interest rate cuts in addressing China's slowing economic growth.

site_title: Raffles Money Change to boost compliance procedures after 1MDB-linked rap
summary: Raffles Money Change (RMC), a remittance agent censured for links to 1MDB fund flows, has announced it will improve its compliance procedures after being criticized by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Despite being censured, RMC claims it has reported suspicious transactions to authorities and cooperated with MAS. The company will enhance its internal controls and risk management policies to address issues. RMC's management has expressed commitment to working closely with the MAS to address any issues.

site_title: Flight MH370 search to be "suspended" if not found in current search area
summary: Malaysia, China, and Australia agree to suspend the search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 if it's not found in the current search area, a statement issued to the next of kin said. The search, spanning 120,000 sq km in the southern Indian Ocean, has been hampered by bad weather and has cost almost A$180 million. The search was originally scheduled to end in June but will be suspended without new credible evidence on its location. The plane disappeared in March 2014 with 239 people on board.

site_title: Singapore shares finish mixed on the day, higher for the week thanks to Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 2,945.35 on Friday, gaining 20 points for the week, its highest weekly gain since March. The index has now gained 2.2% for the year. The rally was driven by Wall Street's consecutive all-time highs, with Singtel and Thai Beverage contributing significantly. However, the index was mixed on Friday, with Wilmar International experiencing a 7% decline. Turnover was below average at 1.1 billion units worth S$949.4 million.

summary:

Singapore stocks rose for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private-home prices declined 0.4% in Q2, a moderation from the 0.7% drop in Q1. Japan's rail firm proposes a 7-year timeline for commercial operations of the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Rail. Singapore's financial sector has brokered $1.6 billion in deals with Chongqing companies. The construction industry calls for revised Public Sector Standard Conditions of Contract and Security of Payment Act. The STI gained 0.7% on Friday, and Singapore shares finished mixed, with a 2.2% year-to-date gain.

site_title: Japan said to mull extra spending in 2016 of about 3t yen
summary: Japan's government is discussing supplementary spending of around 3 trillion yen for the current fiscal year, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aiming to keep the figure low. The spending is part of a broader fiscal package to support the economy, following a convincing win for his ruling party in an upper house election. The exact timing of an announcement on the spending hasn't been made, and the Bank of Japan's board is set to meet next week to consider changes to its monetary stimulus program.

images.alt_text: Japan's government is currently discussing supplementary spending of around 3 trillion yen (S$38.4 billion) for the current fiscal year, according to two officials familiar with the talks.

site_title: Hammond says Britain to reset fiscal policy in strongest hint to change
summary: Finance Minister Philip Hammond suggests Britain may reset fiscal policy if necessary after the Brexit vote, indicating a less aggressive approach to reducing the budget deficit. Hammond's comments, made during a trip to China, come as markets are jittery about the economy post-Brexit. The Autumn Statement, scheduled for later this year, will provide further insight into any fiscal steps Hammond might take.

site_title: China seeks top-10 automation ranking by 2020: robot industry group
summary: China aims to reach a top-10 ranking in automation by 2020 by increasing robot presence in its factories, driven by labor shortages and rising wages. Currently, the country has 36 robots per 10,000 manufacturing workers, ranking 28th globally. This push is part of China's efforts to modernize its manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: China is aiming for a top-10 ranking in automation for its industries by 2020 by putting more robots in its factories, the International Federation of Robotics (IFR) said.

site_title: Apple to open first Apple Store in Taiwan
summary: Apple plans to open its first Apple Store in Taiwan, following a US$1.38 billion bond offering on the island. The move comes as the company seeks a team for the store, indicated by job postings. This is the first Apple Store in Taiwan, following a decline in Apple's Greater China revenue, which includes Hong Kong and Taiwan, due to an increasingly saturated smartphone market.

site_title: Rowsley posts Q2 net loss of S$5.3m
summary: Rowsley, a MAINBOARD-listed company, reported a net loss of S$5.3 million in the second quarter ended June, up from a profit of S$516,000 in the same period last year. Revenue increased 26% to S$22.3 million, driven by contributions from the UK hospitality group and higher revenue from RSP Architects Planners & Engineers. No dividend was recommended, and shares gained 0.2 Singapore cents or 1.5% to close at 13.5 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Flash: Singapore, Chongqing finance firms to sign deals involving US$1.6b in transactions: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced that Singapore and Chongqing finance firms will sign deals worth approximately US$1.6 billion in transactions. No further details about the deals are provided.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Zico Holdings subsidiary granted capital markets services licence by MAS
summary: Zico Holdings' subsidiary, Zico Capital, has been granted a capital markets services licence by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The licence, granted on July 13, allows Zico Capital to provide advice on fund raising, corporate arrangements, and restructuring. The company expects the licence to have minimal impact on its earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the 2016 financial year. The counter closed at 28.5 Singapore cents on Friday.

site_title: Gold eases as slight nerves set in on Fed policy outlook
summary: Gold prices eased 0.5% to $1,324.66 an ounce, as investors weighed the possibility of the US Federal Reserve tightening monetary policy before the end of 2016. Despite a global interest rate backdrop that has supported gold, the US Fed's potential policy shift has created uncertainty, leading to a decline in gold prices. This marks a reversal from earlier this month when gold hit its highest level in two years due to loose monetary policies in Europe and Japan.

site_title: Government bans newspaper published by ISIS
summary: The Singapore government has banned Al Fatihin, a newspaper published by Furat Media, an affiliate of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), under the Undesirable Publications Act. The move was gazetted by Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust Q1 profit grows 14%, to maintain distribution at S$0.0136
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 14% increase in Q1 net profit to S$9.4 million, maintaining its distribution at S$0.0136 per unit. Total property income rose 6% to S$36.1 million, driven by base rent growth of 7% and positive rental reversions. The trust also realised S$590,000 in exchange gains, compared to a loss of S$10.4 million in the previous year. Looking ahead, the trust expects stable rental values in Bangalore and improving values in Chennai and Hyderabad, according to Jones Lang LaSalle Meghraj's forecast.

site_title: Flash: Singapore finance firms broker about US$4.5b in deals for Chongqing firms: MAS
summary: Singapore finance firms have brokered about US$4.5 billion in deals for Chongqing firms, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore. The transactions involve Singaporean companies investing in Chongqing-based firms, marking a significant economic collaboration between the two regions. This deal is part of Singapore's efforts to expand its economic ties with China.

site_title: Australia: Shares pause near recent peak; NZ hits fresh record
summary: Australia's shares paused near a one-year high, closing 0.26% lower at 5,498.20, despite a rally in the natural resources sector. New Zealand's benchmark index hit an all-time high, finishing 0.16% higher at 7,226.05. Both indexes recovered from a slump following the Brexit vote.

site_title: Formula One: Rosberg signs new Mercedes deal
summary: Nico Rosberg has signed a new two-year deal with Mercedes, extending his partnership with teammate Lewis Hamilton until 2018. The deal was announced on Twitter, with a video and photograph of the contract signing. Rosberg leads Hamilton by one point ahead of the Hungarian Grand Prix on Sunday.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as miners weaken and Skanska skids
summary: European stock markets fell on Friday, down 0.4% due to a drop in mining company shares and a decline at Swedish construction company Skanska. Copper prices eased back, contributing to the decline. The Stoxx 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indexes were both affected.

site_title: Kia Motors expected to pick site for first India plant next month: sources
summary: Kia Motors is expected to pick a site for its first India plant next month, with the proposed factory starting production in 2019 and having a capacity to make 300,000 Kia vehicles a year. The move aims to leverage Hyundai's existing supplier base in India, a key market expected to become the world's third-largest car market by 2020. Three sites in Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, and Gujarat are under consideration, with Andhra Pradesh considered the frontrunner. Kia's investment size and model production have yet to be decided.

site_title: UK economy wilting fast after Brexit vote, as PMI shows record drop
summary: The UK economy appears to be shrinking at its fastest rate since the 2008-09 recession, following the Brexit vote. Markit's purchasing managers' indices show the services sector, a key driver of British economic growth, has plummeted to 47.4 in July, the largest drop in its 20-year history. Economists expect a sharp contraction in the economy, with the Bank of England considering aggressive action to cushion the shock. Sterling fell against the dollar, and British government bond prices rose, as the news raised concerns about the BoE's ability to manage the economy.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust reports 3% DPU rise in Q3
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a 3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for its fiscal third quarter, reaching 2.41 Singapore cents. The company attributed the rise to higher net property income, mainly due to the acquisition of 357 Collins Street, increased income from Alexandra Technopark, and lower maintenance expenses. Despite a weakening Australian dollar affecting income from Australian properties, the company's occupancy rates for certain properties were lower. Microsoft also extended its lease at Alexandra Technopark for five more years.

site_title: Singapore cyber law to ensure operators secure information
summary: Singapore is introducing a Cybersecurity Act to ensure operators across industries secure critical information infrastructure and protect sensitive data. The legislation aims to cover integrated management of cyber threats, proactive security measures, and incident reporting. The initiative follows Singapore's high rate of internet usage and reliance on online data-processing, exposing it to greater cybersecurity risks. The bill is set to be introduced in parliament next year and will allow the Cyber Security Agency to better manage cyber incidents and raise standards for cybersecurity service providers.

site_title: S$560m redevelopment of Funan mall to begin in Q3
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust Management announced a S$560 million redevelopment of Funan DigitaLife Mall, set to begin in Q3 2016 and complete by Q4 2019. The project aims to transform the mall into an "aspirational lifestyle destination." Estimated incremental gross revenue and net property income per annum are S$47.5 million and S$36.6 million, respectively. The redevelopment is expected to boost the mall's value and competitiveness.

site_title: National Australia Bank unveils new structure to focus at home
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has announced a top management shake-up and restructuring to boost growth in Australia and New Zealand. The move comes after the bank's underperformance compared to its rivals and declining market share. CEO Andrew Thorburn will lead three customer-facing divisions, and three senior executives will leave the bank. Despite the changes, investors have been unimpressed, with NAB shares falling 1.12% in a weak market. The bank aims to focus on corporate and mid-market lending, shifting away from institutional lending.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares join others in Asia, follow Wall Street down
summary: Hong Kong shares declined 0.2% on Friday, following a 1.4% gain for the week, as Asian markets slid after weak corporate earnings halted Wall Street's record run. The Hang Seng index closed at 21,964.27 points, while the China Enterprises Index fell 0.3% to 9,031.93 points. The decline in Hong Kong shares mirrored a downturn in other Asian markets, with investors brushing off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: BMW plans electric car battery factory in Thailand: industry minister
summary: BMW plans to build a plug-in hybrid vehicle battery factory in Thailand, with construction expected to start in the middle of 2017 and an investment of 2 billion baht (S$77 million). The factory will aim to make hybrid vehicles more affordable for Thai consumers, with the Thai government offering tax incentives to support the project. This move is seen as a strategic expansion for BMW in the region, where Thailand is a major production and export hub for the automotive industry.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop as BOJ rejecting helicopter money supports yen
summary: Asian stocks declined, led by Japan's Topix index, after the Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda ruled out "helicopter money," a potential stimulus measure. The yen strengthened, while the yuan rose for a fourth day. Malaysia's ringgit fell to a month low, and the Australian and New Zealand dollars declined amid speculation of interest rate cuts. US shares retreated from a record, and futures on the S&P 500 declined 0.1%. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 0.6%, trimming this week's advance to 0.4%.

site_title: Singapore, Chongqing finance firms to sign 28 deals involving US$1.6b in transactions: MAS
summary: Singapore and Chongqing finance firms will sign 28 deals worth over US$1.6 billion, marking the start of a new collaboration between the two financial institutions. The agreements include bond issuances and cross-border loans, and are part of the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative, a government-led project between China and Singapore. The move aims to provide a channel for overseas investors to access investment opportunities in China, while also allowing Chongqing to tap into Singapore's financial markets and international investors.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Hong Kong student leader pleads not guilty
summary: A Hong Kong student leader, Billy Fung, pleaded not guilty to multiple charges related to a protest against a pro-Beijing figure at Hong Kong University in January. The charges come amid heightened tensions in the city over Beijing's tightening grip. Fung, former president of the university's student union, faces a raft of charges over the protest, which was part of the "Umbrella Revolution" movement. The court cases have fueled concerns about freedoms in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: A Hong Kong student protester pleaded not guilty Friday to multiple criminal charges over a demonstration against a pro-Beijing figure, a day after the conviction of an "Umbrella Revolution" leader was blasted by rights activists.

site_title: Oil prices edge up on weaker US dollar
summary: Oil prices rose 0.25% on Friday, driven by a weaker US dollar, following a 2% drop the previous day. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 11 cents to $44.86, while Brent rose 20 cents to $46.40. Despite a weaker dollar, analysts warn that global supply glut concerns will limit gains, following recent losses due to the Brexit vote and lower expectations for stimulus from the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan.

site_title: MasterCard may apply for China payment license this year
summary: MasterCard may apply for a payment license in China this year, following the country's opening of the market to foreign payment card companies. The company is weighing its options, considering whether to apply alone or with a partner, and is studying China's rules and business plan requirements. China's 55 trillion yuan card payment market, dominated by state-run China UnionPay, is seen as crucial to MasterCard's future, with the company hoping to enter the market as soon as possible. The application process is uncertain due to the complexity of China's rules and standards.

images.alt_text: MasterCard Inc hopes to apply this year to become a payment service provider in China after the government opened the market, but the company is still weighing whether to do so alone or with a partner, senior executives said on Friday.

site_title: Fire diverts North Korea Air Koryo flight: report
summary: A fire on a North Korean Air Koryo flight forced the plane to divert and land in Shenyang, China, on Friday. The flight from Pyongyang to Beijing was scheduled but caught fire, according to a passenger report to China's Xinhua news agency. The report did not provide further details on damage or passenger injuries. The plane was forced to land in Shenyang due to the fire, but the exact circumstances and cause of the fire are not specified.

site_title: 'We are better than this,' Clinton tweets at Trump
summary: Hillary Clinton fired a tweet at Donald Trump after his acceptance speech, stating "We are better than this." Trump had attacked Clinton's record, calling it marked by "death, destruction, terrorism and weakness." This came after Trump accepted the Republican nomination for president. Clinton's tweet was a response to Trump's comments, emphasizing a contrast between the two candidates' values.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower, Nintendo up on Pokemon launch
summary: Tokyo shares fell 1.09% on Friday, weighed down by a rebounding yen, but Nintendo rose 4.4% as the popular Pokémon Go app launched in Japan. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 16,627.25, while the Topix index dropped 0.89%. The yen's rise hit exporters, but Nintendo's success in its home market lifted the gaming company's shares.

site_title: DBS consumer banking head appointed to NETS board (Amended)
summary: NETS has appointed Jeremy Soo Hsiao Chin, DBS's managing director and head of consumer banking group, Singapore, to its board. Soo has 30 years of consumer banking experience, succeeding Rachel Yap as a DBS representative to the NETS Board. His appointment takes immediate effect, and he oversees key consumer-related products and services in Singapore. NETS previously incorrectly stated Soo's experience as 20 years.

site_title: Ex-remisier charged under Securities and Futures Act for fraud
summary: A former remisier, Dennis Tey Thean Yan, 32, has been charged with 18 counts of fraud under the Securities and Futures Act in Singapore. He allegedly manipulated market prices in 18 stocks between October 2012 and January 2013 to buy or sell contracts for differences at artificially raised or lowered prices. Tey also faces charges of deceiving four firms by using fake accounts to buy and sell shares without authorization. The maximum punishment for each charge is a fine of S$250,000 or a jail term of seven years.

site_title: Hot stock: CNMC Goldmine shares down 9.8% in early trading
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings shares plummeted 9.8% to S$0.415 in early trading, with over 40 million shares changing hands. The Malaysia-based gold mining firm was notified to temporarily halt operations at the Sokor gold field by the Kelantan State Lands and Mines Office. The stock was among the most actively traded on the Singapore Exchange on Friday morning.

site_title: Australia dollar set for worst week in 2-1/2 months; NZ dollar ailing
summary: The Australian dollar is poised for its largest weekly fall in 2-1/2 months, down 1.4% for the week, amid expectations of a potential rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The US dollar, however, rose due to upbeat economic data. The New Zealand dollar also fell, reaching a six-week low, as markets anticipate a rate cut by the central bank. Markets are pricing in a 60% probability of a 25 basis point rate cut in Australia and expect no lasting effect from potential policy easing in Japan.

site_title: China sovereign wealth fund CIC profit drops 17%
summary: China's sovereign wealth fund CIC reported a 17% decline in net profit to $73.9 billion in 2015, its lowest since 2011, due to negative returns on overseas investments and huge foreign exchange losses. The fund's return on overseas investments declined to a negative 2.96% and reported a record foreign exchange loss of $3.77 billion. CIC's chairman and CEO Ding Xuedong attributed the decline to a challenging year for the fund, citing a sluggish global economic recovery and fierce competition in the investment industry.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends slightly firmer, stocks soften
summary: The South Korean won ended slightly firmer at 1,134.4 to the dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed down 0.1% at 2,010.34 points. Foreign investors purchased a net 15.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares for the 12th consecutive day. The market took a cautious stance ahead of US and Japan central bank meetings, with stocks softening 0.2% on a weekly basis.

site_title: Australia shares pause near recent peak, NZ reaches fresh record
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index paused near a one-year high, easing 0.3% to 5,495.2, despite gains in the natural resources sector. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index reached an all-time high, up nearly 5% in July. The rallies were driven by a 1.8% rise in iron ore prices and a jump in metal prices, while energy stocks fell due to recent oil price drops.

site_title: Quick takes on private residential, HDB Q2 statistics
summary: Singapore's private residential market showed moderation in Q2, with a 0.4% decline in prices, compared to a 0.7% drop in the previous quarter. HDB resale prices remained unchanged, while transactions increased 31.2% to 5,838 cases.

site_title: China: Stocks slide as central bank official casts doubt on monetary stimulus
summary: China's stocks declined on Friday after a central bank official, Sheng Songcheng, expressed doubts on further interest rate cuts, citing a "liquidity trap" that would have little effect on real investment. Instead, tax cuts would be a more effective way to stimulate the economy, according to Songcheng. This cast a negative light on the market, leading investors to take profits and causing stocks to slide.

site_title: Five charged over France truck attack
summary: Five suspects, including a 22-year-old Franco-Tunisian and a 37-year-old Tunisian, have been formally charged over the truck attack in Nice, France that killed 84 people. The suspects, who are accused of being accomplices to murder by a terror group, were brought before anti-terrorism judges and charged with various crimes, including breaking the law on firearms. The investigation, which has involved over 400 investigators, has found no direct proof of the suspects' allegiance to the Islamic State group, but has revealed a plot that dates back to 2015, with the suspect having taken photos of the Bastille Day fireworks display and crowds in previous years.

site_title: Japan rail firm says only 7 years needed for Singapore-KL High Speed Rail commercial operations
summary: Japan's East Japan Railway Company (JR East) claims it can start commercial operations for the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Rail (HSR) in 7 years if it wins the project. Engineering studies for the Singapore side may take up to 24 months, with construction potentially starting in 2018. Japan's Minister for Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, Keiichi Ishii, expressed high interest in the project, stating the possibility of Japan winning the bid is "very high". Commercial operations are expected to begin in the seventh year.

site_title: Singapore June headline CPI seen falling for 20th month: poll
summary: Singapore's headline annual consumer price index in June is expected to have declined for the 20th consecutive month, with a median forecast of a 1.1% drop from a year earlier. The decline is attributed to easing housing and private transportation costs. Core CPI is expected to rise 1% from a year earlier, steady from May's pace. The streak of consecutive year-on-year declines in headline CPI is the longest since Singapore's independence in 1965.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 2.63 points to 1,656.13. The market saw 109 losers and 41 gainers, with a trading volume of 25.89 million lots worth RM10.79 million.

site_title: White House calls for Malaysian transparency in wake of fund scandal
summary: The White House has urged Malaysia to demonstrate good governance and transparency, following US prosecutors' lawsuit to seize $1 billion in assets allegedly bought with stolen funds from a state development fund. The lawsuits, which may affect relations between the two countries, were not unexpected, according to a US congressional aide. The move comes as US President Barack Obama has visited Malaysia twice during his administration, highlighting the potential for strained ties.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak. The White House urged Malaysia on Thursday to demonstrate good governance and a transparent business climate, a day after US prosecutors sued to try and seize US$1 billion in assets they said were bought with money stolen from a state development fund.

site_title: Phillip Capital appoints BNP Paribas Securities to service its Singapore funds
summary: Phillip Capital Group has appointed BNP Paribas Securities Services to service its Singapore-based funds, aiming to enhance operational efficiency and fulfill regulatory requirements. The partnership will enable a standardized and scalable approach to custody services, allowing Phillip Capital to focus on its core business. The move follows the migration of its largest SGD money market fund to BNP Securities Services Singapore, with plans to expand to Hong Kong through a joint venture with Phillip Capital Management (HK) Ltd.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: HDB resale prices flat in Q2
summary: HDB resale prices remained unchanged in the second quarter, with 5,838 resale transactions recorded, a 31.2% increase from the first quarter. The number of approved subletting cases rose 5.2% to 11,824, with 52,171 flats sublet as of June 30. In the first half, 13,110 flats were offered, including 7,940 BTO flats and 5,170 balance flats.

site_title: Gold heads for 2nd weekly drop as investors weigh stimulus cues
summary: Gold prices fell for a second consecutive week, declining 0.5% this week as investors shifted focus to riskier assets amid rising equity markets. The European Central Bank and Bank of Japan signaled limited stimulus measures, while the Federal Reserve's next policy-setting meeting on July 26-27 is expected to be cautious. The stronger US dollar and rising equity markets are curbing demand for gold, with some analysts viewing it as a "buy the dip" opportunity for long-term investors.

site_title: Samsung strikes back at Huawei with Chinese mobile patents suit
summary: Samsung Electronics Co has filed a lawsuit in China against Huawei Technologies Co, accusing the company of infringing on its mobile technology patents. The lawsuit, filed with an intellectual property court in Beijing, claims a total of 161 million yuan (S$32.7 million) in damages. Samsung alleges Huawei employed its patents in its Mate 8, Honor, and other smartphones and tablets, covering wireless communications, digital cameras, and other technologies. This move signals growing confidence among Chinese technology companies in asserting their intellectual property rights, following Huawei's recent lawsuit against Samsung in the US and China.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co has filed a lawsuit in China against Huawei Technologies Co, accusing the country's largest smartphone maker of infringing on its mobile technology patents.

site_title: DPM Tharman to attend G-20 meeting in Chengdu
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will attend the G-20 finance ministers' and central bank governors' meeting in Chengdu, China on July 23-24, focusing on policies to enhance economic resilience amid global uncertainties. Tharman will also speak at the G-20 high-level tax symposium, discussing tax policies to support innovation-driven growth and tax certainty in the digital economy. He will be accompanied by officials from the Ministry of Finance and Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Philippines suspends new Uber, Grab vehicle registrations as backlog mounts
summary: The Philippines has suspended new Uber and Grab vehicle registrations due to a backlog amid a government review of its policies on fare spikes. The country was the first to regulate app-based car-hailing operations after introducing rules last year. The suspension affects new applications, not existing vehicles, according to Cherie Mercado, a spokesperson for the transportation department.

site_title: Grab partners Lippo Group to implement mobile payments platform
summary: Grab, a ride-sharing app, is partnering with Indonesian conglomerate Lippo to implement a mobile payments platform in Indonesia. The platform will be integrated with Grab's app and can be used to pay for Grab rides and services at Lippo's retail companies, including department stores and cinemas. The move aims to tap into the unbanked population in South-east Asia, with Grab's CEO Anthony Tan stating that the potential for mobile payments is "limitless". The partnership will provide a mobile wallet option for users across Lippo's retail companies.

site_title: Trump accepts Republican nomination for US president
summary: Donald Trump formally accepted the Republican Party nomination for US president at the convention in Cleveland, vowing to defeat Hillary Clinton and restore safety in the nation. Trump, a billionaire and reality TV star, defied political norms to win the primary and has never held elected office. He promised to end crime and violence and restore safety starting January 20th, 2017.

site_title: Yen off 6-week low after "helicopter money" mania shot down
summary: The yen hovered above a six-week low after Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's comments on helicopter money. The yen rebounded to 105.88 yen per dollar from 107.49, triggered by Kuroda's downplaying of the idea of injecting cash directly into the economy. This move was seen as a signal that Japan may not be preparing a radical economic stimulus. Kuroda's comments have dampened speculation about a potential "helicopter money" policy, which could have negatively impacted the yen's value.

images.alt_text: The yen hovered above six-week lows on Friday after comments from Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda dented speculation Japan may be preparing a radical "helicopter money" economic stimulus.

site_title: Divide and rule by Beijing throws Asean into disarray
summary: Beijing's aggressive stance on the South China Sea has caused unprecedented divisions within the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), with China's allies Laos and Cambodia playing a key role in driving a wedge between member states. A UN-backed tribunal found no legal basis for China's claims to most of the sea, but Beijing has rejected the ruling, instead using soft loans and diplomatic pressure to split the bloc. The upcoming Asean summit in Vientiane, hosted by Laos, is expected to deepen the divisions, with analysts warning that the bloc's inability to remain united will weaken its overall influence.

site_title: Ringgit heads for worst week since September on oil, 1MDB woes
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is set for its worst week since September due to lower crude oil prices and the fallout from the 1MDB controversy. The currency fell 2.8% this week, to 4.0608 per dollar, and 0.5% on Friday. The US Justice Department seized $1 billion laundered through America's banking system, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore seized $240 million in assets linked to alleged fraud. The decline in oil prices and the 1MDB woes have sapped demand for the nation's assets, with bonds surging.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, following a first loss for the Dow on Wall Street in six sessions. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.40% to 21,913.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.89 points to 3,038.12. Investors cashed in profits following a recent rally.

site_title: Singapore construction industry calls for more equitable allocation of risks
summary: Singapore's construction industry is calling for a review of the Public Sector Standard Conditions of Contract and the Security of Payment Act to more equitably allocate risks to contractors and simplify payment dispute resolution. Industry leaders, including Jimmy Koh and Scal president Kenneth Loo, have established working groups to propose amendments to these laws, citing issues such as unrealistic contract periods, tight resources, and shifting blame responsibilities. The aim is to reduce disputes and improve the overall efficiency of the construction industry.

images.alt_text: Singapore's construction industry has called for the review of the Public Sector Standard Conditions of Contract (PSSCOC) and the Security of Payment (SOP) Act for more equitable allocation of risks to contractors and easier settlement of payment disputes.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall in line with overseas markets; display makers down
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.4% on Friday, tracking losses in overseas markets, after hitting a one-year high in the previous session. Display makers Innolux and AU Optronics Corp were among the biggest losers, with drops of 0.8% and 2.4%, respectively. The decline was partly due to weaker demand for displays, as shown in Taiwan's export orders from China in June. The Taiwan dollar also softened against the US dollar, closing at NT$32.079 per dollar.

site_title: Pokemon GO launches in Japan, bringing smash-hit mobile game home
summary: Nintendo's Pokémon GO mobile game has launched in Japan, joining the US, Canada, Australia, and over 30 European countries. The game, developed by Nintendo, Niantic, and Pokémon Co., allows players to interact with virtual characters in the real world. Nintendo shares rose over 4% in Tokyo trading, while Japan's McDonald's Holdings Co. shares surged 7% due to its partnership with the game. The launch marks a significant milestone for the augmented-reality game, which has been a global hit since its release in 2016.

site_title: Hammond seeks UK business in China following Brexit vote
summary: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond is visiting China to promote business opportunities in the wake of Britain's vote to leave the European Union. During his trip, Hammond will emphasize the financial-services sector and assure Chinese leaders that China-UK relations will not change following Brexit. He will meet with Chinese political leaders and businesses, including firms like HSBC Holdings and Clifford Chance, to discuss potential partnerships and collaborations. The visit aims to strengthen UK-China ties and attract British businesses to China.

site_title: Golfing buddies Obama and Najib in a tight spot over 1MDB
summary: US President Barack Obama's administration is facing a complicated situation with Malaysia as it pursues a $1 billion money laundering case linked to alleged misappropriation from 1MDB, a Malaysian state fund. The US Justice Department's Kleptocracy Asset Recovery Initiative has filed civil filings alleging a broader $3.5 billion misappropriation. The move puts the Obama administration in a difficult position, with Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak potentially distancing himself from the US and accusing the US of conspiracy. The case risks overshadowing ties between the two countries, which have evolved over meetings in the US and Malaysia.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on weak Wall Street, rising yen
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on July 22, 2016, after Wall Street fell due to weak corporate earnings. The Nikkei-225 index dropped 0.94% to 16,651.60, while the Topix index fell 1.03% to 1,325.65. A rising yen also weighed on the Japanese bourse.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won calm as investors await US, Japan global events
summary: South Korean shares and the won remained mostly unchanged in early trade on Friday, awaiting US and Japanese central bank policy decisions next week. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) was little changed, while the won rose 0.1% to 1,134.9. Investors are expected to hold positions ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee and Bank of Japan meetings, potentially limiting further declines. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and LG Chem Ltd fell due to foreign stock-dumping.

site_title: Japan to miss FY 2018 deficit-cutting target on tax hike delay: NHK
summary: Japan is likely to miss its deficit-cutting target in fiscal 2018 due to the delay of a sales tax hike, according to a public broadcaster. The Cabinet Office now forecasts a 1.9% primary budget deficit in fiscal 2018, up from the initial 1.7% target. The delay in the sales tax increase, now set for October 2019, is expected to hinder the government's efforts to reduce the primary budget deficit. The government aims to achieve a primary budget surplus by fiscal 2020 through boosting economic growth.

site_title: FLASH: HDB Resale Price Index flat in Q2 from quarter ago
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) reported that resale prices for HDB flats remained flat in Q2 compared to the previous quarter, according to the latest index. This indicates no significant change in the resale market.

site_title: US moves to block massive health insurer deals
summary: US anti-trust officials have filed lawsuits to block two massive health insurer deals. Anthem Inc's proposed purchase of Cigna Corp and Aetna Inc's planned acquisition of Humana Inc. would reduce competition, raise prices, and stifle innovation in the national health insurance market. The deals, worth $45 billion and $33 billion, would create the largest US health insurer by membership and merge the largest US manager of Medicare Advantage businesses. The Justice Department claims the mergers would harm millions of Americans, doctors, and hospitals, and the Obama administration is taking action to protect consumers.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wall Street's tumble
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened down 0.3% at 2,931.57 after US stocks tumbled overnight, pulled down by disappointing earnings reports from Intel and American Express. The market had previously notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Trading saw 49.3 million shares change hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 71 to 37.

site_title: Singapore commercial space prices, rentals fall further in Q2
summary: Singapore's commercial space prices and rentals declined in Q2, with office space prices down 1.5% and rentals down 3.5% compared to the previous quarter. Retail space prices decreased 3.1% and rentals fell 3.9%. The office vacancy rate dropped to 9.1%, while retail space vacancy rose to 7.8%. A total of 1.022 million square meters of office space and 734,000 square meters of retail space were in the pipeline by the end of Q2.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cambridge Industrial Trust, CMT, DBS, Ezra
summary: Stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Cambridge Industrial Trust reported a 10.9% drop in second-quarter distributable amount, while CapitaLand Mall Trust saw a 3.3% rise in distributable income to S$97.1 million. Meanwhile, stocks like CMT, DBS, and Ezra are also being watched, but specific updates are not mentioned in this article.

site_title: New UK finance minister to talk up trade on China visit
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond will visit China to promote British business opportunities and reassure Chinese investors that "Britain is open for business" despite the Brexit vote. Hammond will meet with Chinese business leaders, officials, and finance ministers from the Group of 20 in Chengdu, aiming to build on the "golden era" of UK-China ties. The visit aims to showcase new opportunities presented by the UK's decision to leave the EU and kick-start a series of visits to key economic partners.

site_title: CMT posts 3.3% rise in Q2 distributable income to S$97.1m
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 3.3% rise in Q2 distributable income to S$97.1 million, driven by higher revenue of 7.1% year-over-year. Revenue growth was largely attributed to Bedok Mall and asset enhancement initiatives at other properties. Distribution per unit was 2.74 Singapore cents.

site_title: Ailes quits as Fox News boss amid sex harassment suit
summary: Roger Ailes, the former CEO of Fox News, resigned amid a sexual harassment lawsuit, effective immediately. He was replaced by Rupert Murdoch, who will take over as chairman and acting CEO of Fox News Channel and Fox Business Network. The resignation follows a statement from the company, which did not specify details of the allegations. Ailes' departure marks the end of an era for Fox News, a network he built into a popular and influential cable news channel.

site_title: Santos Q2 sales volume jumps, helping to offset oil price drop
summary: Santos Ltd reported a 25% increase in oil and gas sales volumes in the June quarter, reaching 19.6 million barrels of oil equivalent, due to the successful start-up of its US$18.5 billion Gladstone LNG plant. Revenue fell 3% to US$590 million, hurt by a 24% slump in average realised oil prices. Despite a 24% reduction in production costs, the company still expects to produce between 57 and 63 million barrels of oil and gas this year.

images.alt_text: Australia's Santos Ltd reported a 25 per cent rise in oil and gas sales volumes in the June quarter on Friday, largely reflecting the smooth start-up of the second unit at its US$18.5 billion Gladstone LNG (liquefied natural gas) plant.

site_title: FLASH: Prices of private homes down 0.4% in Q2, rentals fell 0.6%, says URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) announced that private home prices in Q2 declined by 0.4%, while rental prices fell 0.6%. This moderation in price decline marks a slight improvement from the previous quarter. The URA attributed the decrease to a decrease in sales volume and a rise in new supply.

site_title: Asia: Shares dips as weak results halt bull run on Wall Street, yen holds gains
summary: Asian stocks declined early Friday as weak corporate results halted Wall Street's record run, while the yen maintained its gains from the Bank of Japan's governor's comments on monetary policies. The US dollar remained steady against the yen, and the euro was unchanged. The Dow Jones Industrial Average snapped a nine-day winning streak due to disappointing results from Intel and key transportation companies. Crude oil fell 0.2% and gold edged up 0.1% as the US dollar retreated.

site_title: Private-home price decline in Q2 moderates to 0.4%: URA
summary: Singapore's private-home price decline in Q2 eased to 0.4% from 0.7% in Q1, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). Landed properties fell 1.5%, while non-landed properties declined 0.1%. Despite a quarter-on-quarter rise in prime and city-fringe areas, Outside Central Region non-landed properties continued to slide. Developers launched 2,371 uncompleted units and sold 2,256 private homes, with 47,250 units in the pipeline, excluding executive condominiums.

images.alt_text: The pace of decline in prices of private homes has eased in the second quarter, where the fall was a smaller 0.4 per cent compared to the 0.7 per cent a quarter ago.

site_title: China Fibretech remains suspended, to engage lawyers to handle damage claims
summary: China Fibretech, whose shares remain suspended since Nov 30, 2015, will engage a law firm to handle 466 million yuan (S$94.6 million) damage claims made by customers. The company attributed discrepancies between its 64.3 million yuan revenue and claims to "processing fees only," with the alleged claims amount based on costs of end-products. This comes after Singapore Exchange (SGX) queries highlighted the discrepancies between revenue and claims.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US: Stocks fall, ending Dow winning streak
summary: US stocks fell, ending the Dow's six-day winning streak, as Intel and American Express reported disappointing earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4% to 18,517.23, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declined. The market's recent surge was attributed to low interest rates and central banks' commitments, but the decline was attributed to earnings reports and concerns about future results.

site_title: Nations of the world confront the Pokemon menace
summary: Security authorities worldwide have raised concerns over the popular Pokémon Go game, citing its potential as a tool for espionage and national security threats. The game has been banned or restricted in several countries, including Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bosnia, and Kuwait, due to concerns over players trespassing on private property, visiting sensitive sites, and sharing photos of security locations. Some officials have also denounced the game as "Satanic" or a CIA plot, while others have expressed alarm over the game's ability to reveal sensitive information.

site_title: PayPal seeks to extend reach with Visa tie-up
summary: PayPal has partnered with Visa to expand its reach, making it easier for customers to use Visa credit and debit cards in PayPal transactions and allowing shoppers to use PayPal in brick-and-mortar retail locations. The partnership is expected to boost revenue and user growth, with PayPal's revenue up 15% and payment volume up 28% in the second quarter. The deal also allows for instant cash withdrawals using a Visa debit card and integrates PayPal into Visa's tap-and-pay feature. The partnership is seen as a significant move for PayPal, with analysts predicting "meaningful upside" for the company.

site_title: Boeing hit by US$2.1b in tanker, production costs
summary: Boeing expects second-quarter earnings to be impacted by $2.1 billion in after-tax costs due to issues with the KC-46 tanker program, including a $393 million charge to address a load issue. The company also booked $847 million in costs for writing off two 787s and $814 million for a lower 747-8 production schedule. The announcement sent Boeing shares down 1.2% in after-hours trade. Despite the charges, Boeing's CEO remains confident in the long-term value of the KC-46 program.

site_title: Pina Bausch returns to S'pore after 40 years (Amended)
summary: Pina Bausch, a renowned German dance company, returns to Singapore after a 40-year absence, with its annual da:ns festival in October. The company will perform its classic 1982 piece "Nelken" (Carnations), cementing its reputation as a leading figure in contemporary dance. The Esplanade's Faith Tan expressed delight at finally bringing the company to Singapore, despite the late notice due to scheduling clashes. This marks a significant milestone for dance lovers in Singapore, with Pina Bausch's return set to thrill audiences.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Thousands march across Istanbul bridge in anti-coup protest
summary: Thousands of Turkish government supporters marched across the Bosphorus Bridge in Istanbul to protest against the failed coup attempt against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The bridge was filled with protesters carrying nationalist signs and slogans, in response to Erdogan's call to continue demonstrating against the coup. The event came a week after the failed coup attempt, which Erdogan blames on US-based cleric Fethullah Gulen. The protest aimed to show support for Erdogan's government and prevent a repeat of the attempted coup.

site_title: Oversupply pushes oil prices downward
summary: Oil prices dropped on Thursday, with West Texas Intermediate benchmark crude falling to $44.75 a barrel and North Sea Brent falling to $46.20 a barrel. The market remains under pressure due to a global oversupply and weak demand, with refiners' margins coming under pressure. The US Energy Information Administration reported a build in gasoline inventories and nearly unchanged distillates, further reducing demand for crude oil. Crude prices have fluctuated between $44 and $52 per barrel in the past month, following a supply glut and weak demand.

site_title: France's EDF to decide on UK nuclear project next week
summary: France's EDF will decide on the UK nuclear project, Hinkley Point, next week, whether to give the final green light to the construction of two nuclear reactors. The £18 billion project has faced criticism due to its high cost, with unions at EDF seeking to delay the decision due to concerns it could bankrupt the company. The project would strengthen EDF's presence in Britain and benefit the nuclear industry, but Brexit has made the project "more difficult."

site_title: Brazil arrests 'amateur' Olympics terrorism group
summary: Brazilian police arrested 10 members of an "amateur" would-be terrorist group expressing loyalty to the Islamic State ahead of the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. The group, calling itself "Defenders of Sharia," was disorganized and had no specific target, with most members not knowing each other. They communicated via messaging services WhatsApp and Telegram, and had attempted to contact a black market weapons supplier. Officials described the group as "an absolutely amateur cell" and downplayed links to the Islamic State, saying the security situation remains unchanged with a minimal probability of a terrorist act during the Games.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat as weaker airlines offset firmer banks
summary: European stocks fell 0.1% on Thursday, as airline stocks dropped amid fears of travel disruptions following recent attacks, while bank stocks rose after the European Central Bank signaled support for the sector with a potential state-funded backstop to address high levels of bad loans. Despite this, the pan-European STOXX 600 index remains down 7% since the start of 2016, amid ongoing market uncertainty following the Brexit vote.

site_title: Painting a historical picture
summary: A photography exhibition, "Snapshots of Heritage," at Capitol Piazza in Singapore features 100 photographs showcasing the country's cultural heritage. The exhibition, which runs until August 11, was organized to promote unity and understanding of Singapore's history through images. The competition received 812 entries, with three winning entries and 15 consolation prizes. The winning photographs were chosen for their technical skill, composition, and ability to capture the essence of Singapore's heritage. The exhibition aims to educate and engage the younger generation with the older ones, and to form a collective perspective of Singapore's heritage.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SMRT accepted the offer to buy its shares for S$1.645, with a target price of S$1.68. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for the second half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Michelin awards 37 stars to 29 Singapore eateries
summary: The Michelin Guide has awarded 37 stars to 29 Singapore eateries, including Hill Street Tai Hwa Pork Noodle, Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken Rice & Noodle, and Candlenut Kitchen, which received one star each. Joel Robuchon's eponymous restaurant took home the only three-star award, while L'Atelier de Joel Robuchon and established names Les Amis, Odette, and Restaurant Andre received two stars. This marks a milestone for Singapore, welcoming its first hawkers and Peranakan restaurant to the guide.

site_title: Japan property firms get 50-year long-term loans
summary: Japanese banks are offering 50-year long-term loans to real estate firms, seeking collateral to mitigate risk as negative interest rates weigh on their bottom line. Total loans to real estate companies reached a record 11.2 trillion yen in the year ended March 31, prompting warnings of a potential property market overheating. Analysts say the trend may lead to increased bad debt and regulatory scrutiny, while the country's aging population and shrinking population pose long-term risks to the real estate market.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust posts lower Q2 distributable income and DPU
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) reported a 10.9% year-on-year decline in Q2 distributable income to S$14.07 million, and a 12% drop in DPU to 1.078 Singapore cents. Revenue rose 1.7% to S$28.3 million, while net property income slid 2% to S$21.17 million. The company expects difficult market conditions and expiring master leases to impact results for the next two quarters, but sees the challenge as an opportunity to recalibrate its business and execute its strategy to recycle capital and reduce gearing.

site_title: Setting its sights further
summary: Eagle Eye Centre, a Singapore-based eye clinic, is poised for further expansion, driven by its organic growth and strategic expansion plans. Founded by co-founders Dr. Julian Theng and Dr. Lim Wee Kiak, the clinic has grown from a four-strong staff to 60-strong, with six clinics island-wide. The group is looking to expand beyond Singapore, with plans to acquire new technology and machines, and is also exploring opportunities in consumer eye health products and overseas partnerships. However, the co-founders are cautious, citing the need for good doctors and avoiding brand dilution if expansion is not done properly, and are not planning to pursue an initial public offering (IPO) at this stage.

site_title: French truck attack was planned for months, with accomplices
summary: A French truck attack that killed 84 people was planned for months with the assistance of five suspects, according to prosecutor Francois Molins. Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, the attacker, had long plotted the attack, with photos on his phone showing he had likely staked out the Bastille Day fireworks display in 2015. The five suspects, including a Tunisian named Mohamed Oualid G, will be presented to anti-terrorism judges and face charges of conspiracy to commit terrorism. Investigations have revealed Bouhlel's fascination with jihad and his violent behavior, with some describing him as "someone who did not practise the Muslim religion."

images.alt_text: The name Mohamed Lahoualej Bouhlel is seen on a plate outside the building where he lived in Nice, France, on July 17, 2016. Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel had long plotted the carnage that killed 84 people, with the assistance of five suspects who are in custody, prosecutor Francois Molins said Thursday.

site_title: Dear 'Bro': US says zelig of the good life pulled 1MDB strings
summary: The US Justice Department has released civil filings detailing how billions of dollars meant for Malaysia's 1MDB fund were allegedly diverted by financier Low Taek Jho. The funds were channeled through bank accounts, purchased luxury items, and invested in a Hollywood movie. Low Taek Jho, known to his Goldman Sachs banker as "Bro", used his connections to bypass bank watchdogs. The filings mark the first time the US has publicly disclosed the alleged manipulation of 1MDB funds.

site_title: Yen recovers after Kuroda plays down helicopter money talk
summary: The Japanese yen surged to a six-week high against the dollar after Bank of Japan chief Haruhiko Kuroda played down the idea of injecting "helicopter money" into the economy. The comments, made in an interview conducted in mid-June, helped cool the yen's gains, but the currency still rose 0.5% to 106.32 yen per dollar. The dollar, meanwhile, touched a six-week high above 107 yen amid expectations of US interest rate hikes and a broad recovery in risk appetite.

site_title: SMRT shares close 6.5% up after Temasek buyout offer (Amended)
summary: SMRT Corp shares rose 6.5% to close at S$1.645 following Temasek Holdings' proposed S$1.2 billion buyout offer. The offer was deemed reasonable by analysts, leading to increased trading volume of 31.57 million shares. The stock opened at S$1.66 and hit a high of S$1.67 before closing above its previous price.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q2 DPU flat at 2.5 cents
summary: Suntec Reit reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.501 Singapore cents for Q2, driven by a 0.7% increase in distributable income from the sale of Park Mall. Gross revenue declined 3.1% and net property income fell 7.5% due to the divestment. Despite office headwinds, the Reit's overall committed occupancy remained stable at 98.9% for offices and 97.7% for retail spaces. The company expects stable office performance in 2016.

site_title: Uber investors pushing for Didi truce in costly China fight: sources
summary: Uber investors are pushing the company to form a partnership with Didi Chuxing in China, amid a costly fight for dominance in the region. The companies have spent billions of dollars expanding in China, with Uber investing at least $1 billion annually. Investors, including Benchmark's Bill Gurley, have discussed potential deal terms with Didi executives, but a truce requires company-wide approval. A deal could help both companies cut losses, but differences in revenue sharing and ownership structure remain major hurdles.

site_title: Sculpting beauty, creating happiness
summary: Dr. Steven Ang, an aesthetics doctor, believes that the pursuit of beauty is not about perfection or vanity, but about creating happiness and self-esteem. He started his own practice in 1998, leaving a high-paying job to focus on evidence-based treatments and cutting-edge technologies. With two clinics and a compounded annual growth rate of 10%, Dr. Ang aims to provide patients with their total beauty needs and stay competitive in the industry. He prioritizes long-term relationships, trust, and honest assessments, and is investing in new services and technologies, including therapist treatments and integrative medicine.

site_title: Nippon Life buys France, Belgium debt amid negative Japan yields
summary: Japan's largest life-insurer, Nippon Life, is buying French and Belgian debt to seek better yields amid negative Japan yields. The company prefers US corporate and mortgage bonds over Treasuries due to rising dollar-yen hedging costs. Hedging costs against the euro are near zero, making roll-down and returns attractive for some tenors. Nippon Life is also increasing its holdings of foreign bonds with currency hedges, with a focus on European debt.

site_title: Address climate change before we get hot under the collar
summary: Global temperatures are on track to set a new high for the third consecutive year, with June being the hottest June worldwide since 1880. The Paris talks in 2015 saw nearly 200 nations, including Singapore, pledge to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. As a small island state, Singapore is vulnerable to climate change's effects and has taken steps to address it, including reducing its carbon footprint. The UN Framework Convention on Climate Change emphasizes the need for collective action to preserve the planet.

site_title: Retail spending: big data is the name of the game
summary: Singapore's retail market is struggling with declining sales, but a new partnership between CapitaLand and American Express (Amex) aims to harness the power of big data. The partnership launched a multi-mall loyalty and credit card, allowing customers to earn loyalty points and receive cashback. Amex will collect data from merchants, providing CapitaLand with valuable insights to optimize sales and inventory management. The success of this partnership depends on Amex expanding its network of merchants, a challenge in a highly competitive market with multiple card issuers.

site_title: US dollar drops vs yen as BOJ's Kuroda plays down 'helicopter money'
summary: The US dollar dropped from a six-week high against the yen after Bank of Japan chief Haruhiko Kuroda played down the idea of "helicopter money" to stimulate the economy. The yen surged as much as 105.41 yen per US dollar before the US dollar regained ground. Analysts attributed the move to technical positioning and profit-taking, rather than a change in expectations for the BOJ's monetary policy. The US dollar has risen 5% against the yen in the last two weeks, and the euro was little changed against the US dollar after European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's comments.

images.alt_text: The US dollar fell from a six-week high against the yen on Thursday after Bank of Japan chief Haruhiko Kuroda said the bank saw no need to stimulate the economy with "helicopter money."

site_title: Mild foreplay, hilarious climax and a satisfying end
summary: A Singaporean play, "My Mother Buys Condoms," tackles ageism and sex in a unique way. The story revolves around Maggie, a 63-year-old retired literature teacher, and her relationship with a 40-year-old Malaysian air-conditioning repairman, Raju. The play, written by Helmi Yusof, features ordinary-looking characters and explores themes of loneliness, love, and self-discovery. With a mix of humor and heart, the play offers a refreshing take on traditional romantic stories. It has been well-received as a scintillatingly original work.

site_title: Is Opec changing tack after market share drive?
summary: OPEC is shifting its strategy, moving away from output cuts to focus on balancing the market and ensuring long-term price stability. Despite concerns over oversupply, the group sees the market reaching balance by next year. Saudi Arabia's energy minister claims the oversupply has ended, and OPEC is now concerned about falling upstream investment, which could lead to higher prices. The group is working to find a "golden mean" that neither stifles investment nor triggers another glut, with prices currently between $116 and $27.

site_title: Broadway Beng soars to Hokkien heaven
summary: Broadway Beng, performed by Sebastian Tan, celebrated his 10th anniversary with a concert that appealed to both men and women of all ages. The show featured Tan's sharp wit, puns, and getai glitz, with a mix of English, Hokkien, and East-West mashups. The concert included a medley of Mandopop hits and original songs, showcasing Tan's well-honed voice and musical range. The performance was well-received by the audience, including uncles and aunties, who appreciated the cultural richness of Hokkien music.

site_title: Doing more, going strong
summary: Family lawyer Anamah Tan is expanding her firm, Ann Tan & Associates, into the trust business to better serve her clients. Tan, 75, obtained a trust licence in 2014 and partnered with the First Names Group, an independent trust provider, to offer personalized trust services. The move allows Tan's firm to complement the services typically offered by banks, which she believes have declined in quality due to frequent relationship manager changes. Tan aims to capitalize on Singapore's potential as a hub for the Asia-Pacific trust industry, while continuing her pro bono work and advocating for a conciliatory approach in family law.

site_title: Twitter stirs debate as troll gets banned for racist abuse
summary: Twitter banned editor Milo Yiannopoulos for fueling racist abuse that drove Ghostbusters star Leslie Jones to quit the platform, sparking debate over free speech on social media. Jones quit after being subjected to hours of harassment from Yiannopoulos's supporters, while the platform stated that "no one deserves to be subjected to targeted abuse online." The ban sparked a hashtag war, with some praising Twitter for taking action and others arguing that it went too far, raising questions about how social media platforms regulate offensive conduct.

site_title: US FDA approves generic cholesterol-lowering pill
summary: The US FDA approved generic versions of the cholesterol-lowering pill Crestor, allowing multiple generics to reach pharmacy shelves. This move could decrease the price of the drug by 80-90% and result in a sharp loss of market share for AstraZeneca, the brand-name drug's manufacturer. The retail price of Crestor is around $260 a month, and the generic versions will likely significantly reduce the cost for consumers.

site_title: With the coup foiled in Turkey, what next?
summary: A failed coup in Turkey has raised concerns about the country's future, with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's government vowing harsh revenge. Erdogan's domestic policies have sown division, and his foreign policy decisions have led to international isolation. The government must address its domestic rifts, increase cooperation with allies to fight ISIS, and make peace with neighboring countries. Turkey's future is uncertain, with some fearing it may accelerate authoritarianism, while others hope for a change in course. The outcome will have significant implications for regional stability, with the Eurasian continent hanging in the balance.

site_title: Building the brand
summary: Charles Chin, group managing director of six organizations in Singapore, has built a business model that prioritizes direct customer engagement and collaboration. His companies, Indiba Asia and AiMediq Asia, operate as direct presence offices for Indiba and AiMediq, respectively, providing better pricing, flexible purchase options, and uninterrupted after-sales services. Chin's approach has led to rapid growth, with 90% of revenue coming from overseas, and he plans to expand into emerging countries such as India and Myanmar. His goal is to provide better value to customers and stakeholders, while leveraging his team's versatility and customer focus to deliver the best experience and value.

images.alt_text: 'I think our business model is quite unique. We do things differently, from how we run our operations to how we do our out-of-the-box sales and marketing.' - Charles Chin, MD of Indiba Asia

site_title: Keppel's Q2 profit falls 48.1% to S$205.8m
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 48.1% decline in net profit to S$205.8 million for the second quarter, citing a harsh winter in the oil & marine sector. Despite the challenging environment, the group's multi-business strategy supported its performance, with a resilient urbanisation trend in Asia offering a silver lining. CEO Loh Chin Hua noted that Keppel is well-positioned to seize growth opportunities in sustainable urbanisation, driven by a growing middle class and rural-urban migration.

site_title: Crawford noodle stall owner: 'A bit of pressure now to deliver'
summary: Tang Chay Seng, 69-year-old owner of Hill Street Tai Hwa Pork Noodle, expressed disappointment after learning his stall was not included in the Bib Gourmand list. He had been told by Michelin officials he was getting an award, but his name was not on the list. After attending the gala dinner and discovering he received a star, Tang remains practical, feeling "pretty normal" about the recognition but acknowledging pressure to deliver high-quality food to meet customers' subjective expectations.

site_title: An instalment that feels familiar - and interesting
summary: The third installment of the rebooted Star Trek franchise, Star Trek Beyond, remains true to its predecessors, delivering a familiar yet engaging experience. The film follows Captain James Kirk and the Enterprise crew as they face a sinister warlord, Krall, who intends to activate a deadly weapon. With the help of an alien ally, Jaylah, and a philosophical Spock, the crew must battle to save themselves and the galaxy. Despite a draggy climactic battle sequence, the film pays tribute to the original series and its late cast members, ensuring a satisfying conclusion to the trilogy.

site_title: Baidu releases indexes on Chinese economy
