summary: Cathay Pacific Airways, Asia's largest international airline, reported weak performance in the first half of 2016, with passenger revenue affected by reduced load factor and intense pressure on yield due to competition from Chinese operators and regional budget carriers. The airline's cargo tonnage stabilized, but yield continues to decline. Cathay Pacific's CEO Ivan Chu attributed the decline to the emergence of mainland Chinese airlines and the increased attractiveness of Hong Kong as a travel destination, prompting luxury operators to offer discounts.

site_title: Turnbull sworn in as Australia's PM
summary: Malcolm Turnbull was sworn in as Australia's prime minister after a narrow election victory, with his Liberal/National coalition holding 76 seats in the House of Representatives. Turnbull's top priorities include budget repair and a public vote on same-sex marriage. The coalition's loss of its comfortable majority raises questions over his ability to govern successfully. Standard & Poor's downgraded Australia's credit rating outlook to negative due to the tight result and potential for crossbench politicians to hinder budget repair efforts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: NOL, Keppel DC Reit, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Trek 2000 International
summary: A trading suspension has been called on Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) after its free float fell below 10%. French shipping line CMA CGM closed its offer for NOL at S$1.30 per share. Keppel DC Reit reported a 3.1% rise in distribution per unit for the second quarter, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust posted a second-quarter DPU of 0.93 cents. Trek 2000 International reported a net loss of US$6.72 million for FY2015 due to a sharp rise in cost of goods sold.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Asia: Markets slip but Tokyo extends gains on weak yen
summary: Tokyo's stock market extended its gains for a sixth-straight day, despite most other Asian markets turning negative, due to a weak yen boosting exporters. The rally was driven by hopes for fresh global central bank stimulus and positive economic data. A weak yen also offset the decline of mobile giant Softbank, which fell after agreeing a $32 billion deal.

site_title: South Korea central bank chief says small, open economies should maintain easy policy
summary: South Korea's central bank chief, Lee Ju Yeol, recommends maintaining accommodative monetary policies for small, open economies like South Korea to avoid low growth. He cautioned against excessive easing due to risks of capital outflows and currency depreciation. The Bank of Korea kept interest rates unchanged at 1.25% last week, with future policy moves dependent on data. Analysts expect the central bank to cut interest rates again to support the country's economy, which is undergoing a massive overhaul of its shipping and shipbuilding sectors.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index dipping 1.87 points or 0.06% to 2,926.89. Despite this, gainers outnumbered losers 72 to 51, with actively traded stocks including Singtel, Singapore Press Holdings, and DBS Bank.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Netflix customer growth slows amid price hike, shares plunge
summary: Netflix reported slower-than-expected customer growth, adding 1.7 million subscribers in the second quarter, below its 2.5 million projection. The company attributed the slowdown to price hikes and increased cancellations. Shares dropped 16% after hours, with analysts citing concerns over domestic subscriber growth and international losses. Despite beating earnings forecasts, Netflix forecast slower growth in US and international markets for the current quarter.

site_title: Brexit bargains scented by Asia's rich following pound's plunge
summary: Wealthy investors in Asia, including those in Singapore and Zurich, are taking advantage of the post-Brexit pound's decline to make investments in UK assets. Hedge fund manager Stephen Diggle plans to increase his firm's investments in UK biotechnology companies, while UBS and Stamford Management are advising clients to buy real estate at distressed prices. The pound has fallen 11% since the Brexit vote, with analysts predicting it will reach a low of $1.27 before recovering to $1.34 in 2017, creating opportunities for investors to buy assets at discounted prices.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares flat as long rally runs out of puff
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares were flat on Tuesday, marking a breather after long recovery rallies following the Brexit vote. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.07% to 5,454.6, while the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.4%. Investors sold financial stocks, but offset losses with gains in defensive sectors like healthcare and retail. The long rallies in both indexes, with gains of 6.8% and 6.7% respectively, have run out of steam, with market analysts expecting a pullback.

site_title: Nintendo shares up more than 10% in early trade
summary: Nintendo's shares rose 10% in early trade on Tuesday, driven by the popularity of its Pokémon GO mobile game. The stock was last up 6.8% at 29,650 yen, following a 9.8% gain on Friday, which saw a record trading volume. This surge comes after Tokyo markets were closed on Monday for a public holiday. The company's shares have been buoyed by the success of Pokémon GO, which has attracted millions of players worldwide.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler faces probes on US car sales
summary: US authorities are investigating Fiat Chrysler's reporting of US car sales, alleging potential violations of US securities laws. The Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department are examining whether the company rewarded dealerships for falsely reporting higher car sales, inflating results. Fiat Chrysler denies the allegations, calling them the product of "two disgruntled dealers." The company has pledged to cooperate fully with the probes.

site_title: Keppel Data Centres partners Certis Cisco unit for cyber-security solutions
summary: Keppel Data Centres Holding has partnered with Quann, a unit of Certis Cisco, to offer cyber-security solutions to its customers. The partnership will provide consultancy, network protection, and monitoring services, including a pay-as-you-use utility model. The move aims to expand Keppel Data Centres' value-added services and allow Quann to reach a broader customer base. The partnership starts in August and covers Singapore and regions where both companies operate, amid growing concerns over rapidly evolving cyber threats.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: World Bank confirms NYU's Romer as next chief economist
summary: The World Bank has confirmed New York University economics professor Paul Romer as its next chief economist, replacing Kaushik Basu, who is retiring. Romer, 60, will focus on investment in human capital and innovation, and is a proponent of "endogenous growth theory," which emphasizes the importance of knowledge-based economies and investments in education and research. Romer's appointment comes amid concerns over a slowdown in global growth and trade, and he will take up the position in September.

images.alt_text: The World Bank on Monday confirmed New York University economics professor Paul Romer as its next chief economist, bringing in a prominent voice advocating for investment in human capital and innovation.

site_title: Judge throws out parts of Bill Cosby's lawsuit over 2006 settlement
summary: A federal judge has thrown out parts of Bill Cosby's lawsuit against Andrea Constand, her mother, and two lawyers, ruling they cannot be sued for speaking to investigators about Constand's accusations. However, the judge allowed Cosby to pursue claims that Constand and her mother violated a confidentiality agreement by making public comments about the case on Twitter and in a newspaper. The decision does not affect other claims Cosby made against Constand and her mother.

site_title: German police kill Afghan teen after train axe attack
summary: German police fatally shot a 17-year-old Afghan refugee after he attacked train passengers with an axe and knife, seriously wounding three people, in what authorities described as a "probable" Islamist attack. The teenager, who arrived in Germany as an unaccompanied minor, had shouted "Allahu akbar" before the attack, but police say the investigation is ongoing and he acted alone. The incident occurred on a regional train near the city of Wuerzburg, and German authorities are reviewing security measures following a string of attacks in the country.

site_title: Boris Johnson to make first US trip for IS talks
summary: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is making his first US trip, meeting with international counterparts to discuss the fight against Islamic State (IS) and the conflicts in Syria and Yemen. He will meet with US Secretary of State John Kerry and other foreign ministers from Germany, France, Italy, and Saudi Arabia and UAE to discuss the fragile Cessation of Hostilities and humanitarian situation in Syria. Johnson aims to emphasize the importance of the special relationship between the UK and US, and to unite the international community in condemning the Syrian regime.

site_title: Yen at 3-1/2-week low, kiwi tumbles after central bank housing proposals
summary: The yen reached a 3-1/2-week low of 106.20 to the US dollar on Tuesday due to growing expectations of the Bank of Japan's monetary easing and a broad recovery in risk appetite. The kiwi dollar also fell sharply after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand proposed new curbs on the hot housing market, increasing the likelihood of a rate cut. Speculators are betting on the Bank of Japan's policy review on July 29 and unwinding safe-haven bids in the yen as Brexit-related shocks subside.

site_title: Audi favors electric cars, services in new strategy: sources
summary: Audi plans to boost spending on electric cars and digital services, investing about a third of its R&D budget by 2025. The company aims to increase electric vehicle sales to about a fourth of its total sales by 2025 and offer on-demand mobility services for premium customers. To fund these changes, Audi will retrench its conventional car program and reduce country-specific engine and transmission variants. This strategy follows Volkswagen's similar plans to become a world leader in green transport by 2025. Audi's CEO Rupert Stadler will outline the details at a closed-door conference on Wednesday.

site_title: North Korea fires three ballistic missiles: South Korea
summary: North Korea fired three ballistic missiles on Tuesday from the city of Hwangju, targeting the Sea of Japan. The missiles, believed to be Scud missiles, have a range to reach all of South Korea. This comes after North Korea threatened to take "physical action" in response to the planned deployment of a US anti-missile defense system, known as Thaad, in South Korea. The launch follows recent nuclear tests and missile launches by the North, which analysts say demonstrate progress toward striking the US mainland. South Korea's military is closely monitoring the situation.

site_title: Trump 'cannot become president': Clinton tells NAACP
summary: Hillary Clinton told the NAACP that Donald Trump is unfit to be president, citing his lack of a policy platform and a history of discriminating against African American tenants. Clinton announced a nationwide voter registration drive to counter Trump's candidacy. She painted Trump as a threat to democracy, emphasizing the need for citizens to take action to protect their rights. The comments came as the Republican National Convention opened in Cincinnati, Ohio.

site_title: US: Stocks hit another record; ARM deal lifts London
summary: US stocks hit a fresh record, with the Dow and S&P 500 reaching new highs for the fifth consecutive session. The gains were modest but driven by central banks' liquidity injection into the market. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.4% following Japan's £24.3 billion acquisition of ARM Holdings. Analysts attribute the UK's attractiveness to foreign groups to the weakened pound post-Brexit. US tech shares also rose, with Apple, Alphabet, and Facebook leading the gains, while oil producers declined due to lower oil prices.

site_title: Beijing to hold South China Sea war games after ruling
summary: China will hold military war games in the South China Sea, specifically in an area off the east coast of Hainan, after an international tribunal ruled against its sweeping claims in the waters. The exercises, set to take place from Tuesday to Thursday, will block access to the area. The move comes after China's maritime administration identified the area as being some distance from the Paracel and Spratly islands, both claimed by Beijing and neighboring states. The ruling is seen as a response to the tribunal's decision against China's claims in the South China Sea.

images.alt_text: Beijing will close off access to part of the South China Sea for military drills, officials said Monday, after an international tribunal ruled against its sweeping claims in the waters.

site_title: Trek 2000 International sinks into the red in FY15
summary: Trek 2000 International reported a net loss of US$6.72 million for FY2015, driven by a sharp rise in cost of goods sold, which surged 47% to US$145.16 million. Revenue rose 34.5% to US$149.14 million, mainly from its interactive consumer solutions business. The company attributed its focus to the medical technology industry, driven by an ageing population's need for innovative healthcare solutions.

images.alt_text: Henn Tan, chief executive officer (CEO) of Trek 2000 International. Trek 2000 International on Tuesday reported a net loss of US$6.72 million for FY2015 compared to a net profit of US$1.15 million a year ago.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: South China Sea issues barely make a splash
summary: A high-level forum in Singapore on China's new economy and changing global realities barely mentioned the South China Sea issues, despite a recent ruling against China's claims to the region's resources. Speakers instead highlighted global threats like terrorism and insularity, as well as domestic issues like demographic shifts. Attendees called for regional stability to facilitate growth, but stopped short of directly addressing the South China Sea disputes. China's Ambassador to Singapore reiterated the country's position on the issue, while some speakers suggested cooperation could be key to resolving tensions.

site_title: Brexit vote knocks UK manufacturers' confidence to two-year low: survey
summary: British manufacturers' confidence in their businesses and the wider economy has fallen to its lowest in two years following the UK's vote to leave the European Union, according to a survey by the EEF manufacturing trade body. 29% of firms expect domestic orders to fall over the next six months, while 12% expect a fall in EU orders. Despite this, a similar proportion forecast a rise in non-EU sales. The survey found that few companies had seen an immediate impact from the Brexit vote, but the economy is expected to slow.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as ARM leads tech stocks higher
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Monday as technology stocks climbed, offsetting concerns over unrest in Turkey. ARM's 40% surge after SoftBank's 24.3 billion pound deal lifted the STOXX 600 Technology sector 3.5%. The STOXX 600 index is down 7% so far in 2016 but 10% above its June low. Analysts attribute the rise to takeover deals and the European Central Bank's pledge to support the market, despite Brexit concerns.

site_title: More UK poor in work, but jobs downturn would hit them hardest: IFS
summary: Britain's poorest households now rely on jobs for half their income, up from less than a third in 1994-95, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. This shift reduces inequality but makes them more vulnerable to a post-Brexit labour market downturn. The poorest fifth of working-age households in the 2014-15 financial year relied on employment income, while government benefits accounted for the remaining half. This trend suggests that any labour market downturn would disproportionately affect the UK's poorest households.

images.alt_text: Britain's poorest households now rely more on jobs than government benefits for their income, reducing inequality but leaving them more vulnerable to any post-Brexit downturn in the labour market, research showed on Tuesday.

site_title: 'We need to change the math of economic success'
summary: Ruchir Sharma, Morgan Stanley's chief global strategist, discusses the current economic landscape, citing a global economic recovery that is the weakest in recorded history and a widening income inequality gap. He attributes the anti-establishment wave, including the Brexit vote, to this economic reality. Sharma predicts a potential global recession, with China's debt situation being a significant risk factor. He suggests that China needs to relax its 6.5% growth target and address its demographic challenges. Sharma also emphasizes the importance of demographics in the global economy, citing a demographic shift that is slowing down growth. He advises investors to consider emerging markets, particularly in South Asia and Eastern Europe, but notes that no country is perfect and that each has its own set of challenges.

site_title: Oil market drifts lower as Turkey worries subside
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, driven by fading market jitters following the failed coup in Turkey. Brent crude finished off 65 cents at US$46.96 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate shed 71 cents at US$45.24 a barrel. Analysts say the situation remains volatile in Turkey, where authorities are cracking down on plotters, but prices remain locked in a US$44 to US$52 a barrel range due to generous supplies and slow demand growth.

images.alt_text: World oil prices fell on Monday on fading market jitters following the failed coup in Turkey over the weekend.

site_title: Nice attacker a devotee of sex, drugs and decapitation videos
summary: A 31-year-old Tunisian man, Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, carried out a deadly truck attack in Nice, France, on Bastille Day, killing 86 people. Investigators found that Bouhlel, a father of three, had recently shown interest in Islamic State group propaganda and had watched videos of decapitations. However, there is no evidence he swore allegiance to the group. His past included a history of violence, including with his wife and children, and he was known to have a "vain" and "unbridled" sex life. A psychiatrist is being considered to investigate the motivations behind the attack.

site_title: Fewer Britons visiting shops after Brexit vote: survey
summary: A survey by the British Retail Consortium found that retail footfall in the UK declined 2.8% in June compared to the same period last year, the sharpest decline in over two years. The decline was particularly pronounced in the weeks leading up to and following the country's vote to leave the EU on June 23. Consumer confidence was hit, despite retailers offering discounts, and the West Midlands, London, and Scotland suffered the largest declines.

site_title: China funds go big on bank debt as corporate defaults rise
summary: China's fund managers have increased their investment in bank debt certificates of deposit (CDs), selling 6.2 trillion yuan in the first half, tripling from last year. This is driven by a rising number of corporate bond defaults, with companies pulling over 200 billion yuan of planned bond sales in the second quarter. Fund managers view banks as less likely to default, and the low yield on CDs suggests expectations that policymakers won't allow lenders to fail. This shift in risk appetite is also attributed to the waning concept of implicit guarantees in China, allowing an increasing number of defaults, even among state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Geo Energy buys out a Kalimantan coal mine for US$90m
summary: Geo Energy Resources acquired a Kalimantan coal mine in Indonesia for US$90 million, doubling its coal reserves to over 100 million tonnes. The mine has an estimated 44.4 million tonnes of coal and will lead to talks for a "life of mine offtake deal" worth at least US$1.2 billion, providing a significant revenue stream over the mine's lifespan.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: How companies can make digital marketing strategy work for them
summary: Companies must adapt to the digital revolution by investing in technology-enabled initiatives and creating a customer-centric vision and governance framework. Digital marketing strategies should focus on converting customers who are aware of the brand into purchasing it, rather than just reaching a large audience. Effective influencers stay "on brand" and create content that resonates with the target audience. Companies like L'Oréal, Red Bull, and Intel demonstrate successful digital strategies by understanding customer needs, gathering insights, and creating novel value. By putting customers at the front and centre of strategy, companies can turn each customer into an influencer and drive business growth.

site_title: LAUD Architects - Eyeing the world stage
summary: LAUD Architects, a Singapore-based firm, is expanding its global presence with 10-15% of projects in overseas markets. The firm, which has 35 staff, has designed various projects, including churches, condominiums, and commercial complexes. It attributes its success to design excellence and has received several awards, including the President's Design Award and World Architecture Festival Design Awards. LAUD aims to export its experience and ideas to other countries while retaining its boutique feel and personal touch. The firm is also embracing sustainability and technology, and has introduced innovative design elements, such as indoor streets and green features, into its projects.

site_title: Failed Turkey coup attempt poisons relations with US
summary: The failed Turkey coup attempt has strained US-Turkey relations, with Washington urging Ankara to uphold democratic institutions and respect the rule of law. US Secretary of State John Kerry warned President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's government against authoritarian actions, amid a crackdown on journalists and opponents. The US and Turkey, NATO allies, have clashed on combating Islamist extremists and human rights issues. The situation of US-based cleric Fethullah Gulen, Erdogan's arch-enemy, remains a sticking point, with the US refusing to extradite him without evidence.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Bain to buy majority stake in cosmetics firm Carver Korea
summary: Goldman Sachs and Bain Capital Private Equity are acquiring a majority stake in Carver Korea Co Ltd, a South Korean cosmetics firm, to tap into the growing demand for Korean beauty products. The companies will retain Lee Sang Rok, the founder and chairman, who will hold a minority stake and participate in day-to-day management. This acquisition comes as the Korean Wave of culture exports boosts overseas demand for beauty products.

site_title: North America oil deals trickling back after Brexit shock
summary: Energy companies have resumed buying oil and gas fields in Canada and the US after the Brexit shock, with dealmakers confident in a stable to slowly increasing oil price. Oil prices have held steady at or above $45 a barrel for two months, with some deals valued at $560 million. The resumption of deals is attributed to a 20% rise in oil prices and a reduction in volatility, allowing buyers and sellers to negotiate at prices around $60 a barrel.

site_title: Nadia still turning heads 40 years on from perfect 10
summary: Nadia Comaneci, a Romanian gymnast, celebrated the 40th anniversary of her historic perfect 10 score at the 1976 Montreal Olympics. At just 14 years old, she became the first gymnast to achieve this feat, captivating the world with her remarkable performance. Comaneci's iconic moment continues to stir emotions four decades later, as she has grown into a sophisticated individual with more refined tastes, but still can't escape the memories of that groundbreaking Olympic moment.

site_title: Yahoo studies bids for assets as losses mount
summary: Yahoo reported widening losses in the second quarter, with a loss of $440 million, despite a slight increase in revenue to $1.3 billion. The company's CEO, Marissa Mayer, said Yahoo is "deep into the process of evaluating all the proposals" for its core assets, but offered no definitive word on bids. Analysts speculate that Verizon and Quicken Loans founder Dan Gilbert are likely bidders, with some estimating the assets could sell for $5 billion or more. The company's future remains uncertain, with Yahoo seeking to revive growth and cut costs amid intense speculation about efforts to sell its main assets.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Q2 profit lifted by Basslink compensation
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 4-fold increase in earnings to S$16.6 million for Q2, driven by insurance compensation from Basslink's cable fault. Revenue fell 10.2% to S$137.4 million due to lower contributions from City Gas and Basslink segments. DPU remained unchanged at 0.93 Singapore cents. The trust's book closure date is July 26, with the payment due on August 19.

site_title: Singapore and Sri Lanka launch FTA talks
summary: Singapore and Sri Lanka launched bilateral free trade agreement (FTA) talks, aiming to promote stronger economic ties and enhance trade flows. The negotiations were signed by Singapore's Industry Minister S Iswaran and Sri Lanka's Development Strategies and International Trade Minister Malik Samarawickrama. The deal is expected to lower barriers of entry and provide increased market access for companies from both countries, with a focus on the Western Region Megapolis in Sri Lanka, a key economic driver.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Balancing growth and change
summary: BBR Holdings, a Singaporean construction and engineering company, is investing in prefabricated pre-finished volumetric construction (PPVC) technology to drive growth. The company has secured contracts for 1,582 hostel rooms and 1,900 modular units for the Ministry of Home Affairs and is developing a mixed development project with a PPVC component. BBR is also exploring green technology, incorporating solar technology and partnering with the Economic Development Board and Public Utilities Board for a floating solar PV testbed project. The company aims to leverage its BBR branding to enter new markets, particularly in Myanmar, Indonesia, and Vietnam, and sees PPVC as a strength in standardizing costs and aesthetics.

images.alt_text: "BBR's technology can be used everywhere. Most countries - if they do a lot of heavy engineering in terms of bridges for example - will need something like what we have. BBR is a name people recognise so it's very easy for us to open doors in new countries." - BBR executive director and CEO Tan Kheng Hwee Andrew

site_title: OCBC Bank merges two China units
summary: OCBC Bank has merged its two China subsidiaries, OCBC Bank (China) and Wing Hang Bank (China) Limited, to form OCBC Wing Hang Bank (China) Limited. The merger aims to comply with China's single-presence policy for foreign banks and establish the largest branch presence of the three Singapore banks in the Pearl River Delta region. The new entity has a registered capital of $1 billion and employs over 1,500 staff across 14 cities in China, with 13 branches and sub-branches in the Pearl River Delta region.

site_title: Scenario analysis, contingency planning key to surviving Brexit
summary: The UK's Brexit decision has sparked uncertainty in the UK and European markets, with financial institutions in Asia, including those in the Asean region, taking note. The UK's potential loss of access to the EU's Single Market could significantly impact financial institutions, with some opting to suspend new loans for London property purchases due to foreign exchange and sovereign risks. The EU's response to Brexit may also trigger a politically contagious effect, with other EU countries potentially facing similar challenges, including France's "Frexit" and Italy's constitutional referendum. Financial institutions in Asean should perform robust scenario analysis and contingency planning to prepare for potential disruptions.

site_title: Forming RegCo should be only the start
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has set up a separate subsidiary, RegCo, to handle its regulatory functions, aiming for greater independence and better regulation. However, critics argue that RegCo's independence is not guaranteed, as it will still derive resources from SGX. The establishment of RegCo is seen as a first step in a developmental process that should culminate in a fully independent entity, free from ties to the exchange. A competing exchange could potentially enter the market, and Australia's experience with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) is instructive in this regard.

site_title: Building the future
summary: SAMWOH Corporation is shifting its focus to recycling and sustainable practices, driven by the need for alternative resources. After a neighboring country banned the export of granite to Singapore, the company began researching ways to reuse construction waste materials in concrete and road construction. Since 2005, SAMWOH has been studying new technologies to improve recycling processes. The company aims to reduce waste sent to landfills and promote sustainable construction practices, highlighting the importance of recycling and R&D in its future growth strategy.

images.alt_text: "... in terms of social responsibility, I want to share what engineering is about with our locals, and let the younger generation know what our industry is really capable of." - Eric Soh, Samwoh CEO

site_title: Singtel innovating to meet changing customer needs
summary: Singapore's leading infocomm provider Singtel is innovating to meet the evolving needs of its customers. The company has adopted a data-centric approach, offering customers more choices, better value, and affordability. Singtel has invested in a future-ready network, enhanced customer service through digital platforms, and introduced interactive digital elements to engage customers. The company also focuses on staff training and development, with a robust talent management program and employee engagement initiatives. Singtel's goal is to deliver great customer experiences through its service culture, which emphasizes a strong service orientation among all employees.

site_title: How and why Temasek uses a hurdle rate
summary: Temasek, a Singaporean investment firm, does not have a firm-wide hurdle rate or investment-return target. Instead, it reports an average of risk-adjusted hurdles for each investment, weighted by size. This approach, known as a risk-adjusted cost of capital, is used to make investment decisions and track performance on a bottom-up basis. The hurdle rate is reported annually in the Temasek Review.

site_title: Holy cow urine industry gets boost thanks to Modi
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has boosted the holy cow urine industry, with its value now comparable to milk, thanks to government initiatives to protect milk-producing cows and support industries derived from their waste. The government has spent billions on cow shelters, enforced beef-eating bans, and tightened measures to stop the illicit sale of cattle. The urine, considered sacred by Hindus, is used to make various remedies, including soaps, disinfectants, and elixirs, with yoga guru Baba Ramdev's company Patanjali Ayurveda Ltd paying 150,000 rupees a day for raw material.

site_title: Retail, infocomm see happier customers
summary: Consumer satisfaction with Singapore's retail and infocomm sectors has increased significantly, according to a survey by the Institute of Service Excellence at Singapore Management University (ISES). The retail sector scored 71.7 points, a 2.4% gain, while the infocomm sector scored 68.5 points, a 1.6% gain. The survey, which included 8,584 locals and 905 tourists, found that the jewellery, fashion apparel, department store, Wireless@SG, and broadband sub-sectors showed significant improvements. The top performers in the retail sector included Bossini, Uniqlo, and Hang Ten, while DFS, Takashimaya, and John Little's led in the department store sub-sector.

site_title: Temasek may take SMRT private: sources
summary: Temasek Holdings, the majority owner of SMRT Corp, is considering taking the company private amid a transition to a new rail model. Analysts say this move would be beneficial for SMRT, allowing it to avoid quarterly updates and disappointing shareholders with reduced operating margins. The new rail model, which includes a cap on earnings before interest and taxes, has led to lower-than-expected profitability, prompting analysts to lower their earnings forecasts.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Brexit drives Russian investors across Atlantic
summary: Russian billionaires Mikhail Fridman and his Alfa Group partners are shifting their investments westward due to Brexit and sanctions, aiming to invest $3 billion in the US healthcare industry over three years. With ties to major US presidential candidates, they're navigating the terrain with expertise in administrative resources. The group's Luxembourg-based LetterOne unit is preparing to acquire US healthcare projects, leveraging innovations in technology and genomics. This move is part of their diversification strategy, with $33.5 billion in collective fortune, as they seek to balance their holdings in Russia and explore new opportunities abroad.

site_title: PM Lee: Better Singapore-South Asia air links will be a boon
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of better air connectivity between Singapore and South Asia, stating it would benefit airlines, tourism, and investments. He noted that existing flights are fully utilized, and expanding air services would lead to increased business, tourism, and investments, ultimately contributing to integration and globalization. Lee also highlighted the need to manage social issues arising from increased openness and integration, particularly with the growing Indian diaspora in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Indonesia starts new tax amnesty programme to boost tax revenues
summary: Indonesia has started a new tax amnesty programme aimed at boosting tax revenues by encouraging the repatriation of funds stashed abroad. The programme, which began on July 18, 2016, will impose a 2-5% tax on assets brought back onshore by March 2017. Repatriated funds can be invested in various assets, including government bonds and stocks, and are expected to bring in up to 75 trillion rupiah (S$7.8 billion) in inflows. However, the programme faces challenges, including a judicial review request from legal activists who claim it will hurt anti-graft efforts and protect tax evaders.

site_title: June NODX crashes back to earth after May's rebound
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 2.3% in June, reversing the 11.6% surge in May. The contraction was better than expected, as some economists predicted. The decline was attributed to an unsustainable rebound driven by gold shipments, pre-fabricated buildings, and pharmaceuticals in May. The results indicate a return to a more realistic growth trajectory for Singapore's economy.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 42% of Hong Kong residents want to leave, survey by independent think-tank finds
summary: A survey by an independent think-tank found that 42% of Hong Kong residents want to leave the city. The decision to leave has been fueled by the city's increasing polarization and tension with Beijing leaders over democratic future. Protests have become violent, with incidents like the February riot where activists set fire to trash bins and hurled bricks at police. The survey's findings highlight the growing discontent among Hong Kong residents with the city's current situation.

images.alt_text: Seventy per cent of 1,500 people surveyed said that Hong Kong had become "worse" or "much worse" to live in.

site_title: How exactly will Trump 'make America great'?
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's agenda is a mix of vague promises, mostly bad economic ideas, and divisive rhetoric aimed at manipulating public opinion. His plan to "make America great again" involves evicting 11 million undocumented immigrants, imposing tariffs, and cutting taxes, but these measures would likely face significant logistical and economic challenges. Trump's campaign relies on mass psychology, peddling hatred and resentment towards specific groups for his own gain, rather than offering a coherent economic strategy. His character is seen as lacking, prioritizing popularity over truth and common courtesies.

site_title: Shakeout looms for hedge funds as returns are eaten by excessive fees
summary: Hedge funds face a shakeout as investors increasingly question performance and fees. Despite traditional marketing claims of preserving capital and outperforming in strong markets, many funds have underperformed, with some returning less than 0.4% in 2015 and 0.19% up to mid-July this year. Fees, particularly the 2 plus 20 structure, are also a major concern, with some funds citing investor demand for more favorable fees as a key driver of change. As a result, some large institutions, including Calpers and the New York City pension fund, have announced exits from hedge funds, and investors are advised to redouble efforts on due diligence and rethink their allocations due to excessive fees.

site_title: Outlook positive for Asia's developing economies: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has reported that Asia's developing economies are expected to grow steadily this year and next, despite Brexit's impact on the region. India and Pakistan will drive growth, while China will register solid growth. Inflation is anticipated to accelerate due to recovering oil and food prices. The ADB also notes that other countries, such as Vietnam and Malaysia, will face challenges from US tariffs and economic pressures. Overall, the report suggests a positive outlook for Asia's developing economies, with growth expected to continue despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: India infrastructure fails to keep pace with air traffic growth
summary: India's air traffic is growing rapidly, with 20% expansion in 2015, but its infrastructure is struggling to keep pace. The country plans to invest $5 billion to improve airport infrastructure, but experts say it needs $40 billion over 15 years. The lack of facilities is forcing carriers to defer deliveries, hurting planemakers like Boeing and Airbus. The situation is particularly dire in Mumbai, where planes often circle for over an hour before landing, and in New Delhi, where the nation's busiest airports don't even figure in the top 20 globally by traffic.

site_title: China sees slowing home price growth in June
summary: China's home price growth slowed in June for a second consecutive month, raising concerns about the sustainability of the economy's construction-led rebound. Home prices rose 7.3% in June from a year earlier, with some cities experiencing eye-popping gains. However, monthly price growth slowed to 0.8%, easing from 0.9% in May, and prices stalled or fell in 15 cities. Economists predict the property rebound will subside and property investment growth will fall in the second half of the year, citing a large glut of unsold homes and tightening policies.

site_title: Designing with the heart
summary: Award-winning interior designer George Budiman is launching a lifestyle brand, budibudi, to promote sustainable tourism by selling "upcycled" objects like watches, tables, and art pieces to eco-friendly hotels. Inspired by his childhood in a fishing village, Budiman aims to minimize waste and leave a pristine environment for future generations. He has created several eco-friendly projects, including a Pullman resort in China using local timber and traditional textiles, and a Singapore design showcase using dismantled door props. Budiman's new brand will showcase his artistic flair and commitment to sustainability.

site_title: Yen slips back as concerns over Turkey coup ease
summary: The yen slipped back towards three-week lows against the US dollar as concerns over the Turkey coup eased, allowing investors to return to higher-risk currencies. The US dollar rose 5% and the pound gained 9% against the yen in the past week. Central bank stimulus and the economic fallout from the Brexit vote are driving market movements, with the European Central Bank potentially reducing interest rates on Thursday.

site_title: German investor sentiment plunges to four-year low on Brexit fears
summary: German investor confidence has plummeted to a four-year low due to Brexit fears. The ZEW economic institute's investor confidence index dropped 26 points to minus 6.8 points in July, its lowest level since November 2012. Concerns about the British vote's consequences for the German economy, particularly export prospects and European banking stability, are driving the decline. The sub-index measuring financial market players' view of the current economic situation in Germany decreased by 4.7 points to 49.8 points in July.

site_title: Celebrating journeys
summary: Singapore's 99% of businesses, employing 70% of its workforce, contribute to nearly half of its GDP. The Business Times' "BT Salutes Enterprise" series celebrates these SMEs' contributions and growth. Interviews with leaders from various industries, including property and F&B, highlight the theme of reinvention and entrepreneurship. OCBC Bank, a partner in the series, supports SME growth, with 40% of SMEs having a banking relationship with the bank. Examples of successful SMEs include Grandwork Interior, expanding in Southeast Asia, and Soo Kee Group, which continues to thrive despite market volatility.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Changjiang Fertiliser, Keppel Corp, CDL
summary: Changjiang Fertiliser narrowed its second-quarter net loss to 5.64 million yuan (S$1.15 million) from 5.91 million yuan a year ago. Keppel Corp refuted allegations related to Lava Jato investigations. City Developments Ltd (CDL) sold its 52.52% stake in Hong Kong-listed City e-Solutions to China Tian Yuan Manganese for HK$566.4 million (S$99 million).

site_title: Business confidence up in Singapore but uncertainty remains in Asia-Pac: survey
summary: Business confidence in Singapore has improved in the last three months, driven by stronger sentiments in China, but uncertainty remains in the Asia-Pacific region. According to a survey by ACCA and IMA, 47% of respondents reported cuts in capital expenditure and 42% declined orders, with 60% on a hiring freeze. Despite an improving global outlook, nervousness persists due to global market volatility, Brexit uncertainty, and potential long-term impact on global confidence.

site_title: Europe oil majors back to survival strategies as refining margins dive
summary: European oil majors are adopting survival strategies as refining margins plummet by as much as half from last year. Companies such as BP, Shell, Total, and ENI are cutting refining capacity and focusing on high-margin assets to improve resilience. The industry is bracing for more pain, with over 1.9 million barrels per day of refining capacity expected to close in the next five years to balance the market. To mitigate losses, companies are exploring ways to maximize efficiency and reduce costs, including shutting underperforming refineries and converting them to biofuels.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sim Lian Group Limited sold 72% of its 504 executive condominium units within the first two days of sales, with the majority of buyers being first-timers from the north-east region of Singapore. Global law firm Reed Smith launched an alliance with local practice Resource Law to expand its offerings in Singapore. Singapore Post appointed Sam Ang as CEO of Quantium Solutions, overseeing eCommerce logistics and freight forwarding operations. Content discovery platform Outbrain renewed its multi-year deal with Singapore Press Holdings Limited to deliver relevant content recommendations across its online news platforms.

site_title: A turbulent summer for European airlines
summary: European airlines face turmoil amid recent terror attacks and the Brexit fallout, with easyJet unable to forecast earnings and Lufthansa warning on profit. Security concerns and currency volatility are affecting advance bookings, particularly for long-haul travel to Europe. EasyJet's shares have lost a third of their value since the Brexit vote, while Lufthansa's shares slumped 7.5%. The German airline attributes its downgraded forecast to attacks in Europe and economic uncertainty. Analysts expect easyJet's pre-tax profit to drop 14% this year.

site_title: UK will ensure gets controls on free movement in EU talks: May
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May stated that the government will ensure controls on free movement from the European Union in negotiations following the Brexit vote. She aims to bring net migration down to "sustainable levels," estimated to be tens of thousands. May plans to set out Britain's negotiating position over the coming weeks and months.

site_title: Volkswagen to halt sales of most vehicles in South Korea amid emissions probe
summary: Volkswagen will suspend sales of most of its vehicle models in South Korea starting July 25 due to pressure from an emissions probe. The move comes after the company admitted to using software to cheat on emissions tests in the US. South Korean prosecutors have accused Volkswagen's local unit of fabricating documents on emissions and noise-level tests, leading to a potential sales ban of 32 models. The company has set aside $18 billion to cover the cost of the scandal, and analysts expect lawsuits and regulatory fines to increase the number.

site_title: S'pore inflation expectation hits a 5-year low
summary: Singaporeans' expectation of inflation has fallen to its lowest level since September 2011, with median one-year-ahead headline inflation at 2.63% in June, down from 2.79% in March. The drop is attributed to global economic headwinds, including Brexit, and a lack of confidence in traditional monetary policies. Core inflation expectations, excluding accommodation and private road transportation costs, rose to 3% in June, while long-term inflation expectations fell to 3.48%, a record low since the survey's inception in 2011.

site_title: Spinning off SGX's regulatory role: seeds sowed after penny stock saga
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been criticized for its dual roles as a market operator and regulator, sparking concerns about conflicts of interest. Despite efforts to address these concerns, the MAS-SGX consultation paper in 2014 proposed reforms to separate regulatory functions. In 2015, three independent committees were established to oversee listing, disciplinary, and appeal matters. The latest developments suggest a bigger separation of SGX's regulatory functions from its commercial mandate, settling the debate after 16 years.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares suffer third day of losses on yen rally
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted for a third consecutive day as a strong yen rally and concerns over a global oil supply glut weighed on investor sentiment. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.43% to close at 16,383.04, while the Topix index fell 1.39% to 1,306.94. The losses were attributed to worries ahead of US and Japanese central bank meetings.

site_title: UK developers offer incentives to entice buyers
summary: UK developers are offering incentives to entice buyers amid the economic contraction and uncertainty following the Brexit vote. Galliard Homes Ltd and Barratt Developments plc are offering discounts, paying sales taxes, and giving away £20,000 worth of furniture to boost sales. With residential property values expected to fall 10% and UK homebuilder sales to drop 5% next year, the housing market faces an oversupply of apartments and reduced demand.

site_title: WhatsApp briefly blocked yet again in Brazil
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court intervened, halting a court order that briefly blocked WhatsApp, the popular messaging service, for the third time in less than a year. The blockage, which lasted nearly four hours, was a result of a dispute over access to communications between alleged criminals. WhatsApp, owned by Facebook, refused to surrender user data, citing concerns over privacy and freedom of communication. The shutdown has angered users, who rely on the free app for everyday social interaction, and has sparked criticism from Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who described the blockage as "very scary in a democracy."

images.alt_text: The hugely popular WhatsApp smartphone messaging service was briefly blocked by a Brazilian court on Tuesday for the third time in less than a year after failing to surrender user data to police.

site_title: Religare: EC World Reit's yield not worth the risks
summary: Religare brokerage has issued a "do not participate" call for EC World Reit's IPO in Singapore due to high downside risks, including cross-border risks, weakening steel demand, and government acquisition risks. The Reit's high exposure to the e-commerce sector, reliance on its sponsor, and risk of a depreciating yuan against the Singapore dollar are also major concerns. Despite a solid portfolio and growth pipeline, Religare believes the low yield does not compensate for these risks.

site_title: Hungary could join euro by 2020, econ minister tells daily
summary: Hungary's Economy Minister Mihaly Varga stated that the country meets all euro zone accession criteria, with stable inflation, debt, and exchange rates. Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Poland are in talks to join the bloc by the end of the decade if economic improvements are made. Varga emphasized the need for a more stable euro and a common fiscal policy before joining the euro zone.

images.alt_text: Hungary meets all of the accession criteria to the euro zone and joining the bloc is plausible at the end of the decade if the country continues to improve its economy, Economy Minister Mihaly Varga told the daily Magyar Hirlap on Tuesday.

site_title: O&M sector's troubles to affect Singapore banks' asset quality: Moody's
summary: Singapore banks, such as OCBC and UOB, face asset quality challenges due to their exposure to offshore marine services companies. Moody's notes that these companies, which are among the principal bankers for the industry, have recorded net losses for the first half of the year. As a result, non-performing loan ratios and new NPL formation rates are expected to increase, putting pressure on the banks' asset quality and profitability. This may lead to a negative outlook on their credit ratings.

site_title: Satisfaction levels and revenue are linked: ISES
summary: The Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) released its 2016 first-quarter scores, showing a positive correlation between customer satisfaction and revenue. Companies with high CSISG scores tend to see increased customer spending and loyalty. The index reveals that service levels and revenue are linked, and companies use the data to improve their service delivery. Key attributes for retaining service staff include recognition, promotion, mentorship, and empowerment, as well as an empathetic environment. Companies are advised to focus on promoting service excellence, experimenting with new business models, and adopting an omnichannel strategy to meet changing customer needs.

images.alt_text: "Often, the difference between a good brand and a great brand lies in how much a business has invested in the design and delivery of its service," says Ms Lachmandas.

site_title: VW profit tops forecast but takes another 'dieselgate' hit
summary: Volkswagen reported higher-than-expected first-half underlying profit, driven by cost-cutting and rising European car sales. However, the company set aside another 2.2 billion euros to cover costs related to the "dieselgate" emissions scandal. Despite this, shares jumped over 5% after the news. Analysts see the results as a sign of recovery, but warn of continued uncertainty and potential lawsuits. VW has already set aside about $18 billion to cover the scandal's costs, and faces a forecasted full-year decline in group revenues of up to 5%.

site_title: Put a lid on insurers' excessive agent buyouts through disclosures
summary: Insurers who have been accused of poaching insurance agents are now facing increased scrutiny, with regulators proposing measures to curb excessive buyouts and ensure transparency. The practice of churning insurance policies, where agents persuade clients to surrender existing policies to buy new ones from their new employers, is also being targeted. Regulators suggest that agents whose sign-on packages exceed 150% of their past annual income should disclose this information to policyholders. A cooling-off period of one year could also be introduced to prevent policyholders from being pressured into buying new products during this time.

site_title: Shell net profit tumbles on low oil prices
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's net profit plummeted 71% to $1.175 billion in the second quarter due to low oil prices, weak refining margins, and production outages. The company's CCS profit was 72% lower than expected, and production fell short of forecasts. Despite a rebound in Brent oil prices, Shell's downstream and integrated gas businesses contributed to the results, while the upstream business faced significant challenges. CEO Ben van Beurden attributed the decline to lower oil prices and implemented cost-cutting measures to manage the company through the down-cycle.

site_title: Mediaset rejects Vivendi's alternative offer for TV deal
summary: Mediaset SpA rejected Vivendi SA's alternative proposal for a TV deal, after the French media company unexpectedly cancelled a share swap valued at 880 million euros (S$1.3 billion) in April. Mediaset's board authorized measures to enforce the original contract, while Vivendi accused Mediaset of attempting a hostile takeover. The deal's collapse led to a sharp decline in Mediaset's shares, reaching its lowest level since November 2014.

site_title: Foreign capital expected to flee Turkey; Erdogan's wrath may worsen situation
summary: Turkey's failed coup attempt risks shattering its image as a stable country, potentially leading to foreign capital fleeing the country. The failed plot, which saw President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's supporters restore order, threatens to further erode his legacy and consolidate power. Investors fear the political instability creates additional risks, with Wells Fargo Funds Management LLC's chief portfolio strategist, Brian Jacobsen, stating "it's not going to be business as usual." The Turkish lira has plummeted, and global stocks have retreated, raising concerns about the country's economic stability and its ability to attract long-term investment.

site_title: Infocomm sector sees rise in satisfaction
summary: The infocomm sector in Singapore saw a rise in customer satisfaction, with statistically significant increases in scores for broadband (67 points, up 3.3%) and Wireless@SG (69.6 points, up 16.8%). Mobile telecom and pay TV sub-sectors showed no significant changes. To retain customers, approaches may need to differ for new and long-term customers. Network reliability, subscription plan adjustments, and loyalty programs are key predictors of satisfaction and loyalty in the info-communications sector.

site_title: Bringing quality to the world
summary: Singapore-based interior fit-out firm Grandwork Interior is expanding globally, with over a third of its yearly revenue coming from international projects. The company, which has been in operation since 1996, is celebrating its 20th anniversary and has grown to become the dominant space builder for luxury brands in Singapore. Grandwork's commitment to quality and timely delivery has earned it the loyalty of top fashion labels such as Prada, Dolce & Gabbana, and Giorgio Armani. The firm plans to continue expanding into new markets, including Vietnam and the Philippines, and aims to establish itself as a global player in the industry.

images.alt_text: "We never fail any project. If you want us to build a shop in one week, we will plan properly and finish in one week, not even one day late." - Grandwork's founder and MD Jay Chiu

site_title: Syrians harness Pokemon frenzy to depict their plight
summary: Syrian artist Khaled Akil and others are using the popularity of Pokémon Go to draw attention to the country's six-year conflict, which has killed over 280,000 people. The artists superimpose Pokémon characters onto real-world scenes, such as bombed-out buildings and rubble-strewn streets. The images aim to redirect attention to the ongoing crisis and its impact on civilians, including the displacement of over half the population. The campaign, also involving opposition activists, seeks to raise awareness and call for international support.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won hold steady ahead of Fed, BOJ
summary: South Korean stocks and the won held steady ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) was down 0.1% at 2,024.88 points, while the won was quoted at 1,133.9 to the dollar, up 0.1% compared to the previous day. Analysts expect the Kospi to rise after global events pass, but warn of a possible drop if South Korea's July export data is weak. Foreign investors purchased 67.7 billion won worth of Kospi shares, and LG Display Co Ltd's second-quarter profit fell 91%.

site_title: Investors start buying London property again
summary: Foreign investors, particularly from Middle Eastern, Chinese, and European markets, are resuming their purchases of London residential properties, taking advantage of the decline in asking prices and sterling's slide. Despite Brexit uncertainty, some buyers view property prices as attractive value compared to 10-year gilt yields. However, the overall market remains cautious, with low transaction volumes and a prolonged period of uncertainty expected before a recovery.

images.alt_text: Agents say Middle Eastern, Chinese and some European buyers have been taking advantage of a decline in asking prices and sterling's slide, which have made some properties attractive.

site_title: Good service a key business differentiator, says customer experience guru
summary: Customer experience guru Bentley Williams emphasizes the importance of service as a key business differentiator, stating that creating positive experiences leads to increased customer loyalty. He stresses the role of service staff in building relationships and forming a critical part of a brand's equation, with well-equipped and motivated staff increasing customer satisfaction and loyalty. Williams advocates for companies to invest in customer experience programs, gather feedback, and respond promptly to customer concerns, and to align staff values with company values to promote staff retention.

site_title: US oil producers prepare for 3rd year of low prices despite rally
summary: US oil producers are hedging against a potential third year of low prices, with over 2 million barrels of 2017 output hedged by Laredo Petroleum Inc. Drillers have increased bets on falling prices by 29% this year, and companies are selling shares to raise cash, raising over $16 billion in equity. Despite a recent rally, oil prices remain volatile, and producers are preparing for another potential downturn, with crude prices potentially falling below $40 a barrel again.

site_title: It's the big Republican show
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has chosen Indiana Governor Mike Pence as his running mate, despite initial consideration of Chris Christie and Newt Gingrich. Trump's choice of Pence, a social conservative, aims to balance his own unpredictable nature and appeal to evangelical Christians. Pence's lack of charisma and personal appeal may not be a concern for Trump, who values Pence's ability to mobilize social conservatives. The Republican convention in Cleveland, Ohio, is expected to be relatively dull, with few major politicians in attendance, but Trump's adversaries may turn the event into a media spectacle.

images.alt_text: Lights, camera - action? Most of the GOP's political stars will not be attending the Republican National Convention.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vallianz, Swiber, Sinarmas Land, KOP
summary: Vallianz Holdings clarified its order book, stating it consists of third-party contracts unrelated to Swiber Holdings. Swiber announced it will withdraw its winding-up application, but cannot pay an upcoming coupon payment for Trust Certificates. Sinarmas Land and KOP agreed to develop Nuvasa Bay in Batam.

site_title: Flagging non-oil business dampens outlook for Gulf
summary: Economists have cut growth forecasts for Gulf countries due to slowing non-oil business activity caused by government austerity measures. The median forecasts for gross domestic product growth have been lowered for four of the six Gulf Cooperation Council countries, including Saudi Arabia and the UAE. The austerity measures, including cuts to energy subsidies and higher taxes, have reduced consumers' income, further slowing economies. Forecasts for Saudi Arabia's GDP growth this year have been lowered to 1.2%, while the UAE's forecast has been cut to 2.5%.

site_title: Growing with the customer
summary: Union Energy, a Singaporean bottled gas distributor, is expanding into diesel, electricity, and health supplements. The company, led by executive director Teo Hark Piang, aims to become a total energy provider, offering LPG, CNG, diesel, natural gas, and electricity. Union Energy has successfully disrupted the market by offering better pricing and service, and has expanded its services to include grocery delivery and health supplements. The company is now generating S$120 million in revenue annually and employs 500 staff, with plans to list its business in the future.

site_title: The happy traveller
summary: Travel industry veteran Albert See, 77, credits the past for being a simpler time to travel, with fewer worries and more carefree experiences. Since entering the industry over 50 years ago, he has helped found household names like SA Tours and CTC Travel. Despite the rise of the internet, See remains optimistic about the travel business, saying it's a "happy business" where people book tours and are happy to travel. However, he predicts turbulence in the industry in five years as younger, internet-savvy travelers come of age, changing the way travel is planned and booked.

images.alt_text: 'People book tours, they are happy to travel. I take their money, I research on travel options, I travel around the world, I am happy also.' - ASA Holidays MD and CEO Albert See

site_title: Singapore bondholders brace for defaults as borrowers seek easier terms
summary: Singapore dollar bondholders are bracing for potential defaults as oil and gas companies seek to extend debt maturities and loosen covenant requirements. AusGroup and Otto Marine are among 10 firms that have started the process, citing tight cash flows. Wealthy investors face limited options, with many bonds lacking secondary market liquidity. The average credit quality of Singapore-listed firms has deteriorated, with the debt-to-equity ratio rising to 43% from 16% five years ago. Analysts predict more pain for bondholders, with Bank of Singapore's Todd Schubert saying that most companies should be able to survive as long as oil prices stay stable.

site_title: OCBC sounds alarm on phone scammers impersonating its staff
summary: OCBC Bank in Singapore has seen a sharp increase in phone scams impersonating its staff since July 1, with over 1,080 customer calls reported. Scammers pose as Mandarin-speaking representatives, asking for personal and banking information. OCBC advises customers to verify calls by checking the caller's number, which is often a truncated 6-7-digit number or a private number with no caller ID. The bank also stated it would never initiate automated calls or ask for verification questions based on sensitive information.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asia but oversupply worries weigh
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia on Monday, driven by a weaker dollar, but analysts warned of a global supply glut and weak demand. Prices hit three-month lows last week due to an unexpected increase in US commercial stockpiles and concerns about US demand. Despite the dollar's weakness, which made oil cheaper for users of other currencies, analysts expect prices to remain under pressure. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 15 cents to $41.75, while Brent rose 15 cents to $43.68, but experts say the gains are unlikely to be sustained.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day lower, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 5.24 points to 1,653.260. The market saw 1.90 billion lots valued at RM2.02 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 445 to 324.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's July 18 close is at S$2.17, with a target price of S$1.90. Analysts expect medium-term pain from Northpoint's asset enhancement initiative to be anticipated, but difficulties at Changi City Point remain a concern. Northpoint and Causeway Point contribute 70% of FCT's net property income, and analysts expect strong rental reversion at Causeway Point to support earnings.

site_title: Qualifying salary for Employment Pass to be raised to S$3,600 from Jan 1: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore announced that the qualifying salary for Employment Pass (EP) applications will increase to S$3,600 from January 1, 2017. This change aims to keep pace with rising local wages, maintain the quality of the foreign workforce, and enhance their complementarity to the local workforce. Only new EP applicants who can command a monthly salary of S$3,600 or more will be considered, subject to meeting other criteria. This update follows the previous revision in January 2014 to S$3,300 from S$3,000.

site_title: HSBC banker arrested at New York airport
summary: HSBC banker Mark Johnson, global head of foreign exchange cash trading in London, was arrested at New York's Kennedy airport for allegedly participating in a front-running scheme involving a $3.5 billion currency transaction in 2011. Johnson and former HSBC trader Stuart Scott, who left the bank in 2014, conspired to manipulate the foreign exchange market to benefit themselves and the bank. The charges mark a significant victory for the US Justice Department, which has struggled to build cases against individuals in its investigation into foreign exchange trading.

site_title: Funds seek opportunities amid 'lower for longer' setting
summary: Investors are seeking opportunities in low-yield environments, with a focus on emerging markets and alternative assets. Central banks' quantitative easing has led to trillions of dollars in bonds with negative yields, prompting investors to consider higher-yielding alternatives. Funds are rotating into cyclical stocks, quality stocks, and sustainable investments. Hedge funds are offering daily pricing, and direct commodities and agricultural investments are being explored. Emerging markets, such as India and Indonesia, are gaining attention, with yields expected to rise. Experts predict a "lower for longer" scenario, with interest rates potentially staying low for another five years.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q2 DPU drops after sale of Sydney office building
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 6.5% drop in net property income to S$32.5 million for Q2 2016, mainly due to the absence of income from 77 King Street, a Sydney office building sold for A$160 million. The Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) dropped to 1.61 Singapore cents, down from 1.72 cents in the same quarter last year. Excluding 77 King Street, property income and net property income remained stable.

site_title: DFS tops department store category for seventh straight year
summary: DFS has topped the Customer Satisfaction Index of Singapore (CSISG) score in the department store category for the seventh consecutive year, according to managing director Wilcy Wong. Strong service values and a culture of continuous learning and development are key to fueling staff and customer engagement. DFS focuses on in-house leader-led learning and development programs, such as its globally-recognised Apprentice to Master frontline employee certification program, to develop talent and retain staff. Wong emphasizes the importance of investing in staff development to drive a service-oriented focus and attract top talent, especially in a labor-scarce industry.

site_title: A growing appetite
summary: Select Group, a Singapore-based food service firm, is expanding into the ready-to-eat food business in Singapore and Malaysia. The company, led by managing director Vincent Tan, has grown from a small food delivery outfit to a Catalist-listed firm with over S$160 million in revenue in 2015. Select plans to launch packs of curry-based meals and Japanese bento boxes in Malaysia, with a target launch date of September. The company aims to operate businesses on both ends of the food market, fine dining and mass market quick service restaurants, and has confidence in the potential of the ready-to-eat business.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.7% down on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 1.7% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index dropping 49.93 points to 2,868.69. The decline was driven by a drop in crude oil prices and the collapse of Swiber Holdings. Traders scrambled for the exits, with 1.20 billion shares changing hands, resulting in an average unit price of S$1.23. The session saw a significant number of losers, with 311 outnumbering gainers 131.

site_title: Panellists: Ensure core business is solid when tackling disruption
summary: Panellists at the FutureChina Global Forum emphasized the importance of solid core businesses when disrupting industries. General manager Liu Xin of Citic Guoan Group advised companies to adapt to the Internet revolution and leverage disruptive technologies to stay competitive. Garena's Forrest Li echoed this view, stating that business models are more crucial than innovation for sustainable outcomes. The panelists highlighted examples of how disruptive technologies can complement traditional industries, such as Garena's e-commerce services in Indonesia, raising consumer satisfaction.

site_title: Thriving on change
summary: Soo Kee Group, a Singapore-based jewellery retailer, has opened its new corporate headquarters in Changi Business Park, marking the company's latest chapter in its history. Since being listed on the Singapore Exchange in 2015, Soo Kee Group has grown from a single jewellery shop in Bedok to a company with over 60 retail stores in Singapore and Malaysia, and over 450 employees. The company has consistently reinvented itself to stay relevant to customers, adopting new technologies, designs, and business models. Its focus on innovation, customisation, and value-adding has enabled the company to stay ahead of the competition and achieve significant revenue and net profit growth.

site_title: SGX to hive off regulatory functions
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to hive off its regulatory arm into a new independent unit, RegCo, by the end of 2017. RegCo will be run by Tan Boon Gin and will have its own board, with MAS ensuring adequate resources and oversight. The move aims to resolve the perception of conflict between SGX's commercial and regulatory objectives. Market players welcome the move, but some express concerns about the need for more regulation and the potential impact on lower-quality listings.

site_title: Nice attacker had 'clear, recent' interest in radical Islam: prosecutor
summary: Paris prosecutor Francois Molins stated that Nice truck attacker Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel had a "clear, recent interest in the radical jihadist movement". Investigations found Bouhlel searched online for information on terror attacks in Orlando and Paris, and had violent images linked to radical Islam on his computer. This new information suggests Bouhlel's motivations behind the attack.

site_title: UK PM May concerned by lawmakers' damning report on BHS
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is concerned by a damning report on retail tycoon Philip Green's role in the collapse of department store chain BHS, which led to 11,000 job losses. The report, by Parliament's Work and Pensions and Business Committees, calls Green's actions "the unacceptable face of capitalism." May has vowed to tackle corporate irresponsibility, and the report increases pressure for her to revoke Green's 2006 knighthood. The decision is left to the Honours Forfeiture Committee, which May respects as an independent body.

images.alt_text: A damning report by British lawmakers on the role of retail tycoon Philip Green in the demise of department store chain BHS is "clearly concerning", a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday.

site_title: Land may not be smartest place for one's nest egg
summary: Land and homes have been disappointing investments over the long run, with the real value of American farmland increasing only 3.1 times from 1915 to 2015, and real home prices rising 1.8 times over the same period. This is lower than the growth rate of the US GDP, which increased 15.5 times from 1929 to 2015. The slow pace of land price increases can be attributed to technological advances in agriculture, which have increased crop yields per acre, reducing the need for new land. Additionally, the development of urban services and changes in housing preferences, such as the rise of micro-apartments, may further reduce demand for land in cities.

site_title: MAS probes case of UOB's unshredded client data
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is investigating UOB after unshredded client documents were found in a trashbag at Boat Quay. MAS will take action against banks that fail to safeguard customer information confidentiality. The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) is also aware of the case, which was highlighted in a report by The Middle Ground. The documents contained sensitive information, including loan applications and internal reports, and UOB has taken steps to address the issue.

site_title: Gold drops three-week low as investors look to equities
summary: Gold prices dropped to a three-week low, falling 0.1% to $1,314.20 an ounce, amid rising equity markets and a strong US dollar. Investors shifted their focus to equities, leaving gold as a safe-haven asset. Asian stocks reached nine-month highs, and the European Central Bank is expected to keep interest rates on hold. Analysts predict gold prices may stabilize temporarily before falling further, potentially towards $1,298 per ounce.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's Bahri to grow VLCC fleet
summary: Saudi Arabia's Bahri plans to increase its fleet size to around 46 ships by the end of 2018, making it the world's largest operator of very large crude carriers (VLCCs). The company, the exclusive oil shipper of Saudi Aramco, currently has 36 VLCCs and 10 ships on order. Bahri expects to grow profits, driven by increasing oil demand, despite fluctuating oil prices. The company has also announced a US$1.5 billion investment fund to buy up to 15 VLCCs, with APICORP providing the majority of the funding.

site_title: Doomed EgyptAir flight broke up midair after fire: report
summary: EgyptAir Flight 804, carrying 112 people, likely broke up in midair after a fire erupted in or near the cockpit, according to a report by the New York Times. The fire may have been triggered by a mechanical malfunction or a criminal act. The crash occurred on May 19 over the Mediterranean, and investigators have found evidence of a fire on the cockpit voice recorder. The Airbus A320 was en route from Paris to Cairo, and no claim of responsibility has been linked to the crash, unlike the previous bombing of a Russian passenger plane in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula.

images.alt_text: An EgyptAir flight that crashed into the Mediterranean in May likely broke up in midair after a fire erupted in or near the cockpit, the New York Times reported Friday.

site_title: PM Lee in Malaysia to witness high-speed rail agreement signing
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is in Malaysia to witness the signing of a memorandum of understanding on the high-speed rail (HSR) project linking Kuala Lumpur and Singapore. The 350-kilometre double-track HSR line aims to reduce travel time to 90 minutes, compared to four to five hours by car. The project is seen as a significant milestone in bilateral cooperation between Singapore and Malaysia, with estimated travel time savings and enhanced people-to-people ties.

site_title: Adding gold to your portfolio
summary: Gold is considered a safe-haven asset as central banks implement unconventional monetary policies, including quantitative easing and negative interest rates. Its value is not subject to government intervention, reducing the risk of devaluation. Gold provides stable liquidity and can be easily liquidated, making it a hedge against market turmoil. Historically, gold has preserved and appreciated in value during economic crises due to its safe-haven status, and it has low or negative correlation with other asset classes, allowing investors to diversify their portfolios and reduce extreme drawdowns.

site_title: Aladdin Group to launch halal e-market in S'pore
summary: Aladdin Group, a Malaysian company, plans to launch a halal e-marketplace in Singapore, targeting both B2B and B2C communities. The platform, Aladdin Street Singapore, will offer halal-certified and non-halal products and services, with the goal of achieving over S$50 million in sales within the first year. The company aims to promote Singapore's halal food safety and hygiene standards to the global market and collaborate with government agencies, trade associations, and halal certification bodies to support Singaporean SMEs.

site_title: China will not halt construction in South China Sea: navy chief
summary: China's navy chief stated that the country will not halt construction of islands and reefs in the South China Sea. State-run Xinhua news agency reported this, saying China won't leave outcroppings under construction half finished. This move comes despite international concerns over China's territorial claims in the region.

site_title: SoftBank to buy UK chip designer ARM in £24.3b cash deal
summary: SoftBank Group Corp has agreed to buy UK chip designer ARM Holdings plc in a £24.3 billion (S$43.5 billion) deal. The acquisition marks SoftBank's largest to date and will transform the Japanese tech group's portfolio. ARM's processor and graphics technology are used by major companies like Samsung, Huawei, and Apple, and the company is central to the "Internet of Things" trend.
