site_title: Saving the New American Century
summary: Key Republican neoconservatives are backing Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton to prevent a potential Trump presidency, which they fear could derail the emergence of a New American Century. Trump's anti-free trade and isolationist rhetoric has alarmed the elite, who believe Clinton can maintain US economic and military power, expand foreign trade relationships, and deepen military alliances abroad. Influential neoconservative Robert Kagan has endorsed Clinton and will deliver a speech at her fundraiser, arguing that she is the only choice to prevent a Trump presidency and save America.

site_title: US regulators pave way for speedy next-gen 5G networks
summary: US regulators have paved the way for the development of next-gen 5G wireless networks by setting aside nearly 11 gigahertz of high-frequency spectrum. The move, approved by the FCC, makes the US the first country to dedicate airwaves for 5G applications, with speeds potentially 10-100 times faster than current 4G networks. Companies like Verizon and AT&T plan to deploy 5G trials in 2017 and commercial deployments in 2020, with potential applications including virtual surgery, smart traffic management, and improved air pollution detection.

site_title: SGX raps YuuZoo on highlighting 'most optimistic valuation' in report via SGXNet
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded YuuZoo Corporation for a press release highlighting the company's "most optimistic valuation" in a research report. The SGX deemed the release unbalanced and unfair, as it presented a favorable outcome without sufficient qualification or explanation. The regulator noted that the valuation was based on a weighted average cost of capital suitable for matured businesses, not slow-growth scenarios. As a result, YuuZoo's shares fell 0.1 Singapore cent to S$0.173 on Friday.

site_title: Russia to impose stiffer punishments on errant banks
summary: Russia's Bank of Russia plans to reduce reporting requirements on lenders while increasing punishment for money laundering infractions. Deputy governor Dmitry Skobelkin announced the move as part of the country's campaign against money laundering, with the goal of making lenders "get more than a slap on the wrist" for flouting rules. The central bank has also set higher fines, with a record "several million" roubles imposed on an unidentified bank this year. The move aims to curb illicit activities after reducing illegal capital flight to 64 billion roubles in the first quarter.

site_title: Fed policymakers signal no rush to raise rates
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers expressed no rush to raise interest rates, citing the uncertainty following the UK's EU exit. Despite near full US employment and low inflation, policymakers are cautious, with some, like James Bullard and Robert Kaplan, advocating for a "patient, gradual" approach. The decision to keep rates unchanged is seen as potentially extending to months, with traders betting on a 2017 rate hike at the earliest. However, not all Fed officials have given up on raising rates, with Esther George warning of distortions from prolonged low rates.

site_title: Trump announces Pence as his vice presidential running mate
summary: Donald Trump announced Indiana Governor Mike Pence as his vice presidential running mate, following a postponement due to the deadly truck attack in France. Pence, 57, has diverging views with Trump but could help unify the party. Trump chose Pence from a short list, including Newt Gingrich and Chris Christie, and the announcement comes ahead of the November 8 election.

site_title: Game of Thrones leads Emmy nominations
summary: The 68th Primetime Emmy Awards nominations were announced, with Game of Thrones leading the pack with 23 nominations, one less than last year. HBO's fantasy epic will compete in the best drama category against other popular shows like The Americans, Mr Robot, and Downton Abbey. Netflix and Amazon made significant inroads, with 54 and 16 nominations respectively. The Emmys reflect the growing talent in television, with movie stars increasingly turning to TV, especially in limited series.

site_title: Japan may be on route for a 'soft' form of helicopter money
summary: Japanese policymakers may adopt a "soft" form of helicopter money by combining aggressive fiscal and monetary expansion to combat deflation. The government is preparing a big spending package, and the Bank of Japan (BOJ) will review its monetary stimulus at its upcoming rate review. While there is no chance of the central bank directly financing government spending, officials say combining fiscal and monetary expansion is possible. The BOJ may justify further stimulus to reach its 2% inflation goal, and coordination of monetary and fiscal policy is seen as crucial for Abenomics.

site_title: A first 4 the 7
summary: BMW's 7 Series has introduced a 2.0-litre, four-cylinder engine in its entry-level 730i model, offering 258 hp and 400 Nm of torque. The new engine is more frugal, with a consumption figure of 6.3 l/100 km and a carbon-neutral emissions banding. Compared to its predecessor, the 730i is faster, with a 0-100 km/h time of 6.2 seconds. The car also features a range of standard luxury features, including adaptive suspension and Integral Active Steering, and is available in a range of trims, including the M Sport model.

images.alt_text: BMW 730i M Sport
Few other two-litre models can claim to offer such an elevated level of luxury.

site_title: Polestar power
summary: Volvo's performance division, Polestar, offers tuning options for Volvo models, such as the V60 T5, to enhance their performance. The Volvo V60 T5 with Polestar Performance Optimisation raises maximum power by 8 hp to 253 hp and boosts torque by 50 Nm to 400 Nm, improving acceleration by 0.1 seconds to 6.3 seconds. The tuning maintains unchanged fuel consumption and carbon emissions, and improves the driving experience with reduced turbo lag and smoother performance.

site_title: Government to take over SMRT's rail assets
summary: The Singapore government has agreed to take over SMRT's rail assets under the New Rail Financing Framework, with the Land Transport Authority (LTA) paying S$1.06 billion for the assets of three MRT lines and one LRT line. SMRT will operate the lines for 15 years, with the possibility of a five-year extension, and will be reimbursed for costs and revenue changes. The move aims to improve the responsiveness of rail services to growing ridership and provide more reliable and well-maintained services.

images.alt_text: SMRT will transfer its rail assets to the government for S$991 million or S$1.06 billion after GST, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: EU plays catch-up on swaps collateral under US pressure
summary: European Union regulators are considering adapting their plans for implementing collateral requirements for derivatives to align with the internationally agreed timeline. The bloc's failure to meet a September 1 global deadline threatens to fracture the $493 trillion derivatives market. The European Commission proposes that the requirements would take effect one month after the EU's technical rules enter into force, while maintaining subsequent global start dates. This divergence could lead to competitive pressures, discourage trading, and make it more expensive for US banks. The EU has no firm timeline for completing the rules.

site_title: When your boss plays favourites
summary: Favouritism in the workplace is a common phenomenon where employees feel unfairly treated by their bosses. Despite managers claiming to treat everyone equally, observations suggest that certain employees receive preferential treatment, including plum assignments, confidential information, and special access. Experts attribute favouritism to cultural matching, where managers prefer employees with similar values, mindset, and background. To address the issue, employees should focus on their own capabilities, analyse their potential, and seek opportunities to showcase their strengths. Open communication, self-promotion, and seeking feedback can help employees build a relationship with their bosses and gain visibility, ultimately leading to a solution.

site_title: ION Orchard ups its F&B game
summary: ION Orchard has revamped its food court, Food Opera, with new F&B options, including local favorites like Pepper Lunch and exclusive menu items like Singapore Chilli Crab Pepper Rice. The mall is also introducing a picnic garden, partnering with UOB to create food based on artwork, and featuring new tenants such as Crave Nasi Lemak and London Sandwich & Co. The revamped offerings aim to appeal to both locals and tourists, with a focus on diverse cuisines from around the world.

site_title: AirTrunk aims to move Apac firms to the cloud
summary: AirTrunk, a Singapore-based startup, plans to invest nearly S$2 billion over the next three to four years to help Asia-Pacific tech companies shift to cloud computing. The company aims to build additional data centers in Singapore and Hong Kong, with initial investments of S$350 million in Australia. AirTrunk offers more affordable, reliable, and scalable data centers, with a focus on "green" operations and low power usage. The company's expansion is driven by the rapid growth of cloud computing in the region, with the Asia-Pacific expected to generate the most cloud traffic by 2017.

images.alt_text: SOLID GROWTH POTENTIAL: Mr Khuda says cloud-services providers are seeing a boom in the Apac and need more data-centre capacity.

site_title: Wine & whisky fair takes off at Suntec
summary: A wine and whisky fair, Wine & Whisky Week (WWW), has kicked off at Suntec in Singapore, offering a one-stop tasting, shopping, and educational experience for wine and whisky enthusiasts. The 11-day event features over 500 curated labels from 200 producers in 15 countries, with savings of up to 50% on selected labels. Highlights include Grand Cru Bordeaux wines and rare whiskies from renowned distilleries. Visitors can also participate in master classes and a lucky draw with prizes such as dining vouchers and exclusive wine holders.

images.alt_text: ENJOY an additional S$10 off Chateau Pichon Longueville Baron 2011, one of the most illustrious "Super Seconds" in the Bordeaux 1855 Classification with great historical vineyards.

site_title: Qatar Airways to buy 49% of Italy's Meridiana
summary: Qatar Airways has agreed to buy 49% of Meridiana, an Italian airline, in a move to bolster its European market presence. The deal, reached at the Farnborough International Airshow, is expected to close in early October, pending conditions. The acquisition could enhance Meridiana's competitiveness in the European market.

site_title: May won't trigger EU divorce until UK-wide approach agreed
summary: Theresa May announced she won't trigger EU divorce talks until a "UK approach" is agreed, aiming to appease Scotland's pro-independence government. Scotland voted 62-38% to stay in the EU, while the UK as a whole voted 52-48% to leave. May wants the Scottish government to be involved in Brexit talks and is seeking a clear negotiating stance before triggering Article 50, which would formally begin the UK's withdrawal from the EU.

site_title: Yuexiu Property offers to repurchase US$350m debt due 2018
summary: Yuexiu Property Company has offered to repurchase its $350 million 2018 debt for cash. The debt has a 3.25% coupon and will be repurchased at a price determined through a modified Dutch auction. The repurchase spread will be within 160-190 basis points. A meeting for note holders will be held on August 9, 2016.

site_title: Influential consumer magazine urges Tesla to disable Autopilot steering
summary: Consumer Reports magazine is urging Tesla to disable Autopilot's automatic steering function and change its name due to a potentially false sense of security it gives consumers. The magazine claims that Autopilot's name promotes the idea that the vehicle can drive on its own, which is not the case. The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating a fatal crash involving Autopilot in May. Consumer Reports wants Tesla to require drivers to keep their hands on the wheel and fully test safety systems before public deployment.

site_title: The picture of health
summary:

Gravity Pilates, a low-impact workout that uses the Total Gym, is suitable for all body types and can be modified to accommodate injuries. Bbounce Studio offers a unique workout called Hybrid Rebounding, which combines trampoline exercises with strength training and cardio. The Bushwick Foodlab sells probiotic beverages like milk kefir and kombucha, which can aid in digestion and immune system function. We Are Cultured offers probiotic powders called Teabiotic, which can support gut health and immune system function. These options aim to promote overall wellness and fitness in Singapore.

site_title: South African Airways makes first flight using fuel from tobacco
summary: South African Airways completed its first flight using jet fuel made from a tobacco plant, a 6,300-liter bio jet fuel used for a one-way trip to Cape Town. The state-owned carrier aims to power 50% of its airliners with biofuels by 2022, and has set a goal of using 20 million liters of bio-jet fuel by 2017. This initiative is part of the global push to reduce aviation's environmental impact and limit dependency on oil.

site_title: London mayor urges PM to build a second Gatwick runway
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan urged Prime Minister Theresa May to approve a second runway at Gatwick Airport, bypassing expansion plans for Heathrow, citing economic benefits for the city. The proposal, valued at £2.5 billion, includes upgrades to airport facilities. Khan's push comes amid a split among politicians over airport expansion, with some opposing plans due to emissions and noise pollution concerns. The decision is seen as crucial for meeting Britain's post-Brexit business travel and air freight needs.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, marking a significant success. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, and MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Citigroup profit beats estimates on fixed-income rebound
summary: Citigroup reported a 17% decline in second-quarter profit to $4 billion, or $1.24 a share, beating analyst estimates. The firm's revenue fell 8% to $17.5 billion, driven by lower consumer banking income, but fixed-income trading rebounded. Citigroup set aside less money for soured loans, and CEO Michael Corbat's profit forecast was met by analyst expectations. The company's shares rose 0.7% to $44.77, despite a 14% year-to-date decline.

site_title: Manufacturing in the US gains more than forecast in June
summary: US manufacturing posted its strongest gain in six months, rising 0.4% in June, exceeding forecasts. The increase was driven by automobile production and signs of improving domestic demand. Total industrial production, including mines and utilities, jumped 0.6%, also surpassing forecasts. Economists attribute the growth to stabilization in oil and commodities prices and fading dollar strength. However, the UK's impending exit from the EU poses a challenge for American companies selling overseas.

site_title: 96-year-old Thai Bev director steps down
summary: A 96-year-old director, Komen Tantiwiwatthanaphan, stepped down as vice-chairman of Thai Beverage due to health reasons. He has been a director since 2003, bringing 20 years of experience in the distilling industry. No immediate replacement has been announced for the Thai Beverage position.

site_title: Anxiety@work - and the vital need to beat it
summary: Anxiety can hinder corporate performance by causing leaders to focus on avoiding loss rather than winning. Harvard researchers Robert Kegan and Lisa Lahey define anxiety as a private emotion in public life, fueled by fear of failure, loss of power, and self-doubt. This anxiety can lead to a "culture of fear" that prevents leaders from playing to win, instead, they play to avoid losing. To overcome anxiety, leaders must develop self-awareness and focus on judgment rather than technical skills. By letting the problem "solve" themselves, leaders can break free from the shackles of self-doubt and achieve success.

site_title: Music to your ears
summary: Onkyo has released its first portable music player, the DP-X1, priced at $999. The Android-powered device features dual Sabre DACs, support for MQA audio, and storage of up to 432 GB. It can play multiple high-resolution files up to 384kHz/24-bit audio and has a real-time Direct-Stream Digital conversion feature. The player comes with links to music apps and access to the Onkyo Music store, but its availability is limited to certain regions. Despite being cheaper in Singapore than in the US, the device's high price may limit its appeal to audiophiles.

site_title: Brexit wipes off US$42b value from UK funds' assets
summary: The value of UK funds' assets under management has dropped by US$40 billion, or 8.2%, since the Brexit vote, largely due to the decline in the pound. This represents a loss of US$468 billion, from US$510 billion immediately before the vote. The decline is concentrated in equity and money market funds, with losses in property funds also reported. Despite a rebound in British equity markets, analysts warn that the outlook for UK assets remains challenging due to the unclear consequences of Brexit.

site_title: US: Stocks fluctuate after longest winning streak in 4 mths
summary: US stocks fluctuated, trimming an early advance, as investors weighed data and earnings. The S&P 500 rose 0.1% to 2,165.15, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 28.63 points to 18,535.04. The Nasdaq Composite Index was little changed. Investors are focusing on economic numbers and earnings, which may justify the rally, but some warn it may not be sustainable unless earnings improve. The S&P 500 is on track for its sixth straight session of record highs, the longest streak since 2014.

site_title: Chew Eng Han makes police report against City Harvest; church calls it 'bare allegations'
summary: City Harvest megachurch executive pastor Bobby Chaw has questioned a police report by former fund manager Chew Eng Han, alleging eight church members were involved in fraudulent misrepresentation. Chew had made the allegations, but the church claims these are "bare allegations" without substantiated facts. The church's lawyers consider the allegations unsubstantiated, leaving the matter unresolved.

images.alt_text: The City Harvest megachurch (CHC) has questioned a fresh police report by its former fund manager Chew Eng Han alleging fraudulent misrepresentation against eight church members.

site_title: US consumer sentiment drops as high earners shaken by Brexit
summary: US consumer sentiment has dropped to a three-month low of 89.5 in July, according to the University of Michigan's preliminary sentiment index. The decline is attributed to the Brexit vote, which caused uncertainty among high-income earners. The current conditions index fell to 108.7, while expectations six months from now dropped to 77.1, the lowest since September 2014. Despite a rebound in global equity markets, Americans' perceptions of their personal finances remain pessimistic, with fewer reporting recent gains in finances and more expecting a decline in the next year's inflation rate.

site_title: Brexit doubts won't slow US-EU trade talks: negotiators
summary: US and EU officials are moving forward with trade talks despite the Brexit setback, with the 14th round of negotiations in Brussels concluding. US chief negotiator Dan Mullaney expressed concerns that Britain's withdrawal from the EU market could affect the deal's value, but stated the economic and strategic rationales remain strong. EU chief negotiator Ignacio Garcia Bercero agreed, with the aim to complete talks by the end of the year. However, top EU diplomats suggest a potential suspension of talks until after major elections in the US, France, and Germany.

site_title: MAS orders 'thorough' report on SGX outage
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has instructed the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to conduct a thorough investigation into the July 14 extended shutdown of the stock market due to a technical glitch. The outage occurred after errors in trade confirmation messages caused a halt in trading activities. This is the second time MAS has looked into a possible supervisory response to an SGX outage, following a similar incident in 2015. The MAS will review the investigation findings before deciding on supervisory actions.

site_title: Waste management forum CESS closes with S$3.5b of projects
summary: The CleanEnviro Summit Singapore 2016 concluded with over S$3.5 billion worth of projects and deals, exceeding initial expectations of S$3.04 billion. The event, a global platform for environmental solutions, also facilitated knowledge exchanges and industry development. The summit aimed to drive sustainability through innovation and created a skilled industry.

site_title: The Japan syndrome
summary: Singapore has become a hub for Japanese culture and cuisine, with pockets of Japan found everywhere, including Chinatown and Little Korea. The latest cluster, Japan Food Town, opened at Wisma Atria with 16 concepts, while another cluster, Itadakimasu by Parco, is set to open in the fourth quarter of 2016. Managing director Makoto Yoshikawa attributes the success to keeping costs down by importing fresh ingredients from Japan and observing Singaporeans' affinity for Japanese food, which he spent four years researching. This trend may soon surpass Tokyo's ramen bars.

site_title: London luxury-home sales slump 43%
summary: London luxury-home sales have plummeted 43% in the 12 working days following the UK's EU referendum. This is a 25% decline in homes under offer, according to Lonres data. Prime-home sales dropped 18% compared to the same period before the referendum, with home values already experiencing a 1.4% decline in May, the largest monthly drop since 2011. Experts attribute the slump to increased supply and decreased demand, particularly at prices above £1 million.

site_title: Unesco adds 4 new sites to World Heritage list
summary: The UN's cultural agency, Unesco, added four new sites to the World Heritage list: qanat water systems in Iran, Zuojiang Huashan rock art cultural landscape in China, Nalanda Mahavihara in India, and Nan Madol in Micronesia. The new sites highlight ancient water-supply systems, bronze age cultures, and ceremonial centers. Three sites, Djenne in Mali and Shakhrisyabz in Uzbekistan, were added to the heritage-in-danger list due to threats from construction and civil war.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.62 points to close at 1,668.40 on Friday, driven by gains in 476 stocks. Total traded volume reached 1.89 billion lots, valued at RM1.92 billion.

site_title: Temasek's Fullerton unit hires JPMorgan's Singapore head
summary: Temasek Holdings' Fullerton Financial Holdings has hired Yeo Hong Ping, the Singapore head of investment banking at JPMorgan, as a senior member of its management team. This move comes as investment bankers are increasingly shifting to private equity firms and sovereign funds. Yeo's hiring follows the recent appointment of former Goldman Sachs investment banker Terence Lim as associate director for transaction structuring and execution at Temasek.

site_title: US consumer prices maintain gains on rising housing, healthcare costs
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in June, marking a fourth consecutive month of gains, driven by increases in housing, gasoline, and healthcare costs. The 12-month increase of 1.0% is below the 10-year average of 1.7%. This steady inflation pressure suggests the Federal Reserve may not raise interest rates soon. The Consumer Price Index has advanced 1.0% in the past two months, matching May's increase.

site_title: US, China clash over market economy status at WTO
summary: The US has warned China that it has not met the requirements for market economy status, potentially sparking a trade battle between the two countries. The WTO clause, set to expire on Dec 11, 2016, allowed US and other members to use "surrogate" prices to judge China's exports. If the clause expires, China's cheap exports could be harder to challenge. China's envoy at the WTO meeting agreed that the clause's expiration does not require automatic market economy status, but the US and EU are debating the issue, with the European Parliament rejecting the idea of loosening trade defenses against China.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust chairman retires
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust chairman Lim Neo Chian has retired, effective July 15, as part of the company's regular board renewal process. He will step down from chairman of the boards, nomination and remuneration committees, and investment committee. Miguel Ko has been appointed as chairman and non-executive director, while Chia Kim Huat has been appointed independent, non-executive director. The changes come after the trust rose 1.5 Singapore cents to 71.5 Singapore cents on the same day.

site_title: M1 Q2 revenue down on lower handset sales
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, reported a 7.5% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$41 million for Q2 2016, driven by a 13.2% drop in total revenue to S$240.4 million. Lower handset sales, down 49.9% year-on-year, contributed to the decline. Earnings per share fell 6.9% to 4.4 Singapore cents. M1 proposed a dividend of seven Singapore cents for the current financial period.

site_title: Strong June US retail sales point to solid domestic demand
summary: US retail sales rose 0.6% in June, exceeding expectations, as Americans bought motor vehicles and other goods, supporting economic growth in the second quarter. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles and food services, increased 0.5% and lifted sales 2.7% from a year ago. The solid sales report suggests the economy regained speed after a first-quarter lull and may lead to an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve later this year, with GDP growth forecast at 2.3% annualized rate in the second quarter.

site_title: HNA to buy 80% of Swiss plane maintenance company SR Technics
summary: HNA Aviation Group Co agreed to buy 80% of Swiss aircraft-maintenance service provider SR Technics from Mubadala Development Co for an undisclosed amount. The Abu Dhabi government-backed investment fund will retain 20% of the company. This acquisition adds to HNA's aviation assets, expanding its operations beyond Hainan Airlines Co. Mubadala, which acquired SR Technics in 2006, will now be the sole owner of the company. Regulatory approvals are required for the deal.

site_title: Geo Energy says it's in talks over acquisition following SGX query
summary: Geo Energy Resources is in talks over a potential acquisition following a query by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about unusual volume movements of the company's shares. The company has confirmed that negotiations are ongoing, but no firm decision has been made. Geo Energy's board stated that various opportunities are being considered and that the acquisition discussions are currently underway.

site_title: SIA's passenger carriage and load factor for June dip amid tough competition
summary: Singapore Airlines' passenger carriage and load factor declined in June due to tough competition, with passenger carriage falling 3.8% year-over-year and load factor dipping 2.1 percentage points to 77.8%. Regional wing SilkAir's load factor fell 4.2 percentage points to 68.1%, while Scoot's load factor rose 0.9 percentage points to 83.5%. However, cargo load factor improved 0.8 percentage points, driven by 5.9% growth in cargo traffic.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SMRT Corp will transfer the ownership of its rail assets to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for S$991 million. Singapore Exchange CEO Loh Boon Chye provided few details on the cause of a technical outage that shut down the stock market for 2.5 hours. Retail sales rose 3% in May, driven by higher car sales. Singapore shares closed higher due to Wall Street's all-time highs. Meanwhile, Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, and the Asian garment industry braced for higher US tariffs.

site_title: DBS to wind down commodity derivatives trading business
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest lender, plans to wind down its commodity derivatives trading business over the next six months due to capital intensity and under-pressure margins. The move comes as many foreign banks have exited the business. The commodities derivatives team, with 11 employees, will be offered opportunities within the bank. DBS expects short-term market making activities to be costly to maintain.

site_title: Susan Chong appointed first female president of E50 Association
summary: Susan Chong, CEO of Greenpac, has been appointed as the first female president of the Enterprise 50 Association, succeeding Andy Lim. Chong, known for transforming Greenpac from a one-woman startup to a multi-million dollar enterprise, aims to develop business leaders and encourage collaboration on overseas opportunities. As president, she will focus on social change, entrepreneurship, and women's leadership, inspiring like-minded entrepreneurs to contribute to positive change. Chong will lead the 16-member management committee and oversee the association's 236 members, past winners of the annual E50 Awards.

site_title: SGX raps YuuZoo for highlighting 'most optimistic valuation' in report via SGXNet
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reprimanded YuuZoo Corporation for using a favourable report from Edison Investment Research to highlight the "most optimistic valuation" of its stock, which led to a significant price increase on SGXNet. The report stated a fair value of S$1.83, but the stock was trading at 21.5-23.5 Singapore cents at the time. The SGX deemed the report's use as a promotional tactic, violating its rules.

site_title: SPH Q3 profit falls 46.4% after impairments in magazine business
summary: SPH's net profit fell 46.4% to S$52.7 million in Q3 due to significant impairments in its magazine business. For the 9-month period, net profit declined 20.7% to S$237.2 million. The media and property group attributed the decline to a weak magazine business.

site_title: Uncertainty is the only certainty for landlords post-Brexit
summary: British landlords are uncertain about the consequences of Brexit for the private rental sector, with 40% saying the vote will have a negative effect and 25% unsure. Factors such as exposure to EU residents and portfolio profitability will determine how landlords weather the storm. Early signs suggest Brexit may have an adverse effect on London's market, with house prices posting the biggest drop since the financial crisis. Experts warn of a potential shock to London's "illiquid" market due to higher taxes on investment properties.

site_title: Swatch warns profit to dive, French attack darkens outlook
summary: Swatch Group, the world's largest watchmaker, has warned investors that its profit will at least halve in the first half of the year due to weak demand in Hong Kong and Europe. Sales fell after Chinese tourists were deterred by fear of Islamist attacks in Europe, and a strong Swiss franc increased production costs. The attack in Nice, France, further exacerbated the pressure on luxury goods and travel companies, with Swatch CEO Nick Hayek describing France as "difficult" and predicting a downbeat earnings season for the luxury industry.

site_title: No special dividend from SMRT asset sale
summary: SMRT Corp will use the S$991 million from the asset sale to pay off part of its debt, totaling S$762 million by Sept 30, 2016. The company will also pay S$159 million in taxes and invest in strengthening its rail engineering competencies. The New Rail Financing Framework (NRFF) transition will not affect SMRT's non-rail business areas, allowing the company to focus on operational reliability and service delivery. SMRT's president Desmond Kuek welcomed the transition, stating it will enable the company to better serve commuters.

site_title: World leaders' horror at Nice attack
summary: World leaders have reacted with horror after a truck attack in Nice, France, killing at least 84 people. US President Barack Obama, Chancellor Angela Merkel, and British Prime Minister Theresa May condemned the attack, calling it a "horrific terrorist attack" and a "cowardly terrorist attack." Other leaders, including Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, European Council President Donald Tusk, and Turkish Prime Minister Binali Yildirim, also expressed their solidarity and condolences to the French people. The United Nations Security Council and Vatican also condemned the attack, labeling it "barbaric and cowardly."

site_title: Asia: Stocks end bright week on a high
summary: Asian stock markets ended a strong week on a high note, with Shanghai and Tokyo gaining, while Hong Kong and Singapore rose sharply. China's economy grew 6.7% in the second quarter, beating expectations, and retail sales rose more than forecast, boosting confidence. Central banks are expected to ramp up stimulus measures, supporting the rally. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.7%, while Shanghai and Hong Kong ended flat.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher in response to Wall St's all-time highs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 78 points or 2.7% to 2,925.35, following Wall Street's all-time highs, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching three consecutive highs and the Nasdaq Composite reaching its highest in 2016. If the S&P 500 index reaches another record on Friday, it would mark the first "perfect week" since 1998. The STI's gain for the week was largely driven by traders seeking to catch up after the market was closed on Thursday due to a system glitch on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: UK construction output fell sharply in May
summary: UK construction output fell 2.1% in May, a sharper decline than expected, amid uncertainty ahead of the EU referendum. This drop, combined with a 2.8% increase in April, suggests the sector may slow economic growth in the second quarter. Construction output has now fallen in every month this year apart from February, and a housing market downturn is expected. Economists warn of a 1.9% expansion needed in June to avoid dragging on economic growth, which seems unlikely.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher after hitting near one-year high
summary: Australian shares rose for a seventh consecutive session, closing at 5,452.7, the highest in nearly a year. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.3% and 4% for the week, its biggest weekly gain in over three months. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index also reached an all-time high, closing up 1%. The rally is attributed to expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the central bank, further fueling investor confidence.

site_title: New sales of private homes up 10% in H1
summary: New sales of private homes in Singapore increased by 10% in the first half of 2023, with 3,763 units sold, exceeding the 3,427 units sold in the same period last year. Despite fewer new launches, sales of existing projects rose, with 73% of sold stock coming from projects launched more than six months ago. Resale volumes also increased, with 2,001 private homes resold in Q2. Market watchers see these positive signals as indicating the market is nearing a bottom.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end week up as Line messenger app soars
summary: Tokyo stocks ended the week up, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.68% to close at 16,497.85, its fifth straight winning session. The broader Topix index also gained 0.45%. The surge was driven by Line's debut in Japanese trading, which skyrocketed, and Uniqlo-operator Fast Retailing's strong quarterly financial results. The five-day gain was over 9%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall at open after Nice attack
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the open on Friday due to the fatal Nice truck attack, offsetting Wall Street records and positive Chinese data. London's FTSE 100 dropped 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 shed 0.4%. The attack, which killed at least 84 people, was declared a "terrorist" attack by French President Francois Hollande.

site_title: Manulife US Reit refinances US$296m at lower interest rate
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) has refinanced US$296 million at a lower interest rate of 2.8% per annum for two years, replacing its bridge loan facilities. The new loans, from Wells Fargo and Royal Bank of Canada, will lower the Reit's weighted average interest rate to 2.46% per annum. The debt maturity will be staggered to four years, with no refinancing required until 2019. This move is expected to increase distributable income to unitholders and demonstrate the Reit's prudent capital management strategy.

site_title: China growth steadies on lending, consumer spending
summary: China's economic growth stabilized in the second quarter, reaching 6.7% as lending and consumer spending picked up, meeting the government's growth target of at least 6.5%. Industrial output and retail data beat estimates, while investment slowed. The People's Bank of China doesn't need to boost policy support, according to analysts, citing the current growth momentum. Consumption contributed 73.4% to economic growth in the first half, up from 60% a year earlier.

site_title: At least 84 dead in 'terrorist' truck attack in Nice
summary: A gunman attacked a crowd of revellers celebrating Bastille Day in Nice, France, killing at least 84 people. The attacker, later shot dead by police, drove a truck two kilometers through the crowd, leaving many strewn with bodies. French President Francois Hollande declared the attack a "terrorist" incident. The attack occurred on the Promenade des Anglais, a palm-lined street in the French Riviera resort.

site_title: Hong Kong ends strong week with flourish
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.46% on Friday, closing at 21,659.25, amid hopes for global central bank stimulus. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index ended flat, edging up 0.28 points to 3,054.30, after China's economy grew more than expected in the second quarter. This marked a strong week for Hong Kong stocks, with a 5% gain over five days.

site_title: Hot stock update: SBS Transit shares soar on rail asset transfer talks
summary: SBS Transit shares rose over 10% on July 15, 2016, after the Land Transport Authority (LTA) confirmed talks on transferring the company's rail assets to the government under the New Rail Financing Framework (NRFF). The shares closed at S$2.73, up 25 cents from the previous day. In contrast, rival SMRT agreed to transfer its rail assets to LTA for S$991 million, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: LTA still in talks with SBS Transit on transfer of rail assets
summary: LTA is still in talks with SBS Transit on the potential transfer of SBS Transit's rail assets, including those on the North East Line and Sengkang-Punggol LRT, to the New Rail Financing Framework announced in 2008. Under the NRFF, the government would assume ownership of bus services-related infrastructure and assets. The talks are ongoing, with no further details on the outcome.

site_title: Oil prices down on resurgent supply glut worries
summary: Oil prices plummeted in Asia, dropping 28 cents to $45.40 per barrel for US West Texas Intermediate and 27 cents to $47.10 per barrel for Brent crude. Analysts attributed the decline to renewed concerns over a supply glut and weak demand, particularly from China, which saw a 2.7% decline in oil demand in May. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) output reached a 8-year high in June, driven by increased production in Nigeria and the Middle East. Crude prices are forecast to fall to $40 per barrel.

site_title: Developers sold 2,344 private homes in Q2, up 65.2 per cent from Q1
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 2,344 private homes in Q2, a 65.2% increase from Q1. This is 10.8% higher than Q2 2015. Meanwhile, 1,116 EC units were sold, a 46.5% increase from Q1. The URA will release final Q2 numbers later this month.

site_title: Malaysia's new central bank governor leaves analysts puzzled
summary: Malaysia's new central bank governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, has surprised analysts by cutting interest rates in his second policy meeting, despite expectations of a clear signal from the bank. The 25 basis point rate cut to 3% is seen as a departure from the previous governor's policy of clear signaling, and may indicate a more dovish stance. The move is attributed to a slowdown in inflation and economic growth risks, particularly following the UK's Brexit decision.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks end a positive week at multi-weeks' highs
summary: The South Korean won reached its highest level in nearly three months, closing at 1,133.9 to the US dollar, and stocks at a five-week peak on Friday. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.4% to 2,017.26 points, while shares gained 2.8% for the week. Net purchases of Kospi shares totaled 486.3 billion won, driven by expectations of Bank of England's easing in August and data from the world's biggest economy.

site_title: Pokemon Go players held at gunpoint in Australia park
summary: A couple playing Pokémon Go in a park in Australia were held at gunpoint by masked men carrying a rifle, but escaped empty-handed. The incident is the latest in a series of complaints about the game, which police say is contributing to crimes, traffic violations, and complaints. Similar incidents have been reported in other Australian states, with police warning players about the dangers of driving while using the game. The couple was not injured in the incident.

site_title: FCT reports Q3 DPU of 3.04 cents
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 0.1% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.04 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended June 30. Gross revenue fell 4.4% to S$45 million, while net property income (NPI) declined 5.1% to S$31.2 million. The decline was mainly due to lower contributions from Northpoint, which is undergoing asset enhancement works. FCT has fully refinanced its S$264 million borrowing and maintained a gearing level of 28.5%. The all-in average cost of borrowings dropped slightly to 2.259%.

site_title: WDA chief appointed SkillsFuture Singapore CEO
summary: NG Cher Pong, WDA chief, has been appointed CEO of SkillsFuture Singapore, a new statutory board established to drive the national SkillsFuture initiative. The board will oversee the implementation of the initiative and ensure competitiveness and quality jobs for Singaporeans. WSG, another new statutory board under the Ministry of Manpower, is also expected to be established in the fourth quarter of 2016, with Tan Choon Shian, principal of Singapore Polytechnic, as its CEO designate.

site_title: Ford invests in startup that makes maps for self-driving cars
summary: Ford Motor Co has invested $6.6 million in seed funding for California-based startup Civil Maps, which creates three-dimensional maps for self-driving cars using artificial-intelligence software. The investment, along with others, aims to develop detailed maps for autonomous vehicles. Civil Maps' format uses less data, reducing transmission costs and providing real-time traffic information. The partnership brings Ford closer to developing fully autonomous vehicles for consumers, as other automakers, such as General Motors and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, also invest in self-driving technology.

site_title: European car sales rise 6.5% in June despite UK dip
summary: European car sales rose 6.5% in June, driven by strong demand in most large markets. However, Volkswagen's sales in the UK fell 0.8% due to a 20% decline in sales and economic uncertainty. Volkswagen, Europe's largest carmaker, is facing its biggest business crisis due to emissions scandal admissions. Despite this, rival brands such as Renault, Fiat, Mazda, Kia, and Hyundai posted double-digit percentage sales gains in June.

site_title: SMRT requests for trading halt, sparking speculation of major announcement
summary: SMRT Corp has requested a trading halt, sparking speculation of a major announcement related to its proposed rail financing framework. The framework, which will be introduced in stages, involves the government assuming ownership of bus infrastructure and assets, potentially relieving SMRT of major capital expenditures. Analysts believe this could lead to a positive impact on the share price, but details will be needed to assess the extent of the impact. The halt comes as shares were trading around S$1.545, up half a cent, or 0.32%, before the halt was sought.

site_title: Australia PM Turnbull 'donated US$1m' to party's election bid
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull reportedly donated A$1 million (S$1.03 million) to the Liberal Party's election bid in the final weeks of the campaign. The move was ridiculed by the Labor opposition, with the party claiming the Liberal Party was "desperate... for finances". The Liberal Party denied being in debt or broke, stating the claim was false. Turnbull's personal donation was made in a bid to help the party secure a narrow re-election victory.

images.alt_text: Australia's wealthy Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull reportedly made a large personal donation to the conservative Liberal Party during the recent fiercely fought election in a move ridiculed by the Labor opposition.

site_title: Developers' private home sales halved to 536 units in June from 1,058 units in May
summary: Singapore private home sales dropped to 536 units in June, down from 1,058 in May, but higher than the 375 units sold in June last year. Including executive condominiums, developers sold 768 units, lower than May's 1,392 but higher than June last year's 485. These figures, released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, show a decrease in private home sales compared to the previous month.

site_title: Rich Asians seen turning more to private banks as Brexit bites
summary: More rich Asians are seeking private bank management due to market volatility, with a quarter of high-net-worth investors in Asia using private banks, up from 10% three years ago. East & Partners Asia predicts 30% of wealthy Asians will become private-bank clients by next May. Private wealth in the Asia-Pacific region surpassed North America's for the first time in 2015, with real estate remaining the favorite investment, followed by equities and alternative assets. UBS and Credit Suisse are expanding their businesses in the region, aiming to capitalize on the trend.

site_title: SMRT to transfer ownership of train assets to LTA
summary: SMRT Corp will transfer ownership of its rail assets to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for S$991 million, subject to shareholder approval. The move is seen as a strategic shift to benefit commuters. Analysts speculate that the development of the Rail Financing Framework, a new business model for Singapore's public bus industry, is the reason behind the sudden halt in trading and the proposed asset transfer.

images.alt_text: SMRT Corp will transfer the ownership of its rail assets, including trains and signalling systems, to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for S$991 million.

site_title: Niantic wants to roll out Pokemon GO in 200 markets soon
summary: Niantic, the developer behind Pokémon GO, plans to launch the game in approximately 200 countries and regions "relatively soon" to bolster server capacity. The game, launched in five countries including the US, Britain, and Germany, has seen Nintendo's shares surge 77% to a six-year high, adding $15 billion in market value. Japan and South Korea are expected to be among the next markets, with China's potential rollout uncertain due to regulatory issues. The company is working on mapping solutions for restricted regions, including South Korea due to security concerns with North Korea.

site_title: China's yuan up on state bank support, central bank seen keeping firm hand
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the dollar on Friday, with the spot yuan closing at 6.6827 per US dollar, up 0.09% from the previous close. State-owned banks were seen defending the yuan at 6.6850 per US dollar, amid a flurry of economic data this week, including a 6.7% second-quarter economic growth rate. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.6805 per US dollar, and traders expect the intervention to last until the end of July to deter speculators betting on yuan depreciation.

site_title: Singapore retail sales rise 3% in May from a year ago due to higher car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 3% to S$3.7 billion in May, driven by a 35.9% increase in motor vehicle sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales decreased 3.3%. Other categories, such as furniture, medical goods, and food services, also saw growth, while some sectors, including electronics, petrol, and department stores, experienced declines. The increase was attributed to a higher car sales, with the food and beverage services index rising 0.7%.

site_title: MAS further revises risk-based capital framework governing insurers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has revised its risk-based capital framework governing insurers, RBC2, to better reflect their risk profiles and business activities. The revised framework is more sensitive to insurers' different risk profiles, leading to more favorable conditions for them. This change aims to enhance protection of policyholders by improving product pricing and asset allocation decisions. Insurers will be able to invest in equities and long-dated bonds, offering long-term retirement solutions, and the risk of reducing offerings is lower. The revised framework will be reviewed further.

site_title: Yen slides as solid Chinese data bolsters risk sentiment
summary: The Japanese yen fell to a three-week low against the US dollar after China's second-quarter GDP and June activity data showed stabilization in the Chinese economy, bolstering risk sentiment. The dollar rose 0.9% to 106.27 yen, its strongest level since June 24, and is on track for its best weekly performance against the yen since February 1999. The euro and Australian dollar also gained against the yen. Analysts attribute the yen's losses to position squaring after recent safe-haven demand and speculation about Japan's potential adoption of more radical stimulus measures.

site_title: China approves Chinatex merger with COFCO
summary: China's State Council approved the merger of state-owned Chinatex Corp with COFCO Group, the country's largest grain processor and trader. The merger aims to improve competitiveness in China's state-owned sector. Total profits for central government SOEs declined 3% to 623.47 billion yuan in the first half of the year, while revenue declined 1.8% to 10.8 trillion yuan. COFCO is restructuring to integrate grain trading and eyeing further acquisitions overseas.

site_title: North Korea arrests defector who 'worked as South Korea agent'
summary: North Korea has arrested a defector, Ko Hyon-Chol, 53, who confessed to attempting to kidnap two orphans and take them to South Korea. Ko, who fled North Korea in 2013 and was granted South Korean citizenship, claimed he was recruited by South Korea's spy agency, the National Intelligence Service (NIS), and was promised $10,000 for each child. Ko's arrest comes amid a dispute between North and South Korea over the defection of a dozen North Korean women to the South. Seoul demanded Ko's immediate release, warning Pyongyang against using its citizens for propaganda.

site_title: China 'may build nuclear plants' in South China Sea
summary: China may build mobile nuclear power plants in the South China Sea to support control and provide freshwater for troops, according to a report by the state-run Global Times. The plants, reportedly 20 in development, would be deployed in the Bohai Sea, contradicting initial claims of deployment in the South China Sea. The development comes after an international tribunal dismissed China's maritime claims in the region, and amid concerns over China's military expansion in the area.

images.alt_text: China may build mobile nuclear power plants in the South China Sea, state media reported on Friday, days after an international tribunal dismissed Beijing's vast claims in the strategically vital waters.

site_title: SGX to waive buy-in penalty following Thursday outage
summary: SGX will waive the buy-in penalty for shortsellers unable to cover their positions following Thursday's market outage, CEO Loh Boon Chye said. Trading was suspended at 11:38 am and resumed on Friday morning due to technical issues with trade confirmation messages. The amount of short selling is considered insignificant, and the waiver aims to support affected investors.

site_title: Venture capital investments rebound for tech startups
summary: Venture capital investments in tech startups rebounded in the second quarter, reaching $15.3 billion, a 20.5% increase from the previous quarter. The recovery was driven by a general stock market recovery and lower valuations, with software startups receiving $8.7 billion in funding, a 70% increase. However, the number of deals decreased by about 5% to 961. Investors are becoming more selective, focusing on companies with sustainable growth potential, and valuations have dropped by 30-50%. The involvement of mutual funds and sovereign wealth funds continues to drive large deals.

site_title: FLASH: SMRT requests for trading halt
summary: SMRT has requested a trading halt, sparking speculation of a major announcement. The halt was triggered by a news item, but the exact reason is unclear. The halt is typically used to prevent market volatility and allow for a more controlled release of information. As a result, investors are eagerly awaiting news from SMRT, and the halt has raised concerns about potential earnings or business changes.

site_title: Gold heads for first weekly loss since May as haven allure fades
summary: Gold prices are on track for the first weekly loss since May, falling 0.6% to $1,328.64 an ounce, as risk appetite returns and investors shift away from haven assets amid record US stock highs. The metal has rallied this year due to turmoil in financial markets, but gains were cut as governments and central banks may provide additional stimulus, lifting equities. Investors will monitor US data before the Federal Reserve's policy-setting meeting on July 26-27 for further price movements.

site_title: SGX CEO sticks close to script, offers few details on cause of outage
summary: SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye held a press conference on Friday, sticking to a script and providing few details about the cause of the technical and process issues that shut down the stock market for 2.5 hours on Thursday. The exchange blamed a "technology issue" affecting trade confirmation processes, which was resolved on Friday morning. SGX waived the buy-in penalty for shortsellers to avoid losses. The CEO acknowledged the recovery process could have been better and apologized for the disruption, but declined to provide further information on the cause of the issue or potential vendor involvement.

site_title: UK revives industrial plan unseen since Margaret Thatcher
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has merged the Department of Energy and Climate Change and the Department for Business, Innovation and Skills into a new ministry, dubbed the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, aiming to balance investment in energy infrastructure with consumer demands for lower bills and pollution reduction targets. The move is seen as the UK's first industrial strategy since Margaret Thatcher's rule in the 1980s, with a focus on decarbonization and tackling climate change.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks extended gains at open on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.13% to 21,589.08, following a record on Wall Street. Investors await Chinese economic growth data, while shares in Singapore and other Asian markets also rose, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore strongly condemns Nice attack
summary: Singapore strongly condemned the Nice attack, killing and injuring many innocent people. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs expressed deepest condolences to the victims' families and wished for the injured a speedy recovery. The safety of all registered Singaporeans in Nice has been verified. The attack was described as "heinous" and Singapore's thoughts are with the people of France at this time.

images.alt_text: Singapore strongly condemns the heinous attack in Nice, France that killed and injured many innocent people, its Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Friday.

site_title: China's oil, coal output slides in sign of more imports to come
summary: China's energy production has declined in the first half of the year, with crude output down 4.6% and coal output falling 9.7% to 1.63 billion tons. The decline is attributed to cost and environmental pressures as the country shifts towards consumer-driven growth. China's demand for overseas energy supplies is expected to continue growing, with coal and oil imports surging 8.2% and 14% respectively. The government aims to cut coal and steel overcapacity this year, with coal output expected to fall by 280 million metric tons.

site_title: Samsung Electronics seeks stake in China automaker BYD, electric car chips boost
summary: Samsung Electronics is in talks to acquire a stake in Chinese automaker BYD, a move aimed at boosting its electric car chip business. BYD specializes in electric vehicles and is backed by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. Details on the potential acquisition, including the amount and stake, are not yet finalized. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to expand Samsung's presence in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Oil falls amid warnings of retreat to US$40 on rocky rebalance
summary: Oil prices fell 1.4% amid forecasts of a potential retreat to $40 a barrel, citing a global glut and weakening demand. Crude prices rose briefly earlier in the week on strong US corporate results, but rebounded as US fuel data showed faltering demand. Analysts warn of a rebalancing trend, with prices potentially dropping due to increased US production and low refinery processing rates. West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $45.05 a barrel, while Brent fell 1.3% to $46.77 a barrel.

site_title: US dollar jumps to 3-week high vs yen after China GDP data
summary: The US dollar surged to a three-week high against the yen on July 15, 2016, after China's second-quarter GDP data showed stabilization in the country's economy. The dollar reached a high of 106.235 yen, its highest level since June 24, and was last trading at 106.19 yen, up 0.8% on the day. This move was driven by improved risk sentiment following the China data.

site_title: Horseback library serves Indonesia's remote readers
summary: A 43-year-old Indonesian horse groomer, Ridwan Sururi, has created a unique mobile library on horseback, visiting remote villages on Java island to provide access to books. Since 2015, his horse, Luna, has carried about 100 donated books, serving as a link to reading for many villagers with no traditional libraries nearby. The service has been a huge success, with children and adults alike eagerly borrowing and reading books, and Sururi aims to build a permanent library one day.

site_title: Asia: Shares power on while oil to kiwi fall before Chinese data
summary: Asian stocks rose for a fifth day, on track for their best week in three months, driven by speculation of Japanese stimulus and the prospect of US policy makers boosting stimulus to offset the UK's Brexit vote. The yen fell, while the kiwi and Australian dollar rose ahead of Chinese economic data. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.4% and the Topix index rose 0.6% for its fifth consecutive day, with US crude oil slipping below $46 a barrel.

site_title: Shale revolution extended to old wells seen unleashing more oil
summary: US oil explorers can tap into untapped potential in old, conventional wells using horizontal drilling techniques, according to a study by IHS Markit Energy. The method can boost production from 10% of surveyed wells, which are in tight conventional plays, with the potential to recover 141 billion barrels of oil equivalent globally. By re-drilling and re-processing these wells, producers can save money and increase output, with the study suggesting this approach will have implications worldwide.

site_title: US, Chinese naval commanders to meet amid tensions
summary: US Navy Commander Admiral John Richardson will meet with Chinese Admiral Wu Shengli in Beijing and Qingdao, amid tensions over China's claims to the South China Sea. The meeting comes after an international tribunal invalidated China's claims, prompting Beijing to promise a "decisive response." The visit is seen as an effort to ease tensions and de-escalate the situation.

images.alt_text: The commanders of the US and Chinese navies will meet amid mounting tensions over China's claims to much of the South China Sea, the US Navy said Thursday.

site_title: Fourth telco airwave auction to be held as early as October, says IDA
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) has announced that the fourth telco airwave auction in Singapore will take place as early as October. The auction is open to new entrants, who must submit application forms by September 1, with a 20-day review period followed by a one-week training session. The IDA will determine the successful bidder based on a computerised auction system. This marks the first airwave auction for Singapore's fourth mobile operator since 2012.

site_title: Australia dollar boasts best week on yen since 2009
summary: The Australian dollar reached a 10-week high against the yen, closing at 81.41 yen, its best weekly performance since 2009, following China's stronger-than-expected economic data. The Aussie surged 7% for the week, driven by speculation of further easing by the Bank of Japan. The Reserve Bank of Australia may cut its cash rate next month if inflation data is soft. Other central banks, including those in Britain and Japan, are also expected to ease monetary policies.

site_title: Indonesia's trade surplus widens to around US$900m in June
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus widened to around $900 million in June, driven by strong exports of electronics, auto parts, and rubber products. Imports fell 7.41% to $12.02 billion, while exports fell 4.42% to $12.92 billion. This marks the 21st consecutive month of declining exports and imports, largely due to low commodity prices affecting overseas shipments and government revenue.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit near 1-year high, NZ bourse holds at record level
summary: Australian shares rose for a seventh consecutive session, reaching an 11-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 0.39% to 5,430.80. New Zealand stocks also reached record levels. The rally was driven by confidence in the banking and energy sectors, with the Reserve Bank of Australia expected to consider further monetary stimulus. Financial stocks led the gains, while defensive shares edged lower.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.750 points to 1660.460. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 45, with a total volume of 29 million lots worth RM10.6 million.

site_title: China's yuan advances as economic growth beats estimates
summary: China's second-quarter GDP expanded 6.7% in the April-June period, beating estimates of 6.6%. This marks a recovery in the world's second-largest economy. The yuan advanced 0.06% to 6.6847 against the US dollar, while industrial production rose 6.2% and retail sales increased 10.6%. Experts say the data indicates stabilizing fundamentals, making yuan-denominated assets more attractive and potentially encouraging capital inflows. This stability is seen as a positive sign for China's economy growth.

site_title: Ericsson chief faces pressure as wireless market awaits 5G boost
summary: Ericsson's CEO Hans Vestberg faces pressure as the company's wireless market sales are expected to drop 8.9% and net income falls 22% in the second quarter, ahead of his results announcement. The decline is attributed to mature markets completing their 4G networks and the company's failure to quickly adopt 5G technology. Analysts predict additional cost-cutting measures may be needed to meet expectations, and Vestberg's "progressive" dividend policy may be at risk due to revenue and profitability pressures.

site_title: Singapore aims for MOU with Malaysia on high-speed rail next week
summary: Singapore plans to sign a memorandum of understanding with Malaysia next Tuesday to build a high-speed rail link, expected to cut travel time between the cities to around 90 minutes. The project reflects improved relations between the two countries, despite past tensions. The MOU does not provide details on the project's timeframe, investment, or contracted firms. The rail link aims to reduce travel time from four hours to Kuala Lumpur from around 50 minutes, including airport checks. The signing of the MOU is seen as a positive development in bilateral relations.

site_title: Temasek Holdings leads financing for pureLifi in tech expansion
summary: Temasek Holdings led a US$10 million funding round for Edinburgh-based pureLiFi, supporting the development of wireless communication technology using light-emitted diodes. The Series-B round brings pureLiFi's total financing to over US$10 million, as the company expands its technology holdings. This investment is part of Temasek's expansion into media, telecommunications, and technology industries, marking a shift in focus away from traditional banks.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally again, China data beats forecasts
summary: Asian stock markets rose for a fifth consecutive session on July 15, driven by strong China economic data and expectations of central bank stimulus measures. China's economy grew 6.7% in the second quarter, beating forecasts and exceeding the government's 6.5% target. Retail sales also rose more than expected, boosting confidence in a domestic-driven economic recovery. Markets rallied across Asia, with Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Sydney gaining 0.1%, 0.4%, and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks extend global rally at open
summary: Tokyo stocks rose at the open on Friday, extending a global rally. The Nikkei 225 index increased 0.06% to 16,396.12, while the Topix index rose 0.33% to 1,315.43. This follows four consecutive days of gains, with Wall Street also reaching fresh records. The global rally appears to be resilient despite US President Trump's recent threats.

site_title: China June investment growth cools to 9% year-on-year, missing forecasts
summary: China's fixed-asset investment growth slowed to 9% year-on-year in the January-June period, missing market expectations of 9.4%. Private sector investment growth was 2.8%, down from 3.9% in the first five months. Industrial output growth quickened to 6.2% in June, beating forecasts of 5.9%, while retail sales rose 10.6% year-on-year. China's economy expanded 6.7% year-on-year in the second quarter.

site_title: Nice attack death toll rises to at least 80
summary: At least 80 people were killed and scores injured in a truck attack in Nice, France, on Bastille Day. A 31-year-old French-Tunisian citizen was found in the truck with guns and larger weapons, and authorities confirmed the attack was of "undeniable terrorist nature." President Francois Hollande extended France's state of emergency for three months and called up army reservists to bolster security services. The attack, the third major strike against France in less than 18 months, was condemned by US President Barack Obama and sparked shockwaves across the globe.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit 1-yr high; currency jumps to highest since Aug 2015
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index reached a one-year high of 8,937.05, up 0.8% on Friday, driven by record highs on Wall Street. The electronics subindex rose 0.8%, while the financials subindex also gained 0.8%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to its strongest level since August 2015 at T$31.940 per US dollar. Shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) were nearly flat despite cutting its estimate for 2016 global smartphone shipments for the second time this year.

site_title: China H1 property investment grows 6.1% y-o-y
summary: China's real estate investment grew 6.1% year-over-year in the first half of 2016, with a 27.9% increase in property sales area, according to official data. This growth slowed from a 7% increase in the first five months. The data, released by the National Bureau of Statistics, also showed a decrease in the increase in property sales area from 33.2% in January-May.

site_title: Ezra sinks deeper into the red for Q3, hit by industry downturn and one-off loss
summary: Ezra Holdings reported a net loss of US$242.9 million for its Q3 2016 fiscal period, down from US$3 million a year ago. Revenue dropped 10% to US$125.7 million, and gross profit deteriorated to a loss of US$0.6 million. The company attributed the losses to its offshore support and production services division, citing pressure on charter rates and decreased utilization. Ezra expects its financial performance to remain challenging over the next 12 months.

site_title: Nintendo shares hit 6-year high, up more than 80% in a week
summary: Nintendo shares hit a 6-year high, reaching 27,800 yen, after the company's popular Pokémon Go mobile game launched. The shares have surged more than 80% in just over a week. This marks the highest level since mid-2010. The rally is attributed to the game's massive success.

site_title: Refiners seen killing market's golden goose in shift to gasoline
summary: Refiners are overproducing gasoline, contributing to a global glut, which has led to a sharp decline in US gasoline pump prices for 33 consecutive days. The shift from producing diesel to gasoline earlier this year, when diesel profits plummeted, is believed to be a major cause. Stockpiles are at record seasonal highs, and demand is not as robust as previously thought, making it difficult to reduce inventories. The glut is expected to persist throughout the driving season, benefiting US motorists who are seeing lower average gasoline prices.

site_title: Trump postpones running mate announcement after Nice attack
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump postponed announcing his running mate on Friday following the Nice attack, which killed 70 people. The attack occurred during a Bastille Day fireworks display in France. Trump had chosen Indiana governor Mike Pence as his running mate but decided to delay the announcement due to the tragedy. The incident occurred just three days before the Republican convention in Cleveland, Ohio, where Trump will officially select his nominee to face Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton in November.

site_title: Federal Reserve policymakers signal no rush to raise US rates
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers have signaled no rush to raise US interest rates, despite signs of near full employment. Three policymakers, including St Louis Fed President James Bullard, expressed a willingness to keep rates unchanged, potentially for months. This stance is a significant shift from last month, when most officials predicted at least two rate hikes this year. Bullard believes a single rate rise is sufficient for the next couple of years unless a significant economic shock occurs.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks climb to multi-week highs on global risk rally
summary: The South Korean won and shares reached multi-week highs on July 15, 2026, driven by strong risk sentiment and positive US economic data. The won rose 0.3% to 1,134.2, its highest level since April 20, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) gained 0.5% to 2,018.92. Analysts attribute the rally to the Bank of England's hint on monetary easing in August and additional easing expected from the Bank of Japan in late July.

site_title: Tech icons pan Trump as 'innovation disaster'
summary: Tech industry leaders, including Vint Cerf, Apple and Wikipedia founders, signed an open letter branding Donald Trump as an "innovation disaster" due to his views on technology and innovation. The letter, published on the Huffington Post, argues that Trump's policies would harm the industry and the US economy. The letter emphasizes the importance of an inclusive country that fosters creativity and opportunity, and calls for a level playing field for all industries. Nearly 150 tech leaders signed the letter, expressing their opposition to a Trump presidency.

site_title: Airbus beats Boeing on orders tally at Farnborough show
summary: Airbus secured 279 orders and commitments worth $35 billion at the Farnborough Airshow, surpassing rival Boeing's 182 aircraft worth $26.8 billion. Airbus reported firm deals for 197 aircraft, led by demand for the A320neo. Both companies said they are on track to meet their delivery targets despite a recent order slowdown. Airbus ended the show with a stronger tally than last year's Paris Airshow, where it trailed Boeing.

site_title: Yen steadies but set for weekly loss on stimulus talk
summary: The Japanese yen eased to 105.46 yen per dollar on Friday, tracking a steep weekly loss due to improving risk sentiment and speculation of potential monetary stimulus. Speculation of "helicopter money" by the central bank weighed on the currency, despite officials denying the possibility. The Australian dollar also declined against the yen, while sterling rose 0.5% to $1.3415 after the Bank of England kept interest rates on hold. The yen's losses are attributed to improving risk sentiment and speculation of potential monetary stimulus.

images.alt_text: The yen eased versus the dollar on Friday and was on track for steep losses for the week, under pressure from improving risk sentiment and speculation that Japanese policymakers could adopt more radical monetary stimulus.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Ezra, Noble, EMAS
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has resumed trading after its CEO apologized for technical glitches that halted the market. Noble Group is raising $500 million through a rights issue, while Ezra Holdings reported a significant net loss of $242.9 million in its fiscal third quarter. EMAS Offshore also reported a loss of $23.2 million, citing weakness in the offshore industry. The losses come amidst a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Private banks lure negative-yield refugees to Asia after Brexit
summary: Private banks, including Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse, are advising clients to invest in Asian corporate notes, taking advantage of higher yields compared to US debt. This trend is driven by investors fleeing negative-yielding bonds due to the global economic uncertainty post-Brexit. According to data, global investors poured a record amount into emerging market-debt funds, with developing Asia bonds being a key beneficiary.

site_title: Singapore startup bets US$1.7b on becoming Asia's digital landlord
summary: A Singaporean startup, AirTrunk, is investing $1.7 billion to become the digital landlord for tech giants building cloud services in Asia and Australia. The company plans to build data centers in Sydney, Melbourne, Singapore, and Hong Kong, targeting lower prices by undercutting rivals. AirTrunk predicts the Asia Pacific market for data center capacity will be worth $12.5 billion by 2019, and its technology for delivering electricity aims to save energy. The company has signed an anchor tenant and expects to finalize a fundraising of $350 million within the next three months.

site_title: Microsoft wins appeal to protect overseas data
summary: A US appeals court has ruled in favor of Microsoft, ordering a finding of contempt against the company and a warrant in a case regarding the storage of user data overseas to be tossed out. The ruling, made in a US court of appeals in New York City, states that the Stored Communications Act does not give US courts authority to force internet companies to seize customer email contents stored on foreign servers. The decision aims to protect people's privacy rights under their own laws, rather than foreign governments.

site_title: BP puts total pre-tax Deepwater cost at US$61.6b
summary: BP estimates the total pre-tax cost of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill at US$61.6 billion, six years after the 2010 disaster. The company identifies "significant progress" in resolving outstanding claims, but expects a pre-tax non-operating charge of US$5.2 billion in its second quarter 2016 results. After-tax charges will be around US$2.5 billion. BP has reached agreements to settle outstanding government claims and has a plan to manage the costs, providing investors with certainty. The company also notes that it has made progress in resolving claims arising from the incident.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher in line with Wall Street
summary: Singapore shares resumed trading higher on Friday, up 0.77% or 22.51 points, following a technical glitch that suspended trading the previous day. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose to 2,929.43, with over 273 million shares changing hands. The market's resilience was attributed to strong risk sentiment, fueled by the US market's recent gains, including a 0.73% increase in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

site_title: Safer borders? Why Brexit may be good news to European criminals
summary: The UK's decision to leave the European Union may hinder efforts to extradite criminals to face trial in the country. Prior to the EU's European Arrest Warrant, fewer than 60 people were extradited annually. Since 2004, over 7,000 were sent to EU member states, and 1,000 were brought back for trial. If the UK leaves the EAW without a similar deal, it may make it harder to bring criminals to justice, potentially leaving innocent British citizens languishing in foreign prisons.

site_title: US, China clash over market economy status at WTO
summary: The US warned China that it has not met the requirements for market economy status at the WTO, potentially sparking a trade battle between the two nations. The US, EU, and other WTO members will no longer use "surrogate" prices to judge China's exports, instead taking prices at face value, making it harder to challenge China's cheap exports.
