summary: Tencent Holdings is in talks with lenders for a non-recourse loan of approximately US$3.5 billion to back its US$8.6 billion deal to acquire a majority stake in Supercell Oy from SoftBank Group Corp. The loan may change in size, and discussions are ongoing with relationship banks. Tencent aims to acquire Supercell, the Finnish mobile game maker behind popular titles like Hay Day, Clash Royale, and Boom Beach.

site_title: Stickers to stocks: Things to know about messaging app Line
summary: Messaging app Line is listing its shares on the New York and Tokyo stock exchanges, raising about $1.3 billion to expand in Asia and tap the US and European markets. The app, which has 218 million active monthly users, offers free calls, instant messaging, and mobile payment services, as well as a vast library of "stickers" that drive its success. Line's revenue rose 40% last year, but it booked a loss due to rising staff costs and expenses. The stock offering comes two years after the firm initially shelved plans for a listing due to disagreements with its parent company, Naver.

site_title: FLASH: SGX confirms order and trade executions are accurate, market will resume trading at 4 pm
summary: SGX confirms that order and trade executions are accurate, and trading will resume at 4 pm. This comes after a brief halt in trading earlier in the day. The halt was due to an unspecified issue. The market's resumption is expected to continue the 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which is largely driven by positive investor sentiment ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Merkel invites British PM May for talks in Berlin, declines to comment on Johnson
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel invited British Prime Minister Theresa May for talks in Berlin, looking forward to working closely with her. Merkel spoke with May via phone and expressed the need for close cooperation with ally countries due to global problems. The chancellor declined to comment on her predecessor, David Johnson, but emphasized the importance of collaboration with May. Merkel's statement came after talks in Kyrgyzstan, where she discussed various international issues.

site_title: Asian local currency debt takes safe-haven appeal amid Brexit fallout
summary: Asian local currency debt is attracting investors seeking safe-haven assets amid the Brexit fallout. Despite dollar safe-haven flight, investors are drawn to Asia's longer-dated bonds due to relatively higher local currency rates. This shift is driven by investors seeking value in markets with negative yielding bonds. The prospect of central bank policy easing in Asia is fueling this trend, according to portfolio manager Brad Gibson.

images.alt_text: The prospect of central bank policy easing in Asia is luring global money managers into the region's local-currency bonds as the Brexit aftermath drives investors to seek debt-assets away from developed economies.

site_title: Taiwan dollar climbs to 11-month high as equity inflows quicken
summary: Taiwan's dollar reached an 11-month high against the US dollar, closing at TW$32.070, as foreign funds poured in, injecting a net $1.2 billion into local equities. This is amid expectations that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on hold, reducing the likelihood of a rate increase in 2016. The move is seen as a sign of confidence in emerging markets and a higher yield in Taiwan stocks, attracting foreign investors. The Taiex index rose 0.1% and is poised for its highest close since July.

site_title: SMEs' average time to settle debt shortens in year-on-year basis
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have become more credit-smart, with the average time taken to settle debts decreasing by 14 days in the last 12 months. The average days turned cash (DTC) national average for SMEs is now 29 days, down from 43 days previously. This improvement is attributed to SMEs tightening their trade credit terms, conducting more due diligence, and sharing payment intelligence to prevent defaults. Wholesale companies, which saw a strengthening of their financial position, led the improvement in payment speed.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have become more "credit" smart with a growing number tightening their terms and conducting more due diligence before extending credit to their clients.

site_title: China sets aside 199 million yuan for weather modification programme
summary: China has allocated 199 million yuan (S$40 million) for its weather modification programme, aiming to combat drought and reduce the impact of natural disasters. The funding will help regions respond to extreme weather events, including heavy flooding and drought. China currently uses weather modification technology, including cloud seeding, to induce rain during droughts and clear the skies ahead of events. The country aims to create 60 billion cubic meters of additional rain by 2020.

site_title: Tokyo: Benchmark stock index recoups Brexit losses
summary: Tokyo's benchmark stock index, the Nikkei 225, recouped losses from the Brexit vote with a 0.95% gain, closing at 16,385.89. This marks the fourth consecutive winning session. The broader Topix index also rose 0.84%. The gains follow a decline in global markets after the Brexit vote in June. The recovery suggests investors are becoming more optimistic about the market outlook.

site_title: Aussie nears two-month high on jobs; kiwi drops on RBNZ outlook
summary: Australia's dollar rose near a two-month high after a report showed full-time employment surged by 38,400 in June, offsetting weakness in the total employment number and unemployment rate. New Zealand's dollar dropped amid speculation the Reserve Bank of New Zealand might cut rates. The Aussie's rally could be its longest since 2012, while the kiwi faces its steepest weekly drop since May 6. The pound gained ahead of the Bank of England's meeting, with economists expecting a rate cut.

site_title: SGX securities market temporarily ceases trading at 11.38 am due to technical issues
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) temporarily halted trading at 11:38 am due to technical issues. Orders can be placed, cancelled, or amended during the closure, but will be matched when trading resumes. Market making activities for the iShares MSCI India Index ETF were also suspended. The SGX advised checking its website for updates or calling its hotline for more information. Once the technical issues are resolved, market making activities will resume.

site_title: Britain's new finance minister Hammond says no need for emergency budget
summary: Britain's new finance minister, Philip Hammond, announced that an emergency budget is not necessary, instead opting to monitor the economic situation over the summer before setting out spending targets in the autumn. Hammond made the statement after being appointed by Prime Minister Theresa May, who replaced Hammond from the foreign office. He plans to meet with the Bank of England governor to assess the economic situation before the autumn statement.

site_title: Indonesia's exports, imports seen contracting again in June
summary: Indonesia's exports are expected to contract by 12.40% in June, a month after a 9.75% decline in May. Imports are forecast to fall 10.10% annually, worsening from a 4.12% decline in May. This marks the 20th consecutive month of declining exports and imports, due to low commodity prices affecting government revenue and purchasing power. Indonesia's trade balance is predicted to be a surplus of $300 million in June, down from a $370 million surplus in May.

site_title: 17 hawker stalls given Bib Gourmand award in inaugural Singapore Michelin Guide
summary: Seventeen hawker stalls in Singapore have received the Bib Gourmand award in the inaugural Singapore Michelin Guide, including well-known stalls like Song Fa Bak Kut Teh and Tian Tian Chicken Rice. Young hawkers' stalls, The Fishball Story and A Noodle Story, also received praise. This recognition highlights the high quality and variety of food available at Singapore's hawker centers, showcasing the city-state's vibrant food culture.

site_title: Gold declines as investors await stimulus from policy makers
summary: Gold prices declined 0.4% to $1,339.25 an ounce, as investors awaited potential stimulus measures from policy makers, including the Bank of Japan and Bank of England. The move follows a 26% rally in gold this year, driven by the Brexit fallout and slowing global economic growth. Investors expect further easing measures, which could support gold prices.

site_title: Singapore's Jurong Aromatics restarts after 1-1/2 yr shutdown
summary: Singapore's Jurong Aromatics Corp (JAC) has restarted its refining-petrochemical complex after a 1-1/2 year shutdown, processing condensate smoothly. The US$2.4 billion plant, which produces paraxylene for textiles and bottles, is expected to reach commercial production in a few weeks. The complex, which includes a 100,000 barrels-per-day condensate splitter, was shut down in December 2014 on a technical issue and went into receivership in September last year.

site_title: Asia: Market rally eases but Tokyo pushes higher
summary: Japanese stocks rallied, pushing the Nikkei index towards a fourth straight gain, while markets elsewhere took a breather after a strong three-day rally. The yen gained against the dollar, and gold rose, amid concerns about the Brexit vote's impact on markets. The Bank of England is expected to cut interest rates to boost the economy, while Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to unveil new spending measures. The pound edged down ahead of the Bank of England's policy meeting, while Hong Kong and Shanghai eased.

site_title: Depleted crews, idled rigs lie in shale oil's path to revival
summary: The oil and gas industry is facing a significant downturn due to low oil prices, which has led to a decline in job opportunities for workers. Maritime Drilling Schools Ltd president Reg MacDonald notes that the industry is too cyclical, making it difficult for workers to find stable employment. With many rigs and crews idled, the industry is struggling to revive, affecting entry-level and experienced workers alike. The decline in oil prices has been exacerbated by the Trump administration's tariff policies, which have further bearish market outlooks.

site_title: EU moving ahead on giving China market economy status: official
summary: The European Union is moving forward with granting China market economy status, but is concerned about overcapacity, which could harm fair trade. EU Commission Vice-President Jyrki Katainen stated that the EU wants to discuss overcapacity with China to boost trade. Despite Britain's Brexit referendum, Katainen assured that investments in Europe would not be impacted. The EU hopes to increase infrastructure investments from China, while tackling overcapacity concerns.

site_title: MH17 families steel for legal fight on second anniversary
summary: The families of 298 people who died in the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 on its second anniversary are preparing for a series of legal battles against Malaysia Airlines and other parties involved. Relatives are set to file lawsuits for compensation, including psychological trauma, and against Russia, Ukraine, and other entities. The deadline to launch action against Malaysia Airlines is Sunday, with dozens of Dutch relatives close to filing a lawsuit. The cases aim to establish liability and seek justice for the victims, with many relatives seeking truth and accountability over the tragedy.

site_title: Australia shares rise for 5th day, NZ stocks near record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,406.7, driven by positive job data, while New Zealand's market advanced near record highs. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 3.4% this week, recouping post-Brexit losses. However, the rally was cautious, with some analysts warning of market exhaustion, and shares in oil and gas explorer FAR Ltd plummeted 20% after a buyout deal. Financials extended gains, while mining stocks declined.

site_title: Duplicate trade confirmation triggers SGX suspension, resume trading at 2pm
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) temporarily halted trading at 11:38 am due to duplicate trade confirmation messages. The market remained orderly, and no trades were executed. Message reconciliation is underway, with trading expected to resume at 2 pm. The halt was unrelated to any specific incident, and the market is expected to continue trading normally after the resumption.

site_title: UBS said to have flagged suspicious 1MDB transactions to MAS
summary: UBS flagged suspicious 1MDB transactions to Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), prompting an investigation. At least $1.24 billion was transferred from a 1MDB subsidiary to a UBS account in 2014. MAS is conducting supervisory reviews of several financial institutions and bank accounts with suspicious transactions. The Malaysian sovereign wealth fund is at the center of probes in several jurisdictions, with regulators seeking to determine if billions of dollars were siphoned off. 1MDB has denied wrongdoing, but a Malaysian parliamentary committee identified $4.2 billion of questionable transactions.

images.alt_text: UBS Group flagged suspicious transactions linked to 1Malaysia Development Bhd to the Monetary Authority of Singapore, prompting an investigation of the accounts involved, a person familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Legal drama could knock Hyperloop off track
summary: A lawsuit filed by former Hyperloop One co-founder Brogan BamBrogan against the startup accuses the company of nepotism, threats, and mismanagement. BamBrogan alleges that co-founder Shervin Pishevar and others created an autocratic culture that marginalized technical experts and squandered the company's cash. The lawsuit claims BamBrogan was subjected to threats and intimidation, leading to his resignation in June. Hyperloop One's board and team are united, and the company vows to respond strongly to the lawsuit, which may stall the company's ambitious timeline for developing the Hyperloop system.

images.alt_text: A Hyperloop One co-founder is suing the startup and accusing former colleagues of nepotism, threats and mismanagement, igniting a drama that could stall the company devoted to revolutionising transport systems.

site_title: Japan emperor abdication debate could stir discussion on female succession
summary: Japan's 82-year-old Emperor Akihito, who has undergone recent health issues, reportedly expressed intention to abdicate within a few years, sparking debate on female succession. However, any move towards female succession is likely to face strong opposition from the conservative ruling party. The Imperial Household Agency denied the earlier reports of a reason cited for the potential abdication, leaving the future of the monarchy uncertain. This development could re-open discussions on Japan's traditional male-only succession rule, potentially leading to significant changes in the country's imperial system.

site_title: South Korea holds interest rate at record low 1.25%
summary: South Korea's central bank maintained its record-low interest rate of 1.25% as it monitors the impact of its surprise rate cut in June. The decision comes amid growing jobless woes, mounting consumer debt, and falling exports, which have declined for 18 straight months. Consumer prices rose only 0.9% in the first half of the year, short of the 2% target. Analysts expect the bank to revise downwards its growth projection for 2016 and may announce the revised forecast later Thursday.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore Q2 GDP growth still lacklustre, caution prevails
summary: Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) grew 2.2% in the second quarter, marginally higher than the first quarter and matching analysts' expectations. The manufacturing sector drove growth, while the construction sector declined. Economists remain cautious, citing weak growth fundamentals and external headwinds from Brexit and China's slowing growth. Forecasts predict a technical recession in the second half of the year, with GDP growth forecast at 1.1% for 2016.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up; TSMC flat ahead of earnings
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.1% to 8,865.35 points, following a nearly four-month high earlier in the week. Tech heavyweight TSMC traded flat ahead of its quarterly earnings release. The electronics subindex was little changed, while the financials subindex gained 0.2%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to its highest level since August 2015, closing at T$32.100 per US dollar.

site_title: Tokyo fiery day traders gear up for year's biggest tech IPO
summary: Tokyo's day traders are expecting a volatile debut for Line Corp's IPO, with the messaging app's strong demand and popularity in Japan driving a 18% price increase. The US$1.3 billion IPO will allocate 7% of shares to Japanese investors, who are eager to snap up a piece of the company. With Line's user base reaching almost half of Japan's population, retail investors are optimistic about the stock's potential, but some warn of the group's fickle nature and reliance on margin trading.

site_title: Investors retain bets on Asia despite chance of more Brexit volatility
summary: Investors are maintaining bets on emerging Asian markets despite the potential for Brexit volatility. Asia's markets, which rebounded after the Brexit vote, remain stable, with attractive stock and bond markets. However, investors are increasingly cautious over political and currency risks. A slight provocation could lead to market volatility, particularly regarding China's growth and currency, as well as the US election. Despite this, Asia's investment landscape is similar to the first half of the year, with high-yielding bond markets and attractive stock markets. This cautious optimism suggests investors remain optimistic about Asia's long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: This year's rally in emerging Asian equities and bonds is gathering steam again, shrugging off the Brexit jolt, but there is one difference: Investors are more jittery, particularly over political and currency risk.

site_title: Gold swings as investors weigh crude slump with stimulus bets
summary: Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,340.63 an ounce, snapping a two-day decline, amid speculation of central bank stimulus measures. The selloff in crude oil tempered optimism in global stocks, but investors remain hopeful for potential easing from the Bank of Japan and Bank of England. Gold has rallied 26% this year due to the UK Brexit fallout and slowing global economic growth, and experts expect it to remain well-bid as central banks implement further easing measures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, edging down 0.12% to 21,297.54, following a three-day rally driven by hopes for global central bank stimulus. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also slipped 0.19% to 3,054.97. This comes as investors await the release of GDP data from Singapore and focus on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 1.780 points to 1,658.610. The index had 19.5 million lots traded worth RM8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 49.

site_title: China's yuan steady, central bank strengthens defence ahead of Q2 GDP
summary: China's yuan remained steady against the dollar on Thursday as the central bank intervened in the market to smooth strong dollar demand ahead of Q2 GDP data. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.6846 per dollar, with the spot yuan opening at 6.6890 per dollar and changing hands at 6.6880. The central bank offered large dollar liquidity to state-owned banks to offset client demand, amid concerns of yuan depreciation. China's economic growth is expected to cool to a seven-year low of 6.6% in the second quarter, with no significant impact on the forex market.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat as stronger yen hits exporters
summary: Tokyo shares opened flat on Thursday, following three days of gains, as a stronger yen weighed on exporters. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.07% to 16,242.20, while the Topix index edged up 0.07% to 1,301.13. The yen's strength has negatively impacted exporters, leading to a flat start in trading.

site_title: Japan palace denies emperor's wish to abdicate
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito, 82, has no plans to abdicate, according to the Imperial Household Agency, which denied reports that the emperor wants to pass the throne to his son. The denial comes after respected public broadcasters NHK and Kyodo News reported the story, citing palace sources. The move would be a huge shock to a country where the royal family symbolizes stability and continuity, and no provision exists in the Japanese constitution for an abdication. The emperor's health issues have raised questions about his ability to perform ceremonial duties.

site_title: Oil rises after big losses, glut concerns likely to persist
summary: Crude oil prices rose on Thursday, recouping some losses from the previous session, but concerns over a persistent global glut in oil persist. Brent crude rose 44 US cents to $46.70 a barrel, while US crude rose 43 US cents to $45.18 a barrel. The International Energy Agency and Energy Information Administration issued bearish reports, citing a glut in oil and strong demand growth despite declines in non-OPEC production. The IEA warned that the rebalancing process is taking time, and prices may drop below $40.

site_title: Brexit crisis to test 'Iron Ladies' Merkel, May
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May, compared to German Chancellor Angela Merkel, shares pragmatic and no-nonsense approaches in politics. Both are seen as strong-willed and decisive leaders, but Merkel has been more liberal on migrants, whereas May has called for stricter controls. Merkel has urged patience with May as she settles in, but expects Britain to trigger Article 50 to exit the EU soon. Merkel is expected to play a key role in negotiations, but May's pragmatism may not make the process easier, and the two leaders will face challenges in finding a balance between single market access and immigration restrictions.

images.alt_text: Pragmatic, childless pastors' daughters with killer instincts who were long underestimated by their blustering male peers - the parallels between new British Prime Minister Theresa May (right) and Germany's Angela Merkel are striking at first glance.

site_title: California rejects Volkswagen's recall plan for 3.0-litre diesel cars
summary: California's Air Resources Board rejected Volkswagen's proposed recall plan for 16,000 3.0-litre diesel cars, citing an insufficient plan to fix the vehicles. The plan was deemed "incomplete, substantially deficient" and would not meet the required emissions standards. The regulator will not have enough data until December to determine the feasibility of the fix, potentially leading to a buy-back of the vehicles, adding billions to Volkswagen's costs. The decision comes after the company reached a $15.3 billion settlement with regulators and owners over its 2.0-litre diesel vehicles.

site_title: Chinese national jailed for hacking US defence firms
summary: A Chinese national, Su Bin, was sentenced to three years and 10 months in prison for hacking US defence contractors to steal trade secrets on behalf of Beijing. Su, 51, also agreed to pay a $10,000 fine. He admitted to conspiring with two unnamed Chinese military officers to acquire plans for F-22 and F-35 fighter jets and Boeing's C-17 military transport aircraft.

images.alt_text: A Chinese national was sentenced on Wednesday in Los Angeles to three years and 10 months in prison for hacking American defence contractors to steal trade secrets on Beijing's behalf.

site_title: Australia posts a welcome jump in full-time jobs
summary: Australia posted a modest 7,900 net new full-time jobs in June, exceeding median forecasts, while the unemployment rate ticked up to 5.8%. The full-time employment increase of 38,400 was welcomed by investors, pushing the local dollar higher. Despite a slight rise in unemployment, analysts consider the jobless rate a better barometer of labor market trends, and leading indicators suggest continued growth in employment. A low consumer price index (CPI) in July could trigger another rate cut, according to economists.

site_title: S'pore startup launches halal dining app in S'pore, the UK
summary: A Singapore-founded startup, The Halal Dining Club, has launched a halal dining app in Singapore and the UK, catering to the 427 million Muslim consumers worldwide. The app, which was incubated by the Singapore Management University, has curated over 1,600 halal restaurants in both countries. The halal dining market is valued at US$1.2 billion in Singapore and US$3.7 billion in the UK, with users often spending up to 90 minutes searching for suitable places to dine. The app is now free to download from the Apple App Store, with an Android version set to launch at the end of 2016.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges up after BOK holds rates, stocks ease on profit-taking
summary: The South Korean won edged up 0.3% to 1,142.7 after the Bank of Korea kept interest rates steady, but gains were limited by expectations of future rate cuts. Analysts expect the Bank of England and Bank of Japan to ease policy, which could impact the won's price range of 1,140-1,150. Meanwhile, South Korean shares slipped 0.2% due to profit-taking, with the Kospi index at 2,000.69 points. Offshore investors purchased a net 57.3 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Nintendo shares jump 9.5% on Pokemon GO phenomenon
summary: Nintendo shares jumped 9.5% on the heels of the success of its Pokémon GO mobile game, which has attracted over 65 million users in the US just seven days after launch. The game's augmented reality concept has topped app stores in record time, sparking hopes it could be a major marketing tool for retailers. Industry experts see the game's popularity as a positive for Nintendo's shares.

site_title: Philippines' firebrand leader treads carefully on South China Sea ruling
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has avoided "flaunting or taunting" the international court ruling in favor of the Philippines in a South China Sea dispute, despite a "stunned" China. A subdued victory mood was reported among Duterte's cabinet after the landmark ruling by the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague. Foreign Secretary Perfecto Yasay called for "restraint and sobriety" in response to the decision, which Duterte's administration will continue to respect. The ruling did not lead to any immediate changes in the Philippines' stance on the issue.

site_title: EU leaders urge new PM May to start Brexit divorce
summary: European leaders, including EU President Donald Tusk, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, urged Britain's new Prime Minister Theresa May to launch the country's divorce proceedings from the EU. The leaders emphasized the need for a swift start to Brexit talks, citing the need for "certainty" and "fruitful working relationship" with the UK. Russia's Vladimir Putin also expressed readiness for "constructive dialogue" with David Cameron's successor, while British leaders, including former Prime Minister David Cameron, congratulated May on her appointment.

site_title: Dying cities can be brought back to life and here's how, says World Bank
summary: The World Bank has released a report stating that rejuvenating large, decaying cities in the developing world requires private sector participation, as governments alone cannot meet the massive financial resources needed. Eight major cities, including Ahmedabad, Santiago, and Washington DC, have successfully revitalized areas through a combination of public and private funding. The report highlights the importance of well-enforced zoning and property tax systems, and provides an online decision tool for local governments to reverse urban decay and achieve sustainable development.

images.alt_text: The rejuvenation of large, decaying areas in the fast-growing cities of the developing world cannot be achieved by governments alone and private sector participation is paramount, the World Bank said in a report on Wednesday.

site_title: The world according to Boris, new Foreign Secretary of Britain
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has appointed Boris Johnson as Foreign Secretary, sparking concerns over his diplomatic skills due to his history of provocative comments. Johnson, known for his wit and outspoken views, has compared Russian President Vladimir Putin to a Harry Potter character, questioned Hillary Clinton's candidacy, and made derogatory remarks about Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and US President Barack Obama. Johnson has shown contrition for some of his past comments, but his appointment as Foreign Secretary raises questions about the UK's ability to navigate international relations effectively.

site_title: UBS retains positions as world's biggest private bank: study
summary: UBS retained its position as the world's largest private bank, with $1.737.5 billion in assets under management, according to a study by Scorpio Partnership. The bank saw a 1% decrease in managed assets, while Bank of America Merrill Lynch fell 2% and Morgan Stanley 2.8%. The overall industry saw a 1% drop in assets under management, with net new money falling 6.9%. Switzerland's Credit Suisse fell further behind Morgan Stanley, with a 7.2% decrease in managed assets.

site_title: CMC Infocomm secures S$3.8m worth of cellular network engineering contracts
summary: CMC Infocomm secures S$3.8 million worth of cellular network engineering contracts with leading mobile operators in Singapore, Thailand, and the Philippines over the next two years. The contracts, expected to be completed by 2018, reflect sustainable demand for the company's services and solutions. The new contracts are not expected to impact the company's consolidated net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: China finds ally in Taiwan's leader in ruling refusal
summary: China and Taiwan are finding common ground after an international court dismissed their shared claims to over 80% of the South China Sea. Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen sent a naval frigate to patrol the disputed waterway, demonstrating the government's determination to defend its national interest. The Permanent Court of Arbitration ruled that China's claims to the area have no legal basis, specifically deeming the Taiwanese-held Itu Aba as a "rock" rather than an island. This move is seen as a significant development in the region's complex territorial disputes.

site_title: Asia: Stock futures meet a speed bump as life returns to havens
summary: Asian stock futures were mixed on Thursday, with Chinese and Hong Kong-listed stocks falling and Australian and Korean equity benchmarks rising. The S&P 500 was little changed, weighed down by a 4.4% drop in oil prices. The yen strengthened against the dollar, while gold rose for a second day. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to unveil a fiscal stimulus package, sparking speculation about "helicopter money." The Bank of England is expected to cut interest rates Thursday to bolster the UK economy.

site_title: Trump, family meet with Pence amid running-mate speculation
summary: Donald Trump met with Mike Pence at Pence's residence amid speculation about Pence potentially becoming Trump's running mate. The meeting was attended by Trump's family members, including Ivanka Trump and Jared Kushner. Pence, a former US congressman, could help Trump build relationships in Washington and gain credibility with social conservatives. Trump plans to announce his running mate choice on Friday, with Christie and Gingrich also in contention for the spot.

site_title: Keppel O&M unit delivers B class jackup rig to Central Panuco
summary: Keppel O&M's unit, Keppel AmFELS LLC, delivered a KFELS B class jackup rig, Uxpanapa, to Central Panuco in Mexico on time and within budget. This is the fifth jackup rig built by Keppel AmFELS for Perforadora Central and the second based on Keppel's proprietary design. Uxpanapa will be chartered by PEMEX, the Mexican national oil company, for work in offshore Mexico, and is seen as a cost-efficient and reliable solution in challenging market conditions.

site_title: Swiss watchdog opens investigation into BSI's former Asia CEO: lawyer
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator Finma has opened an investigation into BSI's former Asia CEO Hans Peter Brunner, following a report by Swiss newspaper Handelszeitung. The investigation may lead to a multi-year ban from working in finance and other penalties. Brunner's lawyer confirmed the investigation, which follows a decision by Finma in May that BSI breached money laundering regulations linked to the 1MDB scandal. BSI is currently appealing the decision and has been ordered to shut down operations.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher despite Wall Street retreat, Bank of England meeting
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Thursday, despite a retreat on Wall Street, due to expectations of a 25 basis point interest rate cut by the Bank of England. The Straits Times Index rose 0.07% to 2,912.71, with 85.5 million shares changing hands. The Bank of England's policy meeting is a key event, while Singapore's GDP grew 2.2% in the second quarter, marginally higher than the previous quarter.

site_title: Peru declares Zika emergency across half of country
summary: Peru has declared a 90-day Zika health emergency across its northern half, following the detection of 102 infected individuals, including 34 pregnant women. The outbreak is linked to microcephaly in babies and has raised concerns for athletes and visitors ahead of the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. Zika symptoms are usually mild but can cause neurological problems such as Guillain-Barre Syndrome.

site_title: Pokemon Go could be next big marketing tool for retailers
summary: Pokémon Go, a mobile game, has attracted over 65 million users in the US in just seven days, surpassing Twitter's user base. The game's augmented reality aspect and nostalgia for the classic cartoon franchise are contributing factors to its instant popularity. Retailers, including local restaurants and coffee shops, are seeing a significant increase in foot traffic and sales. Industry experts predict that major brands like McDonald's and Home Depot may incorporate Pokémon Go into their marketing strategies, potentially disrupting the business models of companies like Foursquare and Groupon.

site_title: UK lenders expect demand for loans to fall after EU vote: Bank of England
summary: UK lenders expect household and business demand for loans to slow after the EU vote, with businesses delaying new investment and company takeovers. Mortgage demand is expected to fall, despite a sharp rise before the referendum. The Bank of England surveyed lenders, finding enthusiasm for credit card lending also rose before the vote. The central bank took steps to ensure banks keep lending, lowering the reserve capital requirement.

site_title: Bank of England readies new blast of QE for post-Brexit Britain
summary: The Bank of England is set to announce a new round of quantitative easing (QE) to shield the economy from the post-Brexit recession. Expected to cut interest rates to 0.25% and extend the £375 billion bond-buying program, economists weigh the effectiveness of QE in addressing Britain's unique economic challenges. The move aims to boost employment and reduce borrowing costs, but critics argue it will fuel inequality. The central bank is considering alternative approaches, including purchasing corporate bonds or implementing an "Operation Anti-Twist" to lower mortgage rates.

site_title: Fed's Harker now sees just up to 2 rate hikes this year
summary: Federal Reserve President Patrick Harker has revised his expectations, predicting up to two interest rate hikes this year, down from his previous estimate of two to three. This comes despite the economy being on "fairly firm footing" and inflation expected to hit 2% by 2017. Harker downplayed the impact of the Brexit referendum, citing a seasonal adjustment for the first-quarter economic weakness, and predicted the Fed would raise rates to 3% by the end of 2018.

site_title: Singapore's Q2 GDP up 2.2% from a year ago
summary: Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) grew 2.2% in the second quarter of 2016, in line with analysts' expectations. The manufacturing sector expanded 0.8% year-over-year, driven by growth in biomedical and electronics clusters. The construction sector grew 2.7% year-over-year, while the services sector remained stable at 1.7%. The GDP growth rate is marginally higher than the previous quarter's 2.1%. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) will release preliminary GDP estimates in its Economic Survey of Singapore in August 2016.

site_title: Meet President and Vice President Barbie
summary: Barbie, a doll from Mattel, has announced its first all-female presidential ticket, featuring President Barbie and Vice President Barbie, aimed at inspiring girls to become leaders. The move follows a two-year makeover of the doll, which now offers more diverse skin tones, eye shapes, and hairstyles. The dolls are part of Mattel's Barbie Careers line and are sold for $24.99. The partnership with She Should Run, a non-partisan women's leadership group, aims to promote female leadership and provide a platform for girls to imagine their potential.

site_title: Amazon says Prime Day orders jump 60% over last year
summary: Amazon reported a 60% increase in orders worldwide during its second "Prime Day" sale, with orders rising by over 50% in the US and doubling on its mobile app. The Fire TV Stick was the best-selling device. Despite early glitches, the event cemented its position as an annual shopping festival for online shoppers, with the largest daily sales for Amazon devices.

site_title: Clinton says Trump corrupts party of abolitionist Lincoln
summary: Hillary Clinton accused Donald Trump of corrupting the party of Abraham Lincoln, stating his campaign adds up to an ugly, dangerous message to America. Clinton delivered a speech on race in America, referencing Lincoln's "House Divided" address, and acknowledged her own role in fueling partisanship. She urged unity and invited Trump supporters to join her in addressing challenges. Clinton criticized Trump for stoking mistrust and pitting Americans against each other, saying his nomination threatens the country's democracy.

site_title: Pyongyang close to developing sub-based missile: expert
summary: North Korea may develop a submarine-based ballistic missile within the next 12 months, significantly increasing the threat it poses, according to a US expert. Pyongyang has already carried out several submarine-launched missile tests since 2014, with the latest reaching an altitude of 33,000 feet before exploding. The capability to fire missiles from submarines poses significant challenges to Washington and its regional allies, with experts warning that the threat could become significant. The US has also announced plans to deploy an advanced missile defense system in South Korea and put North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un on its sanctions blacklist.

site_title: Theresa May becomes British PM, makes Johnson foreign minister
summary: Theresa May, 59, became the UK's new Prime Minister on July 13, 2016, after David Cameron stepped down following the Brexit referendum. She assumed the role after an audience with Queen Elizabeth, who is her 13th prime minister. May's task is to negotiate Britain's divorce from the European Union, amid economic uncertainty and uncertainty for European unity.

site_title: Credit Suisse said to lift salary, chop allowance for some staff
summary: Credit Suisse has changed the compensation structure for some senior London bankers, increasing fixed pay while eliminating variable allowances that were under regulatory scrutiny. The move is seen as a response to European regulators' final rules on bonus caps, which cap bonuses at twice fixed pay. Affected employees were informed of the change last quarter, and the bank will continue to use role-based allowances for other staff. This move is part of a broader trend among UK banks to comply with the bonus cap, with bonuses expected to be down a quarter this year due to the UK's EU referendum vote.

site_title: Airbus plays down A380 cutback as storm clouds gather
summary: Airbus has downplayed concerns about cutting production of the A380, citing long-term optimism and hopes to return to higher output levels. Despite fresh jet orders, doubts over demand and cost overruns on the A400M military airlifter overshadowed the Farnborough Airshow. Airbus Group CEO Tom Enders remains optimistic about the 544-seat A380's prospects, despite the company facing fresh losses. The move is part of a broader effort to adjust production and address financial challenges.

site_title: Pound falls as new British government named
summary: The pound fell 0.8% to $1.3144 against the US dollar and 1% to 84.36 pence against the euro after a new British government was formed by Prime Minister Theresa May. Finance minister Philip Hammond, a pro-Brexit critic, was seen as a good choice to lead negotiations with the EU on Britain's departure. Analysts expect his understated style to reassure investors amid market volatility. The euro edged higher against the US dollar, but the pound's decline was attributed to concerns about a long wait for a new leadership after the Brexit vote.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Soilbuild Reit, Yanlord Land, Global Yellow Pages
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Soilbuild Reit posted a 3.1% fall in distribution per unit for the second quarter, despite a 0.5 Singapore cent gain in stock price to close at S$0.70. Yanlord Land Group partnered with China Ping An Insurance to develop a 295,000 sq m integrated development in Suzhou city's Gusu District. Global Yellow Pages terminated its agreement to buy Hunters Plaza Shopping Centre in Auckland due to key issues identified during due diligence. The Singapore stock market rallied 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Oil price falls on disappointing US inventories
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after US inventories failed to meet expectations, with West Texas Intermediate dropping $2.05 to $44.75 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude falling $2.21 to $46.26 a barrel. Commercial crude oil inventories declined by 2.5 million barrels, but product inventories unexpectedly increased, and crude production rose by 50,000 barrels per day. The data contradicted recent OPEC expectations of a supply glut easing, leading to a bearish market sentiment.

site_title: Merkel, May stress 'friendly ties' as Brexit talks loom
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and new British Prime Minister Theresa May reaffirmed their countries' "friendly ties" in their first phone call, amid Brexit talks looming. Merkel congratulated May on her appointment and expressed her commitment to cooperating in the spirit of their countries' friendly ties. May emphasized the need for patience in the Brexit negotiations, hoping for a constructive and positive spirit. The conversation came as May faces the task of overseeing Britain's exit from the EU, following David Cameron's resignation.

site_title: Indonesia sukuk beats Malaysia in attracting Brexit-haven funds
summary: Indonesia's Islamic bonds have outperformed Malaysia's in the past three months, with yields falling 37 basis points compared to 24 basis points. This is due to Indonesia's higher-yielding notes attracting investors fleeing plunging rates in the developed world. Over $6.5 billion was invested in Indonesian debt, while $4.9 billion was invested in Malaysian securities, as investors seek yield amid concerns over Brexit and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate increases.

site_title: Lost at the Louvre? An app will help you
summary: The Louvre Museum in Paris introduced a geo-locator application, "My Visit to the Louvre", to help visitors navigate the museum's vast space. The app, available on iTunes and Google Play, calculates a path from famous artworks like the Mona Lisa to others, and can also pinpoint users' locations and buy tickets online for priority entrance. The app is part of a 53.5 million euro project to make the museum more user-friendly, with other changes including a redesigned reception area and shorter waiting times. The app is free and will continue to expand with more artworks.

site_title: Italy probes train crash as dead mourned
summary: Italy is investigating a deadly train crash that killed at least 23 people, with a "risky" signalling system potentially to blame. The single-track line, where station managers communicate directly with train drivers, was deemed "one of the least sophisticated and most risky" by the transport minister. Relatives identified victims at the morgue, where some were left sobbing outside due to restrictions on the number of mourners. The government has pledged 1.8 billion euros in investment to upgrade regional networks, and Prime Minister Matteo Renzi vowed to "throw light on what happened and who is responsible."

site_title: US economy shows few signs of sustained inflation pressure: Fed
summary: The US economy continued to expand from mid-May to the end of June, but inflation remained under control, with wage pressures being "modest to moderate" and price pressures slight. The Federal Reserve's Beige Book report showed little indication of sustained inflation pressure, despite a strong job growth rebound in June. The Fed has held off further interest rate increases this year, with traders expecting rates to remain on hold until mid-2017. The labor market remains near full employment, with modest employment growth and some signs of softening in consumer spending.

images.alt_text: The US economy continued to expand from mid-May through the end of June but there was little indication that inflation would surge any time soon, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

site_title: US: Wall Street ticks up to extend record streak
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, setting record highs for the S&P 500 and Dow industrials. Investors expect strong earnings to continue the rally, driven by economic data and monetary policies. Despite a decline in the Nasdaq, the S&P 500 posted 54 new 52-week highs. Analysts anticipate growth to resume in the second half of the year, with consumer discretionary, healthcare, and industrials sectors expected to outperform.

site_title: US foreign direct investment jumps 68% in 2015, inversions a factor
summary: US foreign direct investment (FDI) surged 68% in 2015 to a record high of US$420.7 billion, driven by corporate tax inversion transactions. Foreigners acquired existing businesses for US$408.1 billion and set up new enterprises for US$11.2 billion, while US$1.4 billion was invested in expanding existing foreign-owned businesses. The increase is attributed to corporate tax inversion transactions, which involve US companies merging with foreign firms to reduce US tax liability. The Commerce Department started tracking FDI in 1982.

site_title: Soilbuild sees challenge amid slowdown in manufacturing sector
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported a 3.1% fall in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter, with DPU at 1.565 Singapore cents, compared to 1.615 Singapore cents a year ago. Income available for distribution increased 3% to S$14.7 million, mainly due to reduced property tax expense. Occupancy rate remained 92% and weighted average lease expiry by gross rental income was 4.6 years. The Reit manager attributed the slowdown in rentals to the manufacturing sector slowdown, with rentals of all industrial properties softening by 2.7% in the first quarter.

site_title: US labels two Russian IS operatives 'global terrorists'
summary: The US State Department designated two Russian IS operatives, Aslan Avgazarovich Byutukaev and Ayrat Vakhitov, as "global terrorists". Byutukaev, a former Guantanamo detainee, is the IS leader in Chechnya and responsible for deadly attacks, including a 2011 Moscow airport bombing. Vakhitov, a former Guantanamo inmate, has fought for IS in Syria and recruited fighters online. The designation includes sanctions prohibiting US transactions with the two and blocks their assets under US jurisdiction.

site_title: Asia's budget carrier in big deals to retain lead
summary: AirAsia, Asia's largest budget carrier, has signed a deal with Airbus to purchase 100 A321neo jets valued at $12.6 billion, surpassing Boeing in the order tally. The deal is the largest purchase at this year's Farnborough Air Show and cements AirAsia's relationship with Airbus, which already has 380 planes on order. The aircraft will be used for destinations in Hong Kong, China, and Indonesia, and AirAsia has also expressed interest in expanding its services in India. The deal reflects the growing demand for low-cost air travel in Asia and AirAsia's success in revolutionizing the industry.

site_title: Being overweight, obese cuts lifespan by one to 10 years: study
summary: A large-scale study published in The Lancet found that being overweight or obese can cut a person's lifespan by 1-10 years, with the risk of premature death increasing "steadily and steeply" with an expanding waistline. The study analyzed data from almost 4 million adults on four continents and found that overweight individuals lost about 1 year of life expectancy, while moderately obese individuals lost about 3 years, and severely obese individuals lost about 10 years. The risk of coronary heart disease, stroke, and certain cancers also increased with excess weight.

site_title: Temasek unit scores knockout with One Championship deal
summary: Temasek Holdings' investment firm Heliconia Capital Management has signed a deal with One Championship, a Singapore-based MMA company. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The email was sent to One Championship's founder and chairman Chatri Sityodtong in April. This move marks a significant partnership between the two entities, and details of the deal are expected to be released in the coming days.

site_title: Pokemon-mania justifies Nintendo's mobile shift
summary: Nintendo's mobile gaming shift has proven successful with the release of Pokémon Go, justifying the company's decision to venture beyond consoles. The game has been downloaded millions of times and topped rankings worldwide. This marks a significant shift for Nintendo, which previously only focused on consoles. Investors are optimistic about the potential for future growth, and the game's success may open a new chapter for the company.

site_title: Taiwan seeks 2 Russians in ATM malware heists
summary: Taiwanese investigators suspect two Russian nationals hacked into First Bank's ATMs, using malware to withdraw over $2 million from 41 machines. The suspects may have used a cellphone to trigger the withdrawals, leaving the money and quickly fleeing. This is the first recorded ATM heist in Taiwan, and the incident shows growing boldness in ATM attacks in Asia. The Ministry of Justice has identified two Russian suspects, but their names have not been disclosed, and it is still investigating if a third person may have been involved.

site_title: 3M lighting solutions on trial in HDB corridors, carparks (Amended)
summary: 3M Singapore's Smart Urban Solutions Lab has launched trials for three locally developed lighting projects, including a 3M Channel Lighting System, 3M Flexible LED, and 3M Panel Lighting for Horticulture. The systems aim to reduce power consumption and maintenance in urban cities, with the Channel Lighting System cutting power consumption by up to 50%. The trials are part of a partnership between 3M and the Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore, with plans to bring the solutions to other countries after completion.

images.alt_text: Dr Olson demonstrating 3M's aluminium tube laminated with reflective film. The light from the panel, where his left hand is, comes from the light on the ceiling that is bouncing off the reflective film within the tube. "We have 13 projects now and we will probably have many more."

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady after four days of gains
summary: European stocks edged lower on Wednesday, settling 0.1% lower after four straight days of gains, despite a drop in oil and gas shares. The Stoxx 600 index remains near its highest level in over two weeks, supported by expectations of central bank stimulus measures and a rebound in banks' shares following favorable court rulings. The index is down 8% for 2016, but up 10% from its post-Brexit low point.

site_title: US dollar falls vs safe havens as risk appetite fades
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro, Swiss franc, and Japanese yen as risk appetite receded. The yen tumbled 4% against the US dollar, its worst performance since November 2014, after Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling coalition won a clear victory. The US dollar index fell 0.2% to 96.250, while the British pound also declined 0.7% against the US dollar. The Bank of Canada's decision to hold interest rates steady may provide clues about future central bank action.

site_title: Bank Negara makes surprise interest rate cut
summary: Bank Negara, Malaysia's central bank, cut the key lending rate by 25 basis points to 3% to boost the flagging economy, citing weak exports and domestic demand. The move is seen as a surprise given the recent rate stability, and analysts expect another possible cut in the next few months. The rate change aims to support growth and encourage businesses and consumers to spend, with inflation projected at 2-3%. The decision comes amid global monetary uncertainty due to Brexit and potential impacts on Malaysia's growth prospects, now forecast at 3.8-4%.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank has cut the key lending rate by 25 basis points in a bid to boost the flagging economy and minimise repercussions stemming from Britain's decision to exit the European Union.

site_title: Investors keep record cash on election fears: UBS
summary: Wealthy US investors are holding record cash balances due to uncertainty surrounding the Nov 8 presidential election, despite confidence in the economy. According to UBS executive Bob McCann, clients are hesitant to invest in retirement accounts because of the election's unpredictability. This trend is causing investors to prioritize cash reserves over investment opportunities, highlighting the potential impact of the election on the financial markets.

site_title: Ruling could help Japan project its maritime power: analysts
summary: Japan welcomes the Hague tribunal's ruling that invalidates China's claims to the South China Sea, seeing it as a justification for strengthening its own maritime power projection with the US. The ruling also creates a precedent for dealing with the disputed Senkaku Islands, with Japan potentially taking its claim to the tribunal. Analysts say the judgment could give Japan a strong regional role and provide a moral justification for Abe to amend Japan's post-war pacifist constitution.

site_title: Digital age means companies can be born global players: Iswaran
summary: Industry Minister S Iswaran says digital connectivity enables homegrown companies to become global players quickly, citing Singapore's advantage. He notes that the quality of offerings and ability to scale up fast determine success, with digital products and services scaling up exponentially. Examples of successful digital companies include Nintendo's Pokémon Go, which boosted the Japanese videogame maker's market capital by $9 billion, and Singapore-based Sing Lun Holdings, which can scale up with the right business model and capital. Iswaran emphasizes the need for a collaborative effort to develop economic strategies for Singapore's future.

site_title: Index providers replacing money managers as the most powerful players in global equity market
summary: MSCI Inc, a US-based index compiler, is replacing traditional money managers as the most powerful players in the global equity market. The company's influence stems from the growing popularity of passive investing, with 33% of equity funds in the US, Europe, and Asia mimicking index providers' security and country allocation decisions. MSCI's decisions have significant market impact, and the company's ability to influence the policy decisions of China's ruling Communist Party has cemented its status as a key arbiter of global stock investments.

site_title: GIC invests in fund that bought Korean logistics centre for US$130m
summary: GIC, a Singaporean sovereign investor, has invested in a real estate fund that acquired the Hyundai Logistics Distribution Centre in Icheon, South Korea for $130 million. The 126,708 square meter Grade A dry-storage logistics centre is fully master-leased to Hyundai Logistics until 2031. GIC believes in the potential of Korea's growing industrial sector, expecting a stable long-term income stream from the asset. The acquisition marks a landmark investment in South Korea's logistics properties market, with the fund's manager citing the centre's prime location and 15-year lease as attractive features.

site_title: SPH and StarHub announce free local data access to SPH mobile apps
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and StarHub have partnered to offer free local data access to nine SPH mobile apps for one year to StarHub Mobile Postpaid customers. The apps include popular titles such as The Straits Times, Berita Harian, and Lianhe Wanbao. This collaboration is part of a memorandum of understanding signed between the two companies in March, aiming to enhance content creation, advertising sales, and data analytics. The partnership is set to launch on Friday, providing users with unlimited local data access while using the apps.

site_title: Institutions doing more to boost infrastructure financing
summary: Financial institutions and development banks are exploring new ways to finance infrastructure development, including policy-based lending and results-based lending, to encourage private sector participation. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is also supporting public-private partnerships (PPPs) and has signed a transaction advisory services agreement with the Melaka Green Technology Corporation. Moody's credit ratings agency has introduced an industry-rating methodology for the infrastructure sector and a green bond assessment methodology to provide transparency and consistency. Despite an estimated $1 trillion annual shortfall in infrastructure funding, institutional investors have a significant amount of capital available, with $92 trillion available, but only a small portion allocated to infrastructure debt.

site_title: Ezra, 2 banks in share charge arrangements for Triyards stake
summary: Ezra Holdings has entered into share charge arrangements with DBS and OCBC, securing S$100m bank borrowings. The charge involves a combined 60.9% stake in its subsidiary Triyards, with 30.455% for each bank. Ezra has also pledged a 75.5% stake in Emas Offshore Limited to secure the loan. The arrangement is part of Ezra's capital financing strategy, with the shares expected to lapse at the end of the loan tenure.

site_title: Miami's 'Condo King' prepares to hand over empire to his sons
summary: Jorge Perez, Miami's "Condo King," is planning to step down as head of his company, Related Group, to focus on travel, philanthropy, and his art collection. His sons, Jon Paul and Nicholas, are expected to take over in a few years. Jon Paul, 31, is already working with his father, while Nicholas, 28, works for Related Cos, a partner on some Related Group projects. Perez's transition marks the end of an era for Miami's real estate landscape, with his sons poised to lead the company into its future.

site_title: Manulife abides by LIA rules on pay
summary: Manulife Singapore has clarified that it adheres to the Life Insurance Association Singapore's (LIA) rules on pay packages for insurance agents and financial advisers. Contrary to a previous article stating that Manulife offered packages exceeding 150% of past annual income, Manulife's pay packages comply with the LIA's recommended ceiling of 150%.

site_title: Saving for retirement in S'pore now takes 9 years more than before
summary: Singaporeans now need 9 years more to build a retirement nest egg than before, according to a HSBC report. The average Singaporean starts saving at 32 and continues for 29 years, compared to 39 years ago. Many respondents wish they had started saving earlier, citing difficulties and lack of information. The majority fund retirement with cash savings or downsized properties, and 21% expect to downsize a property. Experts stress the importance of diversification in savings plans, as Singaporeans tend to favor cash and property over other asset classes.

site_title: Google HQ plan given new life after Silicon Valley land swap
summary: Google's ambitious plan for its new Silicon Valley headquarters, featuring a glass canopy and moveable walls, has been given new life after a land swap with LinkedIn Corp. Google agreed to sell LinkedIn over 11.3 hectares of land in exchange for four sites, including a four-hectare plot in the North Bayshore area. The city of Mountain View now wants more residential buildings in the area, potentially altering Google's original plans, which would require reauthorization from the city council.

site_title: Keep an open mind on how UK handles the Brexit trilemma
summary: The UK's post-Brexit outlook is uncertain, with a "trilemma" of competing promises, EU/EEA rules, and single market participation. The UK's desires to control immigration, repatriate sovereign decision-making, and strike trade deals cannot be fulfilled without breaking one of these elements. The EU/EEA rules govern the four freedoms of movement, making it difficult to introduce immigration controls while maintaining single market inclusion. A compromise on "limits" or "emergency brakes" could be possible, but this would face resistance from EU member states. The UK's long-term status should reflect the democratic will of the majority, and its future trajectory is uncertain.

site_title: Brazil's designer brothers turn chaos into art
summary: Brazilian designer brothers Humberto and Fernando Campana create unusual, avant-garde furniture pieces using everyday discarded objects, such as cardboard, plastic packaging, and woven rope. Their work, which often incorporates materials found in Brazil's slums, has made them renowned in the design world, with pieces selling for thousands of dollars in top modern art institutions like MoMA and the Centre Pompidou. The brothers' aim is to "imitate how people improvise shelter" and showcase Brazil's unique "know-how" in design.

site_title: Tesla defends its self-driving technology amid US safety probe
summary: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has launched an investigation into the fatal crash of a Tesla driver using Autopilot, which killed Joshua Brown on May 7. Despite acknowledging the system's failure to apply brakes, Tesla defends Autopilot as safe when properly used, and the company plans to educate owners on how to use it safely. The NHTSA seeks data on the system's performance, including miles driven with Autosteer activated and warnings given to drivers to take control. Tesla officials argue that driver misuse, rather than the system's failure, is the primary cause of accidents, but critics question the technology's safety and the risks of false sense of security.

site_title: Deciphering SingPost's governance review report
summary: A corporate governance review report by Heidrick & Struggles for Singapore Post (SingPost) was published on July 4, but its executive summary is difficult to understand due to consultant jargon. The report's findings and recommendations are largely what would be expected, with some being overtaken by recent company policies. The report recommends a strict tenure limit for board members, appointing a legal expert, and a board size of around 10 directors, but lacks clear explanations for some of its recommendations. The new SingPost board is taking steps to improve corporate governance, but the report's complexity and lack of clarity may hinder its effectiveness.

site_title: Abe adviser urges fiscal and monetary stimulus at the same time
summary: A key economic adviser to Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, Koichi Hamada, has suggested boosting fiscal and monetary stimulus at the same time, playing down the likelihood of employing "helicopter money" to combat Japan's struggling economy. The government is preparing a fiscal stimulus package and the Bank of Japan will consider the impact of the package in its quarterly projections. Analysts expect the package to be worth around 10 trillion yen, which could offset downward pressure on prices and help the BOJ meet its inflation target.

site_title: Over one-third of consumers have suffered card fraud: report
summary: A new study by ACI Worldwide and Aite Group found that 36% of consumers in Singapore have experienced card fraud in the past five years. The most common risky behavior among Singapore respondents was throwing away papers with account numbers in the trash bin. This highlights the need for improved security measures to prevent card fraud.

images.alt_text: Thirty-six per cent of consumers in Singapore have experienced card fraud in the past five years, according to a new study done by ACI Worldwide and Aite Group.

site_title: Jin Jiang not checking into AccorHotels board for now
summary: French hotel group AccorHotels has temporarily put off Jin Jiang's potential board seat, alleviating concerns of a possible takeover. Jin Jiang, the world's seventh-largest hotel group, has increased its stake in AccorHotels from 5% to over 15% and sparked French concerns of a potential takeover. However, Jin Jiang vice-president Chen Liming confirmed that the company is in talks with AccorHotels but has no intention to take control. This decision comes after French President Francois Hollande warned Jin Jiang against a potential takeover.

site_title: China building more coal-fired power: Greenpeace
summary: China is building 200 GW of coal-fired power capacity despite new measures to cut fossil fuel use and tackle overcapacity. The expansion is part of a rapid growth in thermal power, with 24 GW added in the first five months of 2016. Greenpeace warns that this could lead to a surplus of 400 GW and up to $200 billion in "wasted" investment. China aims to cap coal-fired capacity at 1,050 GW by 2020 and has set up a warning system for provinces on overcapacity.

site_title: RBI braces for Basel battle on state debt
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is opposing proposed changes to the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision's global regulatory framework, which would increase capital charges on sovereign bonds held by Indian banks. With 30% of their assets in government debt, Indian banks would face higher capital requirements, exacerbating their struggles with surging bad loans. The RBI, led by Governor Raghuram Rajan, is joined in opposition by countries such as Italy, arguing that the changes could destabilize the financial system. The Basel Committee is considering four options, including revising risk-weighted and large-exposure rules, to reflect the "risky nature of public debt".

site_title: Worker shortage to prolong decline in US oil production
summary: US oil production is expected to decline further due to a worker shortage. Despite a rebound in the rig count, the industry still faces challenges in quickly recovering due to layoffs and equipment idling. An estimated 350,000 oil industry workers have been laid off globally, and the US rig count is significantly lower than two years ago. This shortage hinders the industry's ability to respond quickly to changes in oil prices, potentially prolonging the decline in US oil production.

site_title: Yanlord to develop site in Suzhou with China Ping An Insurance unit
summary: Yanlord Land Group has partnered with China Ping An Insurance Group's unit to jointly develop a 295,000 square meter integrated development in Suzhou city's Gusu District. Yanlord acquired a 30% stake in the project company, which holds a prime residential site acquired for RMB4 billion (S$805 million). The project will feature amenities such as shopping malls, hospitals, and schools. This is Yanlord's second joint venture with China Ping An Insurance, following a similar partnership in Tianjin. The move is seen as an opportunity to capitalize on favorable market sentiments in Suzhou city.

site_title: PE firms see new allure in old-world Indian retail
summary: Private equity firms, including Blackstone and Xander Group, are investing in Indian retail malls, betting on the growing middle class and foreign brands entering the market. With new regulations easing foreign investment and online discounts, malls are seen as a gateway to high-end brands. The sector is expected to see faster rental growth and higher yields, with retail rents rising by up to 20% in some malls. The influx of investment could revive India's sluggish real estate market and kick-start projects.

images.alt_text: Private equity (PE) investors like Blackstone and Rothschild-backed Xander Group are looking for malls in India, betting that people will flock to stores as more foreign brands open and online retailers ease their aggressive discounting.

site_title: IE Singapore plans consortium to win China sponge city projects
summary: Singapore plans to form a consortium to bid for China's sponge city projects, which aim to build cities that can better harvest rainwater through urban underground water systems. Led by International Enterprise (IE) Singapore, the consortium will include large corporates and SMEs, such as Surbana Jurong and Hyflux, to offer water management solutions. The project is part of China's 20% target for modern sewer infrastructure by 2020 and 80% by 2030, with a budget of 600 million yuan (S$121 million) for pilot cities. The consortium will target sponge city projects in Jiangsu and Zhejiang, with presentations to be made in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Private condo rents flat, HDB rents dip in June: SRX Property
summary: Singapore's private condo rents remained flat in June, while HDB flat rents dipped 0.3% from May, according to SRX Property's flash estimates. Non-landed private home rents in the city fringe increased 0.8%, while those in the Core Central Region and Outside Central Region decreased 0.4% and 0.3% respectively. HDB flat rental volumes fell 0.5% to 1,826 transactions, with three and four-room flats experiencing a 1.3% and 0.3% drop in rents, respectively.

site_title: Japan's emperor intends to abdicate in a few years: NHK
summary: Japanese Emperor Akihito, 82, intends to abdicate in a few years, a move unprecedented in modern Japan. The decision comes after the monarch has had heart surgery and prostate cancer treatment. Akihito expressed his intention to the Imperial Household Agency, paving the way for a potential transition. This step is seen as a significant change for the Japanese monarchy, with Akihito's abdication marking a new era in the country's history.

site_title: EU, US launch controversial Internet privacy deal
summary: The European Union and the US have launched the "Privacy Shield" deal, aimed at curbing government spying on European citizens' personal Internet data. The new agreement sets out tough rules to prevent US intelligence agencies from accessing Europeans' data, with companies facing penalties if they do not meet European standards. Critics argue the deal still fails to provide sufficient protection from American surveillance and lacks legal redress, potentially facing court challenges. Companies must self-certify as compliant by August 1, with the deal subject to an annual review.

site_title: Brexit not deterring UK race fans from Singapore Grand Prix
summary: Despite the UK's Brexit vote, it is expected to be one of the largest source markets for the Singapore Grand Prix, with a 41% week-on-week increase in travel from the UK to Singapore for the event. According to Sojern, a travel data marketing firm, interest from the UK remains strong, with a significant number of UK fans planning to attend the event from September 16-18. This trend suggests that the UK's departure from the EU has not deterred fans from traveling to Singapore for the event.

images.alt_text: Regions which will clock a jump in travel to Singapore during race week vis-a-vis the week before include East Asia (104 per cent), Western Europe (19 per cent) and Oceania (46 per cent).

site_title: Ikea extends furniture recall to China after criticism
summary: Ikea extends its furniture recall to China after two weeks of public pressure, following a US recall of 29 million pieces due to toddler deaths. The company initially excluded China and Europe from the recall, citing local regulations. Ikea will now recall 1.7 million chests and dressers in China, citing consumer safety as a priority. The move marks the growing power of the Chinese consumer, who demands safety and quality, and reflects the country's increasingly stringent regulation of consumer products.

site_title: Force of law or law of force? The ball is in China's court
summary: China's refusal to participate in a Hague-based international tribunal's ruling on the South China Sea has sparked concerns of rising tensions. The tribunal found China has no legal basis to claim "historic rights" to islands in the sea and has violated the sovereign rights of the Philippines. China's dismissal of international law may lead to a military confrontation with the US and other regional powers, including Japan, South Korea, and Australia. Beijing's actions could damage its reputation among Asian nations and undermine its interests. China has an opportunity to break the "logic of international relations" by adopting a more diplomatic approach.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages ends agreement to buy Auckland shopping centre
summary: Global Yellow Pages has terminated an agreement to buy the Hunters Plaza Shopping Centre in Auckland for NZ$45.6 million. The decision comes after a due diligence investigation identified key issues, leading to unsuccessful negotiations with the vendor, Talavera Retail. The company cited these issues as the reason for terminating the agreement.

site_title: CiticEnv's Memstar opens membrane production facility
summary: CiticEnv's Memstar has opened a 5,100 square metre membrane production facility in Singapore, doubling its production capacity to 10 million square metres per year. The facility is part of a $25 million investment and enables quick testing and prototyping of new technologies. Memstar has also signed an agreement with Hydranautics to design, produce and sell containerised membrane systems for water purification and recycling. The system uses the company's 3G-TIPS membranes and is targeted at providing cost-effective water-treatment solutions to remote communities.

site_title: New PSLE scoring system to be based on pupils' raw scores
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Education has introduced a new PSLE scoring system based on pupils' raw scores in four examinable subjects, replacing the current T-score system. Under the new system, pupils will receive an Achievement Level (AL) in each subject, with a total score ranging from 4 to 32. The goal is to reduce fine differentiation, competition, and anxiety among pupils, allowing for more choices in secondary schools and better matching of pupils with their interests and learning needs. The new system will take effect in 2021.

site_title: Sim Lian prices Treasure Crest at an average S$742 psf
summary: Sim Lian Group Limited priced its executive condominium project Treasure Crest at an average S$742 per square foot, with prices starting from S$649,000 for a three-bedroom unit. The 504-unit project is over 2.1 times subscribed, with 1,077 e-applications and 4,000 visitors to the sales gallery during the e-application period. Balloting and booking will take place this Saturday. The company attributes the strong response to the project's attractive pricing, ideal location, and spacious unit layouts.

site_title: Legal activists seek to block Indonesia's tax amnesty plan
summary: Indonesian legal activists filed a request for judicial review of the country's tax amnesty law, claiming it protects money launderers and tax evaders. The law, signed by President Joko Widodo, aims to bring in billions of dollars stashed overseas, but activists argue it contains at least 21 constitutional violations and will harm anti-graft efforts. The Constitutional Court has received the request and will hold a preliminary hearing 14 days after required documents are filed, despite policymakers defending the plan as carefully prepared.

site_title: Amazon Prime Day sales up 30% for third-party merchants
summary: Amazon's Prime Day sales from third-party merchants surged 30% compared to last year, driven by international demand, particularly in the US and UK. Despite initial technical glitches, the event saw a record number of items sold by small businesses and sellers. Amazon offered more deals and deeper inventory this year, relying on thousands of third-party merchants to boost sales. Prime membership continues to grow, fueling a larger number of shoppers onto the site and mobile apps.

site_title: Genting M'sia shares down 3.6% since Brexit vote
summary: Genting Malaysia Bhd, a major casino group in Asia, saw its shares decline 3.6% since the Brexit vote due to investors' uncertainty about the UK gaming market. The company's exposure to the UK is significant, with 43 casinos, and its parent's ringgit bonds yielded 145 basis points more than the sovereign. Analysts predict a one-per-cent drop in earnings per share for Genting Malaysia for every 10-per-cent slide in the pound-ringgit rate. The pound's weakening has also led to a 24% increase in revenue from UK casinos in the last quarter.

site_title: Circular economy is key to reducing waste, say waste managers
summary: Singapore's waste generation has increased by 45% in a decade, with 800,000 tonnes of food waste generated last year. Industry experts say businesses embracing the "circular economy" concept can reduce waste by reusing products at the end of their life cycle. IKEA and other companies are investing in recycling services and product design to close the loop, citing benefits such as cost savings and enhanced customer experience. Experts see significant investment opportunities in this area, with companies like Caterpillar and Greenpac reaping revenue from remanufacturing and efficient use of resources.

site_title: Former BSI Asia chief exec sues bank over bonus
summary: Hans Peter Brunner, former Asia chief executive of BSI SA, has sued the Swiss private bank over frozen bonus payments.
