Brunner alleges BSI breached bonus agreements and a separation pact, claiming there's no basis for suspending his deferred bonuses. Brunner is among six BSI bankers referred to Singapore prosecutors amid a global probe into 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), a client of BSI. Brunner has not been charged and BSI has declined to comment on the lawsuit.

site_title: Nissan unveils its driver-assist system
summary: Nissan has unveiled its driver-assist system, ProPilot, which enables its new Serena minivan to handle some highway driving on its own. The system, available in Japan next month, sends warnings when drivers take their hands off the wheel and will eventually disable if prompts are ignored. Nissan's move comes as regulators scrutinize Tesla's similar Autopilot technology following a series of crashes. Nissan plans to extend ProPilot to Europe, the US, and China, and will add autonomous-driving functions step-by-step, including lane-changing and urban road navigation, by 2020.

site_title: Make tech support a valuable business pillar
summary: Singapore's telcos and banks face scrutiny for poor tech support, with customers increasingly demanding more personalized and efficient service. Despite the criticism, the telcos and banks claim to prioritize customer engagement, with M1, Singtel, and StarHub investing in digital channels and commissioning customer loyalty audits. Banking institutions, such as DBS and OCBC, also report improved tech support efficiency, with average resolution times and target response times. As the industry continues to evolve, companies are recognizing the importance of tech support in delivering a consistent customer experience and driving long-term success.

site_title: NTU, NEA in tie-up to build incinerator research facility
summary: Researchers at Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and the National Environment Agency (NEA) are working together to build an incinerator research facility in Singapore. The project aims to develop technology to recycle ash from incineration plants, which could be used as a construction material. The goal is to make ash available on the surface of buildings, reducing waste disposal costs and environmental impact. The project is expected to be completed by 2018, with potential applications in Singapore and other countries.

site_title: It's not a civil war but a nation divided
summary: US police officers were killed in a shooting in Dallas, Texas, by a lone gunman, Micah Johnson, in July 2016. The incident sparked widespread outrage and fears of a national schism, echoing the 1960s period of racial tensions and violent protests. The shooting was seen as retaliation for police killings of African Americans, including two incidents in Louisiana and Minnesota earlier that week. The event highlighted the growing resentment among white Americans against affirmative action and policies aimed at improving the status of minority groups. Donald Trump's presidential campaign was seen as a driving force behind this resentment, fueling his ethno-nationalist agenda.

site_title: Financing retirement needs by extracting housing equity
summary: Singapore - A panel discussion on life-cycle financing for ageing populations agreed that extracting housing equity is a better way to finance retirement needs in Asia than annuities. This approach is seen as more effective for Asian cities, where populations are rapidly ageing. Governments are also expected to step in to mitigate tail risks, such as when seniors outlive their home leases. The discussion highlighted the need for alternative solutions to address the financial security of seniors in the region.

site_title: Yen under pressure as global stock markets rally
summary: The yen lost ground against the dollar, extending a 4% decline since the start of the week, as risk appetite rebounded in the European session. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling coalition won upper house elections, fuelling expectations of more fiscal stimulus. The dollar recovered lost ground, trading at 104.80 yen, while the euro rose 0.2% to 116.02 yen. Investors are buying riskier assets, putting the yen under pressure, and analysts expect the yen to bounce back if Japan disappoints with stimulus.

site_title: Wanda's AMC buys Odeon cinemas
summary: AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc has purchased Odeon & UCI Cinemas Group for US$1.2 billion, expanding Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin's movie theatre empire into Europe. The deal leaves the fate of AMC's deal for Carmike Cinemas Inc. uncertain, with CEO Adam Aron stating they will engage in dialogue to salvage the deal. The acquisition extends Wang Jianlin's movie theatre empire globally, solidifying his position as a major player in the film industry.

site_title: 'Bond King' hints at big money if stocks fail to stay near current highs
summary: "Bond King" Jeffrey Gundlach predicts "big money" for those betting against stocks if they fail to stay near current highs. He has been selectively betting against the Standard & Poor's 500 index and favors emerging-market bonds over high-yield debt. Gundlach warned investors last week that the 10-year Treasury yield is a "terrible trade location" and sees it settling around 1.7% as a near-term base case. He also defends his stance on high-yield junk bonds, citing their "dangerous" recovery rates.

images.alt_text: Mr Gundlach, who is known for his bold, prescient predictions including last year's oil-price plunge and China's slowdown, has defended his stance on high-yield junk bonds.

site_title: US crude stockpiles fall less than expected: EIA
summary: US crude oil stockpiles decreased by 2.5 million barrels last week, lower than the expected 3 million barrel drop. Gasoline stocks rose 1.2 million barrels, contrary to the 432,000-barrel drop forecast. Distillate inventories surged 4.1 million barrels, exceeding the 256,000-barrel increase predicted. Refinery crude runs fell 143,000 barrels per day, and US crude imports decreased 522,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Oil down 2% on IEA warning, fear of US stockpile rise
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Wednesday after the International Energy Agency (IEA) warned of a global supply glut threatening market recovery. Crude stockpiles rose last month, pushing floating storage to a 7-year high, and the IEA predicted a possible rise in US inventories. Brent crude dropped $1 to $47.47 a barrel, while US crude fell 80 cents to $46. The US government's Energy Information Administration will issue official inventory data later, which could further impact prices.

site_title: Fantasy epic Game of Thrones tipped to top Emmys nods
summary: The 2016 Emmy Awards nominations are expected to favor Game of Thrones, with HBO's fantasy epic tipped to dominate the field after winning 12 awards last year, including best drama series. Other top contenders include Mr Robot and The People v OJ Simpson: American Crime Story. The limited series category is expected to feature a number of nods for shows tackling racial issues, including The People v OJ Simpson and Roots. The nominations will be announced on Thursday, with the awards ceremony set to take place on September 18.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow ease back after hitting new highs
summary: US stocks eased back from new highs after a three-day record-setting rally amid signs of a steadying global economy. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average touched new intraday highs before closing at record levels, with the S&P setting a new record of 2,156.45 and the Dow hitting 18,390.16. Investors now await corporate earnings results to see if stocks justify market valuations, with second-quarter earnings expected to fall 5% but growth expected in the second half of 2016.

site_title: Cameron urges incoming premier Theresa May to stay close to EU
summary: Outgoing British Prime Minister David Cameron urged his successor Theresa May to remain close to the European Union, positioning Britain as close to the EU as possible. This comes after Britons voted to leave the EU in last month's referendum, contradicting Cameron's wishes. Cameron handed over to May on Wednesday, following his final weekly question session in parliament.

site_title: US economy performing despite headwinds, leaders must cooperate: Lew
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew stated that the US economy is performing steadily despite global headwinds, emphasizing the need for cooperation among leaders to promote shared economic growth. Lew met with British finance minister George Osborne to discuss the UK's post-Brexit relationship, urging flexibility in negotiations.

site_title: Brexit raises questions about pound's elite status
summary: Britain's vote to leave the European Union has led to a 14% slide in the pound, its largest drop since the 1973 floating exchange rate system, and raises questions about its elite status as a reserve currency. The pound's share in international reserves has been declining, with the US dollar and euro taking its place, and could potentially drop below 3% if it continues. This could lead to a weaker and more volatile pound in the long term, affecting Britain's ability to fund its chronic current account deficit and its credit rating.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.42 points to close at 1,660.39 on Wednesday, driven by a strong trading volume of 1.7 billion lots valued at RM2.37 billion. The market saw 523 gains and 280 losses.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:

The US stock market opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from President Trump on Canada. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. No major changes were reported in the financial sector.

site_title: Indonesia hopes fishermen can net its South China Sea claims
summary: Indonesia plans to send hundreds of fishermen to the Natuna Islands to assert its sovereignty over the South China Sea, which China claims as part of its "nine-dash line". The move comes after the Permanent Court of Arbitration rejected China's claims, and Indonesia objects to China's inclusion of Natuna waters within its claims. The government aims to boost fishing in Natuna waters and upgrade the island's infrastructure, with the relocation of fishermen from Java set to begin by the end of October. The plan is seen as a way to bolster Indonesia's sovereignty and promote regional stability.

site_title: Google says anti-piracy effort has delivered US$2b
summary: Google announced that its anti-piracy efforts on YouTube have generated $2 billion in payments to copyright holders whose content is shown on the platform. The system has been producing income since 2012, and Google is now offering more convenient, legitimate alternatives for consumers to purchase music, films, and other content.

site_title: Brexit strengthens case for LSE-Deutsche Boerse merger: Bundesbank
summary: The UK's decision to leave the EU has strengthened the business case for a merger between the London Stock Exchange and Deutsche Boerse, according to Bundesbank board member Andreas Dombret. The merged entity could serve as a bridge between the UK and Germany's economies post-Brexit. London Clearing House, a major euro clearing operation, is likely to relocate to Frankfurt, and euro-denominated trading is unlikely to continue outside the EU. Dombret warned against circumventing bank regulations, particularly bail-in rules, and urged eurozone countries to respect these rules.

site_title: US import prices rise modestly on weak consumer, capital goods
summary: US import prices rose 0.2% in June, less than expected, due to declining consumer and capital goods prices. This modest increase was offset by rising petroleum product costs. The 12-month decline in import prices was 4.8%, the smallest since November 2014. Economists believe the dollar's surge since 2014 continues to dampen imported inflation pressures, keeping inflation below the Federal Reserve's 2% target.

site_title: Opec delegates say Saudi comments show higher oil price desire
summary: Saudi Arabia's top oil minister, Khalid al-Falih, has expressed a desire for an oil price above $50 to achieve a balance in oil markets, contrasting with previous statements. This shift in tone suggests the kingdom may be looking to prop up the market, but no actual policy shift or supply cuts are expected. Opec delegates see this as a positive sign, with some hoping for a stronger market to support oil prices, which have fallen to half their level two years ago.

site_title: Ikea recalls furniture in China after North America move
summary: Ikea is recalling over 1.6 million cabinets and items in China due to potential safety hazards, following a similar move in North America. The recalled items, made between 1999 and 2016, may fall over if not properly fixed to the wall, posing a risk to children. The company is offering free wall fittings and installation or full refunds to affected customers, and has apologized to Chinese consumers. Six children died in North America due to similar accidents, but no fatal incidents have occurred in China.

site_title: China sets up state-owned aircraft engine maker
summary: China has established a state-owned aircraft engine manufacturer, as part of its efforts to develop home-grown, high-tech capabilities. The State-Owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission will inject capital into the new company, which will be part of the Aviation Industry Corp of China. This move aims to push Chinese products and services up the value chain, particularly in areas like aircraft engines, high-speed rail, and nuclear power. The goal is to compete with international markets, including US aircraft engine maker Pratt & Whitney.

site_title: Japan emperor intends to abdicate "in a few years": NHK
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito, 82, intends to abdicate in a few years, a step unprecedented in modern Japan. The decision, made to the Imperial Household Agency, comes after the monarch has been cutting back on official duties and handing over responsibilities to his heir, Crown Prince Naruhito. Emperor Akihito's intentions are seen as a departure from his previous remarks on World War II, with some interpreting his recent expression of "deep remorse" as an effort to cement a legacy of pacifism.

site_title: Cameron bows out with jokes, May to take over as British PM
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron resigned on July 13, 2016, after the UK's vote to leave the European Union. Theresa May, a safe pair of hands, will succeed him as the country's second woman prime minister. May, who campaigned for Remain, will focus on executing Brexit and uniting a divided nation. She plans to set up a new government department to lead the EU exit process and has vowed to make the exit a success. Markets reacted positively to her appointment, with sterling making strong gains against the dollar and euro.

images.alt_text: David Cameron entertained parliament with a series of farewell quips on Wednesday in his last appearance as prime minister before making way for Theresa May to lead the monumental task of extricating Britain from the European Union.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 1-month high, won firmer on global risk appetite
summary: South Korean stocks reached a one-month high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing 0.7% up at 2,005.55 points. The won also strengthened, rising 0.1% to 1,146.4 to the dollar, as global risk appetite increased following Wall Street's record high. Offshore investors bought a net 582 billion won worth of Kospi shares, extending their buying streak to five sessions.

site_title: Fed policy change on the table but data dependent: Mester
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Loretta Mester stated that a change in interest rates will be on the table at every Fed meeting, but timing will depend on the economy's performance. She sees a gradual upward path for rates, but believes policy is not currently behind the curve on inflation.

site_title: Yanlord ties up with China Ping An Insurance unit to develop site in Suzhou
summary: Yanlord Land Group has partnered with Shenzhen Lianxin Investment Management Co, a unit of China Ping An Insurance, to develop a 295,000-square-metre integrated development in Suzhou's Gusu District. Yanlord acquired a 30% stake in the project, which includes a prime residential site acquired through a public land auction for 4 billion yuan. The site is connected to key thoroughfares and metro stations, offering residents amenities like shopping malls, hospitals, and schools. The project is expected to be developed in the future.

site_title: STI advances for third straight day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.83 points to 2,910.65, its third consecutive gain for the week, bringing its year-to-date gain to 28 points or about 1%. This follows Wall Street's second consecutive all-time high, with Japan and Hong Kong also experiencing gains. The STI's rise was driven by a "risk on" market sentiment, with an average turnover of 1.9 billion units worth S$1.1 billion.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars hold gains as commodities rally
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars gained ground, with the Australian dollar reaching a three-month high at US$0.7650 and the New Zealand dollar hitting its highest in over a year at US$0.7325. The gains were driven by a rally in global risk appetite and a decline in the Japanese yen, as investors bet on more policy stimulus. Commodities, including iron ore, also contributed to the surge.

site_title: Hague ruling shows how seas, oceans are global commons
summary: The Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague has ruled that China's claims in the South China Sea have no legal basis, declaring the seas and oceans a global commons. China's nine-dash line has been deemed invalid, and its maritime features in the Spratly Islands are not considered natural islands. The ruling is a significant victory for the Philippines, but China has rejected it, with President Xi Jinping expected to continue advancing territorial claims through non-military means. The ruling's impact is uncertain, with the Philippines and other nations likely to engage in back-channel negotiations to manage the situation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post third straight gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a third consecutive session on July 13, 2023, following a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.46% to 21,322.37, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.37% to 3,060.69 and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.82% to 2,041.66. The gains were in line with an Asia-wide rally, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Sterling firm with eyes on new prime minister's Brexit view
summary: Sterling rose to a two-week high against the euro as Theresa May took over as Britain's prime minister, easing Brexit uncertainty. May has said "Brexit means Brexit," but indicated the UK won't rush to trigger Article 50. Traders await clarity on the new prime minister's views on the EU exit and potential single market access. Sterling rose 0.1% to $1.3270, while the euro fell 0.3% to 83.25 pence. Market uncertainty remains due to the UK's current account deficit and potential interest rate cuts.

site_title: Abe's stimulus plan to moderate any BOJ price f'cast cuts: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan will factor in Japan's planned fiscal stimulus package in its quarterly projections, which may moderate any cuts to its inflation forecasts. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus package, expected to be around 10 trillion yen, could boost consumption and offset the impact of a delayed sales tax hike. Analysts say the package is aimed at beating deflation, and the BOJ's consideration of its impact is a departure from its usual reluctance to factor in fiscal stimulus packages. This move may help moderate any price forecast cuts.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher as STI gains for third straight session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed higher for the third consecutive session, gaining 8.83 points to 2,910.65, bringing its 2016 rise to 28 points or 1%. The index's performance was boosted by Wall Street's all-time high and rises in Japan and Hong Kong. Singtel was the standout performer, rising 17.4% this year and outperforming the local STI. The index's three-session gain was reinforced by a "risk on" market sentiment, despite Dow futures trading in the red.

site_title: Opec producer sees oil at US$60 until 2018 with demand picking up
summary: Kuwait's acting oil minister predicts crude oil will rise to a range of $50-$60 a barrel until at least 2018 as demand increases and markets absorb an oversupply, citing a successful strategy by Opec to balance the oil market. Demand is expected to pick up in the fourth quarter, with Kuwait aiming to produce 4 million barrels a day by 2020, and other producers, including Royal Dutch Shell and BP, have signed agreements to work on oil deposits to support this goal.

site_title: China claims right to declare air defence zone
summary: China has declared its right to declare an air defence identification zone over the South China Sea, despite an international tribunal ruling against its expansive claims in the strategic waters. China's Vice-Foreign Minister Liu Zhenmin warned that the country "has the right" to declare the zone, but its decision depends on the level of threat. The ruling comes after the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) tribunal in The Hague backed the Philippines' case that there was no legal basis for China's claims. China has described the ruling as "a piece of waste paper" and has vowed to defend its territorial claims, with Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen sending a naval frigate to patrol the disputed waterway.

images.alt_text: China warned it "has the right" to declare an air defence identification zone over the South China Sea as it stepped up denunciations of an international tribunal that ruled against its expansive claims in the strategic waters.

site_title: Oil prices dip in Asia as oversupply worries return
summary: Oil prices dropped in Asia on Wednesday after a rise in US stockpiles, sparking concerns about a supply glut. The American Petroleum Institute reported a 2.2 million barrel increase in reserves last week, contradicting expectations of a decrease. Oil prices sank 1.09% to US$46.29 for West Texas Intermediate and 1.24% to US$47.87 for Brent. Analysts attribute the drop to profit-takers after the previous day's rally and the potential return of oversupply due to increased production from producers outside OPEC.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Amended)
summary: The average Singaporean saves 9 years more for retirement than their predecessors, with a starting age of 32 and 29-year duration. In contrast, predecessors started at 39 and saved for 20 years. Meanwhile, Malaysia's central bank cut its benchmark rate by 25 basis points, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow. Vietnam reacted to the US tariff announcement, while the Asian garment industry braced for higher tariffs. The UK economy also shrank for the second month, dealing a blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: China imports down 2.3% on year in June: government
summary: China's imports fell 2.3% year-on-year in June, with exports rising 1.3% and the monthly trade surplus increasing 12.8% to 311.2 billion yuan. Weakening commodity prices are attributed to the decline in import values. China's imports and exports both fell in the first half of the year, with 4.7% and 2.1% declines respectively. The decline in business with major trading partners such as the US and ASEAN is seen as an obstacle to China's foreign trade development.

site_title: Most major conventional oil projects at risk at US$50 oil price
summary: Major conventional oil projects are at risk of cancellation or deferral at a US$50 oil price, according to Wood Mackenzie. The consultancy found that global upstream spending has dropped by over US$1 trillion since 2014. Deepwater projects in west Africa and non-OPEC nations are particularly unviable at the current price. However, cost cuts have increased the percentage of projects viable below US$60 a barrel to 70%, with around 9 million barrels per day commercially viable at US$60 a barrel. Many projects are expected to move forward in 2017.

images.alt_text: Most major conventional oil projects are at risk of cancellation or deferral if global prices remain at US$50 a barrel, consultancy Wood Mackenzie said in a report on Wednesday.

site_title: GIC invests in real estate fund which has acquired Hyundai Logistics Distribution Centre for US$130m (Amended)
summary: Singapore's GIC invests in a real estate fund that acquired the Hyundai Logistics Distribution Centre in Icheon, South Korea for $130 million. The 126,708 sq m grade-A dry storage logistics centre is fully master-leased to Hyundai Logistics, a top-tier logistics company in South Korea. GIC sees potential in Korea's growing industrial sector and expects a stable long-term income stream. The acquisition is a landmark investment in South Korea's logistics properties market, with a 15-year long-term master lease and prime location.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.2% to 6,668.61 points. This decline follows recent strong gains. British Prime Minister David Cameron steps down after the UK's vote to quit the EU, with Theresa May taking over as the new prime minister. In the eurozone, Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also fell, with the CAC 40 dipping less than 0.1%.

site_title: Citic Envirotech unit sinks S$25m into new HQ, research hub and production facility
summary: Citic Envirotech's subsidiary Memstar is investing S$25 million in a new international headquarters, research centre, and manufacturing facility in Singapore. The facility will double production capacity to 10 million square metres a year, enabling faster testing and commercialization of new technologies. The company also signed an agreement with Hydranautics to design and sell containerized membrane systems for water purification and wastewater recycling, targeting communities in remote areas. This new product reduces civil work and installation costs, making it a cost-effective alternative to traditional water plant construction.

site_title: Pokemon Go unleashes legions of monster hunters
summary: Pokémon Go, a free mobile game that overlays real-world locations, has triggered a craze in the US, Australia, and New Zealand since its release last week. Players use GPS and mapping capabilities to find and hunt cartoon monsters, with some spending hours playing and socializing with others. The game has been downloaded 7.5 million times in the US, generating $1.6 million in daily sales, and has sparked concerns about player safety and data collection. Despite warnings from authorities, many businesses have welcomed the game, and its popularity shows no signs of slowing down.

site_title: China to slow energy project construction, shifts to capacity cuts: Xinhua
summary: China plans to slow energy project construction and shift to capacity cuts, aiming to cap total national energy consumption at 5 billion tonnes of standard coal equivalent by 2020. The government will ban new coal-based chemical facilities and coal-fired power plants until 2018, reducing coal's share to 58% from 64%. China will also shed overcapacity in coal mining and oil refining, phasing out 500 million tonnes of coal production by 2020.

site_title: Malaysia central bank surprises by cutting benchmark rate by 25 basis points
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, surprised markets by cutting its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.00% on July 13, 2016. The move aims to maintain steady economic growth amid stable inflation and healthy financial intermediation. This is the first rate cut since July 2014, when the rate was raised by 25 basis points to curb rising household debt. The decision was contrary to economists' expectations of no change.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank surprised markets by cutting its key interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.00 per cent on Wednesday, saying uncertainties in the global environment could weigh on the country's growth prospects.

site_title: Know how to strike a trade deal? Brexit Britain wants you fast
summary: The UK, seeking to strike a trade deal following its Brexit vote, is on the hunt for experienced trade negotiators. The government aims to assemble a team of up to 300 specialized employees by the end of the year. Companies are also hiring top lawyers and consultants, with some firms like Goldman Sachs offering former European Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso as an adviser. The task is complex, with the UK needing to replicate the EU's dozens of trade agreements and negotiate with major economies like China and the US.

images.alt_text: The UK's vote to leave the European Union has hit the pound, squelched company mergers and cast a pall over corporate profits. For one niche profession - trade negotiators - it has created a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit Q2 DPU falls 3.1% on bigger unitholder base
summary: SOILBUILD Reit reported a 3.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter, reaching 1.565 Singapore cents, due to a larger unitholder base. Income available for distribution increased 3% to S$14.7 million, mainly driven by a reduction in property tax expenses. The company's DPU was lower than the same period last year, despite a higher income available for distribution.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index ends just shy of pre-Brexit level
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.84% on Wednesday, closing at 16,231.43, just shy of their pre-Brexit level. The Nikkei 225 and Topix index gained 0.84% and 1.13%, respectively, as investors welcomed stimulus hopes. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data. The rally was also attributed to traders brushing off new Trump threats, and US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks retreat from nearly 4-month high; TSMC down
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.04% on Wednesday, retreating from a nearly four-month high. The main TAIEX index closed at 8,837.89 points. Tech heavyweight Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) led the decline, dropping 1.8%. The electronics subindex also fell 0.4%. Investors took profit after the previous session's gains, with TSMC's decline being the largest contributor to the decline.

site_title: Theresa May prepares to take over as Brexit PM
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron steps down, and Theresa May takes his place, becoming Britain's second female prime minister. May will form a government, but European leaders urge her to quickly renegotiate the UK's relationship with the EU. May faces significant challenges, including bridging Conservative Party divisions, dealing with potential economic downturns, and convincing Brexit supporters she will implement the referendum result.

site_title: NEA and NTU to develop new waste-to-energy incineration research facility
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) has signed a collaboration agreement with Nanyang Technological University (NTU) to co-fund a $40 million waste-to-energy research facility in Singapore. The facility, expected to be completed by late 2018, will house a next-generation gasification incinerator capable of producing synthetic gas for commercial use or electricity generation. The project aims to support the research and commercialization of waste-to-energy technologies in Singapore, with a focus on creating sustainable waste management solutions and training highly skilled manpower for the industry.

site_title: Investors keep record cash on US election fears: UBS executive
summary: Wealthy US investors are holding record cash balances due to fears of the US presidential election's impact on their retirement accounts. A UBS executive, Bob McCann, stated that clients are hesitant to invest, citing unpredictable election rhetoric and potential losses. Historically, individual investors define risk as portfolio volatility, but now it's about the permanent loss of money. A UBS survey found 84% of high net worth investors believe the election will impact their financial health, with an average 20% cash allocation over the past five years.

site_title: China committed to market reforms, fighting overcapacity: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang reaffirmed the country's commitment to market reforms and tackling steel overcapacity, amid tensions with the European Union. Li emphasized China's determination to improve market access for foreign companies and promote fair competition. China's steel sector has faced global scrutiny over cheap exports, sparking anti-dumping complaints and concerns about its market economy status. Li assured that China is taking strong measures to address overcapacity, while calling for the EU to resolve trade disputes through bilateral discussions and create a stable environment for bilateral trade.

site_title: Taiwan sends warship to South China Sea after ruling
summary: Taiwan sent a warship to the South China Sea on July 13, 2016, to defend its maritime territory following an international tribunal's ruling that China has no historic rights in the waterway. The Permanent Court of Arbitration in the Hague ruled that Taiwan-administered Taiping island, a key location, is a "rock" rather than an island, undermining Taiwanese claims to waters surrounding it. Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen rallied troops before the warship departed, vowing to defend Taiwan's rights and sovereignty.

site_title: Tesla won't disable Autopilot despite accidents: report
summary: Tesla's Autopilot system won't be disabled despite accidents linked to it, according to founder Elon Musk. Musk stated that owners need more education on using the technology, citing a lack of understanding of how to turn it on. The US auto safety regulator's probe into a fatal Autopilot-related accident in May is ongoing.

site_title: Legal activists hope to block Indonesia's tax amnesty plan
summary: Indonesian legal activists have filed a request for judicial review of the country's tax amnesty plan, citing concerns that it protects money launderers and tax evaders. The nine-month program aims to bring home billions of dollars stashed overseas, but activists see it as an illegal free pass for criminals. The Constitutional Court has received the request and will hold a preliminary hearing 14 days after all required documents are filed. The program has won praise from investors and credit rating agencies, but policymakers defend the law, saying it was carefully prepared to ensure no issues.

site_title: China: Stocks close up on stimulus hopes
summary: China stocks rose 0.3-0.4% on Wednesday, driven by hopes for further fiscal and monetary stimulus in the second half of 2016. The CSI300 index gained 0.3% to 3,282.87 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.4% to 3,060.69. Analysts attributed the gains to domestic policy, with investors largely ignoring the impact of a tribunal ruling on the South China Sea arbitration case. China's economic growth is expected to cool to a 6.6% pace in the second quarter, down from a 7-year high.

site_title: Post-Brexit Britain wakes up to smell a pricier cup of coffee
summary: Post-Brexit Britain is facing higher coffee prices due to the pound's slump against the dollar, causing UK coffee roasters to pass on increased import costs. London's small-scale roasters, who supply the capital's quality roast market, are feeling the impact of the foreign exchange reaction to the UK's EU exit vote. As a result, coffee drinkers can expect to pay more for their morning coffee in the coming months.

site_title: China says US deliberately misread WTO rules in steel subsidy spat
summary: China's Commerce Ministry stated the US deliberately misread WTO rules in a steel subsidy spat. The US Commerce Department found in favor of anti-dumping measures for Chinese steel imports, setting a preliminary subsidy rate of 57.30%. China plans to use the WTO dispute settlement process to defend its interests. The US had levied high taxes on Chinese steel products, which China considers a "man-made obstacle" to its steel exports.

site_title: Offshore yuan rises as borrowing costs surge amid reduced supply
summary: The offshore yuan strengthened for a second day due to a shortage in the overseas market and surging borrowing rates. The yuan's overnight interbank rate in Hong Kong reached a five-month high, with lenders setting aside cash to meet regulatory requirements and speculating about tightening funding conditions. China's central bank aims to avoid quick slides in the currency, according to Commerzbank AG. The strengthening yuan is a response to reduced supply and rising borrowing costs, which are pushing up the cost of betting against the Chinese currency.

site_title: Oil drops as investors lock in gains; surprise US stockpile build
summary: Crude oil prices fell on Wednesday, with Brent futures dropping 37 US cents to US$48.10 a barrel and US crude falling 28 US cents to US$46.52 a barrel. The decline came after oil prices surged nearly 5% in the previous session, partly due to forecasts of increased demand next year. A surprise build in US crude stocks and a stronger US dollar also contributed to the drop. Analysts are closely watching US weekly production statistics, which are expected to be released later in the week.

site_title: China's yuan firms, central bank suspected of intervening offshore
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar, with the central bank suspected of intervening in the offshore market to ease depreciation pressure. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.6891 per US dollar, and the offshore yuan was trading 0.06 per cent softer than the onshore spot. The yuan's firming was seen as a response to concerns about depreciation pressure, with traders noting that state-owned banks intervened on behalf of the central bank to offset the decline. The move aims to limit the upside of the USD-CNY and USD-CNH exchange rates.

site_title: Bank of England mulls rate cut after vote for Brexit
summary: The Bank of England is considering a rate cut for the first time in over seven years to address economic uncertainty following the UK's vote to exit the EU. The move is seen as a response to the government's efforts to reduce uncertainty and boost lending. Analysts expect a rate cut, but some believe it may not occur until August due to reduced political uncertainty. The central bank has already taken steps to calm fears, including relaxing capital requirements and vowing to pump £250 billion into money markets if needed.

site_title: Discrimination is biggest challenge for Airbnb, CEO says
summary: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky stated that the biggest challenge facing the company is blatant discrimination on its platform, not regulatory crackdowns. Chesky admitted that the issue was overlooked by the company's founders, who are all white men. The company has faced complaints of racial bias and has taken steps to address the issue, including banning a host in North Carolina for using racial slurs. Airbnb is conducting a 90-day study to root out discrimination and may implement design changes to the website.

images.alt_text: The biggest challenge facing Airbnb is not the regulatory crackdown from cities such as New York, but blatant discrimination occurring on the company's platform, Chief Executive Brian Chesky said on Tuesday.

site_title: Manny Pacquiao plans to fight again this year: report
summary: Filipino boxing star Manny Pacquiao plans to fight again later this year, according to ESPN. Pacquiao's promoter, Bob Arum, stated that the former welterweight champion is set to fight on either October 29 or November 5 in Las Vegas, as long as it doesn't conflict with his senate duties in the Philippines. Pacquiao's return to boxing comes after initially announcing his retirement.

site_title: China should remove trade barriers, speed up SOE reform: European commission president
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker urged China to remove trade barriers and speed up state-owned enterprise reforms. China's excess industrial capacity is impacting EU-China relations, with the steel industry being a major concern. Juncker emphasized the need for the rule of law, independent courts, and free Chinese lawyers to support businesses. Negotiations for an investment deal between China and the EU have accelerated, despite EU concerns over China's market economy status and protectionist measures.

site_title: Ex-CEO of BSI Bank in Singapore sues firm over bonus amid 1MDB probe
summary: Former BSI Bank Asia chief Hanspeter Brunner sued the Swiss private bank over frozen bonus payments amid a 1MDB probe. Brunner alleges BSI breached bonus agreements and a separation pact, claiming no basis for suspending his deferred bonuses. The bank is also accused of renegeing on other payment obligations totaling US$1 million. Brunner's lawsuit comes as BSI faces scrutiny from Singapore prosecutors over its ties with 1MDB, a Malaysian state firm under investigation for money laundering and embezzlement.

site_title: Banyan Tree's first foray in Morocco to open in Sept
summary: Banyan Tree announces the opening of its first resort in Morocco, Banyan Tree Tamouda Bay, on September 1. The luxury resort features 92 pool villas with Mediterranean sea views and is a 20-minute drive from the Medina of Tetouan, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. International visitors can arrive via Casablanca, Rabat, or Tangier International Airport.

site_title: Average Singaporean saves 9 years more for retirement than predecessor did, says report
summary: The average Singaporean saves 9 years more for retirement than their predecessors, starting at 32 and saving for 29 years. Despite this, 41% of working-age Singaporeans wish they had started saving earlier, and 38% have stopped due to difficulties. HSBC's report finds that most Singaporeans prioritize cash savings and property investments, and many lack knowledge on retirement planning, with 23% of pre-retirees saying they have never received advice or information on retirement.

images.alt_text: The average Singaporean starts saving for retirement at 32 and continues for another 29 years, nine more years than their predecessors who saved an average of 20 years and started later at age 39.

site_title: Private home rents flat, HDB rents dip 0.3% in June: SRX
summary: Private non-landed home rents remained flat in June, while HDB rents dipped 0.3% due to declines in three and four-room flats. Rental transactions for non-landed homes increased 2% to 4,256 units, a 7.9% rise from last year. HDB transactions fell 0.5% to 1,826 units. Rents in the Core Central Region and Outside Central Region decreased 0.4% and 0.3% respectively in June.

site_title: Pokemon-mania vindicates Nintendo's mobile game shift
summary: Nintendo's mobile game shift has proven successful with the release of Pokémon Go, which has topped online rankings and been downloaded millions of times. The game's debut has boosted Nintendo's Tokyo-listed shares by nearly 60% and increased its market value by billions of dollars. The game's success vindicates Nintendo's decision to move into mobile gaming, which was initially met with skepticism due to concerns it would harm its core business. The company's shares are expected to continue to rise as investors anticipate the game's impact on future growth.

site_title: China vows to protect South China Sea sovereignty after ruling
summary: China has vowed to protect its sovereignty in the South China Sea after a ruling by an international tribunal rejected its claims in the region. China rejected the Permanent Court of Arbitration's ruling, calling it a "puppet" of external forces, and has the right to set up an air defence zone, according to the Chinese government. The ruling has been seen as a test of China's rising power and its economic and strategic rivalry with the US. China has accused the US of stirring up trouble in the region, and has vowed to take all necessary measures to protect its territorial sovereignty and maritime rights and interests.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.640 points to 1653.510. Trading volume was 31.14 million lots worth RM13.67 million, with 65 gainers outnumbering 47 losers.

site_title: Nissan debuts ProPilot as similar Tesla system faces scrutiny
summary: Nissan has introduced ProPilot, a driver-assist feature for its new Serena minivan that enables it to handle some highway driving on its own. The system, available in Japan next month, sends warnings when drivers take their hands off the wheel and can disable itself if ignored. This comes as Tesla's Autopilot system faces scrutiny after several crashes, with regulators and analysts warning that clear communication of limitations is crucial for mass-market adoption of autonomous driving technology. Nissan plans to extend ProPilot to Europe and the US, with other automakers also introducing similar systems.

site_title: New Zealand tightens trust laws after Panama Papers
summary: New Zealand is tightening its trust laws after the Panama Papers leak, which referenced the country over 60,000 times. The changes aim to improve disclosure and registration of foreign trusts and strengthen anti-money laundering rules. A database will be set up to allow police and tax officials to search for details of foreign trusts and their beneficiaries. The move comes after a review found it was "reasonable to conclude that illicit funds are being hidden in New Zealand foreign trusts." The government aims to maintain its reputation for probity.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open up
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.62% to 21,356.64 in early trading on Wednesday, building on previous gains. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. These gains follow another record close on Wall Street. The increases are attributed to investors' optimism despite ongoing trade tensions, including US President Trump's recent threats.

site_title: A year after bailout, Greece struggles for brighter future
summary: A year after Greece accepted a third bailout deal worth 86 billion euros, the country remains struggling financially, with its economy expected to shrink by 0.3% this year. Greece's youthful left-wing prime minister Alexis Tsipras has faced criticism for backing down on austerity measures, despite the mandate of the Greek people behind him. The government has implemented tax hikes and pension reforms, sparking popular unrest and concerns over the country's debt, which amounts to 182% of GDP. The EU has paid out almost 30 billion euros, and talks are underway to ease Greece's debt.

site_title: Asia: Shares near 2016 peak as risk appetite improves
summary: Asian shares near 2016 peak as investors regain risk appetite amid solid US growth prospects and accommodative economic policy. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.4% to 427.83, just below its year-to-date high of 428.22. Japan's Nikkei gained 1%, while Australian and South Korean stocks added 0.3% and 0.6%, respectively. Shanghai advanced 0.3% as investors look beyond Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares up again as global rally continues
summary: Australian shares rose for a fifth consecutive day, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 0.3% to 5,369.1. The rally was driven by banking and resources counters and hopes of economic stimulus in countries like Britain and Australia. However, analysts see strong resistance at 5,400 points, which the index briefly breached in May. The global market rally continues, with stocks in other regions, such as Singapore and the US, also experiencing gains.

site_title: Yen recoups some losses, sterling firms
summary: The yen recouped some losses against the dollar and euro in Asian trading on Wednesday, following Japan's decision not to adopt a "helicopter money" stimulus policy. The dollar slipped 0.5% to 104.20 yen, while the euro fell 0.5% to 115.26 yen. The yen's recent weakness was partly due to investor hopes of the policy, but the chief cabinet secretary's statement and rebounding equity markets led to a sell-off. Expectations of more economic stimulus in Japan have contributed to a recovery in risk sentiment, with the dollar still up about 3.6% against the yen this week.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler offers US$1,500 to find vehicles' cyber soft spots
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV is offering up to $1,500 to good-guy hackers who identify potential bugs and vulnerabilities in its vehicle software. The company, in partnership with crowd-sourced cybersecurity firm Bugcrowd, is tapping a network of 32,000 researchers worldwide to find security threats. The program aims to prevent vulnerabilities that could have been exploited by hackers, such as those seen in the 2015 Jeep hack that compromised 1.4 million cars. The program will focus on 3G connected vehicles and their software, with cash awards ranging from $150 to $1,500 depending on the severity of the vulnerability.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump to 1-month high tracking Wall Street, won inches up
summary: South Korean stocks surged to a 1-month high on Wednesday, driven by strong US stocks and positive economic data from major economies. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.6% to 2,003.64 points, its best intraday level since June 10. Investors are optimistic about the economy's recovery from the Brexit shock, with offshore investors buying 263.9 billion Korean won worth of Kospi shares. The South Korean won also strengthened to 1,145.3 to the US dollar, up 0.2%.

site_title: Ambitious Google HQ plan survives after Silicon Valley land swap
summary: Google's ambitious headquarters plan for Silicon Valley has survived after a land swap with LinkedIn Corp, with the tech giant gaining control of a 10-acre plot in the North Bayshore area. The deal allows Google to build its grand glass canopy designs, but may require changes to its plans due to the city's new goals for the area, which include more residential buildings and a mix-use plan. Google can proceed with LinkedIn's original plans or seek re-authorisation from the city council to change them.

site_title: NZ central bank says remains focused on low inflation
summary: New Zealand's central bank reaffirmed its focus on low inflation, citing a "persistent period" of weaker-than-expected inflation since the financial crisis. The bank is continually reviewing its forecasts, with inflation currently at 0.4%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is mandated to keep inflation within a 1-3% target range, and recent research suggests its forecast performance has been reasonable compared to external benchmarks.

site_title: What would Mrs Thatcher say? Women run UK after vote to leave
summary: Women are taking center stage in the UK's post-Brexit politics, with Theresa May poised to become the country's second female prime minister. May will negotiate the UK's EU departure with European leaders, while other women like Nicola Sturgeon in Scotland and Arlene Foster in Northern Ireland will play pivotal roles in shaping the country's future. Despite progress, women make up only 21% of Conservative parliament members, with the Labour party having a higher representation. The article highlights the need for more women in politics and challenges the notion that women are not tough enough for leadership roles.

site_title: South Korea to announce site of THAAD anti-missile system
summary: South Korea's defense ministry plans to announce the location of the US military THAAD anti-missile defense unit, which has been met with anger from China and threats of retaliation from North Korea. The deployment, aimed at countering North Korea's missile threat, was announced by South Korea and the US on Friday. North Korea's military has vowed to take a "physical response" once the location and time of the deployment are decided, escalating tensions between the allies and the North. The announcement is expected to be made later on Wednesday.

site_title: Next UN chief ballots remain secret, despite televised debates
summary: The UN General Assembly held televised debates for the first time, requiring public nominations and town hall events, but the Security Council's secret ballot process will remain unchanged. Ten candidates, including five women, participated in the debates, with issues like climate change and leadership style being discussed. However, the Security Council's informal secret ballots, involving 15 members, will not be made public, with the US, Britain, France, Russia, and China holding veto power. A consensus among member states is emerging for a strong secretary-general, with the possibility of a female leader gaining popularity.

site_title: Philippine central bank says peso will remain market determined
summary: The Philippine central bank governor, Amando Tetangco, stated that the peso's exchange rate will remain market-determined, but the bank is prepared to act to manage excessive currency volatility. The peso hit a 4-1/2 month low on Tuesday, but opened slightly stronger to the dollar at 47.22 on Wednesday. Tetangco emphasized that the central bank will not go against the fundamentals driving the peso, but will "smoothen very sharp fluctuations" to prevent destabilization. The bank's actions will be guided by the need to ensure adjustments to the exchange rate are not destabilizing.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank is prepared to act to manage excessive currency volatility, its governor said, even as he reiterated policymakers will let market forces determine the exchange rate.

site_title: ChemChina said to plan US$10b sale of preferred stock
summary: ChemChina plans to sell US$10 billion of preferred shares in a unit to fund its record US$43 billion acquisition of Syngenta AG. The sale, which would raise another US$15 billion in cash, would bring the total equity contribution to US$25 billion. The fundraising is part of the company's efforts to secure technology for China's growing population and is subject to US regulatory approvals during an election year. State-owned ChemChina aims to complete the acquisition by the end of 2016, despite hurdles and concerns over national security.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, make up Brexit losses
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, erasing losses from the Brexit vote, as investors sought stimulus hopes. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 1.54% to 16,343.00, while the Topix index rallied 1.56%. The gains follow two positive sessions and come ahead of UK's Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint, OKP, ST Engineering
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited plans to issue US$200 million in fixed-rate notes. The announcement was made before the Singapore market opened on Wednesday. This is the only material announcement from the listed companies mentioned.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence eases in July: survey
summary: Australian consumer confidence eased in July, dropping 3% from June, according to a survey of 1,200 people. The Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank survey found optimism outnumbered pessimism, with the sentiment index 7.4% higher than July last year. The economic outlook for the next 12 months fell 6.1%, but expectations for the next five years remained steady. The survey attributed the decline to the Brexit vote and prolonged election uncertainty in Australia.

site_title: FBI gives up on old crime of hijacker who leaped from plane
summary: The FBI has closed the 45-year-old case of DB Cooper, a hijacker who jumped from a plane with a parachute and ransom money in 1971. After an exhaustive probe, the FBI will no longer actively investigate, redirecting resources to other priorities. Cooper, a well-dressed man, commandeered a Northwest Orient airlines plane, freed 36 passengers, and jumped out with $200,000, but was never found. Crumbling ransom money was discovered on a sandbar in 1980, and evidence, including a parachute and black tie, will be preserved for historical purposes.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover to test over 100 autonomous cars in Britain by 2020
summary: Jaguar Land Rover plans to test over 100 autonomous cars in Britain by 2020, with the first models hitting the streets later this year. The company will use a 41-mile test route to drive the vehicles on motorways and urban roads. The move aims to overcome legal obstacles and reduce hazards, with the technology expected to improve traffic flow and reduce accidents. The project is part of a growing trend of carmakers investing in autonomous technology, with competitors such as Tesla and Google also working on driverless vehicles.

site_title: The world's most powerful stock pickers don't manage a penny
summary: MSCI Inc, a New York-based index compiler, has become a powerful force in the global equity market despite managing only $7.7 billion. The company's influence has grown as passive investing surges, with the average proportion of equity funds mimicking index providers' decisions doubling to 33% over the past eight years. Index providers like MSCI, FTSE Russell, and S&P Dow Jones Indices are replacing traditional money managers as the most important arbiters of where global stock investments flow. Their decisions can significantly impact market prices and influence the policy decisions of governments like China's ruling Communist Party.

site_title: US auto sales this year to fall short of 2015 record, LMC says
summary: US auto sales are expected to fall short of 2015's record of 17.7 million vehicles this year, according to LMC Automotive, with revised estimates now at 17.4 million. The decline is attributed to "recent plateauing" of deliveries and growing economic and political risks, including the Brexit result and the upcoming US election. This marks the first annual decline in seven years and would be the first decline since 2009.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on global rally
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, lifted by the global stock market rally. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 10.13 points or 0.35% to 2,911.95, with 226.5 million shares changing hands. The rally follows overnight gains in US bond markets, driven by optimism about the US economy and concerns about Brexit receding.

site_title: Brazil's Lula says Rousseff can escape impeachment
summary: Brazil's suspended President Dilma Rousseff may avoid impeachment, her ally Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said. Lula believes Rousseff can secure support from 6 extra senators, needed to reach a 2/3 majority in the Senate vote on August 25-27. The vote could determine Rousseff's fate, with a majority favoring impeachment allowing interim President Michel Temer to stay in office until 2018. Rousseff's popularity is at an all-time low due to Brazil's economic woes, corruption, and instability.

site_title: In India, private equity firms see new allure in old world retail
summary: Private equity firms in India are shifting focus to traditional retail, investing in shopping malls, as online retailers' advantage is waning due to government regulations easing discounts. Key players like Blackstone and Xander Group are seeking malls in cities like Delhi, Mumbai, and Hyderabad, betting on a growing middle class's desire for physical brands. With consumer spending projected to reach $3.6 trillion by 2020, mall valuations and yields are expected to rise, attracting investor interest, particularly through real estate investment trusts (Reits).

site_title: Venezuela's woes deepen as Citibank shuts teller window
summary: Venezuela's economic crisis worsens as Citibank closes the government's overseas payments account, further isolating the country from the international financial system. The move is the latest in a string of closures or scaling back of operations by foreign companies, including Coca-Cola, Kraft Heinz, and airlines Lufthansa and American Airlines. The Maduro government has responded by shifting power to the military, which now oversees food distribution and basic goods, amid acute shortages and a 180% inflation rate. Critics blame the government's economic model and currency controls for the crisis.

site_title: Obama makes call for unity at Dallas memorial
summary: President Barack Obama addressed a memorial for five slain policemen in Dallas, urging Americans to show unity and understanding amid gun violence and racial tensions. The President, accompanied by his wife, leaned on scripture to minister to the nation. He acknowledged the country's struggles following a week of tragic events, calling for Americans to come together in the face of adversity.

site_title: Cameron chairs last cabinet as British PM
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron chaired his final cabinet meeting on Tuesday, marking the end of his six-year tenure after the country's Brexit vote. Theresa May, who led the Conservative Party to victory, became the new Prime Minister and vowed to deliver Brexit while maintaining unity within the party. May will trigger Article 50, the formal procedure for withdrawal from the EU, within the next few weeks. The pound rebounded against the US dollar following the news, and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn won a boost after being confirmed on the leadership ballot.

site_title: Euro 2016: Portugal invites bereft France fan to visit
summary: Portuguese tourism officials have invited a French fan who was consoled by a young Portuguese fan after Portugal's Euro 2016 defeat, as well as the boy's guardian, who is the son of Portuguese parents living in France. The heartwarming moment, captured in viral footage, has been shared globally. The French fan was given a shoulder to cry on and a hug by the young Portuguese boy, showing kindness and support in the face of defeat. Portugal's tourist board has extended an invitation for the pair to visit the country and experience its culture.

site_title: US: Stocks hit records as global rally accelerates
summary: US stocks hit new records on a global rally, with the Dow and S&P 500 closing above 2016 highs. The tech-rich Nasdaq reached 5,000 for the first time this year. Gains were attributed to confidence in the US economic outlook, Fed easing, and expectations of further monetary stimulus in Japan and the UK. Broad-based gains were seen in financials, tech, and energy, while utilities and consumer staples pulled back.

site_title: At least 22 killed in Italy head-on train collision
summary: At least 22 people were killed and dozens injured in a head-on train collision in southern Italy's Puglia region on Tuesday. Emergency services extracted victims from the wreckage, which was scattered across a single track into olive groves. The collision, which occurred on a slight bend in the track, is believed to have been caused by human error, with one train traveling at a high speed. Rescue workers searched the wreckage through the night, and a crisis unit was set up to help survivors and relatives of the victims.

site_title: Fed's Kashkari says no urgency to raise US interest rates
summary: Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari stated that there is no urgency to raise US interest rates, citing low inflation and the economy still being short of full employment. Kashkari believes the Fed should be patient and wait for the economy to continue healing before raising rates. This stance aligns with other Fed officials, who are unconvinced that inflation is moving towards the 2% target. The Fed will evaluate data in July to determine if the US recovery is on track, with a potential rate hike unlikely this month.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve should not be in any hurry to raise US interest rates because inflation is so low and the economy is still short of full employment, a top Fed official said on Tuesday.

site_title: SingPost: some answers, more questions
summary: SingPost has released a code of business conduct and ethics for directors, addressing conflicts of interest and board renewal and tenure. The new code clarifies directors' responsibilities and sets a tone for the board. However, questions remain, particularly regarding the company's acquisition strategy and intangible assets. The board tenure limit has implications for existing directors, and goodwill and other intangible assets have increased significantly, raising questions about their valuation. Shareholders should consider asking about the accuracy of projections supporting acquisitions, audit procedures, and the independence of the external auditor, PwC.

site_title: US dollar takes breather vs yen after rally, sterling steadies
summary: The US dollar eased slightly against the yen, falling 0.2% to 104.46 yen, but remained near 2-1/2-week highs. The euro also fell 0.3% against the yen to 115.46 yen. The dollar is up 3.8% against the yen for the week, while the euro is up 3.9%. The dollar steadied against the euro at US$1.1057. Economic stimulus in Japan and risk sentiment boosted the dollar's value.

site_title: Investors advised to seek Asian assets with stable income, rental upside
summary: Investors are advised to focus on Asian assets with stable income and rental upside, particularly in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Tokyo, as global growth slows and emerging markets gain traction. Prime office yields in Australia and Tokyo remain attractive, while Singapore's retail sector is expected to face challenges, including falling rents and vacancy rates. Experts also highlight the potential for S-Reits to outperform as a safe-haven asset class in a low-interest rate environment.

site_title: Amazon's 'Prime Day fail' frustrates shoppers during checkout
summary: Amazon's Prime Day event experienced technical difficulties during checkout, leaving many shoppers frustrated. The issue was reported about six hours after the 3 am kickoff, with Amazon initially confirming the problem and later resolving it. Despite the issues, analysts believe the event will help boost Prime membership and contribute to a strong holiday shopping season. Amazon's shares initially fell 0.3% but had climbed 12% this year through Monday. The company's high demand and expectations for reliability are seen as a testament to the event's success.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc's effort to woo shoppers with exclusive deals on "Prime Day" left many frustrated as they struggled to add items to their online shopping carts.

site_title: Airbus A380 rate cut may mark beginning of end for superjumbo
summary: Airbus announced a drastic cut in production of its A380 superjumbo, reducing the build rate by over half to one plane a month by 2018. The move acknowledges demand has fallen short of projections, with only 193 A380s delivered and 126 orders left to fill. Interest in the plane has faded with the introduction of more efficient twin-engine wide-bodies, leaving Emirates as the only carrier to fully embrace the giant aircraft's potential. The cut in production suggests the program is on the brink of a terminal decline, with some experts predicting the plane's demise in a few years.

site_title: Theresa May's first job as UK leader is naming Brexit Tsar
summary: Theresa May's first act as UK prime minister is to name a Brexit Tsar, tasked with extricating the UK from the European Union. The role requires someone loyal to May and a strong negotiator, with the formation of a new Brexit department expected to be one of her first announcements. May has ruled out candidates like Sajid Javid and George Osborne, opting for a Brexit backer, with her campaign manager Chris Grayling considered the top contender. The Brexit secretary will face the challenge of selling the UK's demands to the EU and managing volatile markets and a still-stunned electorate.

images.alt_text: When Theresa May takes office on Wednesday, her most-watched act as UK prime minister will be naming a Brexit Tsar.

site_title: Revisions galore as bond strategists miss big picture
summary: Bond strategists have struggled to accurately forecast yields due to global economic and geopolitical surprises. The Federal Reserve has cut rate projections twice, causing banks to revise forecasts repeatedly. Chief economist Stephen Stanley at Amherst Pierpont Securities has cut his Treasury 10-year yield forecast five times, now predicting 2.2% from 3.6%. The uncertainty has made it difficult for forecasters to predict yields, with Stanley saying he's "pretty much pulled out what's left of my hair" trying to figure out bond yields this year.

site_title: Bond market now is like a miscalibrated, unreliable speedometer
summary: The bond market is indicating a high risk of recession in the next year, with a 60% chance based on historical patterns, according to Deutsche Bank analysts. Long-term interest rates have hit record lows, with prices for inflation-protected bonds suggesting low inflation and a low chance of interest rate increases in 2016 and 2017. However, some analysts believe that current prices are influenced by safe asset demand and not necessarily a conviction of a disastrous economic future, making the bond market an unreliable indicator.

site_title: DeClout's unit Procurri launches mainboard IPO
summary: Procurri Corporation, a subsidiary of DeClout Ltd, has launched its initial public offering (IPO) for a Singapore Exchange mainboard listing. The IPO offers 68.88 million new shares at S$0.56 each, aiming to raise about S$38.6 million. The funds will be used for mergers and acquisitions, infrastructure enhancement, and growth expansion plans. Procurri's CEO, Sean Murphy, expects the IPO to accelerate the company's disruption in the cloud industry and become the global aggregator of enterprise hardware and services.

site_title: Bond investors likely to drop longer dated Japan debt for shorter dated
summary: Foreign investors in Japan are shifting from long-dated bonds to shorter ones due to favorable cross-currency basis-swap rates. Yields on 40 and 30-year bonds have fallen near zero, making longer-dated bonds less attractive. The government's latest 30-year bond sale drew the weakest demand in a year, and life insurers may also reduce purchases, potentially keeping yields above zero. The Bank of Japan's policy meeting on July 29 may influence long-term yields, with speculation of expanded monetary easing.

site_title: Opera declines after warning sale to Chinese group may fail
summary: Opera Software ASA's stock fell 10% in Oslo after the company disclosed that a Chinese group's takeover bid may not receive government approval before July 15's deadline. The $1 billion deal, which needs approvals from Chinese authorities and the US Committee on Foreign Investment, is exploring alternative options. Opera has 350 million monthly active users and its browsers are embedded in devices made by major smartphone manufacturers. The sale would give Opera access to the Chinese web-user base and additional financing. The company will provide an update later on the deal's status.

site_title: Asian casino operator pays price for UK voters' Brexit gamble
summary: Genting Malaysia, a casino operator exposed to the UK market, saw its shares slump 4.4% since the Brexit referendum. The company's parent company has significant assets in the UK, with 43 casinos, and is among the 10 Asia-Pacific companies most at risk to Britain's economic slowdown. The pound's 12% decline against the dollar since the vote has negatively impacted Genting Malaysia's earnings, with a 1% drop in earnings per share predicted for 2016. The company's UK revenue accounts for 24% of its group revenue.

site_title: Oil rebounds from 2-month lows
summary: Oil prices rebounded Tuesday from two-month lows after the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) forecast a easing of the global oversupply that has weighed on the market. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose $2.04 to $46.80 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude finished at $48.47 a barrel. Opec predicted global demand growth will pick up in 2017, leading to a reduction in excess oil stocks, but said it would take until 2018 for inventories to trend lower.

site_title: Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman's comments
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has taken note of the Arbitral Tribunal's ruling in the Philippines v China case under the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). Singapore supports the peaceful resolution of disputes among claimants and values its long-standing relations with all parties. The ministry urges all parties to respect legal and diplomatic processes and exercise self-restraint, calling for the full and effective implementation of the Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea and a legally-binding Code of Conduct. Singapore is studying the Award and its implications.

site_title: EU and US launch controversial internet privacy deal
summary: The European Union and the US launched the "Privacy Shield" deal on Tuesday, aiming to curb government spying on European citizens' personal internet data. The new agreement sets out tough rules to prevent US intelligence agencies from accessing Europeans' data, with companies facing penalties if they fail to meet European standards. Critics argue the deal still lacks sufficient protection and may face court challenges. The agreement includes commitments by the US to limit bulk-collected intelligence and fines for non-compliant firms.

site_title: Terrorist, traffickers use US shell companies: Treasury
summary: US Treasury officials warn that terrorist groups and drug traffickers are using anonymously owned US shell companies to hide and move money. Acting Undersecretary Adam Szubin calls on Congress to crack down on the loophole, citing concerns that secrecy provided by US companies is allowing money laundering. The US Treasury proposed legislation requiring beneficial owners to be identified when a US company is formed, but previous attempts have been defeated by "interested stakeholders." This issue has been addressed globally, with the Group of 20 recommending measures to improve financial transparency and tackle loopholes like shell companies.

site_title: New Boeing defence CEO focuses on basics, growth areas
summary: Boeing's new defence CEO, Leanne Caret, has outlined six key priorities for the company, focusing on improving programme performance and customer relationships. Despite setbacks on the KC-46A tanker and loss of a big bomber deal, Caret emphasizes the company's strengths in areas like commercial derivatives, rotorcraft, and services. She aims to identify and address challenges head-on, with a focus on execution, operational depth, and long-term growth. Caret also plans to invest in service life extensions and upgrades for fighter jets, such as the F-15 and F/A-18E/F.

site_title: Gold falls most in 3 weeks as stocks rise, growth concerns ease
summary: Gold prices fell 0.9% to $1,344.90 an ounce, marking the largest decline in three weeks, as stocks rose amid expectations of policy maker action to spur growth and ease global economic concerns. The UK's Brexit vote sparked initial losses, but equities recovered, and US small-business optimism rose for a third straight month. Central bankers' signals and rising equities may be helping stem worries about a global economy, with some predicting no recession for two to three years.

site_title: Investing in a post-Brexit environment
summary: A post-Brexit environment has seen risk assets recover from an initial sell-off, with volatilities returning to average. However, it's too early to declare an all-clear. The UK's exit from the EU is expected to negatively impact European stocks, particularly the eurozone and UK, while US equities are seen as a safer bet. Currencies such as the GBP/USD are expected to weaken further, while the USD and surplus currencies like CHF and JPY are likely to remain resilient. Bond markets are expected to perform in line with their yields to maturity, with a preference for investment-grade corporate bonds and emerging market bonds.

site_title: Leadership woes at Malaysia Airlines could undermine recovery plan
summary: Malaysia Airlines has restructured into Malaysia Airlines Berhad (MAB) to address legacy issues, but leadership woes persist. Peter Bellew, the new CEO, has vowed to fix the airline, but his predecessor Christoph Mueller's early departure due to a "change in personal circumstances" has raised concerns over the carrier's recovery plan. The revolving door of top executives has hindered the airline's progress, and Mueller's potential exit to Emirates Airline could signal unresolved issues, including cultural and vested interests. Bellew's ability to stay the course will be closely watched.

site_title: Governments should get out of innovation's way (Amended)
summary: Singaporean speakers at the World Cities Summit argue that governments should step aside and let private companies and citizens drive innovation in urban development. Experts believe that governments are limited by rules and procedures, whereas private entities are bound by imagination and designed to improve their own well-being. They suggest that governments should create an innovation-friendly environment by sharing data and information, and removing regulatory burdens to let market forces decide the future of city development.

images.alt_text: The cities of tomorrow can be driven by their citizens who have a greater stake in ensuring a sustainable and liveable future for their cities.

site_title: Asia's budget-airline king splurges on planes to keep dominance
summary: AirAsia, Asia's budget-airline king, has signed a massive deal with Airbus for 100 A321neo airliners worth $12.6 billion, surpassing Boeing's order tally. The move solidifies AirAsia's position as the largest operator of Airbus single-aisle aircraft and cements its dominance in the Asian market. Under Tony Fernandes' leadership, AirAsia has revolutionized the industry, driving down fares and increasing accessibility to air travel in Asia. The airline's success has been marked by significant growth, with a 50.7 million passenger capacity last year, and shares have more than doubled this year.

site_title: Shanghai Futures Exchange warns of zero tolerance for trading abuse
summary: The Shanghai Futures Exchange has vowed to have zero tolerance for trading abuse, following an unprecedented boom-bust episode in raw-material futures from March to May. The exchange said its products are not for retail investors and are geared towards professionals. Over 900 cases of abnormal activity were settled in the first five months, and the exchange plans to press on with opening up to overseas investors to support the government's supply-side reforms.

site_title: UniCredit to launch strategic in-depth review under new CEO
