Xerox would acquire RR Donnelley and then merge parts of it within the two newly created companies. The acquisition is a strategic move to strengthen Xerox's financial printing capabilities.

site_title: Pokemon Go mania drives players into wild outdoors
summary: Pokémon Go has taken the US by storm, with millions of downloads in its first few days, surpassing the dating app Tinder and reaching 5% of Android phone users. The game, developed by Niantic Labs, uses GPS and mapping capabilities to encourage players to explore the real world, capture monsters, and train them for battles. The game has been praised for promoting physical activity and social interaction, but has also raised concerns about player safety, with reports of players trespassing and being targeted by criminals.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit near 4-month highs; Hon Hai inches up
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.42% to a near four-month high, reaching 8,823.34, driven by gains on Wall Street and regional bourses. The electronics and financial sub-indexes also gained 0.6% each, as Taiwan stocks hit their highest level since March 21.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on weaker yen, stimulus hopes
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 2.29% and the Topix index jumping 2.24%. The weaker yen, which eased on stimulus hopes, boosted exporters. This follows a solid lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The rally is seen as a positive sign for the market, with investors remaining optimistic despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: High stakes legal ruling looms in South China Sea dispute
summary: An international arbitration court in The Hague is set to rule on a dispute between China and the Philippines over the South China Sea, where China claims vast territory for resource exploitation. China has boycotted the hearings, while the US has conducted military exercises in the area, fueling regional tensions. The ruling, expected to be significant, will determine the legality of China's 'nine-dash line' claim and impact overlapping claims by five countries, including Taiwan, Vietnam, and Malaysia, potentially leading to further escalation.

site_title: Alcoa earnings beat expectations, shares leap
summary: Alcoa, a US aluminum and metals giant, reported second-quarter earnings that beat market forecasts, with adjusted earnings of 15 US cents per share. Despite a 3.6% decline in net income, shares jumped after-hours, driven by revenue of $5.29 billion, exceeding expectations. Alcoa maintained its 2016 forecasts, citing a 5% rise in global demand, and reaffirmed its plan to split into two companies, one focused on commodity products and the other on value-added products for aerospace and auto industries.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday after S&P record high
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher on Tuesday, rising 7.88 points or 0.27% to 2,884.02, following the S&P 500's record close. The benchmark index saw 78.4 million shares traded worth S$69.7 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 80 to 34. The upbeat mood was fueled by the S&P 500's one-third of one percent gain overnight, following solid non-farm payrolls numbers.

site_title: Gold extends drop as risk appetite returns on possible stimulus
summary: Gold prices extended their decline as equities rose on possible UK and Japan fiscal stimulus. The metal fell 0.1% to $1,353.46 an ounce, after touching a 2-year high of $1,375.34 on Monday. Risk appetite returned to global markets, driven by expectations of a Bank of England interest rate cut and Japan's planned fiscal stimulus. The US jobs report also eased concerns about the US economy, contributing to the market rally.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices post 4th consecutive m-o-m gain: SRX Property
summary: Singapore's resale prices of non-landed private homes rose 0.5% in June 2016, marking the fourth consecutive month-on-month increase, according to SRX Property's flash estimates. Year-over-year, the resale price index increased 1.1% from June 2015. Core Central Region prices rose 0.9%, while the suburbs or Outside Central Region saw a 0.5% gain. The median transaction over X-Value (TOX) improved to negative S$7,000 in June from negative S$8,000 in May.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Select Group, Swiber
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed memorandums of understanding with Mitsubishi Electric and Scinor (Asia) to test-bed new technologies for water under an S$8 million initiative. The company hopes to co-own intellectual property and secure preferential pricing for the new technologies if the results are positive. Meanwhile, Select Group's consortium extended its unconditional general offer until July 19, offering 52.5 Singapore cents per share. Swiber Holdings is looking into its legal options regarding a delayed US$200 million investment in its subsidiary.

site_title: Three reported dead at Michigan courthouse: media
summary: A shooting at a Michigan courthouse has left three people dead, including the attacker, and several others injured. Two of the dead are court bailiffs, while the shooter was the third. The incident occurred amid heightened tensions following the killing of five police officers in Dallas last week.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks choppy, won eases as investors eye Japanese stimulus
summary: South Korean stocks experienced choppy trading on Tuesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rising 0.1% to 1,990.64 points. The won eased 0.2% to 1,149.5 per dollar as investors awaited Japanese stimulus to boost its economy. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a new round of fiscal stimulus, which could weaken the yen, boost the won, and pressure stocks. Carmaker Ssangyong Motor Co. and Hyundai Mobis Co. gained 2.2% and 1.8% respectively, while offshore investors purchased 55.5 billion Korean won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: US House approves bill to upgrade airport security
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a bill to upgrade airport security, sending it to the Senate for approval. The legislation includes measures to enhance vetting of aviation workers, expedited security checks, and increased use of police dogs. The bill also extends funds for the Federal Aviation Administration for another 14 months. The measure is expected to be signed by President Barack Obama before Congress leaves for a summer break.

site_title: For Wall Street bond strategists, there's wrong and less wrong
summary: Wall Street bond strategists have drastically revised their forecasts for US Treasury yields in 2016, with the median forecast now calling for yields to reach 2.10% by year-end, down from 2.78% in December. The Fed's rate hike projections have also been cut, with only one expected hike in 2016. The global economic and geopolitical environment, including negative interest rates in Europe and Japan, has driven the yield tumbles. Strategists have cut their forecasts by three or more times, with some predicting yields could fall further in the second half of the year.

site_title: Kim Dotcom to revive Megaupload
summary: Kim Dotcom plans to relaunch Megaupload in 2017, exactly five years after its shutdown. The file-sharing service was once the 13th most visited site, with 50 million daily users. Dotcom denies any wrongdoing and will appeal an extradition ruling, which could see him jailed for up to 20 years. He claims to have around 100 million users from the old site who will be given premium accounts on the new site, giving it critical mass from day one. Dotcom is determined to revive Megaupload despite the legal fallout.

site_title: Tesla readies updated 'secret masterplan'
summary: Tesla is preparing an updated "secret masterplan" to address concerns over its Autopilot semi-autonomous driving mode following fatal crashes and federal safety investigations. The company, founded by Elon Musk, aims to rebound with plans for increased production, including a "gigafactory" in Nevada to produce special batteries. The updated masterplan, announced by Musk on Twitter, promises to publish later this week, outlining Tesla's long-term vision for affordable family cars and its autonomous driving technology.

site_title: Honda co-develops 1st heavy rare earth-free motor for hybrid cars
summary: Honda co-develops the world's first heavy rare earth-free electric motor for hybrid cars with Daido Steel. The technology, set to be used in the Freed minivan, will trim costs and reduce dependence on expensive rare earth metals controlled mainly by China. This breakthrough paves the way for hybrid vehicles to overcome supply chain challenges, making them more accessible in developed countries.

site_title: Exxon Mobil says no attacks at its facilities despite Nigerian militants' claim
summary: Exxon Mobil has denied claims by Nigerian militant group Niger Delta Avengers that it had been attacked, despite the group stating it had blown up the Qua Iboe 48" crude oil export pipeline. The Qua Iboe pipeline, which exports over 300,000 barrels per day, is Nigeria's largest crude oil stream. The Niger Delta Avengers has demanded a greater share of Nigeria's energy wealth for the impoverished southern Niger Delta. Attacks by the group have pushed Nigeria's crude production to 30-year lows.

site_title: UK retail spending slowed in June as Britons faced EU referendum
summary: UK retail spending slowed in June, rising 0.2% compared to the same period last year, amid bad weather and uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum. This marked a significant slowdown from May's 1.4% growth. Despite this, a leading credit card firm reported spending increased immediately after the referendum on June 23. The slower spending growth is a fresh blow to UK economy, which has already shrunk for the second month in a row.

site_title: Top China commodity exchange pledges 'zero tolerance' for abuse
summary: The Shanghai Futures Exchange has pledged a "zero tolerance" for abuse of trading rules, following an unprecedented boom-bust episode in raw-material futures earlier this year. The exchange emphasized that its products are not for retail investors, but for professionals, and will enforce strict rules to prevent abnormal activity. The market has seen over 900 cases of abnormal trading settled in the first five months, with 47 account holders receiving public warnings and some having their positions restricted. The exchange aims to promote well-functioning markets to support the government's supply-side reforms.

site_title: For China, Trump perhaps better the devil they don't know
summary: China is watching the US presidential election with concern, particularly for Hillary Clinton's tough stance on the South China Sea dispute. China views Clinton as a difficult partner due to her human rights record and Asia "rebalancing" policy. In contrast, Donald Trump is largely an unknown quantity, with some officials expressing skepticism about his foreign policy views. China may view Trump as a businessman who can be negotiated with, but also sees him as less likely to be tough on human rights issues. The outcome of the election is seen as crucial for China's relations with the US, with officials hoping that whoever wins will understand the importance of a strong bilateral relationship.

site_title: Clinton, Sanders team up Tuesday as Trump highlights safety
summary: Bernie Sanders is set to endorse Hillary Clinton's presidential bid, joining her for a campaign rally in New Hampshire. This comes as Donald Trump, Clinton's Republican opponent, campaigns in Indiana, sparking speculation about a potential running mate. Trump has emphasized his stance on law and order, amidst rising gun violence. Meanwhile, global markets and economies are also in the news, including Vietnam's reaction to US tariffs, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK's shrinking economy.

site_title: BP fined about US$20m for rigging US natural gas markets
summary: BP Plc has been fined approximately US$20.16 million by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) for rigging US natural gas markets in Texas in 2008. The company was accused of manipulating commodity markets to profit from a natural disaster, and the FERC found the violation to be serious. BP had previously denied the allegations but was ordered to pay the penalties and surrender unjust profits within 60 days, with the option to appeal to a federal court.

site_title: Ascott acquires Melbourne property for A$71m
summary: Ascott Limited, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has acquired its first property in Melbourne, Australia for A$71 million through a 50:50 joint venture with Qatar Investment Authority. The 221-unit property, named Quest NewQuay Docklands, will be operated by Quest Apartment Hotels under its franchise when it opens in 2019. This acquisition is part of Ascott's A$500 million partnership with Quest, aiming to expand its presence in Australia and achieve 80,000 apartment units globally by 2020.

site_title: US SEC investigates Tesla for possible securities law breach: WSJ
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Tesla Motors Inc. for possible securities law breach, specifically regarding a fatal crash in May that questioned the safety of a steering and braking system. Tesla stated it had not received any communication from the SEC. The company's shares sank in after-hours trading, following a tweet by CEO Elon Musk about a "Top Secret Masterplan." The SEC declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Australia business conditions brighten despite political fog: survey
summary: Australian businesses reported a strong increase in business conditions and employment in June, defying the uncertainty of the time. The National Australia Bank's survey showed a 2-point increase in its business conditions index to +12, and a 3-point increase in business confidence to +6. Employment conditions also improved, with the employment index rising to +4. This suggests a solid near-term employment growth and reinforces the resilience of the non-mining economy. The survey's results are seen as a positive sign for the economy, which beat forecasts in the first quarter with an annual growth rate of 3.1%.

images.alt_text: Australian firms reported a marked pick-up in business conditions and employment in June, a surprisingly strong sign the economy is keeping an even keel in the face of heightened political uncertainty at home and abroad.

site_title: Game makers everywhere are hungrily eyeing Pokemon Go phenomenon
summary: Game developers worldwide are taking notice of Pokémon Go's instant success, with many considering incorporating augmented reality and location-based technology into their own games. Analysts predict that the game's success will inspire copycats, with potential developers including Activision Blizzard's Skylanders game. However, replicating Pokémon Go's technology may be challenging, as Niantic, the game's developer, has refined the mechanics over years. The game's enduring popularity, driven by the beloved Pokémon franchise, is a key factor in its success, but some analysts believe it will be fleeting due to its rudimentary augmented reality technology and potential issues with server stability and security.

site_title: Lyft is 'very likely' to expand outside US, co-founder says
summary: Lyft is "very likely" to expand outside the US, according to John Zimmer, the president and co-founder of the company. Lyft has formed partnerships with ride-hailing companies in China, India, and South-east Asia, and has been working with Qatalyst Partners LP on potential deals. Zimmer said the company has enough money to reach break-even and is exploring ways to reduce losses, such as cutting driver incentives or increasing fares. No specific expansion plans or timeline were announced, but the move comes as Uber continues to expand globally.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise second day as Japan jumps after yen tumbles
summary: Asian stocks rose for a second day, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index up 0.9% to 131.80, driven by a tumbling yen and speculation of policy makers' actions to stem the fallout from the UK's Brexit decision. Japan's Topix index climbed 2.2% after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced fiscal stimulus. US shares also rallied, with the S&P 500 index adding 0.3% on Monday, as investors await earnings reports and expect potential interest-rate cuts.

site_title: Rio Olympics local committee has deficit of up to 500m reals: source
summary: The Rio Olympics local committee is facing a deficit of 400-500 million reais (S$163-204 million), about 6% of its budget, due to high rent for the Olympic Village and smaller-than-expected sponsorship funding from Petrobras. The committee's privately funded budget, not public money, is used to operate the Games, and any shortfall could negatively impact the experience of fans and athletes. The committee claims to be on track to deliver a balanced budget, but the deficit must be covered by the city, state, and federal governments, which are already strained.

site_title: Aerosmith's Joe Perry collapses in concert
summary: Aerosmith guitarist Joe Perry collapsed during a concert in New York on Sunday night with Hollywood Vampires, a side project featuring Alice Cooper and Johnny Depp. A video posted online showed Perry slow down and exit the stage, but he is stable and receiving care. The band plans to continue their tour, with the next date scheduled for Tuesday night in Ohio. Perry, 65, is recovering from the incident and will not perform with the band at a scheduled appearance on "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert."

site_title: Europe's troubled steelmakers finally head for long-craved deals
summary: Europe's steel industry is on the verge of significant deals, with Tata Steel and Thyssenkrupp in talks for a potential joint venture. This follows ArcelorMittal's acquisition of Ilva, Europe's top steel plant, and efforts to consolidate the industry to reduce excess supply and support prices. The deals aim to address the sector's enduring problem of oversupply, driven by China's record exports. Consolidation is seen as crucial for the EU steel sector's sustainability, with analysts predicting a stronger number two player in the euro market.

site_title: Europeans fear that refugee influx raises terror risk: survey
summary: A majority of Europeans, 80% of the population in 10 countries, believe the recent refugee influx increases the risk of terrorism and costs their countries jobs and social benefits, according to a Pew Research Center survey. The majority of respondents in countries such as Hungary, Poland, and Italy share these concerns, while France shows a lower percentage. The survey also found that negative attitudes toward Muslims influence perceptions of refugees, with over 60% in Hungary and Italy holding unfavorable views of Muslims.

site_title: Zhongmin Baihui to close loss-making store in Jiangsu province
summary: Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group has decided to close its loss-making Nanjing Nanzhan store in Jiangsu province, China. The store, which opened in 2012, has been unprofitable due to slower-than-expected surrounding area development. The department store and supermarket sections have ceased operation, and tenants are moving out. The company expects a potential gain of 41 million yuan (S$8.3 million) from the closure, largely non-cash in nature, and will hand over the store to the landlord once vacated.

site_title: Britain's May must protect London's financial centre: lawmaker
summary: Britain's incoming Prime Minister Theresa May must protect London's financial sector as the country negotiates its exit from the European Union. Senior lawmaker Stephen Hammond advises May to prioritize financial services, ensure they remain in London, and consider regulatory structures to maintain an advantage. He suggests allowing negotiations to take up to 18 months to secure a clear Brexit strategy, and cautions against triggering Article 50 too early, which could harm markets and the UK's financial standing.

site_title: Eurozone warns on economic hit of Brexit
summary: Eurozone finance ministers warned that the UK's decision to leave the EU could lead to a 1.2% growth rate in 2017, down from the official forecast of 1.8%, or a 1.5% growth rate in a more optimistic scenario. The ministers, led by Economics Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici, urged swift action on the issue, which they said was causing problems across the European economy, and called for the UK to notify its intentions to the EU under article 50.

images.alt_text: Eurozone finance ministers assessed on Monday the impact of the British decision to leave the EU, warning that the country risked becoming "Little Britain" in the aftermath.

site_title: Starbucks to raise wages for US workers in October
summary: Starbucks will raise wages for all US workers and store managers at company-operated stores by at least 5% starting October 3, with some employees potentially seeing a 15% increase. The move comes after employees signed a petition alleging staffing hour reductions were hurting morale and making it difficult for employees to afford benefits. The company also plans to double the annual stock reward for hourly employees who have worked at company-operated stores for at least two years.

site_title: US: Strong economy, earnings bets propel S&P 500 to record high
summary: The S&P 500 broke its record high, closing at 2,137.16 points, driven by upbeat economic data and low bond yields. Defensive sectors such as utilities, telecoms, and consumer staples led the gain, while technology stocks also rose. The strong performance is attributed to investor concerns over global stagnation and low bond yields pushing fixed income investors into stocks. Despite concerns over second-quarter earnings, analysts expect the market to continue its rally.

site_title: Taylor Swift world's highest paid celebrity: Forbes
summary: Taylor Swift has become the world's highest-paid celebrity, earning $170 million between June 2015 and June 2016, according to Forbes magazine. Her earnings surpassed previous records, including Adele's $80.5 million, and outpaced other musicians like Rihanna and Madonna. The pop star's top earnings came from her "1989 World Tour," which grossed $200 million in North America and $250 million worldwide. This year's top 10 list also features One Direction, James Patterson, and Calvin Harris. The total earnings of the world's 100 highest-paid celebrities reached $5.1 billion.

site_title: Qatar Airways looks at up to 30 Boeing 737s in place of A320neos
summary: Qatar Airways is considering purchasing up to 30 Boeing 737s to replace its A320neo aircraft due to unresolved engine issues. The carrier has canceled one A320neo delivery and will continue to reject planes until the problems are fixed. Qatar Airways is exploring both the NG and Max versions of the 737, which could be a significant blow to Airbus. The airline is also concerned about delivery rates of the A350 wide-body aircraft, with only one out of 10 scheduled deliveries this year.

site_title: Yen slumps on Japanese stimulus hopes
summary: The Japanese yen fell 2.3% to 102.82 yen per US dollar and 2.4% to 113.68 yen per euro following a landslide victory for Japan's ruling coalition in weekend elections, with conservative premier Shinzo Abe pledging a stimulus package worth up to 20 trillion yen. The move was seen as a boost to the pound, which found some footing ahead of the UK's Brexit leadership change. However, markets are pricing in a potential Bank of England interest rate cut on Thursday to bolster an economy at risk of a Brexit-induced recession.

images.alt_text: The yen fell sharply against the US dollar and the euro Monday on rising Japanese stimulus hopes following a landslide victory for Japan's ruling coalition in weekend elections.

site_title: New Bill defines contempt of court, sets out penalties
summary: A new Administration of Justice (Protection) Bill has been introduced in Singapore's parliament, aiming to consolidate and clarify the country's contempt law. The bill sets out the maximum penalties for contempt of court and seeks to provide greater certainty. The move is seen as a step to improve the country's legal framework.

site_title: AirAsia eyeing HK listing as it expands in North Asia
summary: AirAsia is considering a dual listing in Hong Kong as part of its expansion plans in North Asia. The budget carrier is also exploring a joint venture in China, backed by a Chinese state-owned enterprise, to capture traffic from secondary and tertiary cities. AirAsia aims to become a pan-Asian low-cost airline player, with plans to add more aircraft and increase capacity, and is reportedly in talks with Chinese banks and potential shareholders.

site_title: Obama renews call for US public health insurance option
summary: President Barack Obama has urged Congress to reconsider offering a government-run health insurance option alongside private plans on the exchanges created as part of his national healthcare law. In an article, Obama stated that the Affordable Care Act has made significant progress in improving access to healthcare and care quality, but challenges remain. Many Republicans continue to oppose the law, citing increased health coverage costs. Obama's call comes as several challenges, including the law's impact on affordability and quality, persist.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama on Monday urged Congress to reconsider offering a government-run health insurance option alongside private plans on the exchanges created as part of his national healthcare law.

site_title: The growth challenges facing Singapore's SMEs
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face significant growth challenges, with varying perspectives on what drives growth. Some blame internal factors, such as entrepreneurial spirit and skillsets, while others attribute it to external factors like competition and economic uncertainty. A lack of clear definition and understanding of growth can hinder SMEs' ability to adapt and thrive.

site_title: Nintendo rally invokes history lesson
summary: Nintendo's stock surged 25% as investors reacted to the success of Pokémon Go, an augmented-reality game that integrates the original Pokémon storyline into real-world surroundings. The game's popularity recalls the novelty of the Nintendo Wii console, which also had a brief but intense impact on the market. However, the Wii's successor, Wii U, failed to replicate its success. Experts caution that Pokémon Go's short-term success may not translate to long-term revenue, as the game has received mixed reviews and limited in-app purchases are the primary source of income.

site_title: Suspect in July 7 StanChart robbery nabbed in Bangkok 3 days later
summary: Police in Bangkok have arrested a Canadian suspect in the July 7 robbery of a Standard Chartered branch in Singapore, three days after the crime. The suspect, identified on the day of the robbery, had left Singapore for Bangkok and was located by the Royal Thai Police. He was arrested at noon on July 10 at the Boxpackers Hostel in Bangkok, with Singapore authorities working to gain custody. The suspect is believed to have handed over S$30,000 in cash during the robbery, and no weapon was used.

site_title: Sterling's fall could batter Britain's fish and chip shops
summary: The British pound's 31-year low following the Brexit vote may increase the cost of imports, including cod and haddock used by 10,500 fish and chip shops. The currency drop, 13% weaker against the US dollar, could lead to higher prices for salmon and squid, with some sellers advising to buy now before prices rise. Independent fishmongers, which spend at least £3,000 a week on fish, are more exposed to the fluctuations, and may need to switch to local fish to avoid price increases.

site_title: Top US officials rejected push to prosecute HSBC: lawmakers' report
summary: US Department of Justice officials overruled internal recommendations to prosecute HSBC for money laundering violations due to concerns about financial stability. A congressional report reveals then-US Attorney General Eric Holder "misled" Congress about the decision not to prosecute. HSBC was fined $1.92 billion in 2012 for violating US sanctions laws and laundering $881 million for Mexican and Colombian cartels. No HSBC executives or employees were prosecuted, despite the Justice Department's Asset Forfeiture and Money Laundering Section considering a guilty plea as early as September 2012.

site_title: Advancer Global soars in debut trading on Catalist board
summary: Advancer Global, a Singapore-based maid agency, made its debut on the Catalist board, closing at 39 Singapore cents, 77.3% above its IPO price of 22 Singapore cents. The IPO was oversubscribed 5.5 times, raising S$7.54 million in net proceeds for business expansion and working capital. Strong demand suggests a positive outlook for the broader IPO market, according to bookrunner IG market strategist Bernard Aw.

site_title: Walmart ups the ante in retail battle against Amazon's Prime Day
summary: Walmart is offering free shipping with no minimum purchase on all online orders for five days starting July 11, as it steps up its battle against Amazon's Prime Day. This move aims to compete with Amazon's highly publicized shopping event, which is expected to be bigger than last year. Prime Day is a key part of Amazon's growth plan, with the company expecting its second annual event to be even larger. Walmart's move is seen as a strategic attempt to increase its online presence and challenge Amazon's dominance in the retail market.

site_title: Infection experts warn of more US superbug cases in coming months
summary: Infection experts warn of a surge in US superbug cases due to the widespread presence of the mcr-1 gene, which renders the antibiotic colistin useless. Found in E coli bacteria, the gene has been identified in 20 countries, including the US, China, and Europe. Experts expect more documented cases in the coming months, with potential spread to carbapenem-resistant bacteria, making infections untreatable. The US is expanding surveillance efforts with $21 million in federal funding to track the gene and prevent infections.

site_title: Oil prices fall on worries about oversupply
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as worries about global oversupply returned, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping 65 US cents to $44.76 a barrel. The decline was attributed to a rise in US drilling activity and a stronger US dollar, making greenback-denominated crude more expensive. Brent North Sea crude also fell 51 US cents to $46.25 a barrel. Analysts noted that despite minor increases in US drilling activity, the market's negative sentiment remained, driven by bearish factors such as increased production and a stronger dollar.

site_title: Airbus close to US$7.5b A320neo deal from GoAir
summary: Airbus is in discussions with GoAir to purchase 70 A320neo planes worth approximately US$7.5 billion. The deal, potentially announced at the Farnborough Air Show, would provide a vote of confidence in the revamped single-aisle jet model, which has faced issues with its Pratt & Whitney turbines. GoAir is expanding its fleet in India's rapidly growing aviation market, where it operates 140 daily flights across 22 destinations. The new order would use Pratt engines, similar to the existing 72 A320neos already in service.

site_title: Europe: Stocks post highest close since Brexit
summary: European stocks rose to their highest close since the Brexit referendum on Monday, driven by Theresa May's victory as UK Prime Minister, reducing political uncertainty. The Stoxx Europe 600 index gained 1.6% to 332.72, with FTSE 250 and British housebuilders rising 3.3% and 7-8%, respectively. Analysts praised May's experience and strategic approach, citing relief from the market. However, Goldman Sachs maintained a "neutral" view on equities, citing concerns over a weak economic backdrop and potential for drawdowns.

site_title: Fading Acer makes virtual reality gambit to turn things around
summary: Acer, a struggling personal computer maker, is betting on virtual reality (VR) headsets to turn its business around. The company plans to sell high-end VR headsets to theaters, theme parks, and cinemas, targeting commercial buyers rather than consumers. Acer aims to capture a slice of the $20 billion headset market by 2020, with a focus on emerging technologies and new markets. CEO Jason Chen hopes to revitalize the company by diversifying its business and building multiple revenue streams, rather than relying on declining industries.

site_title: Financial markets applaud Japan PM's landslide election victory
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling coalition secured a landslide victory in the upper house election, giving them a two-thirds majority and allowing them to launch a national referendum on amending Japan's post-war pacifist constitution. The Nikkei 225 stock average rose 4% as Abe instructed his government to start work on a fiscal stimulus package worth 2% of Japan's GDP, aimed at boosting the economy. Analysts hail the victory as a boost to investor confidence, with some predicting a "Japan Premium" in risk asset markets.

site_title: Surbana Jurong launches 'Smart City in a Box'
summary: Surbana Jurong launches "Smart City in a Box", an integrated platform that combines various smart city solutions for city officials to monitor and manage cities efficiently. The platform, which includes 14 apps, allows for customizable applications to be loaded on a dashboard to monitor traffic, security, energy efficiency, and other city services. By year-end, the platform will be rolled out to 16 town councils in Singapore and cities in Africa and China, with plans to expand globally. The platform aims to provide a convenient and scalable solution for cities to improve their services and engage with residents.

site_title: Yen slips as Tokyo stocks jump
summary: The yen plummeted by over 1% against the US dollar as Tokyo stocks surged, following Japan's ruling coalition's landslide victory in upper house elections. This boosted hopes for more monetary stimulus, which could lead to further yen devaluation. The yen's decline was partly due to a strong US jobs report, which increased expectations of a possible interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve before the end of the year.

site_title: Paktor snags US$10m funding; Infocomm Investments partners Bansea to fund seed-stage startups
summary: Paktor, a Singapore-based dating platform, secured US$10 million in funding, bringing its total funding to over US$20.5 million. The startup plans to expand into Japan and South Korea. Infocomm Investments (IIPL) partnered with Bansea to jointly invest in local seed-stage startups. This move aims to deepen the presence of Asian startups in the global market.

site_title: Beijing says there should be no South China Sea discussion at Asem
summary: Beijing has stated that the South China Sea should not be discussed at the upcoming Asia-Europe Meeting (Asem) summit in Mongolia. Chinese Assistant Foreign Minister Kong Xuanyou said the issue is not on the agenda and should not be brought up. Despite this, diplomats involved in Asem preparations believe the dispute will be raised at the summit, which will be attended by leaders from China, Japan, and Germany. Tensions in the region have been rising ahead of a July 12 ruling by an arbitration court on a dispute between China and the Philippines over the South China Sea.

site_title: Civil service internet curb: govt e-services, email with public won't be affected
summary: Singapore's government has implemented a measure to restrict internet access on work computers for public servants to combat hacking and cyber-attacks. The move, set to take effect in May 2017, aims to protect sensitive data containing personal information of citizens. However, teachers and some public officers will be exempt from the restriction. The government assures that public e-services and transactions will not be affected, and citizens can still send and receive emails from government officers. The cyber security threat level in Singapore is deemed significant and ongoing, with measures to be taken to improve resilience.

site_title: MAS can make grants to IMF with House's approval
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) can now participate in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Poverty Reduction and Growth Trust (PRGT) through a $20 million grant paid from Singapore's share of the IMF's gold sales profit, subject to parliament's approval. This amendment allows MAS to provide grants to the IMF, with all future grants requiring House approval. The move aims to support the IMF's poverty reduction and growth efforts.

site_title: Google to train 2 million Indian developers on Android
summary: Google has launched a programme to train 2 million Indian developers on its Android platform, aiming to create innovative mobile apps. The Android Skilling programme will be offered for free through hundreds of public and private universities and training schools in India. This move is part of Google's efforts to compete with Apple Inc in the country, where developers can create apps for various platforms. The programme will be available through the National Skills Development Corporation of India, starting this year.

site_title: China holds the cards if talks with Manila come to pass
summary: China is likely to have the upper hand in talks with the Philippines over the South China Sea dispute, as at least 60 countries have expressed support for China's stance not accepting any ruling made by the international tribunal. China's influence is growing, particularly in Africa, where 51 countries benefit from its investments. The Chinese government claims that features in the South China Sea, including low-tide elevations, are part of a single entity and have always been considered as a whole. This stance is expected to influence the outcome of the arbitration tribunal's decision.

site_title: Taking bilateral ties to a new high
summary: Switzerland's President Johann N Schneider-Ammann is on a state visit to Singapore, marking the first-ever visit by a Swiss head of state. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral ties in areas such as trade, investment, education, and innovation. Schneider-Ammann emphasizes the importance of cooperation in environmental protection, particularly in combating climate change, and in vocational education, citing Switzerland's successful dual-track apprenticeship model. He also highlights the need for continued engagement in international institutions and research cooperation, including with Singapore and other Southeast Asian countries. The visit is seen as a significant step in elevating bilateral relations between Switzerland and Singapore.

site_title: DBS sees pay off from digital investment
summary: DBS, ranked as the world's best digital bank by Euromoney magazine, is seeing the benefits of its digital investments, with a focus on using data analytics to drive productivity and expand its mobile-only banking strategy in Indonesia. CEO Piyush Gupta attributes the success to its digital transformation, which has helped reduce costs as a proportion of income.

site_title: China pension funds ready 2t yuan war chest for market foray
summary: China's pension funds, holding approximately 2 trillion yuan, are set to invest in the stock market, boosting yields for the low-return pension system. The National Council for Social Security Fund (NCSSF) will oversee the investments, starting in the second half of the year. The move aims to enhance yields for China's pension system, which has struggled with low returns. The NCSSF has a reputation for being a value investor, and its entry into the market is seen as a positive event for sentiment, although the actual impact may be gradual.

site_title: HDB inks S$10m deal for smarter estates
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has signed three agreements with industry partners for collaboration and research. A S$10 million contract with a consortium will develop a digital master plan and smart hub for HDB towns, focusing on smart initiatives and data analysis. A research collaboration with 3M Singapore will study noise mitigation in high-rise, high-density environments. Additionally, HDB will host a conference in 2017 to bring together housing and planning experts worldwide. These partnerships aim to improve HDB's planning and operations, and enhance the quality of life for residents.

site_title: Making cities more liveable and resilient
summary: Singapore and ETH Zurich are collaborating on the Singapore-ETH Centre, a research project focusing on making cities more liveable and resilient. Over 100 researchers work on two programs: the Future Cities Laboratory and the Future Resilient Systems. They aim to develop innovative solutions for sustainable and efficient urban planning, including energy-efficient cooling technologies, active mobility, and smart infrastructure systems. Recent projects include the 3for2 beyond efficiency project, which seeks to reduce building energy consumption by 40%, and the Reclaiming Backlanes project, which redesigns back lanes into vibrant public spaces.

site_title: Defiant Portugal gatecrash French party in style
summary: Portugal's national soccer team won the Euro 2016 title after substitute Eder scored the winning goal in extra time, defeating France 1-0. The victory marked Portugal's first major international title in 95 years, with the team showing resilience and determination despite losing their captain Cristiano Ronaldo early in the match. Portugal's performance was seen as a testament to the team's unity and composure, with the entire squad contributing to the historic win.

site_title: Brexit likely to dampen global growth: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam warns that Brexit is likely to dampen global growth due to economic and political uncertainties. While Singapore's growth is not expected to be significantly affected in the short term, the UK and Europe's growth may be reduced until trade and investment relationships are settled. Tharman also notes that the UK's ability to regain economic competitiveness and remain a valuable partner for Singapore depends on the outcome of the Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Equity investment gains boost LPI's H1 bottom line
summary: LPI Capital Bhd posted a 94.1 million SGD (RM278 million) profit for the first half of 2016, nearly doubling last year's earnings. The insurer rewarded shareholders with a 25 sen per share dividend and attributed its success to a "prudent underwriting approach." Despite Brexit uncertainties, LPI remains confident in its results, driven by equity investment gains.

site_title: BOC Aviation region's 2nd biggest cross-border IPO in H1
summary: BOC Aviation, a Singapore-based member of Bank of China Group, raised US$1.13 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, the second-largest cross-border IPO in the Asia Pacific for the first half of 2016. The Asia-Pacific cross-border IPO market declined by 68.2% to US$4.96 billion, primarily due to lower Chinese IPO volume and economic uncertainty. Despite this, the region remains the top choice for cross-border listings, with 60% of transactions in the past five years.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Global Invacom's subsidiary, Skyware Global, is believed to have a solid turnaround after a US visit, with major changes including restructuring of its key management team and manufacturing processes. Creative Technology warns of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. Meanwhile, Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer is 9.8 times oversubscribed. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Singapore stocks have rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Exercising for fitness and corporate success
summary: Strauss Zelnick, CEO of Take-Two Interactive, leads an exclusive fitness program called "The Program" in New York City, which combines high-intensity interval training with social camaraderie. The program, which has around 80 participants, aims to push Zelnick into a younger mindset and has become a key part of his work-life balance. Zelnick believes that exercise has driven his investment philosophy and has also changed how he runs his firm, encouraging employees to prioritize their well-being. The program is part of a growing trend of CEOs integrating athletics into their work lives, with toned bodies and calm minds becoming new metrics for success.

site_title: A masterpiece of engineering excellence - and a new attraction
summary: The Gotthard Base Tunnel, the longest train tunnel in the world, has officially opened in Switzerland, connecting neighboring countries, regions, and cities north and south of the Alps. The 57km-long tunnel, reaching depths of up to 2,300 meters, reduces travel time by 17 minutes and increases transport capacity. The tunnel, completed on schedule and on budget, is expected to perfect Switzerland's public transport system and enhance the country's strategic location as a hub for European goods traffic. The tunnel's opening marks a significant milestone in the AlpTransit project, which aims to improve public transport and shift transalpine freight traffic from road to rail.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Swiber Holdings is investigating legal options for a delayed US$200 million preference share subscription by AMTC Ltd. Singapore Press Holdings has partnered with Grapeshot for contextual categorization and targeting. Development 35 acquired a 1,115 sqm plot in Geylang for S$20 million. Golden Energy and Resources received a Dec 31 extension to restore its shareholding levels.

site_title: Brief
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed memorandums of understanding with Mitsubishi Electric and Scinor to test-bed new water technologies. PUB has signed a MOU with General Electric to reduce energy requirements for desalination and wastewater treatment. Memstar has opened a new membrane production facility in Singapore, doubling its production capacity. DHI is expanding its R&D centre with 60 new researchers. CH2M is positioning its Singapore operations as an InfraHub. John Holland Group has set up its regional office in Singapore, while Acciona is opening its first Asian office.

images.alt_text: As Singapore looks to reduce the energy requirements for desalination and wastewater treatment, PUB has signed a MOU with General Electric to explore ways to collaborate over technology in the next five years.

site_title: Water sustainability issue an opportunity for EU-Asian collaborations
summary: The European Union and Asian countries are exploring collaborations to address water sustainability issues, which are expected to affect half of the world's countries by 2025. Rapid urbanization and population growth in South-east Asia are already causing water stress, and Singapore has taken a lead in this area through its Singapore International Water Week. New smart water technologies and collective responses are needed to tackle these concerns, and EU-Asian collaborations could help drive innovation and solutions.

site_title: Singapore can learn from Swiss system: ITE chief
summary: Singapore can learn from Switzerland's vocational education and training (VET) system, which values skilled professionals over academic graduates. The Swiss VET system is highly regarded, with two-thirds of young people opting for it, providing deep skills learning and a solid foundation in a given occupation. Swiss apprenticeships typically last 3-4 years, combining work and study, and offer nationally recognized qualifications. The system is closely linked to the labor market, resulting in low youth unemployment rates. Singapore's Institute of Technical Education (ITE) is exploring ways to adopt a similar VET system, including in-company training and internships, to develop and deepen the skills of Singaporeans.

site_title: S'pore to kick off tenders for S$9.5b in water and waste projects
summary: Singapore will soon issue tenders for water and waste projects worth S$9.5 billion, starting from the third quarter of this year. The second phase of the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System (DTSS) will be the focus, with PUB calling for consultancy and construction tenders for various project components. This is part of Singapore's efforts to upgrade its water and waste infrastructure.

site_title: Boeing lifts 20-year forecast for new aircraft
summary: Boeing has revised its 20-year forecast for new aircraft, predicting 39,620 new planes worth $5.9 trillion will be needed by the world's airlines. This represents a 4.1% increase from last year's estimate, driven by growth in low-cost carriers and emerging markets. The forecast was made on the first day of the Farnborough Airshow in England.

site_title: Citigroup sees bullish commodities as spending cuts choke supply
summary: Citigroup forecasts a sustainable commodities market rally in the second half and beyond, driven by spending cuts curbing supply and moderate demand growth. Global demand is supported by expanding US and Chinese economies, while supply cuts are seen in petroleum, natural gas, base metals, and farm products. Citigroup is bullish on gold, soyabeans, and sugar, and expects strong investor flows into raw materials to resume in the second half, despite potential Brexit-related volatility.

site_title: EDB working with more Swiss firms who want to come here
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) is working with a growing number of Swiss companies to support their business in Asia. The EDB's managing director, Yeoh Keat Chuan, attributes the partnership to the strong bilateral relations between Singapore and Switzerland, which have strengthened in recent years. Swiss companies have been attracted to Singapore's competitive location, skilled workforce, and favorable business environment. The EDB is supporting Swiss companies in various sectors, including pharmaceuticals, electronics, and finance, and is also encouraging partnerships between Swiss and Singaporean institutions to develop the skills of Singaporean workers.

site_title: Post-Brexit uncertainties cloud benefits of cheaper pound
summary: The pound sterling has experienced a significant depreciation since the UK's Brexit vote on June 23, with a 13% drop against the US dollar and 10% against the euro. Proponents of Brexit had argued that a cheaper pound would boost the UK economy by lifting exports and foreign investment. However, the uncertainty surrounding post-Brexit trading arrangements and individual trade agreements with non-EU countries is casting doubt on these benefits, making it unclear if the pound's depreciation will lead to the desired economic boost.

site_title: Engie opens green-energy research lab in Singapore
summary: Engie, a French energy giant, has opened its first Asian research centre in Singapore, focusing on green energy and addressing key challenges in the region, including micro-grids, industrial energy efficiency, and gas technologies. The lab aims to develop decentralized energy systems for small islands and industrial sectors with high carbon footprints in South-east Asia. This move aligns with Engie's three-year strategy to shift towards renewable energy.

site_title: New CBD in Jurong to offer flexible spaces for future economy
summary: Singapore's second central business district, Jurong Lake District, will feature adaptable spaces for the future economy, with a focus on flexibility and innovation. The area will comprise high-quality office spaces, mixed-use development, and business parks, with a goal of achieving a more aggressive public transport mode share. The district will be anchored by the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High-Speed Rail terminus and will include a third new precinct, Lakeside Gateway, which has potential for 4-5 million sq m of total gross floor area. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a request for proposal (RFP) for master plan proposals, with shortlisted teams to develop concept master plans by February 2017.

site_title: Osborne heads to US and Asia as disarray roils UK politics
summary: Chancellor George Osborne is embarking on a two-week US and Asia tour to boost investor confidence in the UK economy, amid financial market turmoil following the Brexit vote. Osborne aims to persuade financiers to stick with the UK as it leaves the EU, despite economic challenges. The trip comes as the pound slumps to a 31-year low and real-estate funds are being frozen. The UK's Labour Party is also experiencing internal disarray, with former business spokeswoman Angela Eagle announcing a leadership bid.

images.alt_text: "My message to the world is that Britain may be leaving the EU, but we are not quitting the world," says Mr Osborne.

site_title: Travelling by public transport in Switzerland is a tourist's delight
summary: Switzerland's public transport system, known as the Swiss Travel System, offers a trouble-free travel experience with 26,000 km of train, bus, and boat routes. The system is integrated and allows tourists to travel easily to every corner of the country. Special tickets and passes, such as the Swiss Travel Pass & Co, provide unlimited travel and bonuses like free admission to museums and 50% discount on mountain railways. The Swiss Travel System also offers eco-friendly travel options, such as trains running on hydroelectricity, and convenient services like baggage transportation and dining on trains. With its compact size and numerous UNESCO World Heritage Sites, Switzerland is a unique travel destination that can be easily explored by public transport.

site_title: Theresa May will be UK's new PM from Wed: Cameron
summary: Theresa May will become the UK's new Prime Minister on Wednesday, promising to put the government at the service of "ordinary working people" and tackle the fears revealed by the EU referendum. She aims to heal rifts exposed by the vote and bring the country closer to the middle ground. May seeks to deliver on "Brexit" while also reforming the economy, enforcing annual pay votes, and boosting productivity. Her campaign focuses on giving people more opportunity and narrowing the pay gap between bosses and workers, a move seen as a shift to the centre ground.

site_title: Line prices IPO at top of range in year's biggest tech debut
summary: Japan's Line Corp set the price of its initial public offering at 3,300 yen apiece, at the top of the targeted range, and will sell 35 million shares. The mobile-messaging service, valued at about $6.9 billion, will raise 132.8 billion yen and begin trading in New York on July 14 and in Tokyo the next day. The IPO is despite market volatility caused by the Brexit decision, and Line aims to expand its 218 million user base beyond Japan, Taiwan, and Thailand.

site_title: MNCs in emerging nations fail to tackle corruption, poverty: anti-graft group
summary: A study by Transparency International found that 75% of the fastest-growing companies in emerging nations scored poorly in transparency tests, allowing corruption to persist and exacerbating poverty. The report criticized multinational companies for failing to tackle corruption, despite operating in 185 countries. The lack of transparency was seen as a major issue, allowing unscrupulous practices to continue unchecked.

site_title: SBF encourages S'pore businesses to explore Swiss opportunities
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) is encouraging Singaporean businesses to explore opportunities in Switzerland, citing the two countries' similar policy perspectives and economic attributes. Switzerland is Singapore's most important trading partner in South-east Asia, with bilateral trade reaching a record high of S$7.5 billion in 2015. SBF has been promoting business opportunities in Switzerland through various activities, including business luncheons and missions. The organization sees Switzerland as a valuable partner for Singaporean companies to learn from and collaborate with, particularly in areas such as innovation, entrepreneurship, and workforce development.

site_title: Swiss business association keen to play a bigger role
summary: Switzerland's president of the Swiss Business Association in Singapore, Tom Ludescher, emphasizes the potential for closer cooperation between the two countries in developing human capital and fostering talent. Both Singapore and Switzerland have high levels of education, low corruption, and a strong work ethic, making them attractive destinations for foreign companies and investors. The SBA is seeking to intensify exchanges between the two countries, including students, employees, and entrepreneurs, to promote mutual knowledge and talent sharing. The association aims to strengthen Swiss-Singaporean business ties, particularly in the tech industry, and increase collaboration in areas such as innovation and disruption trends.

site_title: China shouldn't see Jakarta's friendship as sign of weakness
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo recently visited the Natuna Islands, where he held a Cabinet meeting on board a warship that clashed with Chinese fishing vessels. The visit was intended to refocus China's attention on Indonesia's sovereignty, with President Widodo asserting that Indonesia's sovereignty is not negotiable. Despite the stern message, differences between the two countries are unlikely to escalate to the point of affecting their overall bilateral structure, which is characterized by comprehensive strategic partnerships on trade, investment, and military relations. Indonesia supports China's 21st Century Maritime Silk Road initiative and has joined the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, signaling a willingness to cooperate with China on regional development and peace.

site_title: Seacor buys 11 Pacific Richfield Marine vessels
summary: Seacor Marine acquired 11 vessels from Pacific Richfield Marine, with prices reportedly pegged at "a tiny fraction" of the ships' rock-bottom values. The vessels, averaging 3-12 years old, were taken over by Norwegian bank DNB and were available for charter. Industry sources suggest Seacor offered around 50 cents to every dollar for the vessels, but prices are likely to be based on future earnings, potentially several years away. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to acquire assets at bargain basement levels, with the vessels likely to lay up imminently.

site_title: Dymon hedge fund tops peers by positioning on right side of Brexit
summary: A top-performing hedge fund, Dymon Asia Currency Value Fund, has gained 13% in the first half of the year, outperforming peers, despite Brexit's impact on the markets. The fund, led by Gerald Chan, has taken bets on a stronger yen and a weaker pound, as well as a rise in gold prices. Investors using less leverage saw a 35% return, while those using borrowed money saw a 35% return. The fund's success is attributed to its ability to position itself on the right side of Brexit, while other macro hedge funds have posted losses this year.

site_title: Tapping Industry 4.0 for SMEs' business growth
summary: Switzerland Global Enterprise (S-GE) has stated that the fourth industrial revolution, also known as Industry 4.0, will benefit small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Switzerland, particularly those with a strong focus on innovation, productivity, and high-value-added offerings. The industry is shifting towards value-creation networks through data exchange and automation of production processes. SMEs in Switzerland are well-positioned to adapt to this new environment, with a high degree of agility, efficiency, and innovative capabilities. S-GE is launching a new "Export Digital" platform to support SMEs in digitizing their international business and accessing new export opportunities.

site_title: Don't neglect social inclusion as cities urbanise
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the importance of social inclusivity in cities as they urbanize. He urged innovation and globalization to benefit all society, not just a select few, by providing better jobs and affordable products and services. Tharman acknowledged concerns about job displacement and migration, but stressed that governments must intervene to support those who lose out, providing training and resources to equip them with relevant skills. He believes that innovation can be a source of inclusivity, and that a society can be both highly informed and open while still being inclusive.

site_title: Pokemon hit gives early taste of smartphone success
summary: Nintendo's Pokémon Go has generated a significant market value increase, adding over $7 billion since its release on July 7, with shares jumping 25% on Monday. The game's success is seen as a sign of potential for the company's mobile gaming future, with investors optimistic about the franchise's ability to drive growth. Pokémon Go's free-to-download model and in-app purchases have sparked a craze in the mobile gaming market, with players taking road trips and renting boats to catch virtual Pokémon.

site_title: Asia Square Tower 1 sets Asia-Pac record
summary: Singapore's Asia Square Tower 1 has set a record as the largest single-asset and office transaction in the Asia-Pacific region with a sale value of US$2.45 billion. The 43-storey retail and office building was sold by BlackRock to Qatar Investment Authority's sovereign wealth fund. This surpasses the previous largest single-asset transaction, Festival Walk in Hong Kong, and marks a significant deal for Singapore as a choice destination for cross-border investors, according to JLL.

site_title: A welcome message
summary: Switzerland's President Johann N Schneider-Ammann made the country's first state visit to Singapore, aiming to strengthen the excellent relationship between the two nations and celebrate their 50-year diplomatic ties in 2017. The visit focuses on areas such as education, science, and innovation, including vocational training and life-long learning. The Swiss community in Singapore, with 5,000 citizens and 400 registered companies, will also be highlighted during the visit. A business forum, "Skills Future - Developing a future ready workforce," will be held to identify new collaboration avenues.

site_title: Indonesia's top diesel buyer says biofuel rule unworkable
summary: Indonesia's state power firm PLN says it cannot comply with government rules requiring the use of B30 biodiesel due to potential damage to generators, which could curb demand for palm oil. The rule aims to reduce crude oil imports and greenhouse gas emissions. PLN's head, Chairani Rachmatullah, cited safety concerns, while the government's biofuel policy director, Rida Mulyana, vowed to investigate and potentially apply sanctions. This could impact palm oil prices, which are already affected by reduced utility biodiesel intake.

site_title: Wall Street rally rubs off on local market
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 29.1 points, or 1.02%, to 2,876.14 on Monday, following Wall Street's Friday rally. The gains were led by banks, Singtel, and Jardine C&C, but the 243-168 advance-decline score suggests the rally was not widespread. This comes as the Dow futures rose 40 points, and other Asian markets, including Hong Kong and Japan, also saw gains.

site_title: Riding the pull of digital advertising
summary: Digital advertising firm Adknowledge Asia connects agencies with advertisers via its proprietary tech platform AdParlor, specializing in social and video advertising. The company's CEO, Matt Sutton, notes that digital advertising is a "pull media" that generates consumption when users request it, allowing for targeted ads and higher ROI. Despite digital advertising's advantages, marketers in Asia are under-investing in online ad spend due to a lack of expertise and risk-averse attitude. Sutton advises SMEs to focus on digital marketing strategy and content generation to maximize ad dollars, and predicts that social and video advertising will dominate the digital advertising landscape.

site_title: Yuexiu acquires residential parcel in Zhejiang for 986m yuan
summary: Yuexiu Property Company acquired a land parcel in Zhejiang province, China for 986 million yuan (S$198 million). The parcel has a site area of 23,592 square meters and a total gross floor area of 76,792 sq m. The acquisition was made through an indirect non-wholly-owned subsidiary via open tender. The average land cost is approximately 12,800 yuan per sq m.

site_title: SGX draws from all international markets including China for listings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has emphasized its focus on sector strengths, including Reits and business trusts, consumer, healthcare, and digital sectors, to attract listings from Asia-Pacific markets. Despite China being a key market, SGX continues to have a presence in the country and welcomes Chinese companies to list on its platform. Recent notable listings include companies such as Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and China Everbright Water, and several Chinese companies have lodged their prospectus for an SGX mainboard listing, including EC World Reit and China Jinjiang Environment.

site_title: Bottlenecks expected as more Canadian oil meets tight pipe space
summary: Deeply discounted heavy crude from Alberta's oil sands is expected to fall further due to hundreds of thousands of barrels of new supply that will struggle to find space in crowded pipelines. This would be another hit for oil sands producers, who have already cut millions in capital expenditures and laid off thousands of workers. The added supply, including 200,000 bpd in 2016 and 110,000 bpd in 2017, will lead to congestion in the system, causing heavy crude to get discounted further against US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) and price spreads to blow out.

site_title: Genting HK to invest 100m euros in German group of shipyards
summary: Genting Hong Kong has invested 100 million euros (S$149 million) in a German group of shipyards, acquired in April. The investment will be used to upgrade manufacturing facilities, including a laser welding line and cabin module factory. Genting Group chairman and CEO KT Lim stated the goal of the investment is to enhance production capabilities and expand the company's presence in the global shipbuilding market.

images.alt_text: Genting Group chairman KT Lim also named industry veteran Jarmo Laakso as managing director of the German venture

site_title: Swiss vocational education works on a strong public-private partnership
summary: Switzerland's dual-track vocational and professional education system is being studied by Singapore as it develops its own model. A Singapore delegation visited Switzerland last year to understand the country's educational and career guidance systems. The Swiss system, which involves a strong public-private partnership, aims to effectively transmit skills and competencies to young people. This partnership is seen as a key factor in the system's success, and Singapore hopes to learn from it in developing its own vocational education model suited to its local economy.

site_title: Global push to make Mediterranean diet sexy again
summary: The Mediterranean diet, rich in vegetables, fruits, and olive oil, is facing a global decline due to the rise of fast food culture. Experts warn that the diet's decline may be irreversible, with 70% of Greeks and 50% of Spaniards adopting the diet in the past 30 years. The diet's decline is attributed to globalization and the growth of tourism, leading to increased consumption of meat and refined foods. The loss of the diet could have significant health and environmental impacts, including rising obesity and diabetes rates, as well as the loss of local skills and traditions.

site_title: Select's offerors extend unconditional offer to July 19
summary: A consortium led by Dymon Asia Private Equity has extended its unconditional general offer for restaurant operator Select Group to July 19. The offer price is 52.5 Singapore cents per share, and the consortium already owns or has received commitments for about 98.56% of Select's shares. The company plans to delist itself following the acquisition.

site_title: Transportation safety board also probing fatal Tesla crash
summary: A federal agency, the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), is investigating a fatal Tesla crash in Florida where a 2015 Tesla Model S operating in Autopilot mode failed to stop when a tractor-trailer turned in front of it. The NTSB, along with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and the Florida Highway Patrol, is examining whether the Autopilot system was at fault. The agency's involvement signals increased scrutiny of the technology, which has raised concerns about the risks of autonomous systems requiring driver intervention.

site_title: German prosecutors say won't be lenient with VW
summary: German prosecutors will not grant Volkswagen leniency in a record vehicle emissions settlement and are demanding a separate fine based on the company's profits from selling illicit engine software. The US government and regulators have agreed to a $15.3 billion settlement to remove about half a million emissions-cheating diesel cars from US roads. Prosecutors are seeking to recover the profits made by Volkswagen from selling these cars.

site_title: May to be confirmed as UK Conservative leader, and next PM
summary: Theresa May is likely to become the new leader of the UK's Conservative Party and prime minister, following Andrea Leadsom's withdrawal from the leadership contest. May will automatically take on the role once confirmed, replacing outgoing leader David Cameron. The process to confirm her leadership is expected to conclude "very soon," with no clear timeframe specified.

site_title: Business forum on SkillsFuture
summary: A Switzerland-Singapore business forum, themed "Developing a future ready workforce," will be held on Tuesday, focusing on Singapore's SkillsFuture and Switzerland's dual-track vocational education system. The forum aims to facilitate dialogue and exchange between industry stakeholders, experts, and policymakers. Keynote speakers include President of the Swiss Confederation Johann N Schneider-Ammann, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, and industry representatives such as Peter R Voser and Robert Yap. The event highlights the potential positive impact of sharing expertise and best practices on workforce development.

site_title: Shanghai interbank rate lowest since May
summary: Shanghai's interbank rate fell to a seven-week low of 2.93% as funds returned to the banking system following increased demand for quarter-end regulatory needs. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) withdrew a net 645 billion yuan in open-market operations, mopping up cash it had injected to meet demand. This decline comes despite signs that the central bank is against maintaining excessive liquidity, with data showing factory-gate deflation easing for the sixth month in a row.

site_title: Managing the world's liquid asset - water
summary: A shift in culture and mindset is needed to effectively manage the world's liquid asset - water. The global business community is increasingly aware of the importance of water as a business risk, particularly for industries that require significant amounts of water. Companies such as Nestle, Unilever, and Coca-Cola have made significant efforts to improve their water use efficiency and reduce their water footprint. However, the public sector has been slow to catch up, and there is currently no agreed-upon global standard for sustainability reports on water management. Investors are now demanding greater transparency and disclosure on water-related data, with some companies facing reputational risks even when water is available.

images.alt_text: The continuing California drought, and droughts in Australia, China and India, show that these events can directly affect the quality and levels of production, costs of doing business, and net profits.

site_title: UK hedge funds look to European watchdog to ease Brexit fears
summary: The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) is set to recommend whether hedge funds based in non-EU countries, such as the UK, should be allowed to sell products within the 28-nation EU bloc post-Brexit. The decision, expected this month, could determine London's status as the hedge-fund capital of Europe. If approved, UK funds may gain access to a marketing passport for European investors, potentially easing Brexit fears. However, the outcome is uncertain, with some industry experts expressing concerns about the potential impact on London's financial sector.

site_title: As engines of growth, cities need to be made more resilient to natural hazards
summary: Cities worldwide are increasingly vulnerable to natural disasters due to rapid urbanization, inadequate infrastructure, and lack of resilience measures. Despite the growing threat of disasters, cities have not matched the growth in disaster protection and resilience. Countries like Singapore, Japan, and Thailand have suffered from major disasters, highlighting the need for smart planning, investments, and partnerships to build strong and resilient cities. Investing in disaster risk reduction and management is crucial to mitigate the effects of climate change and rising sea levels, and can save billions of dollars in damages.

site_title: In Thatcher's footsteps: Theresa May, Britain's Brexit PM
summary: Theresa May, Britain's new Prime Minister, is a pragmatic leader who has emerged from the Brexit referendum unscathed. A Conservative and pragmatist, she was initially in favor of staying in the EU but stepped into the vacuum left by David Cameron's resignation. May insists on "Brexit means Brexit" but will not trigger the formal process until a negotiating strategy is clear. With her background in finance and experience as home secretary, May aims to unite a deeply split country and party, but faces an uphill struggle ahead.

site_title: France's Engie opens first Asian research lab in Singapore
summary: France's energy giant Engie has opened its first Asian research centre in Singapore, focusing on green energy. The Engie Lab Singapore will concentrate on decentralised energy systems, industrial energy efficiency, and gas technologies in the South-east Asian region, where many islands rely on diesel for power generation. This lab is part of a global network of 12 research centres, part of Engie's three-year transformation plan to focus on low-carbon activities.

site_title: Facebook sued for US$1b for alleged use of medium for terror
summary: A US$1 billion lawsuit was filed against Facebook, alleging the platform allowed Hamas to use it to carry out attacks that killed four Americans and wounded one in Israel, the West Bank, and Jerusalem. Facebook is accused of providing material support and resources to Hamas, allowing it to share operational and tactical information and post notices of upcoming attacks. The suit claims Facebook is liable for the violence, with Hamas considering the lawsuit an attack on freedom of the press and expression. The lawsuit was filed in the US District Court for the Southern District of New York.

site_title: Microsoft confirms Finnish site closure and job cuts
summary: Microsoft has confirmed the closure of its Finnish mobile phone unit and plans to cut up to 1,350 jobs in the Nordic country. The move is part of the company's plan to shed 1,850 jobs from its smartphone business, which it acquired from Nokia in 2014. The job cuts are the latest in a series of restructuring efforts by Microsoft aimed at improving its mobile business.

site_title: Development 35 acquires plot in Geylang for S$20m
summary: Development 35 has acquired a plot in Geylang, Singapore for S$20 million. The 1,115 sqm plot will be developed into an eight-storey residential block with a roof terrace and swimming pool, pending necessary approvals. Development 35 is 51% owned by TEE Land and 49% owned by KSH Holdings.

site_title: British Land rents out space in London's financial district after Brexit
summary: British Land Company Plc, a major London commercial landlord, has leased additional space in its "Cheesegrater" skyscraper to two tenants since the EU referendum. This move indicates confidence in London's status as a financial centre, despite concerns over Brexit's impact on the city's business and jobs. Head of offices and residential at British Land, Tim Roberts, stated that the commitments from occupiers demonstrate the enduring appeal of London, contradicting predictions of a downturn in the London property market.

site_title: Sembcorp in tie-up with two firms to test-bed emerging water technologies
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed memorandums of understanding with Mitsubishi Electric and Scinor (Asia) to test-bed emerging water technologies under the Industrial Living Lab initiative. The $8 million initiative aims to co-own intellectual property and potentially secure preferential pricing for the new technologies if successful. This collaboration may lead to improved water management and sustainability solutions, benefiting the environment and the company's operations.

site_title: Eight banks face US$1.5b annual bill for Brexit
summary: Eight major US and European banks face a potential annual cost of $1.5 billion if they need to relocate operations out of London due to Brexit. This translates to a 2% increase in annual expenses. The estimated costs could last for about five years, totaling $7.5 billion. Analysts predict higher costs for moving operations, restructuring, and obtaining necessary licenses and real estate licenses in Europe. The move could also affect banks' average return on equity, potentially cutting it to 6% in 2018.

site_title: US: S&P 500 Surges to all-time high
summary: The S&P 500 surged to an all-time intraday record, reaching 2,138.79, driven by Wall Street's confidence despite global growth concerns and market volatility. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.7%. The record-breaking performance comes as investors brush off worries over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: GLP sells 1.5b yuan of panda bonds; 3-years to yield 3.12%, 5-years to yield 3.58%
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) sold 1.5 billion yuan of panda bonds, yielding 3.12% for three-year bonds and 3.58% for five-year notes. The bonds, listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, were more than three times subscribed by institutional investors. GLP plans to use the funds to repay debt and fund business growth in China.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB agrees to request for arbitration filed by UAE's Ipic
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB has agreed to request for arbitration filed by UAE's International Petroleum Investment Company (Ipic) over a debt restructuring agreement that went sour. Ipic claims approximately $6.5 billion from 1MDB and Malaysia's finance ministry. 1MDB is confident in its legal position and has submitted a formal response to the request through its legal counsel.
