He also highlighted the ongoing struggle for American independence, emphasizing the importance of respecting each other and addressing issues like hunger.

site_title: NZ stocks rise on confidence, Australian shares fall on uncertainty
summary: New Zealand shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by business confidence rebounding in the second quarter. In contrast, Australian shares fell 0.96% due to uncertainty surrounding the Federal election. Financials sector was the hardest hit, with major banks experiencing declines. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 50.88 points to 5,230.9 points, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 21 points to 6,960.73.

site_title: Red, white and extra blue as tight security marks US July 4th celebrations
summary: The US celebrated the 4th of July holiday with parades, picnics, and fireworks displays across the country, despite heightened security concerns due to terrorism and gun violence. Police deployed additional officers and "vapor wake" dogs to monitor crowds, with New York City seeing nearly 2,000 new officers and Chicago increasing patrols by 5,000 officers. Despite some incidents, including a 19-year-old tourist injured by a homemade firework, the holiday was marked by patriotic events and festivities, with over 1 million people attending the Macy's Fireworks display in New York.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.970 points to 1653.000. The market saw 19.5 million lots traded worth RM7.12 million, with 60 gainers for every 48 losers.

site_title: Asia: Stock outlook clouded with silver in demand as crude falls
summary: Asian stock markets are expected to decline, following European shares, amid uncertainty after the UK's post-Brexit decision. The yen remained steady, while the Australian dollar held onto gains, and precious metals like silver rose. Economists predict the Reserve Bank of Australia will keep interest rates at a record low after the election. The odds of the Federal Reserve raising rates this year have decreased, with global growth slowdown threatening its plan for two hikes in 2016.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall in opening trade
summary: Tokyo shares fell at the start of trade on Tuesday, snapping a six-day rally. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.59% to 15,682.16, while the Topix index fell 0.40% to 1,256.87. This marks the end of a six-day winning streak for the Nikkei 225 index.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust to acquire Mapletree Business City for S$1.78b
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust is acquiring Mapletree Business City for S$1.78 billion, a discount of 2.6% to average valuations. The purchase will be funded through debt and equity, with up to 795 million new units issued. The deal will contribute a 5.6% net property income yield, higher than the Reit's existing 5.1% yield. The acquisition will increase MCT's portfolio to S$6.1 billion, up from S$4.3 billion.

site_title: Emirates chief sees scant benefit from EU-level aviation deals
summary: Emirates chief Tim Clark expressed doubts about the benefits of an EU-level aviation agreement with the UAE, citing existing deals as sufficient. The EU has given the European Commission a mandate to pursue air traffic agreements with the UAE, Qatar, and others to support the European aviation sector. Clark stated that he hasn't seen the mandate and is skeptical about how it would improve existing agreements, which he believes already provide favorable terms for Emirates. He also expressed concerns about Brexit's impact on demand and consumer confidence.

site_title: Watch your families, China party says after latest graft case
summary: China's ruling Communist Party has warned party members, especially leaders, to keep a tight leash on their family members to prevent corruption. A former top aide to retired President Hu Jintao was jailed for life after being found guilty of taking bribes and abuse of power. The party's official newspaper, the People's Daily, emphasized the importance of following rules and maintaining clean governance to maintain the party's winning position. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, with dozens of senior officials jailed during his term in office.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks retreat after 6-day rally, won inches down
summary: South Korean stocks retreated after a six-day rally, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) down 0.3% at 1,988.53 points. The won was pressured, down 0.5% against the dollar, as investors took profits and awaited the Federal Reserve's June meeting minutes and US jobs report. Foreign investors sold KOSPI shares worth 55.2 billion won, contributing to the decline. Chipmakers SK Hynix and SK Innovation lost 1.8% and 1.7%, respectively, with decliners outnumbering advancers 487 to 285.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence rebounds in second quarter: survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence rebounded in the second quarter, with 19% of firms expecting general business conditions to improve, up from 2% in the previous quarter, according to a private think tank's survey. This rebound is a significant improvement from the previous quarter.

site_title: Rio Tinto chief shelves giant Guinea iron ore project
summary: Rio Tinto has shelved its $20 billion Simandou iron ore project in Guinea due to a sustained slump in prices. Despite initial plans for a feasibility study and potential revenue of $7.5 billion, the project's viability was deemed unfeasible. Guinea's ministry of mines plans to pursue the project, stating a financing solution will be found with partners who share a long-term perspective.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Commercial Trust, Geo Energy, Lereno Bio-chem
summary: Geo Energy secured a coal supply deal worth US$1.2 billion with Engelhart Commodities Trading Partners. Mapletree Commercial Trust's trustee plans to acquire office and business park components for S$1.78 billion, potentially boosting the trust's net property income yield. However, Lereno Bio-Chem's independent auditor raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to significant losses and liabilities exceeding assets.

site_title: Silver tops US$21 for first time since '14 as investors seek haven
summary: Silver prices surged to a two-year high, reaching $21 for the first time since 2014, as investors sought a safe-haven asset amid uncertainty following the UK's Brexit vote. Gold also advanced for a fourth day, while mining shares rose sharply. Silver has jumped 47% this year, outpacing gold's 27% gain, and investors are buying more silver than gold. Analysts attribute the rally to speculation of central bank stimulus and a lower gold-silver ratio, which could favor silver's long-term performance.

site_title: Brexit will not hit Balkan EU aspirants: France, Germany
summary: French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Britain's exit from the EU will not impact the membership negotiations with Western Balkan nations. These nations, including Albania, Bosnia, Kosovo, Montenegro, and Serbia, aspire to join the EU, despite the bloc's current enlargement freeze until at least 2020. The leaders expressed determination to continue the enlargement process, which would provide these countries with a "beacon of stability and prosperity" amidst widespread poverty and turbulence in the region.

site_title: Alitalia strike action cancels 142 flights
summary: Alitalia canceled 142 flights on July 5 due to strike action by staff protesting the ending of certain employee benefits, including free travel to Rome and Milan. The airline condemned the strike as "incomprehensible and unfair." The Fit-Cisl labor union described it as an "attack on workers' rights." The cancellations affected around 20 flights operated by Meridiana, another Italian airline. The strike is linked to the airline's efforts to secure a partnership with Qatar Airways.

site_title: Greek capital controls can be lifted when confidence is fully restored: Finance minister
summary: Greek Finance Minister Euclid Tsakalotos said that capital controls can be lifted when public confidence is fully restored in the country's banking system. This confidence is contingent on the success of the recapitalisation process and the stability of the banks. Tsakalotos emphasized that it's a continuous process of liberalisation, and lifting capital controls will depend on the return of deposits to the banks and public trust in the measures taken to deal with bad loans.

site_title: Monsanto, Microsoft to invest in agricultural technology in Brazil
summary: US biotech company Monsanto and Microsoft Corp announced a partnership to invest in agricultural technology startups in Brazil. Monsanto will join a Brazilian investment fund with up to 300 million reais, evaluating ideas for new digital tools to apply to agricultural production. Selected startups will receive up to 1.5 million reais for early development, with the option to pay back the investment or convert it into equity. Technology company Qualcomm is also investing in the fund, aiming to foster new startups in the agricultural sector and drive research and development in the country.

site_title: Suicide bombers hit three Saudi cities, killing at least four officers
summary: Suicide bombers struck three Saudi cities, killing at least four security officers. The attacks targeted US diplomats, Shi'ite worshippers, and a security headquarters at a mosque in Medina, coinciding with the approach of Eid al-Fitr. The bombings follow mass killings claimed by the Islamic State group in Turkey, Bangladesh, and Iraq. The coordinated attacks seem to be part of a larger campaign by the group to disrupt celebrations during the holy month of Ramadan.

site_title: Clinton blasts Trump over 'anti-semitic' tweet
summary: Hillary Clinton criticized Donald Trump for posting a "blatantly anti-Semitic" tweet featuring a picture of herself with stacks of money and a six-pointed star, which Trump claimed resembled a sheriff's star, not the Jewish Star of David. Clinton called the tweet "anti-Semitic."

site_title: France must "react" to Britain corporation tax cut: presidential aspirant
summary: France's presidential aspirant Alain Juppe says the country must "react" to Britain's plan to cut corporation tax to below 15% and enact reforms to reduce its budget deficit. Juppe aims to prove France is competitive, pressing for fiscal harmonization within the EU. He plans to cut the corporate tax rate and scrap a wealth tax if elected, aiming to close the gap between France's tax rate and the EU average. Juppe's goal is to attract big business to Paris, capitalizing on the Brexit vote.

site_title: Coal dust kills 23,000 per year in EU: report
summary: A new report by a coalition of green energy groups reveals that coal dust from EU power plants causes 23,000 premature deaths annually and 12,000 new cases of chronic bronchitis, with costs totaling 32.4-62.3 billion euros. Fine particulate matter from coal-fired plants enters deep into the lungs and bloodstream, leading to strokes, heart disease, and lung cancer. The report blames 280 coal-fired plants across the EU, with the five countries most affected being Germany, Italy, France, Greece, and Hungary.

site_title: Uptick in enquiries, now that oil prices have stabilised
summary: Offshore drilling activity has seen an uptick in enquiries, with oil prices stabilizing between $40-$50. However, industry veterans warn that the supply overhang may hinder the sub-sector's return to profitability. Several rig contracts are in the pipeline, including a five-year deal with BP for a development-drilling campaign. Analysts caution against discounted rig day rates, predicting lower rates of $70,000-$100,000 for premium jack-ups. Rig-builders, including SembCorp Marine and Keppel Offshore & Marine, are adapting to the downturn by focusing on higher-value contracts and acquiring new capabilities.

site_title: New measures for more secure govt e-services
summary: Singapore is introducing two-factor authentication (2FA) for most government e-services, starting Tuesday, to enhance security. Around 80% of 2 million SingPass users have already activated 2FA, with 400,000 yet to do so. A 30-day grace period will be given to these users to register and activate their 2FA, allowing them to perform urgent transactions. The IDA has assured users that security remains a priority and will monitor the take-up rate before removing the grace period.

site_title: Rio Tinto's new boss rules out spinoff, sale of unloved assets
summary: Rio Tinto's new CEO, Jean-Sebastien Jacques, rules out spinning off or selling its unloved assets, including coal and uranium, citing they are run for cash. The company's newly formed energy and minerals division will serve as an "incubator" for new businesses outside its core areas. Jacques plans to focus on growth through acquisitions, particularly in copper, and is open to exploring lithium opportunities, which could benefit from the electric car revolution.

images.alt_text: Mr Jacques, aged 44, is the youngest chief executive in Rio's 143-year history, and the first born in France.

site_title: Geo Energy secures offtake deal worth US$1.2b for Indonesian coal mine
summary: Geo Energy has secured a $1.2 billion offtake deal with Engelhart Commodities Trading Partners (ECTP) for its Indonesian coal mine, PT Sungai Danau Jaya. The deal will supply 10 million tonnes of coal from July 1 to December 31, with an option to sell an additional 4 million tonnes. The agreement is worth an estimated $1.2 billion at current coal prices, and will allow Geo Energy to focus on expanding its coal production. The deal is seen as a strong testament to the company's track record of delivering coal.

site_title: Pessimism among UK businesses almost doubles after EU vote: survey
summary: UK businesses show almost double pessimism about the economy following the EU vote, with 49% expecting a poor economic outlook over the next 12 months, up from 25% before the vote. The Brexit decision has led to economic uncertainty, a drop in sterling, and clouded the economic outlook. The survey results reinforce concerns that the economy could be in for hard times.

site_title: Neo-Soviet street style is all the rage
summary: Vetements, a prominent fashion brand, showcased a provocative haute couture show in Paris, defying traditional rules of haute couture by incorporating clothes from 17 other brands, including Levi's and Brioni. The show featured jarring designs, such as oversized jackets and diamond-shaped peep holes, and blurred the lines between high- and low-end brands. Vetements' founder, Demna Gvasalia, aimed to challenge the fashion system and promote more efficient production methods, resulting in a show that sparked both shock and admiration.

site_title: Honeywell buys supply-chain firm for US$1.5b in return to bite-size M&A
summary: Honeywell International Inc has acquired warehouse automation company Intelligrated for $1.5 billion, its largest purchase so far this year. The deal will help Honeywell tap into the growing demand for fulfilment centers spurred by online commerce. Intelligrated designs and installs warehouse automation systems, which aligns with Honeywell's scanning and mobility business. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of the third quarter and is part of Honeywell's strategy to spur profit through smaller deals, following a record-breaking attempted $90 billion takeover bid that was scrapped.

site_title: Gold glitter looks set to continue - at least for rest of the year
summary: Gold prices continue to rise, trading near a two-year high, amid global economic uncertainty and low interest rates. Analysts forecast the metal's rally will persist through the end of the year, with central banks expected to maintain liquidity and intervene if needed. However, some investors, such as Jim Rogers, question the metal's upside potential, citing a 25% rise in gold prices this year and potential dollar strength. Despite this, gold exchange-traded funds have seen inflows, and central bank purchases are expected to increase, supporting the metal's price.

site_title: Accounting fraud: making it less likely by raising the chances of detection
summary: Accounting fraud remains a significant issue worldwide, with estimated costs of $1.7 million in direct losses and $600,000 in additional costs. Traditional methods of detecting fraud have limitations, and new research has developed an ensemble learning model that outperforms existing methods, predicting accounting frauds 10-fold more accurately. The model uses raw accounting data and employs a machine learning approach to identify firms at high risk of fraud, providing an early warning for further investigation and potentially deterring potential fraudsters.

site_title: Top South Korean carrier unveils cut-rate Internet of Things web
summary: SK Telecom Co, South Korea's largest mobile carrier, has completed a nationwide low-cost IoT network using LoRa technology, aiming to connect over 4 million devices by the end of next year. The carrier will invest $117 million and charge a monthly flat rate of under $2 for 100 megabytes of data to drive adoption. The move is part of its strategy to outstrip rivals and generate new revenue from IoT services, including device tracking and smart home control.

site_title: Heartbreak, selfies and soccer: the life of a Bangladesh cafe killer
summary: Nibras Islam, a 25-year-old student from Bangladesh, was among at least six gunmen who attacked an upscale restaurant in Dhaka on Friday night, killing 20 people, mostly foreigners. The attack appears to have been a revenge attack against the restaurant's owner, who was accused of making derogatory comments about Islam on social media. Police suspect Nibras was the mastermind behind the attack, which was also captured on camera, including a selfie taken by one of the perpetrators. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, but it is believed to be linked to Islam's online presence and social media activities.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Healthcare expenditure in Singapore is projected to triple by 2030, reaching S$44 billion, driven by an ageing demographic. Brokers have upgraded or maintained their ratings on healthcare companies, including IHH, SOG, and ParkwayLife Reit. EZION Holdings has proposed a renounceable underwritten rights issue, but its operating environment remains tough. Sembcorp Marine is undergoing a tough period due to the cyclical downturn of the O&M sector, with a "sell" rating and a target price of S$1.16.

site_title: Era of high food prices probably over but risks remain: report
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) report that the era of high food prices is likely over, with a 1.5% yearly rise in crop production globally and a 20% jump in agricultural output in South-east and East Asia over the next decade. Despite this, the report warns of the need for vigilance due to the high probability of major price swings. Livestock prices are expected to rise relative to crop prices as demand for meat and feed grows in emerging economies.

site_title: America's politics is broken
summary: A Pew poll found that only 19% of Americans trust the government all or most of the time, a significant decline from 77% in 1964. The country is disillusioned with politics and government, with many viewing the election as a choice between lesser evils. The breakdown of traditional compartments, such as rigid gender roles and racial segregation, has led to increased conflicts, but the political system has struggled to contain them. Weakened political parties, limited powers for party leaders, and the rise of ideological extremes have contributed to the country's political paralysis, making it difficult to find a consensus on how to address pressing issues.

site_title: Essentials of NextGen leadership in times of great flux
summary: Conventional leadership development practices are inadequate for the 21st-century business environment, requiring a broader skills set for rising leaders to address global demands such as climate change, demography, and technology. Effective global leaders must think and act globally, embracing cross-cultural diversity and collaborative relationships. With the "Baby Boomer" generation retiring at pace, leaders must operate with urgency to inspire and engage people while addressing changing customer requirements and delivering results.

site_title: Hotdog-eating champ tastes victory again in US contest
summary: Joey "Jaws" Chestnut reclaimed his title as hot dog eating champion at the Nathan's Hot Dog Eating Contest on Coney Island, consuming a record 70 hotdogs in 10 minutes. Chestnut broke his previous record of 69 hotdogs and surpassed challenger Matt "Megatoad" Stonie, who came in second with 53 hotdogs. Miki Sudo won the women's contest for the third time with 38.5 hotdogs, and the competition awarded a total prize purse of $40,000. Chestnut trains regularly and has previously eaten 205 chicken wings and 30 gyros in record times.

images.alt_text: Legendary competitive eater Joey "Jaws" Chestnut wolfed down a record 70 hotdogs - buns and all - in just 10 minutes on Monday to reclaim his crown at an annual New York competition.

site_title: EFG to focus on basics, discretionary funds in rebuilding BSI
summary: EFG International, a Swiss bank, will rebuild BSI Bank's tarnished business by focusing on fundamentals, leveraging its strengths in fixed income and US equities, as well as discretionary services. The takeover of BSI comes after investigations into allegedly improper money movements at Malaysian state investment company 1MDB. EFG Asset Management sees growth opportunities in discretionary portfolio management, which is a fast-growing sector in Asia. The bank expects uncertainty surrounding Britain's EU exit to continue, but is overweight on the US, Japan, and Asian emerging markets.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Temasek Holdings has invested 510 million euros (S$764 million) in French asset manager Tikehau Capital Partners as part of two capital increases, acquiring a stake of more than 5% in the holding company. This marks Temasek's first investment in both Tikehau Capital Partners and its holding company, Tikehau Capital Advisors.

site_title: Starting early on meeting new sustainability reporting standards
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced new sustainability reporting standards, requiring listed companies to disclose their sustainability practices or explain why they do not. The requirements, set to take effect from December 31, 2017, are part of a growing trend among exchanges and investor networks to promote transparency and accountability. The SGX requirements align with the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) guidelines but have some notable differences, including a requirement for the board to state its consideration of sustainability issues and the need for performance targets for material ESG factors.

site_title: Tackling unproductive productivity solutions
summary: Singapore's efforts to boost productivity have yielded mixed results, with some companies experiencing decreased operational efficiency after implementing productivity solutions. A piece-meal approach to productivity, focusing on isolated parts of the workflow process, can lead to bottlenecks and decreased efficiency. Successful companies, on the other hand, have integrated productivity solutions with back-end kitchen processes, resulting in improved efficiency and customer satisfaction. To achieve lasting productivity gains, companies must adopt a holistic view of their workflow and consider the interdependencies across workflows, rather than focusing solely on technological solutions.

site_title: Singtel staff to get 2 days off for SkillsFuture courses
summary: Singtel will give its full-time staff two days of leave each year to attend SkillsFuture courses, supporting the Singapore government's initiative to equip employees with necessary skills for digital ventures. This move aims to encourage staff to manage their own professional development. Over 10,000 employees across Singtel and its subsidiary NCS will benefit from this additional leave.

site_title: Turnbull in for hard time even if he gets to form next Aussie government
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is likely to face a hard time in his next government, regardless of whether his coalition secures a majority in the House of Representatives. The country's preferential voting system may take weeks to finalize, and Turnbull's own party colleagues, particularly those to his right, may attempt to undermine his leadership. The incoming government may also face economic challenges, including sluggish demand and weak profits. Meanwhile, the return of Senator Pauline Hanson, who has been elected on an anti-establishment platform, could pose a threat to Turnbull's minority government, and he may need to make concessions to independents to pass legislation.

site_title: Ignore court ruling and we can talk, China offers Philippines
summary: China is prepared to start negotiations with the Philippines on South China Sea-related issues if Manila ignores an upcoming arbitration ruling on July 12, which contests China's claims to the sea. China has rejected the arbitration case, claiming the court has no jurisdiction, and plans to hold military drills around the disputed Paracel Islands. Negotiations could cover joint development and scientific research if the Philippines ignores the tribunal's ruling.

site_title: Singapore expected to lag regional peers in retail sales: report
summary: Singapore's retail sector is expected to underperform its regional peers, with an estimated annualized growth of 10.5% from 2015 to 2018, according to a Frost & Sullivan study. Despite this, the country's affluent population is likely to provide stability, particularly in luxury goods. In contrast, Indonesia and Malaysia are expected to drive growth in the region, with estimated annualized growth rates of 18.5% and 17.5%, respectively, to reach a combined retail sales of US$1 trillion by 2018.

site_title: Japan's N-reactor move sparks safety warnings
summary: Japan's Nuclear Regulation Authority has recertified two ageing reactors, allowing them to operate beyond 40 years, despite safety concerns raised by a former commissioner. The move has sparked warnings that Tokyo is neglecting the lessons of the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Critics argue that the regulator is prioritizing industry pressure over public safety, and that a powerful quake in April highlighted the risk to Japan's nuclear reactors. The move has also raised concerns about the regulator's ability to effectively oversee the industry, with some experts saying it is "failing" in its oversight of Fukushima.

site_title: Brexit weakens EU's non-euro members
summary: Denmark's bank watchdog, the Financial Supervisory Authority, warns that the UK's departure from the EU will weaken the ability of non-euro members to shape financial regulation. Director General Jesper Berg states that the UK's influence will be missed, citing its intellectual leadership and close ties to a large financial market. This loss may hinder efforts to establish common financial standards among EU member states.

site_title: Singapore chalks up 383 deals worth US$43.4b in first half-year
summary: Singapore recorded 383 deals worth US$43.4 billion in mergers and acquisitions, private equity, venture capital, and IPOs for the first half of 2016, up 16% from the same period in 2015. M&A transactions accounted for 339 deals worth US$40.5 billion, with sovereign wealth funds GIC and Temasek Holdings driving the growth. Singapore's M&A deal volumes grew 16% but deal values declined by 35% compared to the same period in 2015.

site_title: Brexit adds to the jitters in O&M sector's recovery
summary: The offshore-and-marine (O&M) sector has seen a glimmer of hope in the stabilisation of oil prices at $40 to $50 per barrel, offering a turnaround since 2014. However, the industry remains vulnerable to concerns over the macroeconomic environment, particularly following the Brexit vote. Despite an increase in enquiries from new oil-and-gas field developments, the sector remains cautious.

site_title: Brooklyn neighbourhood is where Airbnb is being put to the test
summary: A study found that rents in New York City's historically African-American neighbourhoods, such as Bedford-Stuyvesant, rose the fastest due to Airbnb's presence. The report, "Short Changing New York City," used 2015 Airbnb data and was commissioned by affordable housing advocates. This trend contradicts the idea that Airbnb helps lower rents, as it was expected to increase competition and drive down prices. The study highlights the need for regulation and oversight of short-term rentals to address gentrification and affordability issues in the city's neighbourhoods.

images.alt_text: New York City rents have risen fastest in gentrifying areas such as Bedford-Stuyvesant, where Airbnb is most popular.

site_title: Nissan CEO stirs fear in Mitsubishi factory town
summary: Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn's plan to acquire 34% of scandal-tainted Mitsubishi Motors Corp has sparked fear in the factory town of Mizushima, Japan. The town, which is home to Mitsubishi's flagship assembly plant, is struggling after the company was found to have improperly tested fuel economy and manipulated data, leading to production halts and job losses. Ghosn's arrival is expected to bring significant changes, including cost-cutting measures, and may lead to further job losses. The town's suppliers and employees are uncertain about the future, fearing a "Nissan Way" that may abandon them.

site_title: Dhaka attack casts shadow over garment industry
summary: A deadly attack on a Dhaka cafe on July 1, 2016, has raised concerns about the future of Bangladesh's garment industry, which relies heavily on foreign trade. The 20-person massacre, carried out by Islamic State jihadists, has sparked fears that the industry could be severely impacted, with foreign brands potentially being turned away from the poverty-stricken nation due to safety concerns. The attack has cast a shadow over the industry's future, which is built on cheaply supplying fashion to major brands.

site_title: India-based jewellery company makes S$12m investment in S'pore
summary: India-based jewellery company GRT Jewellers has made a S$12 million investment in Singapore, opening its second international showroom on Serangoon Road. The company plans to use Singapore as a hub for future international expansion, with a goal of reaching 100 stores globally within the next 10 years. GRT aims to make close to S$100 million in investments in the region over the next five years. The company's presence in Singapore is seen as a strategic move, with the city-state offering ease of doing business and transparency.

site_title: MMP Resources plans to buy Hokkaido ski operator for S$1m
summary: MMP Resources plans to acquire Hokkaido ski operator JRT Trading for 80 million yen (S$1.05 million) in cash, repaying a 37.5 million yen loan in the process. The acquisition is part of the group's new strategy to focus on construction opportunities, asset acquisitions, and brand growth in tier one markets. MMP Resources has seen a turnaround in its financials, reporting a profit of S$229,000 in the first quarter and 80% revenue growth. The deal is seen as a strategic move to diversify the company's portfolio.

site_title: China criticises Japan over 'dangerous' jet scramble
summary: China criticized Japan over a military aircraft scramble on June 17, with the Chinese defense ministry stating two Japanese jets took "provocative actions" at high speed near Chinese fighter jets in the East China Sea. The Japanese military acknowledged the scramble but denied any radar lock or danger. China called for Japan to cease provocative actions, amid a dispute over East China Sea islands. The incident follows Japan's top military commander accusing China of escalating military activity in the region.

images.alt_text: Japan is embroiled in a dispute with China in the East China Sea over ownership of a group of islands which lie about 220 km north-east of Taiwan.

site_title: Final Four ready for semi-final showdown
summary: The Euro 2016 football tournament in France kicked into high gear over the weekend, with four quarter-final matches producing 15 goals and several dramatic moments. The games were marked by penalty shootouts, with Portugal and Poland, and Germany and Italy, needing extra time to determine their winners. Underdog Wales continued its fairytale journey, while Iceland bid farewell to the tournament. The semi-finals are set to take place, with the stage now set for a thrilling showdown between the last four teams.

site_title: When US cities spurn growth, national equality suffers
summary: US cities experiencing rapid growth are often met with anti-growth sentiment, threatening national equality. Research suggests that restrictive zoning laws contribute to stagnant economies, racial segregation, and deeper class disparities. The high cost of living in affluent cities like Boulder, San Francisco, and New York City is driving lower-skilled workers to cheaper areas, exacerbating income inequality. Efforts to streamline zoning laws are underway, with politicians and developers joining forces to address the issue, which economists say can have profound damage to the American economy and society.

site_title: Cryan, Thiam score failing grades one year into their jobs
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan and Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam received failing grades in an informal survey of investors and analysts one year into their jobs, reflecting doubts about their ability to turn around the banks. Despite this, Thiam scored better on strategic thinking, while Cryan won marks for communication and execution. The banks' shares have lost over half their value in the past year, with Deutsche Bank trading at a third of its tangible book value and Credit Suisse at half. The CEOs must show their strategies are bearing fruit to reverse the decline.

site_title: Temasek beefs up footprint in medtech sector
summary: Temasek Holdings has strengthened its presence in the medical technology (medtech) sector with two key investments. Accuron Technologies, a unit within Temasek's tech and engineering holding company, has acquired a majority stake in Malaysian medical device maker Aurum Healthcare Sdn Bhd, expanding Temasek's medtech offerings. Additionally, ASLAN Pharmaceuticals, a biotech startup backed by Temasek, has raised US$23 million in a pre-IPO financing round, setting up for a 2017 listing. These investments demonstrate Temasek's bullishness on the medtech sector, positioning Accuron and ASLAN for growth.

site_title: Transport problems risk snarling Rio's Olympic dream
summary: Rio de Janeiro is one month away from hosting the Olympics, but transport issues remain a major concern for residents. The metro system, a key infrastructure project, is unfinished and will only be completed on August 1, just before the Games. Locals face a daily nightmare of long bus rides and packed, often late buses. The government has proposed emergency measures, including a temporary bus line and special lanes for Olympic-related vehicles, but experts predict major traffic jams. Despite this, 61% of residents believe the Games will be a success, but 85% see crime and 39% see transport issues as potential problems.

site_title: Trendlines' roadshow features seven portfolio companies
summary: The Trendlines Group, an agritech and medtech incubator, launched its first Asian roadshow in Singapore, featuring seven of its Israel-based medical portfolio companies. The entrepreneurs made presentations at the event, which will also cover Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing. The roadshow aims to promote the group's medical portfolio companies and expand its presence in the Asian market.

site_title: Aussie credit rating under threat
summary: Australia's top credit rating is under threat due to a national election result that left the country without a strong majority government. A budget gap of over $30 billion must be reversed, requiring tax increases, spending cuts, or structural reforms to boost economic growth. These options pose significant political challenges, making it uncertain whether the nation's credit rating will be maintained. The credit rating agency has warned that any failure to address the budget gap could lead to a downgrade.

site_title: Berenberg gets US$500m private equity boost for ship loans
summary: Berenberg, Germany's oldest bank, has secured US$500 million in private equity funding to invest in ship loans. The bank, seeking to fill funding gaps left by peers, has signed a memorandum of understanding with an international investment firm to jointly grant loans to 400 shipping clients. This move comes as the ship loan asset class, abandoned by many peers, regains some popularity. The partnership aims to capitalize on the growing demand for shipping finance.

site_title: Businesses bemoaning Brexit welcome Osborne's tax-cut proposal
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne proposes slashing corporate taxes to 15% to boost business investment and signal the UK's openness for business, following the Brexit vote. Business groups welcome the move but argue it's just one step to reassure investors. Osborne's vision for a "super competitive economy" contrasts with warnings of a slowing effect on investments. The proposal faces objections from EU countries, including Germany, which may press Ireland to increase its corporate tax rate.

site_title: STI up 24 points amid fresh easing hopes
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) rose 24.19 points or 0.85% to 2,870.56, driven by hopes of central bank easing measures to support the global economy following the Brexit outcome. The market saw gains across Asia, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng advancing 0.6% and 1.3%, respectively. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) also rose, with the FTSE ST Reit index up 9.81 points. Despite some caution from market strategist Bernard Aw, the market appears to be stabilizing, with HSBC's Asia Pacific Herald van der Linde noting the limited impact of Brexit on Asia equities.

site_title: Realtors pitch Toronto, Vancouver to soak up capital flight from Brexit
summary: Realtors in Toronto and Vancouver are capitalizing on the UK's post-Brexit economic uncertainty by pitching Canadian cities as safe havens for foreign investors. With the pound at a record low, wealthy buyers are seeking bargains, and Canada's stable economy is attracting attention. This could lead to increased demand for homes, condos, and office towers in these cities, potentially exacerbating the existing issue of record-high home prices.

site_title: European shares feel Brexit draught
summary: European shares declined on July 4, 2016, amid uncertainty over Britain's EU exit. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.8% and the FTSE 250 dropped 2.1%. A stern European Central Bank warning on Italy's Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena's bad-debt burden weighed on financials. Meanwhile, Asian stocks rose on hopes of more stimulus for economies, with the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also declining. Investors await guidance from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes and US June jobs data.

site_title: S'pore June PMI slumps, putting aside talk of 'green shoots'
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector saw a decline in June, contrary to expectations of "green shoots" in the sector. Economists attribute the drop to the fading effects of increased production after February, suggesting that manufacturing will settle at lower levels this year. DBS economist Irvin Seah stated that those seeking positive signs in manufacturing may instead see negative outcomes. The sector's performance is expected to be worse than last year's.

site_title: No guarantees for EU citizens in UK without reciprocal deal: UK immigration minister
summary: UK immigration minister James Brokenshire stated that Britain should not guarantee the right of European Union nationals to remain in the country without reciprocal assurances from other EU states. He emphasized that EU nationals would still be welcome in Britain, but a parallel assurance for British nationals living in the EU is necessary. This comes as the UK's decision to leave the EU has raised concerns about the status of foreign nationals and Britons abroad.

site_title: 'Noisiest park in the world' pipes down
summary: China's People's Park in Chengdu, known for its noisy amateur dancers and musicians, has significantly reduced noise levels after installing noise monitors. The park, dubbed the "noisiest park in the world," had previously faced conflicts with residents due to loud activities, with some complaining about disturbances. The new noise limits, set at 80 decibels, have resulted in a noticeable decrease in noise levels, with many residents praising the change, saying it has made the park a more enjoyable place to visit.

site_title: Aussie dollar recovers after shaky start
summary: The Australian dollar recovered from a weak start on Monday, rebounding to US$0.7530 after global commodities rose and safe-haven currencies fell. The recovery was driven by expectations of further stimulus from central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, to offset the impact of the Brexit vote. Meanwhile, sterling rose to US$1.3290, stabilizing after a 31-year low, and bond markets rallied with Treasury yields falling sharply. The outcome of Australia's election, which produced no clear winner, is seen as having little impact on the currency.

site_title: SingPost to adopt corporate governance review proposals (Amended)
summary: SingPost will adopt the recommendations of the Corporate Governance Review, except for the recommendation to remove non-independent directors with over nine years' tenure. The company will implement guidelines for mergers and acquisitions, document processes, and establish a market disclosure committee. SingPost aims to have a 10-member board with directors having expertise in law, e-commerce logistics, and finance and accounting. The company has already addressed some recommendations, such as introducing a board code of business conduct and ethics. SingPost will prioritize implementing the remaining recommendations by the end of September.

site_title: Amazon is quietly eliminating list prices
summary: Amazon is quietly eliminating list prices from its product listings, replacing them with a single price without any mention of a discount. This shift comes as the company aims to create a seamless shopping experience, where buying happens naturally and frequently. By removing the emphasis on discounts, Amazon hopes to encourage customers to make purchases without being swayed by price comparisons. The change is part of Amazon's broader strategy to become deeply embedded in customers' lives, with the goal of increasing sales volume and revenue.

site_title: After Brexit, EU proposes tougher tax rules on trusts
summary: The European Commission is proposing stricter rules on trusts to prevent tax evasion, requiring beneficial owners to be recorded in public registers. This move comes after the Brexit referendum, which has weakened Britain's influence in EU discussions. The new rules, which will be formally adopted by the Commission, follow the publication of the Panama Papers revealing widespread tax avoidance practices. Britain may ignore these new rules after completing its exit from the EU, but EU leaders have stated that it must fully apply European Union legislation to maintain access to the EU internal market.

site_title: StanChart PE takes 'significant' stake in Phoon Huat
summary: Standard Chartered Private Equity (SCPE) has taken a "significant stake" in Singapore-based food and beverage wholesaler Phoon Huat Pte Ltd, providing strategic input and support for the company's development plans. This investment follows SCPE's US$52 million investment in Crystal Jade Group Holdings last year. Phoon Huat, founded in 1947, runs 12 retail stores and supplies bakery, beverage, and confectionary ingredients to restaurants and households. The deal is seen as a boost for the company's succession planning, with SCPE's management expertise and network to help take the business further.

site_title: China's Midea buys 25.1% stake in Germany's Kuka for US$1.3b
summary: China's Midea Group Co has acquired a 25.1% stake in German robot firm Kuka AG for US$1.3 billion. Voith GmbH sold its stake, generating about $1.79 billion. Midea's shares rose 13%, while Kuka's shares jumped 26%. Kuka's CEO Till Reuter backed the deal, promising job and plant protection until 2023.

images.alt_text: Kuka's heavy industrial robotic arms and its nifty commercial robot that can fill a glass of beer (above) are the toast of the recent Kuka AG exhibition in Munich, Germany.
Kuka's heavy industrial robotic arms and its nifty commercial robot that can fill a glass of beer are the toast of the recent Kuka AG exhibition in Munich, Germany.

site_title: July 4 food mail orders a big business in US
summary: US restaurants see a surge in demand for nostalgia-inducing foods during the Fourth of July weekend, with many specializing in cross-country orders. Companies like Montgomery Inn, Ben's Chili Bowl, and Graeter's report significant sales, with online orders making up a substantial portion of their business. The convenience of online ordering, fueled by travel shows on the Food Network and the Travel Channel, has contributed to the growth, with some companies generating millions of dollars in revenue from mail orders.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.62 points to 1,654.840. The index saw 1 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.22 billion, but losers outnumbered gainers 363 to 338.

site_title: MayAir looks to grow in China and beyond
summary: MayAir Group Plc, a clean-air specialist, aims to expand its commercial segment in China and beyond, driven by the growing demand for air filtration systems. The company, which has been in the China market for 15 years, expects to benefit from the country's continued pollution problems. MayAir plans to diversify its business, focusing on the industrial sector in South-east Asia and commercial sector in China, with a growth rate of about 5% in the region. The company has seen a rise in brand recognition and is confident in its ability to compete on quality, delivery, and service.

images.alt_text: Buildings are shrouded in haze in Huangpu, Shanghai. Because China's pollution problems will not disappear overnight, MayAir, with its track record in industrial clean-room services, expects to expand its commercial segment.

site_title: StreetSine launches AI chatbot for property sector
summary: StreetSine launches Sevi, an AI chatbot for the Singapore property sector, allowing users to interact with property-related queries in real-time. Sevi, available on Facebook Messenger, can provide answers in English and is expected to be expanded to other languages and platforms, including WhatsApp and WeChat. The chatbot uses machine learning to improve its service and is seen as a "game-changer" in the complex property transaction process. Sevi's launch comes as social media giant Facebook and Google also introduce their own chatbot functionalities, marking a growing trend in AI personal assistants.

site_title: UK plans lower corporation tax to cushion hit from Brexit
summary: The UK plans to cut its corporation tax rate to less than 15% in an effort to cushion the economic impact of Brexit. Finance Minister George Osborne aims to build a "super competitive economy" with low business taxes, signaling a shift towards a global focus. The move could help prevent an exodus of British firms and attract US and European companies. However, negotiations with the EU on market access are crucial for Britain to become a truly attractive proposition to foreign investors. The cut would cost at least 10 billion pounds and could lead to a tax haven-like economy.

site_title: French billionaire Dassault on trial for tax fraud
summary: French billionaire Serge Dassault, 91, is on trial for allegedly stashing millions of euros in tax havens, including Luxembourg, Liechtenstein, and the Virgin Islands. He is accused of hiding 31 million euros and failing to declare 16 million euros in 2011 and 11 million euros in 2014. The trial also relates to charges of vote-buying in elections in Corbeil-Essonnes, where Dassault was mayor from 1995 to 2009. Dassault denies the charges, but his lawyers have raised questions about the constitutionality of the charges against him.

site_title: Diversifying to stay ahead (Amended)
summary: Top Global Limited, a lifestyle property group, has successfully diversified to stay ahead in the challenging real estate sector. Under the leadership of COO Jennifer Chang, the company recorded a 290% revenue growth in 2015, reaching S$195.7 million. Chang has steered the company towards hospitality, acquiring 5Footway Founders Pte Ltd and expanding its reach to neighboring countries. TGL also continues to develop residential properties in Singapore, achieving over 70% sales for its recent developments. Chang attributes the company's success to its proactive stance, diversified business model, and focus on affordable premium hostel segment.

images.alt_text: "From what I see now, the government will continue to drive this growth. The engine has already started and can't stop. And I believe there will be more exciting things coming along the way." - Ms Chang (left), on its emphasis on the hospitality business, anticipating growth in Singapore's tourism sector

site_title: Conservative leadership gets off the ground as UKIP leader resigns
summary: UKIP leader Nigel Farage has resigned, citing the party's "greatest potential" lies in attracting Labour voters. Conservative leadership contenders Theresa May and Andrea Leadsom are vying for the UK's next prime minister. May, with 92 supporting MPs, wants to invoke Article 50 by the end of the year, while Leadsom seeks to begin negotiations immediately if elected. The battle for the Conservative leadership is intensifying as the UK prepares for a post-Brexit world.

images.alt_text: Currently in the process of a vicious campaign to reject Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, Mr Farage (above) is hoping Labour voters will reject their parliamentary representatives and shift towards UKIP.

site_title: Recent hand grenade attack in Selangor linked to IS: M'sian police
summary: Malaysian police have linked a recent hand grenade attack to the Islamic State (IS) group, contradicting initial reports of a business rivalry or revenge attack. Two men have been arrested, and two others are on the run, with authorities suspecting 13 more Malaysians of terrorism-linked activities. The incident raises concern over the presence of IS sympathizers in the country, with scores of Malaysians having traveled to join the group in Syria and Iraq. The government's anti-terror fight has been criticized for secrecy, and the country has not seen any notable terror attacks in recent years.

site_title: British PM candidate Fox says no place for free movement in trade deal
summary: Liam Fox, a British prime ministerial candidate, stated that free movement of people should not be included in trade deal negotiations with the European Union. Fox, a former Defence Secretary, said the public rejected the concept of free movement, which would be seen as a betrayal by the British people. He also proposed activating the two-year EU withdrawal process by the end of the year, aiming for a full exit from the bloc by January 1, 2019.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher with STI up 24 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 24.19 points or 0.85% to 2,870.56 on Monday, driven by expectations of central bank easing measures to support the global economy post-Brexit. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid ongoing market optimism despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: EU exit could trim UK GDP by 1.5 to 4.5% by 2019: IMF head
summary: IMF head Christine Lagarde warned that a European Union exit could trim UK GDP by 1.5 to 4.5% by 2019. The worst scenario would involve Britain being treated as a third-country trading partner under World Trade Organisation rules. The impact of the Brexit vote on talks between Britain and the EU is uncertain, with no clear timeline for negotiations or outcome.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing contracts for a full year with June PMI at 49.6
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector has contracted for a full year, with the June Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.6, undershooting expectations. This marks a third consecutive contraction, following May and April readings of 49.8. The PMI signals a decline in manufacturing activity, with conditions slumping for the first time in 10 months.

site_title: UKIP leader Farage says will step down after Brexit victory
summary: UKIP leader Nigel Farage announced his resignation as party leader, citing his achievement of winning the Brexit referendum. He stated that he never wanted to be a career politician and had achieved his goal of getting Britain out of the European Union. Farage will step down after the party's leadership election, allowing a new leader to take over.

site_title: Gold eases off near 2-yr high, silver crosses US$21/oz
summary: Gold eased off a near two-year high, reaching $1,357.60 per ounce, as short-covering in China prompted a burst of buying. Silver surged to a two-year high, crossing the $21 level, driven by Chinese onshore players covering their short positions. Global uncertainty is expected to fuel precious metal demand, with analysts predicting further price increases.

site_title: ECB spent 85.1 billion euros on QE debt in Brexit-blighted June
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) spent 85.1 billion euros on quantitative easing (QE) debt in June, bringing total holdings to 1.08 trillion euros. The move comes as the UK's Brexit decision sent shockwaves through the financial system, prompting concerns over the impact on the euro area's investment and consumption gains. ECB officials are considering adjusting the asset-purchase program, which has been criticized for being too focused on a nation's economy size.

site_title: Brexit leader's photo gets dirty laughs in Malaysia, Philippines
summary: Nigel Farage, the UK Independence Party leader, was pictured underneath a banner in Malaysia and the Philippines with the acronym "UKIP" and "PUKI" (Malay and Tagalog slang for vagina) accidentally spelled out. The image went viral on social media, with internet users in Southeast Asia quickly pointing out the mistake. The incident occurred on July 4, 2016, during Farage's trip to the region.

site_title: Fischer Tech sets up China subsidiary
summary: Fischer Tech Group, a specialist manufacturer, has set up a wholly owned subsidiary, Fischer Advanced Technology (Suzhou) Co, in China with a registered capital of US$15 million. The subsidiary will manufacture and sell precision plastic injection moulds and products for the automotive, electronics, and consumer product industries. The move is expected to have no significant effect on the company's financial performance.

site_title: London exchange defends Deutsche Boerse deal after Brexit
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG) is pushing forward with its $27 billion merger with Deutsche Boerse, despite concerns it may be "shackling itself to a corpse" following the UK's Brexit vote. LSEG chairman Donald Brydon expressed confidence in satisfactory regulatory approval from Brussels, citing no reason to think otherwise. The deal needs 75% shareholder approval, with LSEG's CEO Xavier Rolet stating the group is "extremely well positioned" globally regardless of the EU's decision.

site_title: Temasek eyes US investments to offset first portfolio drop in 7 years
summary: Singapore sovereign investor Temasek is seeking US investments to offset its first annual decline in seven years, following a 55% drop in the value of its Standard Chartered stake. The 10% drop in sterling against the Singapore dollar also contributed to the decline. Temasek has appointed a new president of its international business and head of its Americas team to accelerate investments in technology, consumer, and healthcare. The investor has formed an advisory group and is considering co-investments with private equity partners to address the decline.

images.alt_text: Singapore sovereign investor Temasek is set to pounce on US deals and look for co-investments with private equity partners to offset its first annual decline in the value of its assets in seven years, bankers and people familiar with the strategy said.

site_title: Eurozone yields rise as focus shifts from Brexit to supply
summary: Eurozone borrowing costs rose for the first time in over a week as investors sought to make room for upcoming bond auctions. Spain's 10-year bond yields jumped 2 basis points to 1.17%, with markets expecting a new bond sale due to low yields and a potential new government. Other eurozone countries, including Austria, Germany, and France, also held bond auctions this week. The rise in yields halted a post-Brexit slide in yields, as investors await further European Central Bank stimulus to offset economic fallout.

site_title: Two-factor log-in for e-government services kicks in
summary: Starting from Tuesday, a majority of Singapore's government e-services will require two-factor authentication (2FA) for log-in and transactions. This move aims to enhance personal data security, with around 80% of SingPass users already activated for 2FA. The remaining 20% will have a 30-day grace period from their next log-in to set up 2FA. The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) will not count the 30-day period as calendar dates, allowing users to proceed with transactions after receiving a prompt after logging in.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks build on gains
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on Monday, extending last week's rally after global central banks pledged support for financial markets following the UK's Brexit decision. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.27% to 21,059.2, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.91% to 2,988.60. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore wants to partner Indonesia in dealing with errant firms involved in haze crisis
summary: Singapore's Ambassador to Indonesia, Anil Kumar, expressed a desire to partner with the Indonesian government in pursuing errant companies responsible for last year's haze crisis. Instead of working against these companies, Singapore aims to collaborate with Indonesia to bring them to justice. This approach is seen as a shift in strategy, allowing for a more effective and cooperative approach to addressing the issue. The partnership is expected to focus on holding accountable those responsible for the environmental damage.

site_title: Hong Kong shares up for 3rd day on stimulus hopes, higher commodity prices
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a third consecutive day, driven by hopes of more stimulus measures from Beijing and higher commodity prices. The Hang Seng index gained 1.3% to 21,059.20, while the China Enterprises Index rose 1.0% to 8,802.35. Key sectors, including property and resources, also saw gains, with companies such as CK Property and China Vanke rising 4.2% and 6.7%, respectively.

site_title: UK construction battered in June by Brexit fears: PMI
summary: UK construction industry suffered its worst contraction in seven years in June due to Brexit fears, according to a survey by Markit. The construction Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 46.0, its lowest level since 2009, with house-building and commercial work being hardest hit. The drop in construction activity may lead to additional stimulus from the Bank of England to mitigate the impact of Brexit uncertainty on the economy.

site_title: Singapore's Temasek buys stake in French investment firm Tikehau
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte has invested in French asset manager Tikehau Capital Partners with a total of 510 million euros (S$763.6 million), acquiring a stake of over 5% in the holding company, Tikehau Capital Advisors. This marks Temasek's first investment in the firm, alongside existing investors Amundi SA, Credit Mutuel Arkea SA, and FFP, the family office of the Peugeot clan. The investment is part of Temasek's expansion into European markets.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings Pte has invested in French asset manager Tikehau Capital Partners as it expands investments in Europe.

site_title: Britain to hire foreign trade negotiators after Brexit, says Hammond
summary: Britain plans to hire foreign trade negotiators to help it negotiate new trade deals after Brexit, according to Foreign Minister Philip Hammond. He stated that the UK should not limit its recruitment to only British citizens, but also consider hiring skilled individuals from countries like Australia and the US. This move comes as the UK faces the challenge of striking new trade deals with Europe and beyond following its departure from the EU.

site_title: China jails former aide to retired Chinese president for life
summary: A Chinese court has jailed a former senior aide to retired President Hu Jintao for life after finding him guilty of taking bribes, state secrets, and abuse of power. Ling Jihua, who was demoted in 2012 after his son was killed in a luxury car crash, accepted the facts of the case without contesting them. The ruling party had investigated Ling in 2014, citing damage to its image, and President Xi Jinping's predecessor, Hu, was reportedly implicated in the case. Ling's guilty verdict presents a dilemma for the government due to his close connection with Hu.

site_title: India central bank new deputy governor Vishwanathan takes charge
summary: India's Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has appointed NS Vishwanathan as its new deputy governor, overseeing banking and financial sector regulations. Vishwanathan, a 58-year-old RBI veteran, replaces HR Khan and will oversee banking regulations, deposit insurance, and risk monitoring. Gandhi will now handle financial markets, while Patel and Mundra's portfolios remain largely unchanged. This change comes as the RBI adjusts its structure following Khan's retirement.

site_title: Auditors highlight material uncertainties relating to Lereno Bio-Chem
summary: Independent auditor Foo Kon Tan has highlighted material uncertainties casting doubt on Lereno Bio-Chem's ability to continue as a going concern. The company incurred a total comprehensive loss of S$1.238 million and net operating cash outflows of S$800,000 for the 2016 financial year. Lereno Bio-Chem became a cash company after the disposal of Lereno Sdn Bhd in 2015, and its current liabilities exceed assets by S$5.62 million and S$5.54 million, respectively. The Singapore Exchange may remove the company from the official list if it fails to meet listing requirements within 12 months.

site_title: Thailand sets up security centres ahead of referendum
summary: Thailand's military government has set up security centers nationwide ahead of an August referendum on a new constitution. The draft constitution, which critics fear will entrench the military's influence, will replace the one scrapped after a 2014 coup. The government aims to increase security measures as the country prepares to vote on the new constitution.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher, extending global rally
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, extending a global rally for a sixth-straight session. The Nikkei 225 index advanced 0.60% to 15,775.80, while the Topix index of all first-section shares rose 0.60% to 1,261.97. The global rally, despite early losses, continues as traders brush off new Trump threats.

site_title: The 500 tons of gold that show global rise in investor angst
summary: Global gold holdings have increased by over 500 metric tons since January, driven by investors' concerns over slowing growth, a possible Fed pause, and the UK's Brexit vote. Gold prices rose to a two-year high in June, and bullion-backed exchange-traded funds (ETFs) saw a 37-ton increase last week. Analysts attribute the rise to a "flight to safety" and the low-yield environment, predicting further upward potential for prices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.4%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices gained 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. Investors are focusing on the fallout from Brexit and US jobs data.

site_title: Brexit means Draghi's ECB Seen as euro-area rescuer again
summary: The European Union is facing an existential crisis following the UK's Brexit vote, with a Bloomberg survey predicting a loss of economic momentum in the euro area. Unemployment remains above 10%, and populist parties are on the rise, while Italy's failing banking system and budget rule reform remain unresolved. The European Central Bank (ECB) is seen as the only institution willing to act, with economists predicting it will need to add more stimulus to counter the slowdown. ECB President Mario Draghi has urged leaders to address bank vulnerabilities, but a region-wide plan is lacking, leaving the euro area at risk of drifting apart.

site_title: Brexit hits eurozone sentiment: Sentix index at 18-month low in July
summary: Sentiment in the eurozone fell to an 18-month low in July, according to the Sentix research group's index, which dropped to 1.7 from 9.9 in June. The decline is attributed to investors' fears of a major economic fallout from Britain's vote to leave the European Union. Analysts had expected a reading of 5.0. This low sentiment is a result of the "Brexit vote at the end of June in the United Kingdom," negatively impacting global economic expectations.

images.alt_text: Sentiment in the eurozone fell to an 18-month low in July, a survey showed on Monday, as investors and analysts fear a major economic fallout from Britain's vote last month to leave the European Union.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: M&A deal volumes rose in Singapore in the first half of 2016, but their values declined by 35% compared to the same period last year. Temasek Holdings acquired a majority stake in Malaysia's Aurum Healthcare. Standard Chartered Private Equity took a significant stake in Phoon Huat, a Singapore food and beverage player. Two-factor log-in for e-government services was introduced, requiring a one-time password. Singapore leads Hong Kong in the fintech hub race, with DBS Singapore head re-appointed as SLA chairman. The STI rose 24.19 points or 0.85% to 2,870.56.

site_title: Australian dollar bounces back after initial wobble on post-vote uncertainty
summary: The Australian dollar rebounded on Monday after slumping following the country's weekend election with no clear winner. It regained its footing against the US dollar, reaching 75 cents, and against the yen, reaching 77.00. Moody's and Fitch expressed no immediate threat to Australia's top-rated credit rating, citing the need for the new government to manage public finances. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to review interest rates on Tuesday, with economists predicting a rate stay at 1.75%.

site_title: Hong Kong officials to visit Beijing for talks over bookseller
summary: Hong Kong officials will visit Beijing for a one-day meeting to discuss notification systems for detained residents, following protests over the disappearance of five booksellers associated with a critical bookshop. The meeting aims for a "comprehensive and in-depth review" of the existing system, with no decisions expected to be made. The disappearances have raised concerns about the "one country, two systems" agreement governing Hong Kong's relationship with China.

site_title: China commodities rally on hopes of stimulus to boost economy
summary: Chinese commodities, including nickel and cotton, surged on hopes of stimulus to boost the economy. An official survey showed a weak manufacturing sector in June, with falling export orders and inventories. Analysts expect Beijing to focus on more stimulus in the second half of the year, which would be beneficial for commodity demand. This rally is seen as a positive sign for raw material demand, following a sluggish economic performance.

site_title: Malaysia's police confirm IS link to nightclub grenade attack
summary: Malaysian authorities have confirmed that the Islamic State (IS) was responsible for a grenade attack on a nightclub, marking the first successful attempt by the militant group in the country. Two men, arrested in connection with the attack, received instructions from a known Malaysian IS fighter. Police are hunting for two more individuals believed to have been directly involved. The IS has been linked to other attacks in the region, and a recent video called on supporters to unify under one umbrella group to launch attacks. The motive was initially ruled out as terrorism, but reassessed after an IS claim of responsibility.

site_title: CICC, China Investment Securities in possible merger talks
summary: China Investment Securities (CICC) and investment bank China International Capital Corp (CICC) are in talks on a possible merger, with no certainty of a transaction. The deal could be beneficial for CICC, which has a strong presence with high net worth individuals and corporate clients. CICC's shares jumped 3.7% on the news, while CICC has 94.1 billion yuan of assets and China Investment Securities has 92.2 billion yuan. The structure of any deal has yet to be decided, and the discussions are private.

site_title: Brexit vote shakes up London property market
summary: The UK's decision to leave the EU has sent shockwaves through London's property market, with foreign banks freezing loans and investors pulling out of commercial deals. However, some foreigners are taking advantage of the weak pound to buy residential properties. The uncertainty has caused a halt in deals, with some investors delaying or canceling purchases worth over £30 million. The British government has warned of an economic slowdown, and economists expect house prices to fall. Despite this, luxury real estate agents are seeing increased interest from foreign buyers, particularly in the top-end of the market.

site_title: MMP Resources to acquire Hokkaido ski operator
summary: MMP Resources, a construction company, plans to acquire Hokkaido ski operator JRT Trading for 80 million yen (S$1.05 million) in cash and repay a 37.5 million yen loan. JRT Trading manages ski lodges, tour businesses, and rental services in Hokkaido, Japan. The acquisition is in line with MMP's strategy to focus on construction opportunities, asset acquisitions, and brand growth in the travel and hospitality industry.

site_title: UK foreign minister Hammond backs May to be prime minister
summary: UK Foreign Minister Philip Hammond has backed Theresa May to be the next prime minister, citing her pragmatism in securing a Brexit deal. Hammond, who campaigned to remain in the EU, says May must make trade-offs between single market access and limiting EU freedom of movement. May, the longest-serving interior minister in over a century, is the odds-on favorite to succeed David Cameron after the EU referendum result. Hammond praises May's ability to make tough decisions, saying she is the best equipped to protect the nation's interests during challenging times.

site_title: Australia PM Turnbull urged to quit after 'Brexiting' himself
summary: Australia's opposition Labor Party urged Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to resign after his Liberal/National coalition failed to secure enough seats to form a government in the 150-member House of Representatives. Turnbull, who took the country to the ballot boxes, was likened to UK's David Cameron due to his failed election victory. Labor leader Bill Shorten stated that Turnbull had to go, but his party also fell short of the 76 seats needed to govern. The election result has raised questions about Turnbull's leadership and future in politics.

site_title: Pound ends biggest 2-week drop since 2009 as UK flags stimulus
summary: The pound ended its largest two-week drop since 2009, rising 0.2% to US$1.3287 after UK authorities announced measures to prop up the economy ahead of the Brexit vote. Chancellor George Osborne floated a lower corporate tax rate, and Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is set to outline macroprudential tools. Analysts say the pound is near oversold levels and may rebound, but a lower pound is still needed to rebalance the UK economy.

site_title: Brazil police investigate federations for allegedly embezzling Olympic investments
summary: Brazilian federal police are investigating local sports federations for allegedly embezzling funds meant for training Olympic athletes. The funds, totaling 1 billion reais, were supposed to boost the country's chances of winning medals at the 2016 Games. Police suspect the federations misappropriated the funds, and are also investigating former sports minister Ricardo Leyser's possible involvement. This investigation comes as Brazil faces its worst recession since the 1930s, straining public finances and threatening police strikes on the eve of the games.

site_title: Suicide bombing near US consulate in Saudi: ministry
summary: A suicide bombing near the US consulate in Saudi Arabia's Red Sea city of Jeddah killed no one, but two security officers were lightly injured. The blast occurred at 2:15am on July 4, shortly before dawn prayers during the holy month of Ramadan. Investigators are trying to identify the culprit, who is believed to be linked to the Islamic State group. The incident is the latest in a series of deadly attacks targeting minority Shiites in Saudi Arabia since late 2014.

site_title: BOJ should refrain from easing, eye tapering: former board member Shirai
summary: Former Bank of Japan board member Sayuri Shirai advises the central bank to refrain from easing monetary stimulus and instead focus on tapering its asset-buying program and deepening negative interest rates. Shirai believes the economy is in good shape, with low borrowing costs, and that recent yen gains may be temporary. However, she warns that sharp yen appreciation could be problematic and cannot be addressed through monetary policy. Shirai's comments come ahead of the BOJ's policy meeting this month.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan should refrain from expanding monetary stimulus, including at this month's policy meeting, as borrowing costs are already very low and the economy is in fairly good shape, former BOJ board member Sayuri Shirai said on Monday.

site_title: Oil prices edge up as Brent pushes further above US$50
summary: Crude oil prices edged up in Asia on July 4, with Brent holding above $50 due to Nigerian militants' attacks on oil infrastructure. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 4 cents to $49.03, while Brent rose 7 cents to $50.42. Analysts attribute the rally to concerns about supply disruptions in Nigeria, which has been hit by pipeline bombings by the Niger Delta Avengers. The attacks threaten to scupper efforts to boost production from Africa's largest oil producer. Trading is expected to be light due to the Independence Day holiday in the US.

site_title: Taiwan said to find improper use of 'war mode' in missile launch
summary: Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense found that the fatal launch of an anti-ship missile was caused by a series of discipline violations and mistakes, including the improper use of "war mode" on the vessel's control panel. The patrol boat's weapons operator was left unsupervised before firing the missile, which struck a Taiwanese fishing boat and killed one person. The incident, which occurred on Friday, was described as an isolated case caused by human error and has had no impact on regional security.

site_title: US offers Bangladesh FBI help as police probe attackers' links
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry has offered Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's help in investigating the killing of 20 people at a Dhaka restaurant. The attack, claimed by Islamic State (IS), was carried out by six local gunmen who were radicalized. US law enforcement, including the FBI, will assist in the investigation. Bangladesh's Home Minister blames Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh (JMB) for the attack, which is the worst in the country since 2005. Analysts suggest IS may be trying to build affiliates in Bangladesh and exploit disaffected youths.

site_title: China says to crackdown on fake news from social media
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration will launch a crackdown on fake news from social media, requiring online media to obtain approval before reporting news taken from social media sites. The regulator has listed several fake news stories, including a bus fire incident, and will strengthen supervision and investigation. The move is part of the government's efforts to curb the spread of rumors and ensure internet security, amid concerns over terrorism and economic risks.

site_title: Singapore shares open 7.11 points higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares rose 7.11 points, or 0.25%, to 2,853.48 on Monday, driven by gains in Thai Beverage, DBS Bank, and Singapore Press Holdings. The market remained calm ahead of the July 4 holiday in the US.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 2.69 points to 1649.34, with 76 gainers and 66 losers. Volume reached 47.6 million lots worth RM18.5 million.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares higher as commodities rally overrides election uncertainty
summary: Australian shares rose 10.3 points, or 0.2%, on Monday as commodity prices surged, outweighing election uncertainty. The S&P/ASX 200 index recovered from a lower opening, with miners such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gaining 1.8% and 3.5%, respectively. Despite the rebound, the benchmark is still down nearly 1% for the year. The Australian general election's inconclusive result and ongoing Brexit uncertainty have weighed on investors, particularly those exposed to the UK economy.

site_title: Standard Chartered Private Equity takes a 'significant' stake in Phoon Huat
summary: Standard Chartered Private Equity (SCPE) has taken a significant stake in Phoon Huat Pte Ltd, a Singapore food and beverage player. The investment, announced on July 4, 2016, will provide strategic input and support the management in its development plans. Phoon Huat managing director Wong Chen Liong welcomed the investment, which he said will aid the firm's succession planning. SCPE head Bert Kwan expressed his honor in partnering with the Wong family and supporting the business's legacy.
