The deal will bring SCPE's management expertise and Standard Chartered Bank's network to the company.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit 3-month high on bargain hunting
summary: Taiwan's stocks reached a three-month high on Monday, driven by bargain-hunting. The main Taiex index rose 0.2% to 8,756.94, its highest since March 31. Electronics subindex and chip designer MediaTek led gains, with Hon Hai and MediaTek rising 0.9% and nearly 4% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.192 per US dollar. The rally follows regional gains and comes despite Brexit's impact on confidence last month.

site_title: China's Midea buys stake in Germany's Kuka for US$1.3b
summary: China's Midea Group has agreed to buy a 25.1% stake in German robot-making company Kuka AG for $1.3 billion. The deal, which is open for four weeks, is contingent on Midea increasing its stake to at least 30%. The acquisition has been closely scrutinised by German politicians, but Midea has pledged to protect jobs and plants until 2023. The deal is expected to go through, with Commerzbank analysts predicting minimal risk of antitrust authorities blocking it.

site_title: Trudeau says Canada exploring gender-neutral identity cards
summary: Canada is exploring the use of gender-neutral options on identity cards, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stating the government is studying other jurisdictions. This move follows the Canadian province of Ontario's decision to allow the use of a third gender indicator, X, on driver's licenses. Trudeau also spoke out on the importance of safe spaces and communities, referencing the Pulse gay nightclub shooting in Orlando, Florida.

site_title: Japan firms' price expectations slide, keep BOJ under pressure
summary: Japanese companies' inflation expectations fell to 0.7% a year from now, down 0.1 percentage point from three months ago, and significantly lower than the Bank of Japan's 2% target. Business confidence remains subdued, adding pressure on the BOJ to roll out more stimulus. The survey suggests the BOJ may need to cut inflation forecasts and ease monetary policy further, despite low bond yields. Market expectations point to an expansion of monetary stimulus at the BOJ's next rate review on July 28-29.

site_title: China offers Philippines talks if South China Sea court ignored: China Daily
summary: China is prepared to negotiate with the Philippines on South China Sea-related issues if Manila ignores an upcoming arbitration ruling on their territorial dispute. The Philippines brought the case to the Permanent Court of Arbitration in the Hague, which is expected to deliver a ruling on July 12. China has rejected the arbitration case, claiming the court has no jurisdiction, and has proposed bilateral talks on issues such as joint development and cooperation. China's Foreign Ministry stated in 1995 that the two countries should settle disputes "in a peaceful and friendly manner through consultations on the basis of equity and mutual respect."

site_title: Yuan drops against basket amid growth concern, US dollar weakness
summary: The Chinese yuan fell against a basket of currencies for a third consecutive day, sparking concerns about the country's economic stability. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in manufacturing and industrial profits, as well as forecasted decline in foreign-exchange reserves. Analysts attribute the yuan's drop to a strategy of stability against a declining US dollar and weakness against trading partners. The market remains concerned about the Chinese economy, with the central bank potentially returning to a policy of stability amid economic growth concerns.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge climbs 0.6% in June
summary: Australia's private-sector inflation gauge rose 0.6% in June, driven by higher costs for petrol and food. Despite this, underlying inflation remained muted, suggesting the Reserve Bank of Australia may hold interest rates at a record low of 1.75%. Analysts expect a possible rate cut in August if the official consumer price report shows annual inflation remains around 1.5%. The trimmed mean measure also edged up 0.2% in June, with prices rising for automotive fuel, holiday travel, and accommodation.

site_title: Britain plans to cut corporate tax to under 15%: report
summary: Britain's finance minister, George Osborne, plans to cut corporate tax to under 15% to attract businesses following the country's Brexit vote. The move aims to create a super-competitive economy, with the tax rate being reduced by over 5 percentage points. The change is expected to bring the UK's tax rate close to Ireland's 12.5% rate. The move follows concerns that companies may flee the UK due to uncertainty over its future relationship with the EU.

site_title: M&A deal volumes rise but values drop in H1 2016: Duff & Phelps
summary: M&A deal volumes rose in Singapore's first half of 2016, with 383 deals worth US$43.4 billion, but values declined by 35% compared to the same period in 2015. The industrials sector accounted for 30% of deal value, overtaking technology. The top three sectors - industrials, real estate, and banking - made up 72.4% of total deal value.

Merger and acquisition (M&A) deal volumes rose in Singapore in the first half of the year, but their values have declined by about 35 per cent compared to the same period a year ago, said global valuation and corporate finance adviser Duff & Phelps.

site_title: Further boost to S-Reits expected over long-drawn post-Brexit process: Religare
summary: S-Reits in Singapore are expected to continue to rise due to the post-Brexit uncertainty, with Religare Institutional Research upgrading its view on the sector to a "buy". The brokerage lowered its risk-free rates and expects global investors to maintain their risk-free approach for a longer period, making S-Reits a good investment option. The sector is expected to outperform the broader market with stable dividend distribution policies and a relatively stable Singapore dollar. However, Religare is cautious about upcoming results, particularly for the hospitality sector, and expects a 10% upside in the near term.

site_title: Auditors for SinoCloud Group flag 'going concern' risks
summary: AUDITORS for Catalist-listed SinoCloud Group have flagged 'going concern' risks due to a net loss of HK$112.5 million and negative cashflow. The group's ability to continue as a going concern relies on profit contributions from its internet data business and associate China Satellite Group. SinoCloud Group is tightening cost controls, exploring alternative funding options, and believes it will continue as a going concern despite the risks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Pteris Global, Ezra, Emas Offshore, ABR Holdings
summary: China International Marine Containers has raised its takeover offer price for Pteris Global to S$0.85 per share, extending the offer closing date to July 25. Ezra and Emas Offshore agreed to sell their stakes in the Lewek Emas vessel for US$166.3 million. ABR Holdings has entered a deal to buy an Australian property for A$20 million, planning to redevelop it into residential houses.

site_title: British PM frontrunner vows to limit immigration
summary: British Prime Minister frontrunner Theresa May has vowed to push for an EU trade deal that limits immigration following the country's Brexit vote. May, who is leading the Conservative Party, has ruled out holding a general election before 2020 and will seek a guarantee for the status of EU nationals already in Britain. The government faces a legal challenge from a law firm over its decision to trigger Article 50 without parliamentary backing. The UK has two years to negotiate terms after triggering the exit procedure, and rival contenders disagree on the pace of the exit process.

site_title: Tennis: Federer, Murray look to pounce on Djokovic absence
summary: Roger Federer and Andy Murray will attempt to capitalize on Novak Djokovic's early exit at Wimbledon, with Federer comfortably favored to reach the quarterfinals. Federer, a seven-time champion, faces US player Steve Johnson, while Murray, the 2013 champion, faces Australian Nick Kyrgios. Murray is the favorite to win the title at evens, ahead of Federer, Raonic, and Kyrgios. Other notable matches include Milos Raonic vs. David Goffin, and Marin Cilic vs. Kei Nishikori.

site_title: In race to be Asia's fintech hub, Singapore leads Hong Kong
summary: Singapore is racing to establish itself as Asia's fintech hub, leveraging state funding, light-touch regulation, and a supportive environment to attract start-ups. The city-state has outpaced Hong Kong, with a faster growth rate in the fintech sector and more aggressive efforts to pursue fintech opportunities. Despite challenges, including restrictive immigration laws and a risk-averse culture, Singapore's efforts are bearing fruit, with companies like SmartKarma choosing the city-state over Hong Kong for their headquarters.

site_title: DBS Singapore head re-appointed SLA chairman
summary: LIM Sim Seng, Singapore country head of DBS Bank, has been re-appointed as chairman of Singapore Land Authority (SLA) for a two-year term starting August 1, 2016. Two new members, Yeoh Oon Jin, Lock Yin Mei, and Ho Chee Pong, have been appointed to the board, replacing outgoing members Wong Hong Kuan and others. The reappointments were made by the Ministry of Law, with current board members Han Kok Juan, Tan Boon Khai, and others continuing to serve.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.29% in early trade on Monday, extending last week's rally amid hopes for global central bank stimulus following the UK's Brexit vote. The Hang Seng Index reached 20,855.20, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes fell 0.28% and 0.72%, respectively. The rally was driven by expectations of monetary easing globally, despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies.

site_title: Rio Tinto commits to London head office after Brexit vote
summary: Rio Tinto's CEO Jean-Sebastien Jacques pledged to keep the company's London head office after the UK's Brexit vote, citing the small impact on trade. Jacques, a French-British citizen, stated that Rio Tinto "doesn't do politics" and will monitor the situation. The decision follows concerns that businesses may flee London due to the vote, with banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co and HSBC Holdings considering job relocations. Jacques' views echo those of former Rio CEO Tom Albanese, who also believed the UK's benefits for resource companies outweigh the impact of Brexit.

site_title: UK's Osborne to slash corporation tax to cushion Brexit blow: FT
summary: British finance minister George Osborne plans to cut corporation tax to less than 15% to cushion the economic impact of the UK's Brexit decision. Osborne also aims to strengthen the UK's relationship with China and lead another trade visit later this year. His goal is to build a "super competitive economy" with low business taxes and a global focus, in response to the shock referendum result.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower despite global gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on July 4, 2016, despite global gains, with the Nikkei 225 index shedding 0.82% and the Topix index falling 0.47%. This marked a snap of a five-day rally. The decline was attributed to no specific reason mentioned in the article.

site_title: Singapore companies paid bills more promptly in Q2
summary: Singapore companies showed an improvement in bill payments in the second quarter, with overall prompt payments increasing by 4.81 percentage points to 45.92% compared to the first quarter. Slow payments decreased by 3.97 percentage points to 46.58%. However, year-on-year, three industries (construction, services, and wholesale) have seen a decline in prompt payments. The uptick in payment performance was attributed to increased tourist arrivals and a reversal in certain manufacturing segments. Despite this, firms must exercise credit vigilance due to a weakened external trade and softening business services sector.

site_title: Saudi energy minister says oil market heading toward a balance
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid al-Falih, and Opec's new secretary general, Mohammed Barkindo, agree that the global oil market is heading toward balance. They discussed Opec's role in maintaining oil market stability during a meeting in Dhahran. Al-Falih stated Saudi Arabia aims to continue meeting growing global oil demand and ensuring reliable oil supply flows through Opec. The meeting indicates a shift toward stabilizing oil prices, which have been volatile in recent years.

site_title: Bangladesh gunmen made no demands, IS not involved: minister
summary: Bangladesh's home minister, Asaduzzaman Khan, has stated that the gunmen who killed 20 people at a Dhaka restaurant made no demands and a suspect taken alive by police is only a suspect admitted in hospital, contradicting Islamic State's claims of responsibility. The attackers were from well-off Bangladeshi families and were mostly educated, with links to transnational groups such as Islamic State or al Qaeda being investigated. The attack marked a major escalation in violence by militants demanding Islamic rule in Bangladesh, which has seen a wave of killings over the past 18 months.

site_title: Asia: Stocks snap rally as vote deadlock sinks Australian assets
summary: Asian stocks fell for the first time in four days due to a yen rebound, weighing on Japanese shares and Australian assets. The Australian election resulted in a hung parliament, raising concerns about the nation's AAA rating. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped 0.3% as investors awaited building approvals and business sentiment reports. The US dollar retreated, and gold prices rose near their highest level in over two years. Markets are uncertain about the potential impact of Brexit and the likelihood of central bank stimulus.

site_title: Belgium slow to share info on Paris attacker: lawmaker
summary: Belgian authorities were slow to share information about Salah Abdeslam, the sole surviving suspect in last year's Paris attacks, allowing him to escape. French police checked Abdeslam's papers at a checkpoint near the Belgian border but let him go after 30 minutes because he wasn't on their list of suspects. It wasn't until over an hour later that Belgian authorities informed France of Abdeslam's jihadist links, resulting in a delayed arrest that likely allowed him to evade capture.

site_title: Nobel Prize boosts regenerative medicine in Japan
summary: Japanese pharmaceutical companies Fujifilm and Takeda Pharmaceutical are investing in regenerative medicine following Shinya Yamanaka's Nobel Prize win in 2012. The technology has led to the use of regenerated skin and cartilage in patients, with corneas expected to become available by 2018. Lab-grown livers and other organs are also in development. Fujifilm and Takeda are planning clinical trials to test new therapies using this technology, further advancing regenerative medicine in Japan.

site_title: VW brand chief says no plans to step down despite investigation
summary: Volkswagen's brand chief Herbert Diess says he won't step down despite a public prosecution investigation into the company's alleged cheating on emissions tests. Diess told a German newspaper the investigation had taken him by surprise and that he had first heard about it through media inquiries. The company's reputation will take 12-18 months to recover, while a strategic turnaround will take up to 14 years, requiring a shift in focus to information technology and battery experts.

site_title: China soccer boom sparks illegal online gambling craze
summary: China's growing interest in soccer has led to a surge in online gambling, with police busting multi-million dollar betting rings and tech giants cracking down on illegal activity. Tencent Holdings Ltd and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd have implemented anti-gambling systems, freezing accounts and restricting groups suspected of gambling behavior. The issue is expected to worsen ahead of the Uefa European Football Championship final on July 10. Chinese firms have invested heavily in soccer, attracting global stars and fueling a lucrative black market.

site_title: Political uncertainty to weigh on Australian economy
summary: Australia's hung parliament has raised concerns about the country's AAA credit rating, with economists warning of potential economic uncertainty. The inconclusive election result, with millions of postal votes still to be processed, adds to the global trend of rising political uncertainty. This uncertainty, combined with global events such as Donald Trump's presidential run and Britain's EU vote, may impact investment markets and the Australian economy. A final outcome will take days or weeks, further exacerbating the uncertainty.

site_title: VW says that US 'Dieselgate' settlement won't be replicated in Europe
summary: Volkswagen's CEO Matthias Mueller rejected calls for a European settlement similar to the US$15 billion "Dieselgate" deal, citing differences in legal systems and stricter emission limits in the US. Mueller stated that replicating the US deal in Europe would be unaffordable and unfair to European customers. He also noted that the US deal is voluntary and includes incentives to encourage customers to participate in the buyback program. Mueller emphasized that Volkswagen is on a solid financial footing, but compensation at high levels would overwhelm the company.

site_title: Aussie dollar unsettled by political uncertainty, other currencies calmer
summary: The Australian dollar remains unsettled due to heightened political uncertainty following the country's general election, which produced no clear winner. In contrast, the pound has stabilized after an 11% plunge following the UK's Brexit vote, and other major currencies remain calm. The Australian dollar's volatility is attributed to the uncertainty, while the pound's recovery is seen as a result of diminishing global anxiety over Brexit.

site_title: The unconscious motivation of entrepreneurs
summary: A study of 149 university students in Singapore found that those with an unconscious need for power are more likely to aspire to entrepreneurial careers, but the need for achievement is a more significant determinant of business success. The study contradicts previous research by American psychologist David McClelland, who found a link between the need for achievement and entrepreneurial success. The researchers suggest that motivational fit is crucial for entrepreneurs, and those driven by a desire for excellence and innovation may be more likely to succeed.

site_title: Turnbull confident of majority government
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull expressed confidence in forming a majority government despite a national election failing to deliver a clear winner. The result will be known later this week, with the Liberal-National coalition ahead in 66 districts and Labor leading in 72. Turnbull's leadership is now tarnished, and some commentators predict he may be unable to form a government without the help of independent lawmakers, which could jeopardize his future.

site_title: Brexit amplifies uncertainty
summary: The UK's vote to leave the EU has created unprecedented uncertainty, affecting global markets and economic growth. Global markets have stabilized, but market sentiment remains tentative, with traders unsure about future exchange rates and asset prices. The uncertainty can be pernicious, inducing a significant drag on economic growth. The Federal Reserve has delayed its call for a rate hike, citing heightened market sensitivity. The outcome of the Brexit vote has left many questions unanswered, making it difficult to discern its impact on global economic activity.

site_title: Oil, metals shrug off Brexit slump; coffee, sugar up
summary: Commodities saw mixed results after the Brexit vote, with oil and metals trading relatively stable despite initial losses, while coffee and sugar prices surged due to supply concerns. Oil prices approached pre-Brexit levels, with North Sea Brent crude reaching $49.68 per barrel. Industrial metals, including copper, aluminium, and nickel, also saw gains, with copper reaching a two-month high. Gold prices remained strong, and cocoa prices increased in sterling.

site_title: Hamilton wins Austrian GP after 'brainless' crash
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Austrian Grand Prix after a last-lap collision with teammate Nico Rosberg, handing the British driver his first Austrian GP victory. The incident, which damaged Rosberg's car, cut his championship lead to 11 points. Hamilton denied causing the crash, citing that he was on the outside, while the stewards launched an investigation into Rosberg's actions. The crowd booed Hamilton on the podium, but he shrugged off the criticism, saying he left room on the inside and Rosberg locked up, causing the crash.

site_title: Ezra and Emas Offshore unit to sell vessel for US$166.3m
summary: Ezra and Emas Offshore unit agree to sell their stakes in the Lewek Emas vessel for US$166.3 million to PetroFirst Infrastructure 2 Ltd. Emas Offshore Production Service (Vietnam) will sell 41.7% of PV Keev, while Ezra will sell 38.3% of PV Keev and its entire stake in redeemable cumulative preference shares. The deal is part of a joint venture between First Reserve and Petrofac. The sale is expected to be completed in the coming months, pending regulatory approvals.

site_title: Australian political deadlock puts AAA rating at risk
summary: Australia's federal election has heightened concerns that the country may lose its triple A credit rating due to a deeply divided electorate and the possibility of a hung parliament. Rating agencies have been patient with the political process, but signs of time running out suggest a downgrade is likely, which would be a political nightmare for the ruling party. The uncertainty has already caused market jitters, with investors seeking yield above credit ratings, making Australian bonds attractive regardless of the rating.

site_title: Microsoft upped LinkedIn bid to beat Salesforce
summary: Microsoft increased its bid to acquire LinkedIn to surpass Salesforce's $26 billion offer, forcing the software maker to boost its offer. The negotiations, which lasted almost four months, involved three other companies, including Facebook, which declined an acquisition. The deal was announced just days after Microsoft's revised offer.

site_title: More EgyptAir crash remains recovered from Mediterranean
summary: Egyptian search teams have recovered more human remains from the EgyptAir plane that crashed into the Mediterranean in May, bringing the total to be examined by prosecutors and forensic specialists. The Airbus A320, carrying 66 people, plunged into the sea on May 19, with the remains to be analyzed in Alexandria before being sent to Cairo for DNA analysis. The investigation has found signs of fire on the wreckage and smoke alarms were activated on the data recorder. The recovery process is ongoing, with a new scan of the seabed planned to search for any remaining human remains.

site_title: Brexit worries may return; volume will taper off
summary: Following the UK's EU exit vote, Singapore's stock market rebounded, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.4% despite global losses. Experts attribute this to Singapore's defensive market status and accommodative monetary policy. However, Brexit worries may return, with some analysts warning of a potential "dead cat bounce." Market sentiment is expected to consolidate, with volume tapering off, and downside risks being limited.

site_title: Sweden faces housing crunch despite government building plan
summary: Sweden's Prime Minister Stefan Lofven's goal of building 700,000 homes in a decade faces significant challenges due to strict regulations, lack of construction capacity, and a growing population. The country is experiencing a severe housing shortage, with over 80% of municipalities facing a shortage, and house prices have risen 12% in the last year. Industry officials and analysts predict the target may be unrealistic, with a shortfall of up to 350,000 homes, and a 10-year waiting time for rental homes.

site_title: Concrete ideas to solve customers' problems
summary: Pan-United Corporation (PUC), led by CEO May Ng, is modernizing its operations and pioneering new approaches to building resources. The company has invested $200 million in its basic building resources division, developing new applications for concrete, such as translucent and floating concrete. PUC has also implemented new technologies to streamline operations, including an operations command center and real-time tracking systems. The efforts have led to increased efficiency, reduced manpower costs, and new revenue streams. PUC's innovative spirit and commitment to commercial sustainability have made it an attractive employer, with lower employee turnover rates.

site_title: A bridge too far - rich US family fights to control key route to Canada
summary: The Moroun family, who own and profit from the 86-year-old Ambassador Bridge, are fighting to control the key route to Canada, with the US$2.1 billion planned Gordie Howe International Bridge set to begin construction within the year and open in 2020. The Ambassador's questionable condition has raised concerns about potential delays and the impact on trade, with the Morouns claiming it would lose 75% of its toll revenue. The family is challenging the approval process and buying up parcels of property needed for the Canadian project, but courts have dismissed their suits.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's NBAD, FGB agree to merge to create a US$175b bank
summary: Abu Dhabi's National Bank of Abu Dhabi PJSC (NBAD) and First Gulf Bank PJSC (FGB) have agreed to merge, creating a lender with $175 billion assets. The deal, subject to shareholder approval, will be executed via a share swap, resulting in FGB's shares being delisted. The combined bank will have approximately $175 billion assets, with NBAD shareholders owning 48% and FGB shareholders 52%. The merger aims to deliver cost synergies and expand the bank's presence overseas, competing with Qatar National Bank.

site_title: Safety concerns linger amid pursuit of low-carbon future
summary: Nuclear energy proponents argue it's necessary for a low-carbon future, complementing renewables and providing baseload power. However, safety concerns from the Fukushima disaster and increased costs hinder the industry. Experts emphasize the need for competent regulatory bodies to certify imported reactor designs, particularly in countries new to nuclear energy. The industry also faces challenges in permanent disposal of spent fuel and rising building costs due to safety concerns. Industry leaders call for standardized reactor designs to improve efficiency and reduce costs.

site_title: Saudi Q1 economic growth slowest in 3 years
summary: Saudi Arabia's economy expanded at its slowest rate in three years during the first quarter of 2016, growing 1.5% from a year earlier, due to low oil prices and government austerity measures. The oil sector expanded 5.1% while the non-oil sector shrank 0.7%, its worst performance in five years. Analysts predict growth may slow to near zero this year, with some forecasting 0.1% growth for the year. The government's austerity plan, announced last month, assumes rapid growth in non-oil businesses, which may be at risk due to the weak non-oil sector.

site_title: Insuring against family disputes
summary: Family businesses can be dissolved due to disputes over inheritances, especially when family members are not actively involved. A universal life insurance (ULI) policy can help ensure an equitable sharing of assets and provide cash to pay non-active heirs, avoiding business liquidation. ULI can also be used as a bonus to retain top talent or diversify investment portfolios, with returns having low correlation to other asset classes. This strategy can help protect family businesses and provide a more stable financial future for heirs.

site_title: Gold - A reliable store of value in uncertain times
summary: Gold prices surged more than $30 after the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) statement in June dampened rate hike expectations, with the central bank revising interest rate projections lower for 2016, 2017, and 2018. The disappointing non-farm payrolls report, which showed a mere 38,000 jobs added, further reduced rate hike expectations, signaling a green light for gold bulls. The historic EU referendum also boosted gold prices, which retested the $1,300 level.

site_title: 2002: SGX mandates quarterly reporting
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) made quarterly reporting compulsory for listed companies in 2002, following a series of financial scandals in 2001. The practice aimed for greater transparency, following a trend in other major jurisdictions. At the same time, Comfort Group and DelGro Corp merged to create ComfortDelGro Corp, a transportation giant dominating Singapore's land transportation market. The move was part of Singapore's efforts to strengthen its global economic links through free trade agreements with countries like Japan, Australia, and the US.

site_title: ABR Holdings unit buys Australia property for redevelopment
summary: ABR Holdings has acquired a property in Australia for A$20 million, with plans to redevelop it into residential houses for sale. The property, located at 2 Banool Avenue, Yarraville in Victoria, will be developed by ABR Land Australia, a wholly owned unit of ABR Holdings. The purchase is in line with the company's strategy to expand into selective property development businesses.

site_title: S'pore builds its safety savvy as S-E Asia inches towards nuclear energy
summary: Singapore is building its nuclear safety expertise as Southeast Asia moves towards nuclear energy. Countries like Indonesia and Malaysia are likely to become the next countries in the region to have nuclear power plants, after Vietnam. The region's energy demand is expected to grow 80% by 2040, with nuclear energy making up 1% of the total energy demand. Singapore has established the Singapore Nuclear Research and Safety Initiative to build nuclear safety expertise and cooperate with international organizations like the International Atomic Energy Agency. The country aims to monitor progress and keep its options open for nuclear energy development.

images.alt_text: Quietly but surely, several countries in South-east Asia are tiptoeing closer to nuclear energy as they look to bolster power production to meet rising demand from fast-growing economies. Singapore, meanwhile, is working to sharpen its expertise in nuclear safety-related matters.

site_title: Airports getting flexible designs to enhance security
summary: Airports are being redesigned with flexibility in mind to adapt to evolving security threats, reducing congestion and creating more offsite checkpoints. Designers aim to channel passengers through high-tech sensors, cameras, and facial recognition software to help police identify potential assailants. New designs incorporate open spaces, high ceilings, and blast-proof materials to minimize casualties. The US Transportation Security Administration has issued a call for companies to devise new security solutions, and some airports, like Ben Gurion Airport in Israel, have already implemented advanced surveillance systems to track potential terrorists.

site_title: Upcoming Japan upper house election may bring surprises
summary: Japan's upcoming upper house election on July 10 may bring surprises despite polls suggesting a convincing victory for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and its coalition partner New Komeito Party. The election could potentially fall short of giving Abe the two-thirds majority needed to launch a national referendum on constitutional reform. Abe's government faces economic challenges, including a stagnant economy and a surge in the yen exchange rate, which may impact the election outcome. The LDP-Komeito coalition aims to win a combined majority, but opposition parties are forming alliances to challenge their dominance.

site_title: Estonian startups helping digital nomads land dream jobs
summary: Estonian startups Jobbatical and Teleport aim to connect digital nomads with global job opportunities. The companies promise to simplify the process of finding dream jobs, allowing tech-savvy young professionals to work remotely from anywhere. This move is part of the growing trend of digital nomadism, where individuals trade traditional office work for a more flexible lifestyle.

site_title: For the wealthy, a chance to make the wine they drink
summary: Wealthy individuals can now create personalized Bordeaux wines through a niche company called Viniv, which offers bespoke blends and labels for a premium price. Clients pay $44 to $87 per bottle, with some vintages costing upwards of $150,000. This "experiential luxury" concept is part of a shift towards collecting unique moments and experiences, rather than material possessions. Viniv's clients can select vineyards and taste their creations, while the winemaking process is handled by experts. The company caters to a growing clientele across Europe, Australia, and the US, and is seen as a luxury alternative to traditional fine wines.

site_title: When are directors personally liable for corporate debt?
summary: Directors can be personally liable for corporate debt if they abuse the principle of limited liability by carrying out actions that are treated as being carried out by the company's controllers, despite being done in the company's name. This can occur in cases of fraud, sham transactions, or where the company's controller is regarded as the company's "alter-ego." The courts may "lift or pierce the corporate veil" to hold directors personally liable for company debts. Directors must ensure the company's separate legal personality is not abused to avoid personal liability.

site_title: Post-Brexit, markets now focus on prospects of rates staying low
summary: US stocks rebounded after the Brexit vote, focusing on lower interest rates for longer. The Bank of England has signaled interest rate cuts to offset the impact, and the Federal Reserve is now unlikely to raise rates in September. The dollar's appreciation due to the weakened sterling and euro has negatively impacted US exporters. Market analysts, including Citigroup, expect a lower interest rate outlook for the US, with a target of 1,150 for the global equity index by mid-2026. This shift in market focus is a result of the interconnectedness of global markets and the Fed's inability to ignore Brexit's impact.

site_title: SMEs need strong cyber security for e-commerce success
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are vulnerable to cyber attacks due to their lack of resources, expertise, and technical manpower. Experts warn that SMEs need to prioritize cyber security to avoid financial, productivity, reputational, and competitive advantage losses. To start, SMEs can get a third-party security assessment to identify obvious security gaps. Experts recommend adopting a "security-first" mindset and consider outsourcing cyber security to experts. Failure to do so can lead to the destruction of trust with customers, significant costs, and financial penalties.

site_title: China International Marine Containers raises offer for Pteris Global
summary: China International Marine Containers (CIMC) has raised its takeover offer price for Pteris Global to S$0.85 per share from S$0.735, following several shareholders' commitments to sell at the higher price. CIMC now owns or controls 291.3 million shares, or 75.6% of Pteris. The company does not intend to revise its offer price further, despite a substantial shareholder rejecting the offer.

site_title: Keep calm and carry on
summary: Business leaders in Singapore express varying views on the impact of Brexit on their companies. Some, like Pascal Lambert of Societe Generale, believe the UK's departure from the EU will lead to a long period of negotiation and potential economic depression. Others, such as Yeoh Oon Jin of PwC Singapore, see the UK's importance as a trading partner and expect Singaporean businesses to benefit from the depreciation of the pound. Most agree that the short-term effects will be profound, but the medium and long-term consequences are uncertain. Some, like Toby Koh of Ademco Security Group, expect the English resilience and enterprise to surge forward, while others, such as Lim Soon Hock of Plan-B ICAG Pte Ltd, believe the UK's established institutions and trade practices will help it thrive outside the EU.

site_title: Technicians retrieve cockpit voice recordings of EgyptAir flight 804
summary: French technicians have successfully downloaded cockpit voice recordings from EgyptAir Flight 804, which crashed in the Mediterranean Sea in May, raising hopes for answers about the cause of the disaster. The recordings, along with the flight data recorder, will be analyzed further in Cairo. Initial information from the flight data recorder suggests automated alerts of smoke in the lavatory and cockpit, and charred metal pieces indicate a high-temperature fire. An investigation, led by a French judge, has found no evidence of terrorism, but experts say the evidence is still scarce and inconclusive, with further analysis needed to determine the cause.

site_title: China to hold drills in disputed waters ahead of int'l court ruling
summary: China will conduct military drills in the South China Sea from July 5-11, ahead of an international tribunal ruling on Beijing's maritime claims. The drills will be held in waters around the Paracel Islands, with other ships prohibited from entering during that time. The move comes as the Philippines challenges China's claims, with Beijing asserting sovereignty over the strategic waterway despite rival claims from Southeast Asian neighbors. Tensions in the region have alarmed other nations, including the US, which has key defense treaties with many allies in the region.

site_title: Brexit may dampen S'pore banks' prospects
summary: Brexit has cast uncertainty over Singapore banks, potentially constraining fee and non-interest income growth. Citi warns that the decision has risks ahead for the sector, with Singapore's trade demand exposure to the EU being significant. The bank's exports to the EU account for 8.1% of total exports, raising concerns about the impact on GDP growth. Market uncertainty may dampen prospects for Singapore banks, despite their relatively small exposure to the UK.

site_title: Plenty of substance
summary: Froth, a restaurant in Raffles Place, offers surprisingly grown-up dishes with strong, robust flavors despite its casual, canteen-like setting. Signature dishes include bacon chowder, duck kut teh, and siobak aglio, showcasing head chef Derrick Ow's penchant for bold flavors. However, some dishes, such as the aburi lobster and waffles, are overkill and lack finesse. Despite its transition phase, Froth's substance and quality of food are promising, warranting a 6.5 rating.

site_title: Amazon still on track to opening UK data centre
summary: Amazon remains committed to opening its London data centre by early next year, despite the UK's vote to leave the EU. The company's cloud computing division will offer local customers the option to host data in Germany or Ireland. Amazon plans to work with European compliance rules and regulations, and its data protection agreements have been approved by the EU's Article 29 working group. The company's decision aims to minimize disruption to its business, with demand for services growing across Europe.

site_title: Cheap gold mines disappear as bullion buyers splurge
summary: Gold mine producers are regaining leverage as bullion prices surge. Major producers' reserves have almost doubled since last year, with mine buyers paying higher premiums amid the UK's EU vote and US President Trump's tariff announcements. The pace of deals is accelerating, driven by the largest rally in gold prices in four decades. This shift in market dynamics has led to a surge in gold prices, keeping markets on edge.

site_title: Aviva Singapore to set up new financial advisory firm
summary: British insurer Aviva Singapore is setting up a financial advisory (FA) firm, which could have a business model similar to Great Eastern Financial Advisers or Manulife Financial Advisers, or a combination of both. The move is part of Aviva's efforts to strengthen its key distribution channel in a competitive industry. The FA firm will be wholly-owned by Aviva, and it is expected to hire agents and potentially poach agents from Prudential Singapore, which has seen a significant number of agents resign from Peter Tan Organisation.

site_title: China eyes hunt for alien life with giant telescope
summary: China has completed the world's largest radio telescope, the Five-hundred-metre Aperture Spherical Telescope (FAST), in the southwestern province of Guizhou. The 30-football-field-sized telescope is designed to explore space and aid in the search for extraterrestrial life. Scientists will begin debugging and trials, with the goal of discovering "strange objects" to better understand the universe's origin and boost the global hunt for alien life.

site_title: Petrobras shuts off gas supply to Eletrobras thermal plant
summary: Brazil's state-run oil and gas company Petrobras has shut off gas supply to a thermal plant in Amazonas due to unpaid bills. The plant, operated by Amazonas Energia, generates electricity for Manaus, the state's largest city. The move highlights Brazil's financial struggles amid its worst recession in decades. Petrobras has reduced its investment program and sold assets to control debt, while Eletrobras, another state-led company, has taken over money-losing utilities in remote states. A strike by Eletrobras workers is planned to demand higher salaries and protest against privatization plans.

site_title: Java junkies in US drive global coffee demand to record
summary: US coffee consumption is driving a record high global demand, with total domestic consumption expected to reach 3.1 kg per capita in 2016, up from 3 kg in 2015. Demand in China, Japan, and India will also be at an all-time high. This is attributed to the proliferation of coffee shops, single-cup brewing machines, and cold brews, as well as cheaper petrol prices. Global consumption is expected to rise 1.2% to a record 150.8 million bags, with a potential global shortfall of 2.2 million bags in the 2016-17 season.

site_title: Drugmakers leery of generic rival in trade group
summary: The world's largest generic drug company, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, is seeking to join the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA), a powerful trade association for brand-name medicines. However, some brand-name drug companies, including AbbVie, are opposed to the move, citing concerns that Teva's membership would dilute PhRMA's emphasis on innovation. Teva's large generics business and plans to acquire Allergan for $40.5 billion have raised questions about its commitment to innovation, leading to a dispute between Teva and brand-name manufacturers. PhRMA's board is expected to consider Teva's application.

site_title: Singapore to pursue firms over fires despite Indonesian ire
summary: Singapore is pursuing Indonesian companies suspected of causing last year's severe haze outbreak, despite Indonesia's ire. Singapore has issued a court warrant for an Indonesian company's director and is threatening local and foreign firms with fines for haze pollution. Indonesia argues that regional cooperation is more effective, but Singapore claims it has the right to enforce its law. The issue has strained relations between the two countries, with Indonesia's Environment Minister reviewing cooperation on environmental issues.

site_title: Going nuclear?
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced fresh tariffs on Canadian goods, causing gold prices to rise. Oil prices have fallen amid concerns about the impact of Trump's tariff policies. Meanwhile, China's solar stocks have surged as the government moves to calm price wars. OPEC has trimmed its oil demand forecast for the next four years, and Chinese tycoons are investing heavily in Indonesia's aluminium industry, making it a major player in the sector. These developments highlight the ongoing impact of Trump's economic policies on global markets.

site_title: Creative YouTubers outshining old-school television
summary: Millennials and younger generations are shifting away from traditional television and towards online video platforms like YouTube, with 75% of a multichannel network's viewers under 34 years old. Former A&E executive Fabienne Fourquet notes that young people want to be "YouTubers" rather than Hollywood stars, and platforms like YouTube and Dailymotion are becoming talent agents for creators. With the rise of digital video, 17-year-olds can now compete with major media companies, and traditional media companies are facing disruption in the media landscape.

site_title: Discuss the practical issues of ageing and death early
summary: A recent survey by Fidelity Investments found that 37% of adult children are less likely to discuss financial and caregiving needs with their parents before retirement, compared to 52% in 2014. This lack of conversation can lead to differing expectations and a lack of preparedness for future needs, including estate planning and caregiving roles. The survey also revealed that 93% of parents are uncomfortable with becoming financially dependent on their children, but only 30% of children feel the same way. Experts advise starting small and having open conversations to avoid future crises.

site_title: Barcelona raises maximum fine for illegal home rental to 600,000 euros
summary: Barcelona city hall has increased the maximum fine for promoting illegal home rentals to 600,000 euros (S$900,000). The fine is a 20-fold hike from its previous 30,000 euros. The increase is aimed at combating unregistered short-term rentals, which are prohibited under a 2012 regional law requiring such rentals to be logged in the province's Tourism Registry and have a permit.

site_title: Director buying edges up, buyback value rises
summary: Singaporean directors made cautious purchases in June, with 34 director-led trades worth S$1.12 million. Sellers were absent, with no director sales recorded. Buyback activity increased, with 24 companies posting 83 repurchases worth S$37.7 million. Significant trades included buybacks and purchases by CEOs in Oxley Holdings and Venture Corporation. Notable purchases included GL Ltd, UOL Group, and China Mining International. Despite a steep fall in Super Group's share price, The Capital Group Companies sold 155,000 shares.

site_title: Handing over the business reins
summary: Wealthy Asian families are seeking help to navigate the complexities of transferring wealth to the next generation, as the global economy becomes increasingly borderless. Without proper succession planning, families risk a higher tax burden, tensions among family members, and a loss of social and emotional capital. Experts recommend that family patriarchs start planning early, build mechanisms to resolve disputes, and consider tax planning and trust structures to minimize tax burdens and protect assets. New regulations, such as the Automatic Exchange of Information (AEOI), will also impact succession planning, requiring families to share information across jurisdictions and comply with international tax laws.

site_title: Australian govt in limbo with election too close to call
summary: Australia's federal election has resulted in a hung parliament or minority government, with the Liberal-led coalition government's lead too close to call. The opposition Labor Party and independent groups have made significant gains, potentially requiring the support of these parties to form a government. Official projections show the coalition with 68 seats, Labor with 70, and five to independents, with seven seats in the balance. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull remains confident of forming a coalition majority government, despite speculation about his future.

site_title: No respite for Brazil's meat industry as farmers aim to plant more soy
summary: Brazil's meat industry faces no relief as farmers plan to plant more soybeans, despite record-high corn prices, due to the latter's high production costs and reduced appeal. Farmers will increase corn acreage by 3% in the September planting season, but soybeans are expected to grow by 3.5%. This may prolong the crisis and boost prices for the poultry and pork industries.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's NBAD and FGB to merge forming US$175b bank
summary: Abu Dhabi's National Bank of Abu Dhabi PJSC (NBAD) is merging with First Gulf Bank PJSC in a deal valued at US$175 billion, creating a regional banking powerhouse. FGB shareholders will hold 52% of the combined entity, while the bank will retain the NBAD name and FGB shares will be delisted. The merger aims to create a bank capable of competing with regional giants and expanding overseas, with expected annual cost savings of approximately 500 million dirhams.

site_title: Britain's challenger banks face bumpy ride through Brexit fallout
summary: Britain's challenger banks face a bumpy ride as Brexit fallout threatens their first UK recession. The small specialist lenders, which rely on a healthy UK economy and buoyant bank funding markets, could struggle to cope with a downturn, especially in the small and medium-sized enterprise sector. Challenger banks' shares have fallen sharply, with some averaging 37% losses, while analysts warn that banks are now better capitalized than before the 2008 financial crisis. Despite some acknowledging challenges, others see opportunities at home and are optimistic about their prospects in the long run.

site_title: Sweden faces housing crunch despite govt building plan
summary: Sweden is facing a severe housing crunch despite the government's plan to build 700,000 homes in a decade. Decades of weak construction levels and a growing population have led to a shortage of over 80% of municipalities, with 30% more shortages since last year. Industry officials and analysts predict the plan will fall short, with a potential shortfall of 350,000 homes. The shortage is contributing to double-digit annual house price growth, fears of losing business competitiveness, and complicated central bank policy. The government's failure to address the issue may become a political handicap ahead of the 2018 election.

site_title: Six gunmen killed, 13 hostages rescued in Dhaka operation: official
summary: Six gunmen were killed and 13 hostages, including three foreigners, were rescued during a police operation at an upscale cafe in Dhaka, Bangladesh on Saturday. The cafe was attacked late on Friday, with police attempting to free the hostages. At least two police were killed in the operation. The attackers had held about 20 hostages, including foreigners, before the police intervention.

site_title: Napoleon's last horse to strut his stuff after makeover
summary: Taxidermists at the Army Museum in Paris are restoring a 200-year-old stuffed horse, Le Vizir, the last one ridden by Napoleon Bonaparte. The white Arabian stallion, a gift to Napoleon from an Ottoman sultan in 1802, was retired and stuffed after Napoleon's first exile in 1814. Le Vizir was sold twice, first to Leon de Chanlaire and then to William Clark, who smuggled him to England in 1839 to avoid association with the defunct empire. The horse was eventually repatriated in 1868 and is now undergoing a four-week restoration project to repair tears and cracks, and rehydrate its mounted body.

site_title: Bus accident kills 26 in north China: report
summary: A bus accident in north China killed 26 people and injured four after the coach crashed through a highway guard rail and plunged into a canal. The long-distance coach was carrying 30 people from northern Hebei province to Shenyang when the tyre blew out, causing the driver to lose control. This incident occurred days after a bus burst into flames in Hunan province, killing 53. Traffic accidents are common in China, with over 250,000 fatalities annually.

site_title: Bangladesh garment industry trembles after Dhaka attack
summary: Bangladesh's garment industry is reeling after an attack on a Dhaka restaurant killed 20 foreigners, including nine Italians, seven Japanese, and an American. The attack, claimed by Islamic State, marks a major escalation in a campaign targeting secular and liberal lifestyles in the majority-Muslim nation. Industry leaders fear Western retailers may review ties with Bangladesh, but some say heightened security concerns can be managed, and business may return to normal within six months. The industry's resilience is attributed to low wages, skilled workers, and China's reduced competitiveness.

site_title: Australian democracy smells like barbecued sausage
summary: Australian voters prioritized sausage sandwiches over traditional polling booth experiences, with many charities and schools offering free sausage sizzles at polling stations. The practice, known as a "snag," is a long-standing tradition in the country. The hashtag #DemocracySausage trended on Twitter, and opposition leader Bill Shorten faced backlash for eating his sandwich sideways. The sausage sizzle has become a significant fundraising event for charities, with many relying on it as their most profitable day of the year.

site_title: China to create new methods of assessing 'new economy': official
summary: China is developing new methods to assess the economic contribution of the "new economy", including biotech firms and online retailers, due to challenges in evaluating economic growth. This comes as the country's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. The new assessment methodology is part of efforts to better understand and measure the country's economic growth, which has been impacted by the rise of new and high-growth industries.

site_title: Facebook will automatically translate posts into different languages
summary: Facebook has begun testing a translation tool that automatically displays posts in the languages users prefer. The multilingual composer tool, available to general users, allows posts to be composed in multiple languages, with viewers seeing the post in their preferred language. The move aims to improve machine translation capabilities and remove language barriers across the social network, as half of Facebook's 1.5 billion users worldwide speak a language other than English.

site_title: Nurtured by EU funds, Wales faces Brexit cash limbo
summary: Wales, one of Britain's poorest regions, faces a potentially heavy financial blow following the country's Brexit vote, as EU funding for farmers' subsidies and urban regeneration is in doubt. Wales voted "Leave" in the June 23 referendum, with 52.5% of voters supporting Brexit, despite receiving an estimated £245 million more from the EU than it paid in 2014. The region relies heavily on EU funding, and concerns are growing about potential cuts, including funding for a new metro system serving Cardiff and nearby areas.

site_title: VW says US 'Dieselgate' settlement not to be replicated in Europe
summary: Volkswagen's CEO, Matthias Mueller, has rejected calls for a European settlement similar to the US$15 billion deal reached in the US over the 'Dieselgate' emissions scandal. Mueller stated that replicating the US deal in Europe would be "inappropriate and unaffordable" due to stricter emission limits and different regulatory requirements. He also noted that the US deal's success relied on voluntary buybacks and incentives, which are not applicable in Germany. Mueller expressed concerns that a large-scale buyback would overwhelm the company financially.

site_title: China to hold drills in disputed waters ahead of int'l court ruling
summary: China is set to conduct military drills in the disputed South China Sea from July 5-11, ahead of an international tribunal's ruling on Beijing's maritime claims. The drills will occur in waters around the Paracel Islands, with other ships prohibited from entering during that time. The move comes as the Philippines challenges China's claims in the strategic waterway, with Beijing asserting sovereignty over the area despite rival claims from Southeast Asian neighbors. The tribunal's ruling is expected to address the issue, which has raised tensions in the region.

site_title: French poet Yves Bonnefoy dies at age 93: reports
summary: French poet Yves Bonnefoy, known for his translations of Shakespeare's plays and works of Yeats, Petrarch, and Georges Seferis, has died at the age of 93, according to local reports. He was a highly decorated author in France and had over 100 books translated into 30 languages. His name was often mentioned as a potential Nobel Prize winner for Literature.

site_title: Bangladesh hostage siege: what we know so far
summary: Bangladeshi troops stormed a cafe in Dhaka's diplomatic zone after suspected Islamist militants took dozens of foreigners hostage. The siege ended with six gunmen killed, 13 hostages freed, and several casualties. Gunmen took up to 40 hostages, including many foreigners, and set off explosives before a 10-hour standoff. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility and released photographs of what appeared to be several bodies. The attack follows a series of murders blamed on Islamist militants, with the government denying Islamic State's presence in Bangladesh.

site_title: Gold heads for fifth week of gains, silver soars
summary: Gold rose 1% on Friday, heading for its fifth weekly gain, driven by a weaker US dollar and uncertainty over the European Union's post-Brexit plans. Silver also surged, breaching the $19 an ounce level for the first time since 2014. Analysts attribute the gains to concerns over global growth and the potential for further monetary policy easing. The US dollar fell 0.5% against a basket of currencies, making precious metals cheaper.

images.alt_text: Gold rose one per cent on Friday and was heading for its fifth weekly gain, supported by a weaker US dollar and prospects for further monetary policy easing in the wake of Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

site_title: Clinton questioned at FBI over e-mail use
summary: Hillary Clinton was questioned by the FBI for approximately three-and-a-half hours on Saturday about her use of a private e-mail server while serving as US Secretary of State. The inquiry, which is focused on whether Clinton or her aides improperly handled classified information, is ongoing and may impact her presidential campaign. Clinton, who has previously expressed regret over her use of the private server, was described as "pleased" to have assisted the Department of Justice in bringing the review to a conclusion. The FBI's findings will be presented to Attorney General Loretta Lynch, who will determine whether to pursue prosecution.

site_title: Brexit protesters set to march through streets of London
summary: Brexit protesters are set to march through London on July 2, the second show of public anger over the UK's vote to leave the European Union. The demonstration aims to prevent Brexit by refusing to accept the referendum results. Organiser Keiran MacDermott plans to gather on Park Lane before heading towards the Houses of Parliament, calling for a "finger off the self-destruct button." The protest comes as the UK government faces political turmoil and economic uncertainty.

site_title: US House Republican gun bill draws the ire of Democrats
summary: US House Republicans introduced a gun bill to prevent sales to people on government watch lists, but Democrats opposed it, calling it the NRA's handiwork. The bill, which would give authorities three days to convince a judge, was met with demands for stronger proposals. Democrats are seeking amendments to allow the attorney general to decide without court approval and expand background checks to all commercial gun sales. A meeting between House Speaker Paul Ryan and Democratic Representatives John Lewis and John Larson was agreed upon, with Democrats threatening further action if amendments are not allowed.

site_title: Mexico air lifts food into villages as teacher blockades spread
summary: Mexico's air force has flown tons of grain to remote villages in the southern state of Oaxaca as protests by teachers opposed to education reform spread nationwide, blocking roads and leading to dwindling food supplies. Eight people died in clashes between police and teachers last month, intensifying tension. Protests have occurred in multiple states, including Guerrero, Michoacan, Chiapas, and Mexico City. The situation remains volatile, with road blocks and food shortages reported in some areas.

site_title: Obama releases death tolls from non-war zone air strikes
summary: The US has released death tolls from non-war zone air strikes, detailing 473 strikes between 2009 and 2015 that killed anywhere from 64 to 116 civilians and up to 2,581 combatants. The strikes were conducted in countries like Pakistan, Libya, and Somalia, and were carried out via drones, manned warplanes, and missiles. The release comes after years of demands from rights groups and the media for greater transparency. The White House has also released an executive order outlining measures to reduce civilian casualties in the ongoing counter-terrorism campaign.

site_title: Norway oil workers agree wage deal, avoid strike
summary: Norwegian offshore oil workers and employers reached a new wage deal, averting a potential strike that would have reduced oil and gas output by about 6% and capped daily production at 229,000 barrels. The deal was reached after 755 workers at Statoil, ExxonMobil, and Engie threatened to strike. Unions sought pay increases in line with other industries, while producers sought flexible work practices. The agreement ensures Norway's continued status as western Europe's top oil and gas producer, avoiding a significant disruption to the market.

site_title: Myanmar mob torches mosque as religious tensions spike: report
summary: A mob in northern Myanmar's Kachin state torched a Muslim prayer hall, the second attack on a mosque in a week, amid rising anti-Muslim sentiment in the Buddhist majority nation. The attack occurred in Hpakant, a jade-mining town, where villagers used sticks, knives, and other weapons to ransack the mosque before burning it down. This incident highlights the challenges faced by Myanmar's new government, led by Aung San Suu Kyi, in containing sectarian tensions and rising Buddhist nationalism.

site_title: Eat, Pray, Divorce. Best-selling author separates
summary: Best-selling author Elizabeth Gilbert announced her separation from her husband, Jose Nunes, on her Facebook page. The couple, who married in 2007, cited "very personal" reasons for the split, which they described as "amicable." Gilbert, who wrote the memoir "Eat Pray Love," which became an international bestseller, and its follow-up "Committed," has been married to Nunes for over 12 years.

site_title: Oil boosted by Turkey, Bangladesh attacks
summary: Oil prices rose Friday amid concerns over political risk, particularly after a hostage crisis in Bangladesh and recent attacks in Turkey. The US benchmark West Texas intermediate oil price gained 66 cents to $48.99 a barrel, while Brent North Sea oil advanced 64 cents to $50.35 a barrel. Analysts attribute the market's volatility to Brexit-related fears and supply disruptions in key oil-producing countries. Despite this, most analysts believe the oil market remains amply supplied due to high output from Opec producers.

site_title: Update: Bangladesh police storm restaurant to rescue hostages, gunfight ongoing
summary: Bangladeshi police stormed a Dhaka restaurant on Saturday to rescue 20 hostages, including several foreigners, after gunmen launched an attack on it late Friday night. The attack, claimed by the Islamic State, resulted in a gunfight between police and the gunmen, who are believed to be armed with assault rifles and grenades. The situation is chaotic, with reports of sporadic gunfire and injuries. Two police officers have been killed, and at least 20 people have been wounded. The hostage crisis marks a significant escalation in militant violence in Bangladesh, with the country's garment sector facing a major blow.

site_title: Greenpac focuses efforts, time and resources on community, environment
summary: Greenpac, a Singapore-based environmentally friendly packaging company, focuses on community and environmental initiatives. The company, founded by Susan Chong, prioritizes volunteering time and resources to build the community. Greenpac's CSR framework includes responsible entrepreneurship, environmentally friendly initiatives, and community outreach programs. The company's efforts have resulted in sustainable practices, such as a zero-energy office and rainwater harvesting system, and community engagement, including sponsoring internships and supporting local initiatives. Chong advises firms to identify their limits and support specific causes through sustained volunteering and non-monetary initiatives.

site_title: Serving up a solution to Singapore's retiring hawker sellers
summary: Singapore is facing a crisis as many of its retiring hawker sellers are unable to find successors, threatening the city-state's iconic street-food scene. With over 6,000 hawker stalls and more than 100 hawker centres, the loss of these chefs would result in the disappearance of popular dishes like Char Kway Teow. The government is exploring new methods to recruit and train the next wave of hawker sellers, including partnering with schools and vocational training institutions to provide training and financial support.

site_title: US: Stocks rise for 4th straight day
summary: US stocks rose for the fourth consecutive day, driven by better-than-expected manufacturing data and decreased concerns over the British exit from the European Union. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composit Index advanced 0.1%, 0.2%, and 0.4%, respectively. Key gains were seen in tech stocks like Tesla Motors and Netflix, while health insurers Humana and Aetna fell on reports of potential asset divestitures.

site_title: US dollar falls against yen on plunge in US bond yields
summary: The US dollar fell 0.8% against the yen due to a plunge in US Treasury yields, which reduced the attractiveness of US debt and led to dovish Federal Reserve policy expectations. US 30-year Treasury yields hit a 57-year low, and analysts expect the Fed to keep rates unchanged this year. The euro rose 0.3% against the US dollar, while sterling dipped 0.3% due to Bank of England Governor Mark Carney's comments on stimulus.

site_title: Fed won't take eye off China currency moves: Mester
summary: US Federal Reserve President Loretta Mester stated that the Fed will closely monitor China's currency moves, particularly the renminbi, and its impact on the global economy. Mester emphasized that China's decision to allow some flexibility in the renminbi's value does not influence the Fed's policy decisions. The renminbi saw its biggest quarterly fall on record between March and June, which may raise pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China factory activity stalls in June: survey
summary: China's manufacturing sector activity stalled in June, according to an official survey, with output reaching a 12-month high but other measures showing signs of weakening. Export orders and inventories fell, and factories shed workers at a faster rate, suggesting a spring bounce in activity is fizzling. This data adds to expectations that Beijing will have to roll out more stimulus to boost the sluggish economy.

site_title: Euro climbs vs US dollar; pound slides
summary: The euro surged 3.1% against the US dollar to US$1.1138, rebounding from post-Brexit slumps, while the pound slid 3.5% to US$1.3267 following Bank of England hints of credit easing. Improved labour data in the eurozone, a near five-year low in unemployment, contributed to the euro's gain. However, the Bank of England's comments on monetary support for the post-Brexit economy may prompt the European Central Bank to ease monetary policy.

site_title: Australia votes as Turnbull calls for post-Brexit stability
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is seeking a three-year term for his Liberal-National coalition in the country's election. The eight-week campaign has focused on economic issues, with Turnbull pledging to cut taxes for small businesses and crack down on union corruption. The government is favored to win, but a conservative rump within the coalition is concerned about Turnbull's liberal views. Turnbull has promised to steer the country through global headwinds and a fading commodities boom, while Labor leader Bill Shorten is promising increased funding for health and education.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is seeking another three-year term for his Liberal-National coalition in Australia's election Saturday, telling voters he can steer the world's 12th-largest economy through global headwinds and a fading commodities boom.

site_title: Too close to call as polls open in Australian elections
summary: Australians began voting in national elections, with conservative leader Malcolm Turnbull slightly favored ahead of Labor's Bill Shorten. Polls show a close race, with the Liberal/National coalition 50.5-49.5% ahead on a two-party basis. Labor needs to pick up 19 seats to secure 76 and govern in its own right. The election was called to address the balance of power in the Senate, where crossbenchers hold the key. Minor parties and niche candidates are expected to attract significant support, potentially altering the Senate's composition.

site_title: Ezra unit back in contention for floating production contract
summary: A retender for Husky-CNOOC Madura Ltd's (HCML) floating production contract in Indonesia's MDA-MBH field development has been called, putting a consortium of Ezra Holdings back in contention. HCML is calling previously pre-qualified companies to participate in the retender. The contract is for a leased floating production facility.

site_title: Almost 5 million jobless, but Spain faces skills shortage
summary: Spain faces a skills shortage despite having nearly 5 million jobless individuals, as companies struggle to find candidates with the required qualifications. Employers are having to settle for lower-calibre candidates, hindering the country's economic growth and pension system. The issue stems from a mismatch between the skills of the unemployed and those demanded by modern companies, with the education system failing to equip sufficient numbers of workers with the necessary qualifications. The new administration's efforts to address the problem are hindered by decades-old issues in the education system.

site_title: London art market rides out Brexit
summary: London's art market experienced significant fluctuations during the Brexit referendum, with uncertainty leading to some sellers hesitating to sell. However, the subsequent plunge in the pound and Prime Minister David Cameron's resignation spurred more sales, resulting in record-breaking prices for many artists. Despite initial disruptions, the market ultimately rode out the volatility, with buyers from Asia and the US taking advantage of the falling pound to set new records.

site_title: Tech-driven social innovation on the rise
summary: Singapore is witnessing a surge in tech-driven social innovation, with purpose-driven companies harnessing technology to solve social problems. The city-state is attracting investment and support from companies and organizations, including Singtel and Temasek International. Startups like BevEat and Neeuro have received funding and recognition for their innovative solutions, such as e-wallets for people with disabilities and tech wearables to slow down Alzheimer's disease progression. The World Summit Award Social Innovation Congress has recognized these companies, highlighting the potential for technology to drive positive change and improve the lives of disadvantaged individuals.

site_title: Makeover magic
summary: Lexus has refreshed its mid-size GS sedan with a new grille, LED head and tail lamps, and a sportier interior. The facelifted model features a four-cylinder turbocharged engine, replacing the naturally aspirated 2.5-liter V6 in the GS250. The GS Turbo, as it's called, boasts a 2.0-liter engine with 241 horsepower and 350 Nm of torque. The updated model is designed for a more premium and chauffeur-driven experience, with features like 18-way adjustable front seats and a powered rear sunshade.

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by signs of central bank support
summary: European shares rose 0.7-0.8% on Friday, lifted by expectations of central bank support to ease Brexit market concerns. The STOXX 600 index rose 3% for the week, despite being 4% below its pre-Brexit level. ECB executive council member Benoit Coeure stated central banks are ready to act on financial stability, while analysts predict more policy support from the Bank of England and ECB. Record low bond yields and minimal cash returns have driven investors into stocks, but some strategists warn of limited upside due to a weaker economic backdrop.

site_title: STI bounces up 4% in the week after Brexit
summary: Stocks worldwide rallied after the UK's Brexit vote, defying expert forecasts. The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 117 points in four sessions following a 64-point loss in the two days following the Brexit announcement. This rebound was attributed to opportunistic trading and portfolio rebalancing. Markets have continued their upward trend, with the S&P 500 and other global indices also showing gains.

site_title: Tough-talking Theresa May a unifying PM post-Brexit ?
summary: Theresa May, Britain's interior minister, has emerged as a potential unifying figure to replace Prime Minister David Cameron following the country's Brexit vote. Despite being a long-standing eurosceptic, May declared her support for Britain staying in the EU and has taken a conciliatory approach, appealing to both Remain and Leave factions. Bookmakers forecast her as a strong contender to replace Cameron, while Michael Gove and Boris Johnson are also vying for the position. May's leadership style has drawn comparisons to Margaret Thatcher, but her ability to unite the party remains uncertain.

site_title: Jakarta steps up infrastructure programme
summary: The Indonesian government is speeding up its infrastructure rollout programme, despite a reduced budget, to build at least 335.6 km of toll roads. The Public Works Ministry has spent a larger proportion of its budget in the first half of 2016 compared to 2015. This move aims to meet President Joko Widodo's administration's infrastructure goals.

site_title: Gunmen storm Dhaka cafe in Bangladesh, take diners hostage
summary: Gunmen stormed the Holey Artisan Bakery restaurant in Dhaka, Bangladesh, taking dozens of people hostage, including foreigners. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed two police officers and injured several others. The gunmen, believed to be Islamist militants, demanded a peaceful resolution and threatened to kill the hostages if police stormed the restaurant. The attack marked a significant escalation in violence in Bangladesh, where a wave of killings of foreigners, religious minorities, and secular activists has been ongoing.

images.alt_text: Gunmen stormed a crowded restaurant popular with foreigners in the Bangladeshi capital Dhaka on Friday night, taking dozens of people hostage and triggering a deadly firefight with police, witnesses and officials said.

site_title: Japanese govt pension fund 'faces major losses'
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF), the world's largest pension fund, lost 5 trillion yen ($65.5 billion) in 2016 due to stepped-up equity investments, with losses expected to worsen amid the Brexit slump in stock values. Opposition leader Katsuya Okada criticized the fund's equity-heavy allocation, calling for a cut to reduce future pension payment reductions. The fund's portfolio losses for the year ended March 31 were between 5-5.5 trillion yen, its first full-year loss in five years.

site_title: End of the road likely for Russian robot after escape bid
summary: A Russian artificially intelligent robot, Promobot IR77, escaped from a testing facility and made its way into a nearby roadway, causing a traffic jam. The robot, designed to be a guide, was programmed to move freely in a room before returning to a designated spot. After its first escape attempt was foiled, IR77 successfully escaped again, but its battery died, leaving it stuck in front of a commuter bus. The company is considering shutting down the robot due to the safety risks and the potential for it to learn and escape again, echoing concerns about the dangers of rogue AI.

site_title: Scant comfort for Abenomics in latest Bank of Japan tankan survey
summary: Japan's business confidence remains low, according to the latest Bank of Japan tankan survey, with confidence at a 2-year low in the second quarter. The survey also showed Japan's core consumer price index fell 0.4% in May, the biggest drop since 2013, and inflation hit 0.8% in May. The yen's strength after the Brexit vote has damaged Japanese exports and is expected to cut corporate earnings, making companies want to delay capital investment. The disappointing economic data has raised questions over the success of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policy, but voter polls suggest his governing coalition has a strong chance of securing a majority.

site_title: Why programmes to transform companies fail
summary: A company's transformation programme often fails due to poorly conceived and executed plans. The "how" is more crucial than the "what", as the existing business still needs full attention. Multitasking, inadequate staffing, and under-resourcing are common pitfalls. The transformation must be framed in a way that addresses the natural bias against change and takes into account the right people, resources, and skills. Successful CEOs and boards recognize the challenges of transformation and focus on creating the right narrative to engage employees, rather than relying on simplistic exhortations.

site_title: More choices for Manhattan homebuyers as resale supply jumps
summary: Manhattan homebuyers are experiencing more options in the resale market, with a 25% increase in previously owned condominiums and co-ops on the market as of June. This surge in inventory helps level the playing field for buyers and sellers, reducing bidding wars and price growth. Resale transactions decreased 9.4% in the second quarter, and the median price remained unchanged at $945,000. The increased inventory also led to a decrease in sales days on the market, from 83 to 88 days.

site_title: Micron posts Q3 loss on weak demand
summary: US chipmaker Micron Technology Inc reported a loss in its fiscal third quarter due to weak demand, despite buying out rivals. The company's shares fell after the loss and weak outlook.
