Demand isn't strong enough to account for industry-wide output, forcing prices of some chips below production costs. Micron faces stiff competition from South Korean companies SK Hynix and Samsung, which have more control over supply and research and development. Analysts expect Micron's profitability to improve in the second half of the year, but note that the company still needs to overcome its scale issues.

site_title: Productivity at Changi to get S$20m Wi-Fi boost
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and Changi Airport Group (CAG) are investing over S$20 million in a Smart Apron initiative, which will provide an airport-wide wireless communication network in the apron area. The network will cover all aircraft stands at Terminals 1 to 4, benefiting approximately 5,000 staff. Additionally, CAAS will invest S$15 million to encourage airlines to adopt self-service passenger processes, with grants available for airlines to offset costs. The initiatives aim to improve productivity and reduce reliance on manpower at Changi Airport.

site_title: HDB resale prices inch up 0.1% in Q2
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore increased 0.1% in Q2, undoing a 0.1% dip in Q1. Experts expect transactions to pick up as prices consolidate, with ERA Realty CEO Eugene Lim predicting minor price movements of plus/minus 0.3% each quarter. Consultants anticipate a slight price decline of around 0.5% for 2016, with a higher volume of resale flats sold due to lower asking prices. The Housing & Development Board (HDB) is also increasing BTO supply, launching 18,000 new flats in 2016.

site_title: Edmund Tie & Company relaunched following management buyout
summary: Edmund Tie & Company has relaunched following a management buyout, with chairman Edmund Tie and CEO Ong Choon Fah leading the firm. Shareholders bought out Cushman's 60% stake, allowing the company to operate under its original name. The firm will offer full real estate agency and advisory services in South-east Asia, with plans to expand globally. Operations will continue in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand, with 500 employees and 1,400 salespeople under associate agency division DTZ Property Network.

images.alt_text: MS ONG: A veteran with over 25 years of experience, she also heads the firm's research and consulting departments.
"We have shared a rich history with DTZ since the alliance was formed . . . over 16 years ago. However, it is now time for us to pursue new and exciting opportunities."- Edmund Tie

site_title: Private bank advice for post-Brexit world
summary: Global markets continue to navigate uncertainty following the Brexit decision, with investors in Asia seeking opportunities to rebalance their portfolios. Private banks such as Bank of Singapore and Lombard Odier advise investors to put cash to work as clarity emerges. Strategists point to potential opportunities in UK real estate, Chinese bonds, and US dollar-denominated assets, citing factors like attractive pricing, rate cuts, and low debt levels.

site_title: Bottoming seen in home prices, going by URA data
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to bottom out, according to property consultants, as the Urban Redevelopment Authority's second-quarter flash estimates show a 0.4% decline in overall private home prices. This is the smallest quarterly drop in 11 months. Non-landed home prices in Core Central Region rose 0.2%, while prices in the suburbs declined 0.7%. Analysts predict a slight drop in Q3 and a full-year decline of under 2%. Some consultants also suggest that Brexit could divert property buying interest to Singapore, but global economic uncertainty remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Most property consultants say that the Urban Redevelopment Authority's second-quarter flash estimates signal that a bottoming out in private home prices is fast approaching.

site_title: US firms selling unapproved 'stem cell treatments'
summary: Hundreds of US companies are selling unapproved stem cell treatments directly to patients, raising concerns about safety and scams in the industry. A report found at least 351 companies marketing unapproved procedures at 570 clinics nationwide. The treatments are sold without FDA approval, despite potential health risks. Researchers urge stricter regulations to protect patients and prevent scams.

site_title: Currency funds on worst streak in three years
summary: US currency-focused hedge funds experienced their longest losing streak in almost three years in June, with a 0.5% decline in the Parker Global Currency Manager Index. Despite the Brexit vote's initial impact, traders failed to capitalize on volatility, which surged to its highest level since 2011. The US dollar fell 2.1% against the euro in 2016, contrary to initial forecasts. Market analysts attribute the decline to uncertainty and unexpected events, warning that the remainder of the year may be challenging for currency managers.

site_title: Coach turns to Disney for help
summary: Coach Inc, a luxury leather goods brand, is seeking to revive its image with a series of collaborations, including a partnership with Disney, to make its products more appealing to consumers. The brand has seen declining sales due to heavy discounting and competition, but has reported a 22% gain in stock price this year. To address this, Coach is releasing limited-edition products, such as Disney-themed handbags, and focusing on its New York heritage to attract overseas buyers. However, the company's heavy reliance on handbags and handbag-related products remains a concern, with analysts predicting a sluggish growth in the category.

images.alt_text: NOVELTY APPEAL: Facing an industry-wide slump, Coach is stamping the Walt Disney Co character on its leather goods, part of a plan to enliven the brand with pop-culture icons and create more limited-edition products. The idea is to give shoppers another reason to buy a new handbag.

NOVELTY APPEAL: Facing an industry-wide slump, Coach is stamping the Walt Disney Co character on its leather goods, part of a plan to enliven the brand with pop-culture icons and create more limited-edition products. The idea is to give shoppers another reason to buy a new handbag.

site_title: The billionaire retail rebel (Amended)
summary: Uniqlo founder Tadashi Yanai is planning for global domination through his retail empire, Fast Retailing, which owns Uniqlo. With 846 stores in Japan, 449 in China, and 388 in the rest of Asia, Yanai aims to become the world's largest apparel retailer by 2020, with projected revenue of $65.6 billion. Despite struggling in Europe and the US, Yanai remains committed to expanding globally. A self-taught entrepreneur, Yanai attributes his success to his willingness to take risks and learn from failures, which he writes about in a book. He believes that his leadership model, which empowers young people and multiple leaders, is key to the company's future success.

site_title: Gold expected to rally as Brexit prompts Fed to hold rates
summary: Gold prices are expected to rally as the Brexit vote prompts the US Federal Reserve to hold interest rates, according to Ivan Szpakowski, a hedge fund manager. Szpakowski predicts gold will end the year even higher. The Brexit vote adds to the case for the Fed to pause on interest rates, which could lead to increased demand for gold.

site_title: Dock your iPad Pro here
summary: Logitech has released a premium aluminium stand, the Base, that complements the iPad Pro. The stand uses Apple's Smart Connector to charge the tablet while it rests on the stand, freeing up the Lightning port for an external drive. The stand has a single position design, anti-slip pad, and magnets to hold the tablet in place. It is priced at $149 and works in landscape mode, but lacks a pass-through feature for charging while typing.

site_title: Bonvests, Tai Tak bow out as Cordlife's substantial shareholders
summary: Singapore-listed Cordlife Group's substantial shareholders Bonvests Holdings and Tai Tak Estates Sdn Bhd are selling their 20% stake in the cord-blood banking firm to Chinese retail giant Nanjing Xinjiekou Department Store for S$86.6 million. This sale represents a 32% premium over Cordlife's closing price of S$1.265. The deal will see Nanjing Xinjiekou emerge as a major shareholder in Cordlife.

site_title: Are you comfortably miserable at work?
summary: In Singapore, a phenomenon known as "comfortable misery" has been observed, where long-term employees dread their jobs and feel trapped in a routine, viewing work as a necessary evil. They often feel a strong need to maintain the status quo and watch the clock, counting down to retirement. This feeling is not unique and affects many working professionals, highlighting a deeper issue with job satisfaction and work-life balance.

site_title: It's team Emerio's day
summary: Emerio takes the early lead in the seventh edition of The Business Times Corporate Golf League with a stableford score of 114 points in the first round. The team, led by captain Harish Nim, edged out Edge Golf and defending champions Team Boustead, who finished second and third respectively. Emerio's Harish Nim expressed happiness with the team's performance, and the winning team will retain their position in the top three, with the goal of staying in the top three for each game.

site_title: China Fishery files for bankruptcy in NY
summary: China Fishery Group, along with 15 affiliates, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in New York, seeking to avoid a forced sale of assets at fire-sale prices. Restructuring proceedings have also begun in Peru, the US, and the British Virgin Islands. The company aims to receive the benefits of US bankruptcy law, including an automatic stay preventing creditors from seizing assets. This move comes after China Fishery's inability to pay its debts led to the appointment of provisional liquidators in the British Virgin Islands.

site_title: Mexican wave
summary: A wave of Mexican restaurants is proliferating in Singapore, with at least six new establishments opening in the last year. While many of these restaurants do not have native Mexican chefs, Chef Luis Rodriguez notes that the country's remote location and high flight costs may be deterring potential chefs from visiting. Rodriguez, one of the few Mexican chefs in Singapore, attributes the lack of native chefs to the country's geographical distance and the high cost of flights, making it difficult for them to venture to the city-state.

site_title: Breastmilk baubles
summary: Creative mums are creating a cottage industry by making jewelry and accessories from breastmilk, dubbed "breastmilk baubles." This trend started around seven years ago on Etsy, with international sellers offering such products. Local craft-savvy mums have since picked up techniques on preserving breastmilk and creating unique items, such as lockets and charms, using precious metals. The trend is seen as a way for mothers to preserve the breastfeeding experience, despite some polarization around the practice.

site_title: Philippine mining set for bumpy ride under Duterte administration
summary: The Philippine mining industry faces uncertainty under President Rodrigo Duterte's administration. Duterte has warned of canceling mining projects causing environmental harm, while new mining minister Regina Lopez has described open-pit mining as "madness" due to its environmental impact. The industry, one of the world's largest in the 1970s, has struggled due to environmental rules and policy flip flops, and faces lower commodity prices. Foreign investors, such as Glencore and Oceanagold, have pulled out of projects due to regulatory uncertainty, and the industry is expected to undergo a nationwide crackdown on irresponsible miners.

site_title: Panamera premiere
summary: The new Porsche Panamera has made its Berlin world premiere, featuring all-wheel-drive and two new engines: a 550 hp V8 Panamera Turbo and a 440 hp V6 Panamera 4S. The car boasts a new styling, cabin, and platform, along with advanced features like three-chamber air suspension and electronic 4D Chassis Control. The base 4S starts at S$543,188, while the Turbo begins at S$711,688.

site_title: FootJoy launches new performance fitting system
summary: FootJoy introduces the FJ Performance Fitting System, utilizing BodiTrak technology and a proprietary algorithm to determine the best golf footwear for each golfer's unique swing. The system, available as a mobile unit, can guide a player through a fitting in as little as three swings, resulting in performance increases of up to 3 MPH of clubhead speed. The system identifies responder types, including mobile, dual, and structured shoes, and will be demonstrated at driving ranges across South-east Asia starting in July 2016.

site_title: Out of the woods
summary: Young entrepreneurs are reviving the carpentry trade in Singapore, with three local companies, Roger&Sons, Herman Furniture, and Triple Eyelid, showcasing their bespoke woodworking skills. Roger&Sons, founded by Morgan Yeo, produces high-end furniture pieces, while Herman Furniture, started by four friends, specializes in "live edge tables." Triple Eyelid, run by Jackie Tan, creates sustainable furniture from reclaimed materials. Despite the carpentry trade being considered a dying profession, these young innovators aim to revitalize it, inspiring a new generation to join the industry.

site_title: Swiber gets new JV partner for Mexico business
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has secured a new joint venture partner for its Mexican business. An independent investor with 70% stake will subscribe to new shares and convertible preferred shares, making Somex Holdings BV an associate company of Swiber. Swiber will retain 30% ownership and continue to lead day-to-day operations of offshore EPIC projects in Mexico and Latin America.

site_title: F&N Foods completes acquisition of 3 Warburg firms
summary: F&N Foods has completed the acquisition of Warburg Vending, Warburg Engineering, and Warburg Vending Services, making the three companies indirect wholly owned subsidiaries of Fraser and Neave.

site_title: Free movement in EU 'will not change'- Juncker
summary: European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker has reaffirmed that free movement within the EU will remain unchanged, despite UK Prime Minister David Cameron's suggestion to reform the rules. Juncker stated that free movement is a "basic freedom" of the EU and will not be altered. A Slovak Republic-led informal EU summit will take place on September 16 to discuss the EU's future, including migration and free movement. The meeting comes after the UK's June 23 referendum to leave the EU.

site_title: Engineering remains key to Singapore's future: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of engineering in the country's future, citing its role in upgrading infrastructure, developing solutions to resource scarcity, and supporting the economy. Despite having world-class capabilities, Singapore still lags behind in certain engineering fields, such as industrial and precision engineering. The government is actively promoting STEM education and attracting top talent, with initiatives including scholarships and partnerships with the private sector.

site_title: Place of peace
summary: Amanpuri resort in Phuket, Thailand, remains a luxury haven 28 years after its debut, renowned for its discreet elegance. Built by hotelier Adrian Zecha in the early 1980s, the resort initially catered to high-end travelers willing to pay $250 per night, a premium price at the time. Its secluded location overlooking a private beach has made it a sought-after destination among luxury travelers, with a reputation that continues to attract Aman enthusiasts worldwide.

site_title: Best World Int'l shares surge on licence grant from China
summary: Best World International's subsidiary, Best World (Zhejiang) Pharmaceutical, has been granted a direct selling licence by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. The licence allows the company to sell its skincare and wellness products directly in China, with the specifics of product categories and locations to be announced later. The company's shares surged 15.7% following the news, becoming one of the top 20 gainers on the Singapore Exchange. The licence is subject to the establishment of service centres in Hangzhou city within six months.

site_title: Newmont exiting Indonesia with US$1.3b sale of assets
summary: Newmont Mining Corp has agreed to sell its Indonesian copper and gold assets to a local consortium for US$1.3 billion. The assets, operated by PT Amman Mineral Internasional, include the Batu Hijau mine, with a gross valuation of over US$2.5 billion. The sale follows Indonesia's ban on raw ore shipments and tax on concentrates, aiming to boost revenue by turning the country into a manufacturer of higher-value products. The deal will reduce Newmont's dependence on copper, lower debt levels, and provide funding for projects, narrowing its geographic focus to the Americas, Africa, and Australia.

site_title: Australian election too close to call
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's gamble on an early election has left the outcome too close to call, with polls showing a dead heat between the coalition and Labor. Minor parties, such as the Greens and independent Senator Nick Xenophon, may emerge as power brokers, potentially blocking major reforms. Turnbull warned voters not to make a protest vote, emphasizing the importance of their single vote in determining the next government. The election's outcome may hinge on the balance of power in the Senate or the Lower House, with far-right parties and independent candidates also vying for influence.

site_title: ISR Capital raises stake in Madagascar firm to 60%
summary: ISR Capital has entered into an agreement to acquire a 40.1% stake in a Madagascar rare earth concession holder from Reo Magnetic for S$26.7 million. This deal, combined with an earlier agreement, will give ISR Capital a 60% stake in the company. The acquisition will be funded by issuing 400 million new shares to Reo Magnetic, representing 21.1% of ISR Capital's enlarged share capital. The deal aims to generate strong returns for shareholders and will be used for a pilot production of rare earth oxides and further development of the concession.

site_title: Automakers look set for solid US sales in June
summary: US automakers are expected to post solid sales in June, driven by demand for crossover SUVs and light trucks. General Motors reported a 1.6% decline in June sales to 255,210 vehicles, following a 13.4% drop in May. The decline is attributed to GM's shift in focus from business-to-business sales to retail sales. Other automakers are also expected to perform well, with the overall market revved up by the robust demand for crossover vehicles.

site_title: Superbugs, govt subsidies draw big pharma back to antibiotics
summary: Big pharma companies are re-entering the development of new antibiotics, driven by government incentives and growing concerns over antimicrobial resistance. Giants like Roche and Merck are stepping up efforts, while startups seek partners to market new products. A pledge by 80 pharmaceutical companies in January to combat antimicrobial resistance has led to a 36% increase in antibiotic research spending and a 6.5% expansion of research staff. Governments and charities are providing financial support, with the US government investing up to $170 million and a joint fund established between Britain and China.

site_title: Aston advantage
summary: The Aston Martin V8 Vantage S Coupe is the sportiest model in the brand's lineup, boasting a 4.7-litre V8 engine and seven-speed automated manual transmission. With major improvements in steering, transmission, and suspension, the Vantage S is faster and sharper than its non-S counterpart. It features a near-perfect 51:49 front/rear weight distribution, a limited slip differential, and a shorter aluminium structure. Priced at S$590,000, the Vantage S offers a perfect blend of effortless performance and quiet luxury.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The trust can finance the redevelopment using debt funding, with gearing rising to 38%. PACC Offshore Services Holdings Hold: Analysts estimate a short-term charter contract for POSH Arcadia, with a potential margin. UOL Group Add: Analysts downplay concerns over UOL's UK exposure, citing a small asset base and strong sales for its Singapore residential projects.

site_title: Private equity interest returns to O&G: EY
summary: Private equity firms are increasing investment in the global oil and gas sector, with 25% planning acquisitions by the end of 2016 and 43% by the first half of 2017, according to a survey by EY. The survey, which polled 100 PE firms active in the sector, found that $971.4 billion of PE capital remains to be deployed, indicating a significant influx of capital into the O&G sector.

site_title: Edinburgh has what it takes to be Europe's new financial capital
summary: Edinburgh, Scotland, is considered a potential successor to London as Europe's financial capital if the UK were to leave the EU. The city's reputation for financial prudence, solid architecture, and continuity of its financial institutions make it an attractive alternative. European cities such as Frankfurt and Paris are vying to become the new financial hub, with Frankfurt estimating 10-15,000 jobs could move there in the next five years. Edinburgh's unique combination of financial infrastructure and cultural mindset make it a viable contender, and some companies, such as HSBC, have a history of having Scottish executives.

site_title: Keppel T&T to recognise S$56m gain from partial sale of DC Reit manager
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) will recognize a S$56 million gain after selling a 50% stake in the manager of its data centre Reit to parent Keppel Corp for S$38 million. The sale, which occurred on July 1, is part of Keppel T&T's efforts to optimize its portfolio. Keppel T&T posted a S$91.5 million net profit for 2015.

site_title: US opens probe after Tesla Model S's fatal crash in autopilot mode
summary: The US government is investigating a fatal car accident involving a Tesla Model S in Autopilot mode, killing the driver. The incident is the first known fatality to involve a Model S operating on Autopilot. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is looking into the crash, which occurred in a collision with a truck. The investigation involves 25,000 cars equipped with the Autopilot system.

site_title: Lagarde should face trial in Tapie case: French prosecutor
summary: French prosecutor recommends IMF chief Christine Lagarde stand trial for negligence in handling of a 2008 state payout to tycoon Bernard Tapie, which saw Tapie receive 404 million euros. The trial, if upheld, will be in the Law Court of the Republic, and Lagarde faces a year in jail and a fine of 15,000 euros. Lagarde denies wrongdoing and claims she acted independently. The trial's ruling is expected on July 22.

site_title: Only the good stuff
summary: Three new cookbooks aim to make healthy eating easier with time-saving recipes. "The Pleasures of Eating Well" by Christina Ong features 147 recipes that cater to various dietary needs, focusing on whole foods and minimal processing. "At Home: From Pot to Pot" by Pauline Menezes is a guide to growing herbs for apartment dwellers, offering 30 recipes using fresh herbs. "Herbalicious" by Joanna Wong explores the use of traditional Chinese herbs in modern cuisine, featuring over 50 recipes that incorporate herbs for wellness and nutrition.

site_title: US: Stocks rise on solid data, car sales
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, driven by solid manufacturing data and strong auto sales, rebounding from recent losses following the UK's EU vote. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3%, the S&P 500 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.6%. The data, however, did not significantly impact the US economy, unlike Britain and Europe. Analysts expect a more muted impact from the US.

site_title: Taiwan mistakenly fires missile towards China, hitting trawler
summary: A Taiwanese warship mistakenly launched a supersonic missile towards China, hitting a fishing boat and killing one person in the Taiwan Strait. The incident occurred during a drill, with the missile flying 75km before hitting the trawler. An investigation is underway, with officials suggesting human error may be the cause. The incident highlights deteriorating ties between Taiwan and China, with Beijing deeply mistrustful of President Tsai Ing-wen's government.

site_title: UK may miss 2020 budget surplus target on Brexit
summary: British Finance Minister George Osborne warned that the government may scrap its 2020 budget surplus target due to the impact of Brexit, citing a significant negative shock to the economy. The UK's EU exit will exert a major negative impact, according to Osborne, who also hinted that the Bank of England could cut interest rates and re activate quantitative easing to boost the economy. Prime Minister David Cameron's resignation and the need for compromises in EU exit negotiations are also expected to affect the government's plans.

site_title: About time for a java
summary: Nespresso's Prodigio, a Bluetooth-enabled coffee machine, allows users to program brewing times via their smartphones. The machine can schedule descaling and monitor water levels and remaining capsules, but manual tasks such as removing spent capsules and topping up water remain. The app also tracks capsule purchases and allows for coffee selection, but users must still manually insert new capsules. The Prodigio is marketed as a convenient option for offices, but its automation may be unnecessary for individual users who prefer to make their own coffee.

site_title: Gove makes case for UK premiership after Johnson betrayal
summary: Justice Secretary Michael Gove announced his candidacy for the UK premiership, breaking with Home Secretary Theresa May and other candidates. Gove, who previously opposed Prime Minister David Cameron and joined the "Leave" camp in the EU referendum, criticized fellow Brexiteer Boris Johnson for his inability to build a team and portray himself as a conviction politician. Gove stated he wants a "renewed Britain" and is only running because he sees no other option, despite expressing reluctance for the role.

site_title: Temasek shows way for local firms to support social entrepreneurship
summary: Temasek International has launched a mentorship program for eight social enterprises under the Singapore International Foundation's Young Social Entrepreneurs (SIF YSE) program. The program connects these social enterprises with a 20-strong team of mentors to help them grow and make a positive impact. The social enterprises focus on various causes, including connecting rural sports talent to professional athletes, providing mental health support to patients with depression, and developing sustainable LED lamps for slum-dwellers. Temasek aims to support these initiatives and help them achieve their goals.

site_title: OCBC raises stake in Great Eastern
summary: OCBC Bank has purchased 611,800 shares of Great Eastern Holdings for S$12.6 million, increasing its stake from 87.6% to 87.73%. The purchase is a result of the bank's ownership of Great Eastern, a subsidiary. This move solidifies OCBC's control over the company.

site_title: Oil falls as oversupply concerns return to centre stage
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday as oversupply concerns resurfaced, with global benchmark Brent crude futures down 30 cents at $49.41 a barrel. Production from Nigeria and Canada revived, while OPEC production reached a record high in June. Despite a bullish week driven by the UK's Brexit vote, oil prices were on track for a weekly gain after a three-week losing streak.

site_title: German PMI growth hits 28-month high in June
summary: German factory activity reached a 28-month high in June, with the Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 54.5 from 52.1 in May. This is the highest reading since February 2014 and indicates growth. Rising demand from the US and China, accounting for about a fifth of the German economy, contributed to the increase. The strong reading signals that German manufacturers are set to increase production in the coming months.

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks opened lower after President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks rallied ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Ascendas Funds Management appoints Lim Hock San as independent director
summary: Ascendas Funds Management appointed Lim Hock San, 70, as an independent director, effective immediately. Lim, president and CEO of United Industrial Corporation and Singapore Land Limited, will serve on several committees, including the investment, operational risk management, and nominating committees. This appointment aims to enhance the Reit's governance and oversight.

site_title: India's US$13b pay rise seen lifting oil demand on new cars
summary: India's federal government has approved a $13 billion pay rise for 9.9 million employees and pensioners, boosting car and motorcycle purchases and increasing fuel use. The move is expected to lift auto sales and accelerate oil consumption, contributing to India's fast-growing oil demand. The country is forecast to surpass Japan as the world's third-largest oil user this year, with a projected oil consumption of 4.34 million barrels per day. The pay increase is seen as a boon for the automotive sector, which is expected to benefit from the increased demand.

images.alt_text: India's US$13 billion pay increase for federal employees will boost car and motorcycle purchases, increasing fuel use in a country with the world's fastest oil demand growth.

site_title: India to step up efforts to extend air travel boom to smaller cities
summary: India plans to develop 90 new airports in the next 12 months to cater to smaller cities, aiming to boost air travel growth. The government will provide funding and incentives to airlines to operate in these areas, including capping air fares at 2,500 rupees (US$37) per hour and offering free land and emergency services. The move aims to tap into latent demand in smaller cities, where airports are either too small or non-existent, and to accelerate growth in the country's aviation market, which has been driven by flights between larger cities.

site_title: CAAS, Changi Airport Group to invest over S$20m to boost productivity
summary: CAAS and Changi Airport Group are investing over S$20 million in two airport-wide initiatives to boost Changi Airport's productivity. The Smart Apron initiative will install an airport-wide wireless communication network, covering 190 hectares, and mobile devices for 3,500 staff, while also enabling track and trace technology. Additionally, CAAS will invest S$15 million in the Fast and Seamless Travel (FAST) Fund to encourage airlines' adoption of self-service passenger processes, benefiting 2,000 employees.

site_title: Benedict to tell all about troubled time as pope
summary: Retired Pope Benedict XVI is set to release a new book, "Final Conversations," in which he will discuss his troubled time as pope, including a "gay lobby" among senior Vatican clerics. The book, an extended interview with German journalist Peter Seewald, will confirm that the group was a clique of 4-5 men working together, not a lobby for gay believers. Benedict also admits to lacking decisiveness and feeling "incredulous" after his election. The book will provide insight into his leadership and the challenges he faced during his papacy, which was marked by scandals and internal conflicts.

site_title: Euro-Area PMI grows at fastest pace in 6 months
summary: Euro-area manufacturing grew at its fastest pace in 6 months, with a Purchasing Manufacturers' Index of 52.8, exceeding the initial estimate of 52.6. The expansion was driven by Germany and Austria, while Greece enjoyed a "welcome return to growth" after a contraction. The UK's exit from the EU is expected to have a short-term impact on the euro area, but the European Central Bank remains prepared to respond.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare unit sells 15% stake in ISEC Penang for RM300,000
summary: ISEC Healthcare's subsidiary, ISEC Penang, sold 15% stake to Dr. Adrian Tey Puat Kean for RM300,000, reducing ISEC Sdn Bhd's stake to 51%. Dr. Tey, a medical doctor, will pay a 10% deposit with the remaining balance paid in monthly installments. This transaction involves ISEC Penang, an indirect subsidiary of ISEC Healthcare, and does not involve any director, CEO, or controlling shareholder of the company.

site_title: US construction spending falls 0.8% in May
summary: US construction spending declined 0.8% in May, following a 2.0% drop in April, the largest since 2011. This marks the second consecutive month of decline. Economists had forecast a 0.6% increase, but the revised April drop and May outlays, which rose 2.8% from last year, indicate a potential slowdown in second-quarter growth estimates.

images.alt_text: US construction spending fell for a second straight month in May after the biggest drop in more than five years in April, which could prompt economists to lower their second-quarter growth estimates.

site_title: US manufacturing expands at fastest pace in more than a year
summary: US manufacturing expanded at the fastest pace in over a year in June, according to the Institute for Supply Management's index, which rose to 53.2 from 51.3 in May. This marks an encouraging sign for American manufacturers, who have been struggling since 2015. Improving consumer spending and strengthening indexes of bookings and production signal sustained factory gains. Economists expect modest growth, with the export orders index reaching its highest level since November 2014, a tentative sign of stabilizing global demand.

images.alt_text: Factory activity expanded in June at the fastest clip in more than a year, an encouraging sign that American manufacturers are gaining traction.

site_title: Keppel unit completes series of share consolidation
summary: Keppel Corporation Limited announced that its subsidiary, Keppel Capital Holdings, has completed the consolidation of shares in Keppel Reit Management Limited, Alpha Investment Partners Limited, and Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management. Additionally, Keppel Capital acquired 50% of shares in Keppel DC Reit's manager for S$38 million. The consolidation aims to strengthen Keppel's position in the real estate and infrastructure sectors.

site_title: London luxury-property values dropped in run-up to Brexit vote
summary: London luxury-property values dropped 1.4% in the three months leading up to the Brexit vote, with properties in prime central London down 8% from their peak in 2014. The decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum outcome, which weakened the pound and led to some overseas buyers re-entering the market. Sellers have taken a pragmatic approach to pricing, with some buyers seeking bargains due to conflicting signals. The impact of Brexit on the luxury-property market won't be clear until later in the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 7.8 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed 7.86 points lower, at 1,646.220, on Friday. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 1.13 billion lots traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 413 to 295.

site_title: Chiwayland appoints Thio Shen Yi as independent director
summary: Chiwayland International has appointed Thio Shen Yi as an independent non-executive director, effective July 1, 2016. Thio, a senior counsel and joint managing director of TSMP Law Corporation, will serve as chairman of the firm's nominating and remuneration committees. His appointment aims to enhance corporate governance to international standards. Executive director Li Bin has resigned to comply with good corporate governance practice, but will continue to manage the firm as president.

site_title: Singapore expands green incentives to encourage LNG bunkering
summary: Singapore has expanded its green incentives to encourage the use of liquefied natural gas (LNG) as a sustainable alternative fuel source in the maritime industry. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has extended the Green Ship Programme (GSP) incentives to ships using LNG, starting July 1. The move aims to reduce carbon-dioxide and sulphur-oxide emissions, with over 50% of qualifying ships exceeding the current Energy Efficiency Design Index. The expansion is part of the Maritime Singapore Green Initiative (MSGI), which also includes the Green Port Programme and Green Technology Programme.

site_title: Singapore shares brush off Brexit, STI gains 4% over the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 4% over the week following the Brexit vote, defying expert forecasts. Despite initial 64-point loss, the index recovered with a 117-point gain over four sessions. Analysts attribute this to central banks' resolve to maintain monetary policies, reinforcing the "bad news is good news" investing mantra. This unusual market behavior occurred as markets worldwide rallied after the Brexit event, with global stocks continuing their upward trend.

site_title: CEO and board changes at EpiCentre Holdings
summary: Epicentre Holdings CEO Fong Teck Loon has resigned, effective July 31, after selling his shares. Lim Tiong Hian, 41, a former executive director of Sino Construction Ltd, will replace Fong as acting CEO and executive chairman. Giang Sovann has been appointed chairman of the remuneration committee. The changes took effect on Sunday, following a mutual agreement between the board and Fong to shorten his notice period.

site_title: Around 20 banks, unfazed by Brexit, to invest £500m in Britain
summary: Around 20 banks, unaffected by Brexit, plan to invest £500m in Britain, boosting the country's financial services sector. The investment, up to £200m already committed, will help counter job cuts and firms moving overseas due to Brexit. The banks, a mix of UK, European, and non-EU businesses, have outlined their plans in their business plans, providing a significant injection of funds into the sector.

site_title: Takata president to take 30% pay cut over recalls
summary: Takata Corp President and CEO Shigehisa Takada will take a 30% monthly pay cut over the next 12 months due to the company's swelling recall costs. This move follows a 25% pay cut in the past 12 months and comes after the company's lowest approval rating among six directors at a shareholders' meeting. Takada signaled his intention to step down once the company finds a way to overcome its crisis, taking responsibility for containing recalls and restructuring the business. The company has formed a steering committee to develop a restructuring plan and hired Lazard Ltd. to pursue buyers.

site_title: Eurozone unemployment falls to near five-year low
summary: Eurozone unemployment fell to 10.1% in May, a near five-year low, according to Eurostat statistics. This decline came before the Brexit vote, which may negatively impact growth and job figures in the medium term. The eurozone's unemployment rate remains above the 1999-2007 average of 8.8%. Germany's jobless rate is 4.2%, while Greece and Spain have the highest rates at 24.1% and 19.8%, respectively. The European Central Bank's stimulus program has yet to show significant effect, and economists expect further challenges ahead.

site_title: Bloated Yahoo may face job cuts after sale of Internet assets
summary: Yahoo Inc, the struggling internet giant, may face significant job cuts after a sale of its internet assets. The company's bloated cost structure, with revenue per employee at less than $116,000, is a major concern. Analysts predict at least 3,000 job losses, with some suggesting that cutting 1,000 more jobs could bring revenue per employee in line with Verizon's AOL. A change in ownership, potentially from AT&T or Verizon, is imminent, with bids valued at $3.75 billion to $6 billion. Streamlining operations is expected to be a priority for any new owner.

site_title: Mothers, daughters, and the Noble Group rights issue
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trading firm, recently completed a rights issue, raising an additional half billion US dollars. The issue, which gave existing shareholders the opportunity to purchase new shares at a discounted price, was announced on June 3 and marked the end of a two-month process. The rights issue was fully underwritten by a consortium of banks, ensuring the company would receive the necessary funds. After the announcement, Noble shares plummeted, falling 22% from their pre-announcement price. The shares then started trading ex-rights on June 28, with a new reality taking hold: the number of issued shares would double, resulting in a decrease in the value of existing shares. To calculate the theoretical ex-rights price, investors can use a formula that takes into account the existing value of the firm, the number of new shares issued, and the discounted price of the new shares.

site_title: US organic dairy farm highlights authenticity with outreach strategy
summary: Organic Valley, the largest US cooperative of organic farmers, is launching an outreach strategy to increase transparency and authenticity in the supply chain. The cooperative, which has over 1,800 members, is introducing a new website and social media efforts to connect consumers with farmers. The website features stories about farmers, recipes, and local store locators, while farm visits and social media partnerships aim to build trust with consumers. The initiative is part of the growing demand for organic food, with sales rising 10.8% in 2015 and now accounting for nearly 5% of US food sales.

site_title: Gold extends decline as Fed rate chances rise after US data
summary: Gold prices extended their decline after the US economy showed signs of growth, raising bets that the Federal Reserve may increase interest rates this year. The metal fell 1% to $1,327.24 an ounce, snapping six weeks of gains. The Fed's policy-setting panel is set to meet on July 26-27, with investors seeing an 8% probability of a rate increase. Despite this, some analysts believe gold prices will moderate in the short term but remain supported by negative real rates in the US.

site_title: Turkey's failed coup takes toll on Malaysia Airports Holdings
summary: Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd (MAHB) shares fell 5% after Turkey's failed coup attempt, with analysts expecting a decline in tourist arrivals due to the country's volatile situation. The failed coup, which killed nearly 300 people and wounded 1,400, has led to travel alerts and a potential impact on airport security, with some governments advising citizens to reconsider travel plans. MAHB's Istanbul airport, Sabiha Gokcen, is a major contributor to the company's earnings, but domestic travelers account for two-thirds of total passengers, potentially providing some shelter from tourism fallout.

site_title: Box traffic set to dip in Singapore
summary: The opening of the Panama Canal's expanded route is expected to divert up to half of container shipping services from the Suez Canal to the Panama Canal, potentially leading to a dip in container throughput at Singapore port. Analysts project that around 4-9 services will switch, with some carriers like Maersk Line considering diverting one service. Despite this, the impact on Singapore port is expected to be "modest" and demand for Suez routings will continue, driven by shorter distances from South-east Asia to the US East Coast.

site_title: Chevron suspends Gorgon LNG production after gas leak
summary: Chevron suspended production at its Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) export facility in Australia due to a minor gas leak. The leak prompted a boost in Asian LNG prices to their highest level since February. Chevron plans to undertake minor repair work before resuming production in the coming week. The facility, a $54 billion joint venture, was briefly shut down in April due to technical problems. No injuries were reported, and Chevron remains on track to make its second LNG shipment in the coming days.

images.alt_text: Chevron on Friday suspended production at Australia's Gorgon liquefied natural gas (LNG) export facility after a leak but remained on track to make a second shipment in coming days, it said.

site_title: Canada to introduce national carbon price in 2016, minister says
summary: Canada's Environment Minister Catherine McKenna announced the country will introduce a national carbon price by the end of 2016. The federal government will publish an emissions reduction plan in the fall, which may include expanded emissions disclosure requirements for companies. McKenna emphasized the need for uniformity in a national price, while provinces work to reach a deal on a mandatory cross-Canada carbon price. She also favored increased emissions disclosure by the private sector, including standardizing, to foster innovation and reduce emissions.

site_title: US, China clash over market economy status
summary: The US has warned China that it hasn't met the requirements to be considered a market economy, potentially leading to a trade battle. China was admitted to the WTO in 2001, but the US claims China's state-controlled prices are being used to judge exports unfairly. This could result in higher tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminum imports. The dispute could escalate into a trade war at the end of 2016.

site_title: Truck ploughs into crowd celebrating Bastille Day, kills 84
summary: A truck driver identified as a 31-year-old Tunisian-born Frenchman plowed into crowds celebrating Bastille Day in Nice, France, killing at least 84 people and injuring scores more. The attack, described as a terrorist act, occurred on the Promenade des Anglais as a fireworks display ended. The driver, not on the French intelligence watch list, had a history of common crimes and was shot dead by officers. French President Francois Hollande called for military and police reservists to be deployed, extending the state of emergency. The attack was condemned by world leaders, including US President Barack Obama and Pope Francis.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reported a 0.4% decline in Singapore's overall private home price index in Q2 over Q1, a smaller drop than the 0.7% quarter-on-quarter decline in Q1. Singapore banks' exposure to foreign property loans remains low, at 2% of total housing lending. Meanwhile, DTZ (SEA) management bought out Cushman's stake and relaunched the firm as Edmund Tie & Company. Additionally, China Fishery Group and Pacific Andes Resources filed for US bankruptcy protection, and Bonvests sold 10% of its stake in Cordlife for S$43.31 million.

images.alt_text: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) latest flash estimates released on Friday showed that its overall private home price index fell 0.4 per cent in the second quarter of this year over the previous quarter, a smaller decline compared with the 0.7 per cent quarter-on-quarter drop in Q1 this year.

site_title: Cyber safety: Keeping kids safe online
summary: Cyber bullying is a growing concern in Asia-Pacific, with children increasingly exposed to online threats due to rapid internet penetration. Experts warn that parents and educators play a crucial role in protecting children against cyber bullying. A multi-pronged approach is needed, including monitoring internet use, open discussions, and limiting usage, particularly for younger children. Cyber security companies can also help by raising public awareness and providing educational tools. The RSA Conference Asia-Pacific & Japan is addressing this issue with a series of sessions and workshops, featuring experts and keynote speakers, including Bob Geldof, to discuss the future of information security and the effects of the digital age.

site_title: Campaign to force Russia out of Rio divides sport heads
summary: A North American-led campaign to ban Russia from the Rio Olympics has sparked international division, with European Olympic Committees president Pat Hickey criticizing the move as "shocked" and "concerned". The campaign, led by the US and Canada, aims to ban Russia due to allegations of government manipulation of doping samples. However, the report's findings are set to be released on Monday, and Hickey argues that the ban could compromise the integrity of the process. The IOC may consider a blanket ban if the report confirms allegations of state-supported corruption.

site_title: ECB to pave way for stimulus in Sept: analysts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to hold fire on monetary policy at its upcoming meeting, but analysts predict it will prepare the ground for more stimulus measures in September as the economic fallout from Brexit becomes clearer. The ECB has already cut its main refinancing rate to zero and launched quantitative easing, but eurozone inflation remains low. Analysts expect the ECB to at least pave the way for more policy support in September, possibly involving an interest rate cut and bigger asset purchases, to address the significant downside risks to the eurozone economy.

site_title: World powers urge 'stability' in Turkey
summary: World leaders, including US President Barack Obama, Russian President Vladimir Putin, and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg, have urged "stability" in Turkey after a military attempted coup against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, resulting in violence in Istanbul. The US, Russia, NATO, and the European Union have called for respect for democratic institutions and restraint, while the UN chief Ban Ki-moon condemned the attempt as "unacceptable." The EU has also backed Erdogan's government, and US military operations against ISIS in Syria and Iraq are unaffected.

site_title: Fighting climate change
summary: Singapore's Climate Action Plan aims to build a climate-resilient city-state by 2030. The plan provides a framework for individuals and businesses to reduce emissions and adopt sustainable practices. Experts from various industries, including BMW, REC, and Dassault Systèmes, emphasize the importance of changing behavior and adopting cost-saving and innovative solutions. Companies are exploring opportunities for carbon-efficient operations, investing in renewable energy, and implementing sustainable technologies. The government's initiatives, such as the Zero Energy Building @BCA Academy and the Zero Capital Partnership scheme, are also supporting the transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Immediate threat to S'pore partly offset in the next two years
summary: The Panama Canal expansion, initially touted as a game-changer for the global LNG trade, may not have a significant impact on Singapore's thriving LNG repair business due to a decline in LNG spot prices. The canal's relevance to the LNG game is challenged, particularly for shipping US LNG to East Asia, with the arbitrage opportunity eliminated due to low oil-linked LNG prices. The Panama Canal may still influence Singapore's position as a regional LNG hub, but its impact is expected to be limited in the next two years, partly offsetting the immediate threat to Singapore's LNG repair business.

site_title: Ezra Holdings Q3 loss balloons to US$243m
summary: Ezra Holdings reported a widened Q3 net loss of US$242.87 million, down from US$3.01 million a year ago, due to lower revenue and a one-time non-cash loss from the sale of its subsea unit. The company's nine-month net loss reached US$548.15 million, with a loss per share of 18.65 US cents. Revenue fell 10% to US$125.73 million, and the company's debt increased to US$558.9 million. Ezra has pledged its shares in two subsidiaries for a S$100 million bank loan to refinance fixed rate notes.

site_title: Alexa Chung Britain's Tory Burch?
summary: Alexa Chung, a 32-year-old English model and television host, is launching her own clothing brand in May 2017. The brand, which will bear her name, will offer tomboyish yet feminine clothing at a contemporary price. Chung's style is compared to that of Tory Burch, with similarities in her background, including not being formally trained as a designer and working in advertising and public relations. Chung plans to hire a team of 10 people, including designer Edwin Bodson, and will release four collections a year. The brand's success is uncertain, but Chung believes that "product" will be the key to its success.

site_title: Bowie's modern art collection to be sold at auction
summary: David Bowie's 400-item art collection, featuring pieces by modern masters and eclectic artists, will be sold at Sotheby's auction on November 10-11. The collection includes a 1984 Basquiat painting, "Air Power," estimated to fetch £2.5-£3.5 million. Bowie's collection showcases his "famously inquisitive mind," with a focus on outsider art, contemporary African art, and design pieces by Italian artist Ettore Sottsass. The collection will be displayed in London and on tour before the auction, providing a glimpse into Bowie's artistic tastes and interests.

site_title: SPH Q3 profit falls 46.4% on impairments in magazines
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 46.4% decline in Q3 net profit to S$52.7 million due to significant impairments in its magazine business. The company saw a 20.7% decline in 9-month net profit to S$237.2 million, with media revenue falling 7.1% and pretax profit from media declining 30.9%. Despite a 1.6% increase in property revenue, SPH sees a "difficult" operating environment ahead and will maintain a conservative stance on investment portfolio allocation.

site_title: SingPost's postal service a 'burning platform subject to disruption'
summary: SingPost's new chairman Simon Israel acknowledged the group's fractured relationship between the board and management, which led to former CEO Wolfgang Baier's resignation last year. Israel stated that the board believes a "different profile" of CEO is needed for the integration task ahead. Shareholders can expect the CEO vacancy to be filled by the end of the year. Israel warned that SingPost's postal service is a "burning platform" vulnerable to disruption, and the group's blended return on equity is likely to drop over time due to declining legacy postal business.

site_title: FCT declares 3.04 cents for Q3 DPU
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) declared a distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.04 Singapore cents for the third quarter, 0.1% higher than the previous year, despite a decline in revenue amid headwinds in the retail sector. Net property income (NPI) fell 5.1% to S$31.2 million, and gross revenue declined 4.4% to S$45 million. The trust attributed the decline to lower contributions from Northpoint and Changi City Point due to ongoing asset enhancement initiatives.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds key rate at record low, cuts growth forecast
summary: The Bank of Korea held its benchmark interest rate at a record low 1.25% and cut its growth forecast to 2.7% amid uncertainty in the economic outlook. The central bank also lowered its inflation forecast to 1.1%. Governor Lee Ju Yeol attributed the decision to risks from the UK exiting the EU and the impact of an anti-corruption law on consumption. Expectations for further rate cuts remain high, with some analysts predicting another cut in September.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday after Wall Street rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.22% to 2,881.79 points on Monday, following a Wall Street rally. US stocks rebounded after the June jobs report, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.38% and the S&P 500 reaching a fresh record high. The rally was driven by gains in materials and industrials.

site_title: Chiwayland making foray into US property market
summary: Chiwayland International, a China and Australia-focused company, is making its first entry into the US property market with a US$69 million project in Los Angeles. The joint venture with Urban Commons plans to build 60 residential units and a 250-suite hotel, with completion targeted for 2019. The company aims to receive approval within 12 months and expects to contribute at least 50% of revenue from overseas projects by 2021. Chiwayland sees the US market as mature and stable, with a strong legal framework and transparency.

site_title: Nintendo soars on Pokemon success
summary: Nintendo's new smartphone game, Pokémon GO, debuted at the top of gaming charts, soaring nearly 9% to 16,270 yen. The game's success marked Nintendo's move into mobile gaming, following the release of its first-ever mobile game, Miitomo, in March. Despite Nintendo's rise, investors remained cautious ahead of US jobs data and the debut of messaging app Line's stock market listing next week.

site_title: Swiber faces trade claims of US$4.76 m
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore marine player, received outstanding letters of demand for US$4.76 million from trade creditors. The group, which is seeking legal advice, is confident it has sufficient resources to satisfy all claims. Swiber is also evaluating its options regarding a delayed US$200 million investment in its subsidiary, after the subscriber, AMTC Limited, requested a postponement. The parent group has turned down the request and sent a letter of demand to the subscriber.

site_title: Managers struggle as usual tools lose value
summary: Bank of America strategists report that stock selection tools, typically based on buybacks, takeovers, and activist interest, failed to work in the first half of 2016, leading to some of the worst relative returns in mutual fund history. This is attributed to an aging bull market, weakening the potency of these tools.

images.alt_text: GAME PLAN: According to the strategists, the best thing you could've done in 2016 was concentrate on just a few stocks and have them go up.

site_title: Recent natural disasters had large impact on China's economy: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that recent natural disasters, including super typhoon Nepartak and severe flooding, have had a significant impact on the country's economy. The disasters killed over 100 people and damaged infrastructure, livestock, and agriculture. Despite this, Li expressed confidence that the economy is "basically stable" and will maintain growth within a reasonable range. However, he acknowledged that downward pressure remains, indicating that the country is facing economic challenges.

site_title: Trade to contribute to UK growth despite May export slump
summary: Trade data shows the UK's goods and services deficit widened to £2.3 billion in May, a 4.4% decline in exports, and 3.5% decline in imports. Despite the sharp decline, the trade deficit is expected to narrow in the second quarter, with a £7.8 billion gap needed to meet the record low. The pound's depreciation since the Brexit vote has boosted demand for British exports, potentially offsetting the negative impact of the EU market weakening.

site_title: Water industry to get S$200m boost: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's water industry is set to receive a S$200 million boost from the National Research Foundation, in addition to S$400 million invested in R&D since 2006. The funds will support research and development in membrane, desalination, and sensor technologies. The government aims to create 15,000 water-sector jobs and S$2.85 billion in annual value-add by 2020, and Singapore will focus on commercializing and exporting its water technologies globally. The move aims to seize growth opportunities in the global water sector and position Singapore as a "living lab" for urban solutions.

site_title: US: Global rally lifts US stocks to new records
summary: US stocks reached new records in opening trade Tuesday, driven by a global rally following Alcoa's better-than-expected earnings. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6% and 0.6%, respectively, with the Dow trading above its all-time closing high. Alcoa climbed 5.9% after reporting adjusted earnings of 15 cents per share. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.7%. The rally followed a global market lift, with investors seemingly shrugging off concerns over US trade policies.

site_title: Cameron names top diplomat as new European Commissioner
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron has nominated Julian King, the country's ambassador to France, as the new European Commissioner. King will replace Jonathan Hill, who resigned after the Brexit vote. King has prior experience at the European Commission, having worked as chief of staff to Trade Commissioner Peter Mandelson and Catherine Ashton, both British commissioners. His nomination requires approval from the European Parliament and EU member states.

site_title: Dior names Chiuri from Valentino as artistic director
summary: French fashion brand Christian Dior has appointed Maria Grazia Chiuri, the first woman to hold the position in its 70-year history, as artistic director. Chiuri, who previously worked with Valentino, will present her first ready-to-wear collection on September 30 and oversee haute couture and accessory collections. She succeeds Raf Simons, who left the position in October. Chiuri's appointment aims to revitalize Dior's stalled sales growth and follows her successful partnership with Valentino's Pierpaolo Piccioli.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day lower, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 6.17 points to 1,644.54. Trading volume reached 1.22 billion lots valued at RM1.44 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 387 to 305.

site_title: Citibank to close Venezuela government accounts: Maduro
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro announced that Citibank NA plans to close the country's foreign currency accounts within a month, denouncing it as a "financial blockade." The move, which will affect the Central Bank and the Bank of Venezuela, relies on strict currency controls in place since 2003. Maduro vowed that the government will not be stopped by the measure, which comes amid the country's economic crisis. The decision follows a series of foreign companies pulling out or reducing operations in the Opec nation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore dollar has reached a record high, driven by haven buying amid global market turmoil, putting pressure on the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to ease monetary policies. DBS completed a one billion yuan offshore bond deal for Chongqing Grain, while Swiber Holdings faces a possible delay in its US$710 million West Africa project due to the oil and gas sector's weakness. Meanwhile, United Global debuted above its IPO price on Catalist, and a British property panic has raised concerns for banks and insurers.

site_title: No emergency for Italy's banking system as a whole: Bank of Italy
summary: Bank of Italy Governor Ignazio Visco stated that Italy's banking system is not in an emergency due to the 360 billion euros in bad loans held by banks. A significant portion of the soured credit is held by sound financially condition banks, making it "wrong to speak of the problem as an emergency." Visco emphasized the need for a public "backstop" to support banks and acknowledged the system is "full of risks" for financial stability.

site_title: Datapulse Technology to sell One Global Inc for S$6.03 million
summary: Datapulse Technology's wholly-owned subsidiary, Alchymie Investment, has agreed to sell its shares in One Global Inc (OGI) for S$6.031 million. OGI, a Taiwanese investment holding company, will retain its seven commercial units in Taipei. Datapulse Technology plans to use the net proceeds of approximately S$5.97 million for general working capital. The sale is part of the company's efforts to optimize its assets and liquidity.

site_title: China: Stocks fall as weak yuan adds to growth worries
summary: China's stocks fell 0.6% to 3,192.28 points, their largest intraday drop since June 24, amid Brexit-driven uncertainty and a weak yuan. The Shanghai Composite Index slid 1.0% to 2,988.09. Listed Chinese firms are in their worst financial shape in a decade, with stocks in major sectors falling. Despite expected stimulus, investors remain wary, and the yuan's decline heightens concerns of capital outflows.

site_title: Chairman of Ascendas India Trust manager retires
summary: Chairman Philip Yeo Liat Kok and deputy chairman David Lim Tik En of Ascendas India Trust's manager, Ascendas Property Fund Trustee (APFT), are retiring due to adopted regulations. Both have served nine years on the board, exceeding the nine-year continuous service limit for independence. Chiang Chie Foo and Manohar Khiatani will take over as new chairman and deputy chairman, respectively. Jonathan Yap Neng Tong will join as a non-executive director, effective July 8. The trust rose 0.5 cents to 98.5 cents on the same day.

site_title: China could cut interest rates if economic data disappoints: govt researchers
summary: China's government researchers warn that an interest rate cut may be necessary if the country's second-quarter economic data disappoints. However, they predict the reserve requirement ratio for banks will remain stable due to sufficient liquidity. The researchers also forecast the yuan may stabilize and appreciate after its recent depreciation. China is set to release June and second-quarter GDP data next week, which may indicate slower economic growth.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse to push Frankfurt clearing in LSE pitch
summary: Deutsche Boerse AG's CEO Carsten Kengeter plans to pitch a takeover of London Stock Exchange Group Plc as Frankfurt's only chance to win a key euro-denominated business amid a post-Brexit tussle. The deal could protect the viability of Frankfurt's existing clearing business and attract other major currencies. German officials have objected to the prospect of Deutsche Boerse moving its headquarters to London, but management is exploring compromises, such as establishing a dual holding company or relocating the headquarters outside the UK. LSE shareholders have already approved the merger, and investors have until July 12 to tender their shares.

site_title: Russia issues stern warning over US missiles in South Korea
summary: Russia warned the US that deploying an advanced missile defense system in South Korea would have "irreparable consequences" for global strategic stability, echoing China's concerns over regional security. The US and South Korea announced the deployment to counter potential attacks from North Korea, which Russia said would "most negatively affect global strategic stability."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down by break
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index down 1.05% due to a plunge in oil prices. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. Investors await US jobs data release later in the day.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat amid election uncertainty
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Friday as investors awaited the outcome of the national election, which was held last week. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 2.6 points, or 0.05%, to close at 5,230.5. Despite Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's coalition government expected to win 76 seats, the close result may leave him with a hostile upper house Senate.

site_title: Bitter battle for China's top homebuilder tests Beijing's patience
summary: A boardroom battle at China's leading property developer China Vanke Co Ltd has entered its seventh month, exposing tensions between state control and market forces. Financial conglomerate Baoneng has amassed a 24% stake in Vanke, prompting speculation of a hostile bid, and has sought to oust the company's board. Wang Shi, Vanke's founder, has called Baoneng "barbarians" with no credibility, indicating Beijing's growing frustration with the situation. The battle has highlighted the struggle for control in China's property market, with Beijing now appearing to have had enough.

site_title: German exports post steepest monthly decline in 9 months
summary: German exports fell 1.8% in May, the steepest monthly decline in nine months, and imports rose less than expected. The decline in exports, combined with a widening trade surplus with the euro zone, suggests weak global demand is curbing growth in Europe's largest economy. Industrial output and orders also fell, and economists predict a sharp slowdown in the second quarter, with some forecasting a near-halt in economic growth.

site_title: Australia cuts 2016, 2017 iron ore forecasts on supply glut
summary: Australia has cut its iron ore price forecasts for 2016 and 2017 due to an industry supply glut and weak demand. The Department of Industry, Innovation and Science reduced its 2016 forecast to US$44.20 a tonne and 2017 forecast to US$44, citing market fundamentals as unchanged despite price movements. This change affects the national budget deficit forecast for 2016-17, potentially increasing it by A$1.5 billion.

site_title: St James's Place moves to bid pricing on UK property fund
summary: St James's Place has introduced bid pricing on its £2.7 billion UK property fund, following a trend of British property funds cutting valuations or suspending trading. This move is in response to a surge in retail investors redeeming high-yielding but risky property investments after the UK's Brexit vote. Bid pricing gives investors a less favorable price for redeeming their money. The change aims to stabilize the fund and manage investor demand amid market volatility.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall on weak yuan, Brexit fallout fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.7% on Friday due to fears of a weakening yuan and concerns over Britain's Brexit decision affecting China's export market. The Hang Seng Index dropped 1.1% for the week, with major losses from footwear retailer Belle and coal miner China Shenhua. The yuan hit 5-1/2 year lows against the dollar, fuelling worries of capital outflows from China.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker for the day but STI unchanged for the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed unchanged for the week despite a 15.13-point drop on Friday due to a 5% plunge in oil prices. Oil concerns about a glut of petrol persisted, while the STI had held up well after the Brexit vote. Singtel stood out for its resilience, unchanged for the week, while banks were less fortunate. The week's trading volume was the lowest of the four days, with 1.5 billion units worth S$887 million traded.

site_title: Beijing will not 'step back' in South China Sea: media
summary: Beijing has stated it will not take a step back in the South China Sea, despite US naval patrols near Chinese artificial islands ahead of an international tribunal ruling. The Permanent Court of Arbitration is set to release its decision Tuesday in a case brought by the Philippines, challenging China's position. Beijing has accused the US and Philippines of provoking tensions and has vowed to defend its claims, warning of military action if provoked. The ruling is likely to result in increased threats to China, prompting the country to prepare for all eventualities.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares slump on dollar strength; end week lower
summary: The South Korean won plummeted 0.6% against the dollar to 1,161.8, marking its biggest weekly loss in six weeks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed down 0.6% at 1,963.10 points, while shares declined 1.2% this week. Foreign investors bought 41.3 billion won worth of KOSPI shares near the end of the session, attempting to stem losses. The slump is attributed to broad dollar strength.

site_title: Update: Five officers killed, six wounded in Dallas shooting protest
summary: Five Dallas police officers were fatally shot and six wounded by snipers during a protest against police brutality, following the fatal shootings of black men Philando Castile and Alton Sterling. The incident occurred amidst nationwide demonstrations and sparked outrage over racial disparities in the US criminal justice system. US President Barack Obama described the killings as tragedies, and Governor Greg Abbott offered condolences to the affected law enforcement community.

site_title: India's steel import curbs raise prices hit consumption
summary: India's steel consumption dropped 4.3% to 6.8 million metric tons in June, the first decline in at least 15 months, due to curbs on imports that raised prices. Steel imports fell 33% to 597,000 tons, and production grew 2.4% to 8.2 million tons. Analysts attribute the drop to seasonal factors and supply outpacing demand, with production growing 3.8% over the three-month period. The government aims to boost steel use to 210 million tons by 2025-26, driven by a building boom and infrastructure investments.

site_title: China auto sales growth accelerates on rising SUV demand
summary: China's passenger-vehicle sales grew 9.5% to 10.8 million units in the first half, driven by rising demand for SUVs and new-energy vehicles. SUVs accounted for 35% of total sales, with local manufacturers offering cheaper models to woo buyers. Electric vehicle sales surged 126% to 86,374 units, with the government aiming for 3 million units per year by 2025. Global carmakers saw gains, with General Motors up 5.3% and Nissan up 3.8%. The growth trend may continue due to the increasing number of affluent Chinese buyers opting for SUVs.

site_title: DBS completes one billion yuan offshore bond deal for Chongqing Grain
summary: DBS Bank completed a one billion yuan (S$202 million) offshore bond deal for Chongqing Grain Group, a Chinese agri-commodities firm. This was the first time a Chongqing corporate issued offshore renminbi bonds in Singapore, allowing full repatriation of funds. The three-year bond is priced at 4.02% and reached an order book of over nine billion yuan from 100 investors. The deal marked Chongqing Grain's first attempt at raising money from international bond markets.

site_title: China's yuan eases, unexpected FX reserve rise fails to cheer market
summary: China's yuan slipped 0.07% against the US dollar on Friday, despite a surprise $20 billion increase in June foreign exchange reserves. The reserves rose to $3.21 trillion, the biggest in 14 months. Traders believe the data indicates the central bank is scaling back interventions, but the weakening yuan could trigger more capital outflows in the coming months. The yuan is expected to weaken 0.5% for the week if it closes at Friday's midday level.

site_title: Super typhoon Nepartak hits Taiwan, disrupts power supplies, transport
summary: Super typhoon Nepartak hit eastern Taiwan, causing widespread disruptions. Over 15,400 people were evacuated, and 187,830 households lost power. The storm brought strong winds and torrential rains, forcing the cancellation of over 500 flights. One death and 66 injuries were reported, with many homes suffering roof damage. The typhoon is rated as a category 5, but is expected to weaken by the time it hits China, where evacuations and precautions are in place to minimize casualties.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower, Nintendo soars on Pokemon
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower for the fourth straight day, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.11% to 15,106.98, and the Topix index shedding 1.32% to 1,209.88. However, Nintendo surged 11.9% after its Pokémon game debuted at the top of gaming charts, boosting investor sentiment. The company's stock price rose to its highest level in over two years.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks edge back down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell back from a one-per-cent gain the previous day, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.41% to 20,622.83. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, 0.55% and 0.10% respectively. Investors await the US jobs report, which could influence market sentiment.

site_title: China floods may boost prices, imports to world's biggest pork market
summary: China's severe floods in southern provinces may boost pork prices, currently around US$2.69 per kg, potentially reaching US$3.29 by the third quarter. Thousands of animals have died, and transportation to slaughterhouses was disrupted, affecting China's 37 million sows and 380 million pigs. High prices may persist due to delayed herd restocking, benefiting European and North American exporters, who are expected to import 2 million tonnes of pork this year, up from 1.55 million last year.

site_title: China should slow wage growth to stay competitive: human resources minister
summary: China's human resources minister, Xin Changxing, recommends slowing wage growth to maintain competitiveness. Several provinces have already slowed or halted minimum wage increases amid rising expenses and weakening demand. Lower wage growth could help Chinese companies compete with overseas low-cost centers. Despite rising labor costs, China maintained its global export market share last year. The government is also exploring ways to lower social benefit costs on companies, which could further aid competitiveness.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets slipped at the opening on July 8, 2016, amid Brexit uncertainty. The FTSE 100 index dropped 0.2% to 6,522.33 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also fell 0.3% each. The upcoming US jobs data release is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans, following a low reading in May. European stocks rose Thursday after dovish ECB meeting minutes and disappointing German economic data, but were weighed down by the country's shrinking trade surplus.

site_title: Hot stock: United Global debuts above IPO price in light trade
summary: United Global, a Singapore-based lubricant manufacturer, made its debut on Catalist with an opening price of S$0.280, trading higher than its IPO price of S$0.25. The company raised S$9.20 million in net proceeds, which will be used for business expansion and working capital. The shares traded between S$0.260 and S$0.285, with over 16.4 million shares changing hands.

images.alt_text: UNITED Global, a Singapore-based independent lubricant manufacturer and trader, made its debut on Catalist on Friday, trading higher than its initial public offering (IPO) price.

site_title: Vietnam's 2016 economy seen slowing to 6.2-6.3%
summary: Vietnam's economy is expected to slow to 6.2-6.3% in 2016, down from 6.68% in 2015, due to a slowdown in export and industrial production growth. Exports are forecast to rise 7% this year, below the government's target, while inflation is projected to reach 5.0-5.5%. The government aims to keep annual inflation at 5% and boost exports by 10% to ensure economic growth of 6.7%.

site_title: Asian markets sink again, US jobs data in focus
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, ending a volatile week dominated by the UK's EU exit fallout.
