Investors now focus on US jobs data, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans. Tokyo fell 0.4%, Hong Kong dropped 0.5%, and Shanghai eased 0.8%. European markets gained, with the FTSE 100 rallying after minutes from the European Central Bank hinted at potential stimulus. The US dollar remained subdued against the yen, while oil prices bounced back slightly.

site_title: British property panic a red flag for banks, insurers
summary: A run on British property funds has raised concerns about the commercial real estate sector's vulnerability, primarily funded by domestic banks and building societies. UK banks had £90 billion in credit extended to domestic commercial real estate in 2015, while German and international banks had £55 billion, and insurers had £25.9 billion. This exposure has drawn attention to the sector's potential risks, particularly with the UK's exit from the EU.

site_title: Volkswagen to pay US$86m in penalties to California over emissions
summary: Volkswagen AG will pay US$86 million in civil penalties to California over its emissions scandal, on top of a US$14.7 billion settlement with US officials. The penalties resolve claims under California's unfair competition law and federal law. The US$76 million will be used to cover investigation and litigation costs, while US$10 million will fund grants for government agencies and universities to study emissions technology. The settlement follows Volkswagen's admission of using secret software to cheat exhaust emissions tests on diesel engines.

site_title: Housing boom endures weak oil in Europe's most mortgaged country
summary: Norway's housing market continues to boom, with average prices increasing 7.3% over the past year, and 13.4% in Oslo. Despite low oil prices and European uncertainty, the market is expected to rise 7-8% in 2016. The economy's reliance on oil prices and low interest rates contribute to the growth, with nearly 85% of Norwegians owning their homes. The country's sovereign wealth fund and generous tax reliefs also support the labor market and property market.

images.alt_text: Norway's property boom doesn't look like ending any time soon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 4.300 points to 1655.600. Volume was 60.9 million lots worth RM23.99 million, with 64 gainers outnumbering 46 losers.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares flat as investors step back
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares remained flat on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 1.18 points to 5,229.1, a 0.2% rise. Investors awaited the outcome of Australia's election, while New Zealand traders took a breather after a nine-session rally. Financial and mining sectors led the gains in Australia, with shares in South32, BHP Billiton, and Rio Tinto rising. New Zealand's benchmark index was flat, with Heartland Bank and Spark leading gains, while Westpac and ANZ fell.

site_title: China created 7.17m new urban jobs in H1 2016: human resources ministry
summary: China created 7.17 million new urban jobs in the first half of 2016, exceeding the target of 10 million set by Premier Li Keqiang. The urban unemployment rate ended June at 4.05%, marginally up from the first quarter. This achievement meets China's goal of maintaining an urban unemployment rate below 4.5% in 2016.

site_title: FBI chief says his staff would face discipline for handling emails the way Clinton did
summary: FBI Director James Comey testified before US lawmakers that his employees who mishandle classified material like Hillary Clinton could face discipline, including dismissal or loss of security clearance. Comey stated that Clinton's handling of classified information was "extremely careless" but did not recommend criminal charges, saying there was no evidence to establish a violation of a criminal statute. The State Department will conduct an internal review of Clinton's email handling, and Republican senators have asked for the suspension of her security privileges.

site_title: Oil prices rise in Asia on bargain-buying after plunge
summary: Oil prices in Asia rebounded on Friday, rising 1.11% and 1.29% for West Texas Intermediate and Brent, respectively, after a 4.8% and 4.9% drop on Thursday. The US benchmark rose 50 cents to $45.64, while Brent gained 60 cents to $47.00, amid concerns about oversupply and the impact of Britain's Brexit vote. Traders sought bargains after Thursday's substantial drop, but analysts noted that oversupply concerns will persist, particularly after the summer driving season.

site_title: US urges respect for South China Sea ruling
summary: The US has urged respect for an international arbitration court's ruling on territorial disputes in the South China Sea, set to be released next week. The Permanent Court of Arbitration is hearing a case between the Philippines and China, with the US supporting the Philippines' claims. China claims almost the entire sea, while the US has urged diplomacy over force, boosting its military presence in the region. Beijing has rejected the US warnings, with Chinese media stating it is ready for a "military confrontation."

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel O&M, Europtronic, SPH Reit, Lum Chang, Ellipsiz, Swiber, Triyards
summary: Singapore-listed companies made announcements after Thursday's market close that could affect trading on Friday. Keppel O&M secured four contracts worth S$120 million, while Europtronic Group sold a 89.05% stake in Europtronic Suzhou for S$36 million. SPH Reit reported a 0.7% rise in distribution per unit to 1.36 cents for the third quarter, driven by higher net property income. Meanwhile, Lum Chang Holdings launched a takeover offer for Ellipsiz, and Swiber Holdings' US$710 million West Africa project might be delayed due to weakness in the oil and gas sector.

site_title: Singapore shares open 2.61 points lower on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.61 points or 0.09% to 2,859.56 at 9:02am on Friday, as UOB and DBS Bank gained while Keppel Corp, Boustead Holdings, and CapitaLand declined. 91.5 million shares worth S$108 million changed hands, with losers beating gainers 79 to 56.

site_title: Swiber flags possible delay in US$710m West Africa project
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine construction services provider, announced that its US$710 million project in West Africa may be delayed due to weakness in the oil and gas sector. The project, which was won in 2014, is expected to be completed later than initially expected, according to the company. Swiber has not recognized any revenue related to the project, and the delay is attributed to the client's reduced expectations.

site_title: South Korea, US formally decide to deploy THAAD missile defence
summary: South Korea and the US have formally decided to deploy the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) missile defense system to counter North Korea's missile threat. The system will be deployed solely to counter the North's threat, despite China's objections due to its radar capabilities. A joint working group is preparing to determine the best location for deployment. The move aims to provide a defense system for South Korea against North Korea's missile threats.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks ease as US dollar strengthens
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.4% to 1,159.2 against the US dollar, easing investor concerns, as the US dollar strengthened due to positive US jobs report expectations and lower oil prices. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 0.7% to 1,959.99 points, with offshore investors selling Kospi shares worth 61.6 billion Korean won. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics rose 1%, while Posco lost 2.2%. Despite a strong US jobs report, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates in September, limiting the won's impact.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rebound on bargain-buying
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded 0.33% at the start of trading on July 8, 2016, as investors bought up bargains after a three-day drop, ignoring a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 50.60 points to 15,326.84, while the Topix index climbed 2.88 points to 1,228.97. The rebound follows a sharp decline in the previous three days, with investors focusing on bargain-buying opportunities.

site_title: Yen rises to top this week on haven demand as US payrolls loom
summary: The yen has risen 1.6% against the US dollar this week due to haven demand, fueled by Brexit fallout and concerns about global growth. Markets are bracing for a US jobs report, which could impact interest rate decisions and risk-off sentiment. A strong payrolls number may strengthen yen strength, while a weak report could intensify risk-off sentiment. The yen reached a 2-year high of 99.02 per US dollar on June 24, and is now at 100.96 as of July 8.

site_title: US missiles in South Korea would 'seriously damage' regional security: China
summary: China strongly opposes the deployment of a US missile defense system in South Korea, calling it "seriously damaging" to regional security. The THAAD system, announced by the US and South Korea, would not aid the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula and would "seriously damage the strategic security interests of countries in the region, including China." China urges the US and South Korea to stop the deployment process, citing concerns over a build-up of US power on its doorstep.

site_title: Singapore dollar near record high puts heat on MAS to ease again
summary: The Singapore dollar has reached a record high amid global market turmoil, with a trade-weighted measure of its strength hitting unprecedented levels. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is under pressure to ease monetary policy again, with analysts predicting a possible move in October. The country's economy is sputtering, with a slowdown in GDP growth and declining consumer prices. Despite a strong credit rating and current-account surplus, the MAS faces a strong downside risk to export and inflation forecasts.

site_title: 24 injured in Taiwan train blast
summary: At least 24 people were injured in an explosion on a train in Taiwan's capital, Taipei, on Thursday. The blast, described as "malicious" by Premier Lin Chuan, occurred when a man allegedly carried a black rectangle-shaped object onto the train, which then exploded, causing a fire and plunging the carriage into darkness. The incident is under investigation, with police reviewing surveillance footage to identify the suspect, who had not been known to have made any threats prior to the incident.

site_title: Uber raises US$1.15b leveraged loan for global expansion and research
summary: Uber Technologies Inc has secured a US$1.15 billion leveraged loan to support global expansion, operations, and research and development. The loan, arranged by four banks, comes after a US$3.5 billion funding raise from Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund in June. The 5% yield on the loan is lower than expected, allowing Uber to keep venture capital backers happy without further diluting their equity. The move demonstrates Uber's growing financial stability as it expands globally.

site_title: At least 35 killed in attack on Shi'ite mausoleum north of Baghdad
summary: At least 35 people were killed and 60 others wounded in a triple suicide attack on a Shi'ite mausoleum near Baghdad, Iraq. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, which reignited fears of sectarian strife between Shi'ites and Sunnis. The attack occurred during the Eid al-Fitr festival, and a gunman was gunned down by the mausoleum's guard before he could detonate his explosive belt. This incident follows recent bombings in Iraq, highlighting the ongoing threat posed by the Islamic State despite losing ground to government forces and Iranian-backed militias.

site_title: Troubled Brazil targets tighter deficit in 2017
summary: Brazil aims to reduce its budget deficit to $41.3 billion in 2017 from $50.6 billion this year through spending cuts and generating new revenues by selling state assets and concessions. Finance Minister Henrique Meireilles announced the plan, part of a broader effort to stabilize public finances under Acting President Michel Temer. The goal is to address Brazil's deepest recession in decades, which saw an 3.8% economy shrink last year. The official 2017 budget will be unveiled in late August.

site_title: Kiwi, Aussie are best performers as hunt for yield picks up pace
summary: The New Zealand and Australian currencies were the top performers among 16 major counterparts, with the kiwi dollar advancing 1.3% and the Aussie gaining 0.3% since July 1. The rally is driven by higher bond yields relative to US Treasuries. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand indicated it would carefully consider risks to financial stability when deciding interest-rate policy, leading traders to pare bets on a rate cut. The two currencies are expected to continue rising in the short term, driven by US payrolls data and the premium in their yields.

site_title: The elderly vote and get money in Japan's silver democracy
summary: In Japan, the elderly significantly influence politics and voting decisions, with those aged 70+ casting higher rates than younger voters. The country's upper house election on Sunday is expected to favor older citizens. The government's budget allocates more funds to senior citizens, with 6.3% of total spending going towards social programs for this demographic. This prioritization is partly due to the elderly's voting power, with policymakers focusing on measures for senior citizens rather than child-rearing programs.

site_title: Facebook Live streaming of shooting spotlights ethical, legal policies
summary: A live 10-minute video of a police officer shooting a black man in Minnesota was broadcast on Facebook Live, garnering over 4 million views and sparking debate on the platform's ethics and policies. Critics argue that the lack of regulation can lead to exploitation of tragedy, while proponents see the technology as a powerful tool for public awareness and pressure. Facebook has expanded its team to review live content and test monitoring of viral broadcasts, but the company faces challenges in balancing openness with responsibility.

site_title: Triyards' Q3 profit falls 24%; revenue jumps 28%
summary: Triyards Holdings, a yard-operating subsidiary of EZRA Holdings, reported a 24% decline in net profit to US$4.12 million for the third quarter, despite a 28% revenue increase to US$82.1 million. Lower gross profit margins due to a different mix of projects contributed to the decline. The company expects challenging market conditions for the oil and gas industry for the next 12 months, but remains optimistic about its diversified clientele base and product offerings.

images.alt_text: Ezra Holdings' yard-operating subsidiary Triyards Holdings on Friday posted a 24 per cent fall in its net profit for the third quarter, despite a rise in revenue, due to lower gross profit margins from a different mix of projects.

site_title: US dollar higher vs euro ahead of US jobs report
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro ahead of the US June jobs report, which showed initial unemployment claims plummeting to a near three-month low and private sector job growth increasing. The jobs data encouraged hopes for a strong employment report on Friday, leading investors to seek higher US dollar values. Meanwhile, the euro slipped against the yen.

site_title: Microsoft leadership shake-up as veteran executive departs
summary: Microsoft has announced a leadership shake-up, with longtime chief operating officer Kevin Turner departing for a new job at Citadel Securities. Turner will aid in the transition at Microsoft until August, then step down. Five executives will assume Turner's duties, including Judson Althoff, Jean-Philippe Courtois, Chris Capossela, Kurt DelBene, and Amy Hood. The move comes as Microsoft prepares to release a major Windows 10 update on August 2, which will power over 350 million devices.

site_title: Gold set for longest weekly rally in two years as jobs in focus
summary: Gold prices are set for the longest weekly rally in two years, driven by uncertainty surrounding the UK's Brexit vote and investors' focus on the upcoming US jobs report. Gold has rallied 28% this year, with a sixth week of gains expected, as demand for haven assets surges amid market uncertainty. The metal traded at $1,358.45 per ounce, up 1.3% for the week, with investors waiting for Friday's US non-farm payrolls report.

site_title: Britain to have first female PM since Thatcher
summary: Britain is set to have its first female prime minister since Margaret Thatcher after Theresa May and Andrea Leadsom made the shortlist to lead the country out of the EU. May won 199 votes, while Leadsom received 84. The new prime minister will be announced on September 9 and will have the task of negotiating Britain's exit from the EU following the June 23 referendum. May has promised to provide proven leadership to negotiate the best deals for leaving the EU, while Leadsom has argued for a rapid exit.

site_title: North Korea calls US sanctions on Kim a 'declaration of war'
summary: North Korea has condemned US sanctions on its leader Kim Jong Un, calling them a "declaration of war". The sanctions, imposed by the US Treasury Department, target Kim and other top officials for human-rights abuses. Pyongyang has threatened to cut off diplomatic communications if the sanctions aren't lifted, which would challenge the dignity of its leader and be the "worst hostility" against the country. The US has imposed financial sanctions on Kim, making it harder for banks to hold or move assets owned by those on the list.

site_title: Britain set for post-Brexit trade talks with India
summary: Britain's business minister Sajid Javid will hold post-Brexit trade talks with India, marking the country's first discussion with a major world power. The talks aim to build on the £16.55 billion bilateral trade relationship between the two countries. Javid plans to meet Indian finance and commerce ministers in Delhi, with similar talks scheduled with the US, China, Japan, and South Korea. The UK aims to establish up to 300 specialist staff to aid in new trade negotiations, following the EU's example of having 58 free trade agreements with countries outside the bloc.

site_title: Korean period drama promises to satisfy fans of erotic thrillers
summary: Korean director Park Chan-wook's new film, The Handmaiden, is an erotic thriller based on the Victorian era crime novel Fingersmith. Set under Japanese colonial rule, the story follows an orphaned pickpocket who is recruited by a conman to cheat a psychologically frail Japanese aristocrat of her inheritance. The film, divided into three parts, is a psychological slow burn with extreme violence and moments of psychological manipulation. With its lush scenery, impeccable aesthetics, and bilingual dialogue, The Handmaiden is a riveting tale of deception and desire.

site_title: NTU scientists invent water filter that cuts energy use by 80%
summary: Scientists at Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have invented a new type of nano-filter that reduces energy use by up to 80% in wastewater treatment. The filter combines ultra-filtration and reverse osmosis membranes, requiring only 2 bars of water pressure instead of 10. This technology, developed over two years, allows for extremely clean water production at a low cost, with high reliability and ease of maintenance. The NTU spin-off company De.Mem is commercializing the technology, with plans to manufacture and test the membranes in Singapore.

site_title: US: Energy weighs on Wall Street but Costco shines
summary: The US stock market experienced a mixed day, with the S&P 500 and Dow industrials falling due to energy shares, while the Nasdaq Composite rose due to gains in tech and Costco. Oil futures prices fell 5% after crude stockpiles fell less than forecast, contributing to the decline. However, Costco's report of higher-than-expected June sales lifted the Nasdaq, and US labor market data showed a stronger-than-expected private sector jobs report. The market is awaiting the monthly payrolls report on Friday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise for first time in four days in broad rebound
summary: European stocks rose 1.1% for the first time in four days, ending their longest losing streak in three weeks. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index rebounded after minutes from the Federal Reserve's last meeting showed officials are losing confidence in tightening policy. Travel and leisure shares and financial firms led the gains, while banks rebounded from their lowest levels since 2011. Optimism prevails that central banks will remain supportive of markets, with some analysts predicting a positive second half of the year.

site_title: EU declares Spain, Portugal in violation of budget rules
summary: The European Commission has declared Spain and Portugal in violation of EU public spending rules, marking the first step towards potential sanctions. The two countries, struggling with high deficits, have failed to meet the EU's deficit limit of 3% of national output. The commission has set a 20-day countdown for fines, which could reach up to 0.2% of gross domestic product. EU finance ministers will decide on the penalties, with some, like France and Italy, considering delaying the process to avoid being next in line for sanctions.

site_title: Amex, CapitaLand tie up in big-data trawl
summary: American Express has partnered with CapitaLand Mall Asia, Singapore's largest retail landlord, to expand its reach beyond the affluent segment through a new loyalty card. The partnership allows Amex to tap into CapitaLand's 350 million shoppers across 15 malls, boosting retail spending and providing valuable data insights. The move marks the end of an earlier card partnership with DBS. The partnership aims to create a win-win ecosystem, benefiting both shoppers and retailers, with Amex offering loyalty points and data analytics to enhance customer experience.

site_title: Fatal police shootings reflect 'serious problem' in US: Obama
summary: US President Barack Obama says the fatal police shootings of Alton Sterling in Louisiana and Philando Castile in Minnesota reveal serious problems in relations between law enforcement and communities they serve. A federal civil rights probe has been opened in the Louisiana case, and the Minnesota governor has asked for the same. The incidents bring back the issue of alleged police brutality, particularly towards young black men. Obama calls for Americans to work together to heal the divisions.

site_title: Still crooning his way to the top
summary: Engelbert Humperdinck, a 80-year-old singer, reminisces about his nearly five-decade music career, including living next to The Beatles and discovering The Carpenters. He recalls his hit single "Release Me" staying in the UK chart for 56 weeks and earning him a Guinness Book of Records entry. Despite his successful career, Humperdinck remains nervous before performances and credits his music's core message of romance and love for his longevity and success, selling over 150 million albums worldwide.

site_title: Oil dives after fall in US inventories disappoints
summary: US oil inventories fell less than expected, disappointing market concerns about abundant global supplies. Oil prices plummeted, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping $2.29 to $45.14 a barrel and global benchmark Brent North Sea oil falling $2.40 to $46.40 a barrel. The US Department of Energy reported 2.2 million barrel decline in commercial crude inventories, which remain at historically high levels. A smaller-than-expected decline in gasoline inventories also raised concerns about oversupply. The news added to market concerns about abundant global supplies and the need for sharper production cuts.

site_title: Clinton's email was probably hacked, say IT specialists
summary: FBI Director James Comey stated that Hillary Clinton's email account was likely hacked, despite no direct evidence of successful hacking. IT specialists and federal investigators believe that sophisticated Russian and Chinese hackers targeted her account due to its widespread knowledge and use. Comey's concern lies in the risks created by Clinton's practice of keeping communications on a private server, which may have allowed hackers to gain access to her system. The central mystery remains whether any hackers gained access to her account, and the FBI's assessment may never be resolved.

site_title: Protesters demand justice after latest US police shooting
summary: Protesters in Saint Paul, Minnesota, gathered outside the governor's mansion to demand justice for Philando Castile, a 32-year-old black man fatally shot by police during a traffic stop. The incident is the latest in a string of high-profile police shootings of black men, sparking outrage across the US. Hundreds of protesters, including Ericka Cullars-Golden, who lost her son to a similar incident last year, chanted "Hands Up, Don't Shoot" and called for police reform. The shooting is the second in two days, following the fatal shooting of Alton Sterling in Louisiana.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) acquired Wing Tai's shareholding interest in Summervale Properties for S$411 million, increasing its stake in the Nouvel 18 project to 100%. CDL views the purchase favorably due to its 100% controlling stake and potential for structuring a profit participation securities transaction. Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) is expected to see a 27% increase in distributable income in FY2016 and a 6.2% increase in FY2017. Singapore Post is searching for a new CEO and may face impairment of goodwill for its TradeGlobal business.

site_title: Nine shop units in Holland Road Shopping Centre up for sale
summary: Nine shop units and one industrial unit in Holland Road Shopping Centre, owned by the Lim family, are up for sale. The units, ranging from 237 sq ft to 732 sq ft, are being sold collectively or piecemeal at a guide price of S$24 million. The sale, driven by a resolution of family differences, includes a freehold unit on the second level of 211 Henderson, with a guide price of S$3.23 million. The sale is seen as an opportunity for end-users and investors, with the freehold status and potential yield return being key attractions in the prime Holland Village location.

site_title: With the Chilcot report, the fate of wasted lives should preoccupy us
summary: The Chilcot report, years overdue, was published on July 7, 2016, detailing Britain's conduct of the 2003 Iraq war. The report, led by John Chilcot, found that the British government, led by Tony Blair, exaggerated the case for war and failed to exhaust alternatives. The government also failed to prepare for the invasion and mismanaged the occupation of Iraq, resulting in "wasted lives." The report's findings were based on thousands of documents and interviews with over 100 witnesses.

site_title: Catalist 'golden' trio rides on gold rally
summary: Singapore's Catalist "golden" trio, CNMC Goldmine Holdings, Anchor Resources, and Wilton Resources Corp, have seen significant gains amid the gold rally. CNMC Goldmine rose 8.5% to 61 Singapore cents, while Anchor Resources jumped 16.7% to 14 Singapore cents. Wilton Resources Corp gained 3.75% to 8.3 Singapore cents. The gold rally is driven by Brexit anxiety, with investors seeking safe-haven assets. Analysts expect gold prices to surge as the dollar weakens and economic uncertainty grows.

site_title: Oil industry is losing the burn of Asian demand
summary: Asian crude oil demand is slowing and may not recover due to structural changes. Despite years of strong growth, China's annual economic growth has slowed, and vehicle sales have fallen. Japan and South Korea, major oil-consuming regions, are also expected to see declining demand due to factors such as reduced nuclear power generation and increased use of alternative fuels. Industry analysts predict that Asia's oil demand growth may never be revisited, with energy efficiency standards for new cars expected to rise, reducing global demand.

site_title: 3 more property funds halt withdrawals after Brexit vote
summary: Three more asset managers, Columbia Threadneedle Investments, Henderson Global Investors, and Canada Life, have suspended redemptions in their British property funds amid concerns over the impact of Brexit on the real estate market. This brings the total to six fund managers to halt customer exits since Monday. The move aims to prevent a cycle of selling that could force the funds to sell assets at low prices and prompt more investors to seek an exit. The pound has fallen to a 31-year low, and the FTSE 100 has dropped 1.25% due to uncertainty following the Brexit vote.

site_title: Learn from Monopoly, bond manager tells Yellen
summary: Bill Gross, a billionaire bond investor, advises Janet Yellen to learn from Monopoly, warning that the economy's credit growth is stagnating and may lead to bankruptcies. Gross believes that the Federal Reserve's interest rate policies, based on outdated models like the Taylor Rule and Phillips Curve, are ineffective. He argues that credit creation, like collecting $200 in Monopoly, is essential for economic growth, but the current system is failing to generate sufficient credit growth, leading to stagnation. Gross urges policymakers to adopt a more dynamic approach to credit creation.

site_title: Eleven nights of open air movie magic
summary: Films at the Fort, presented by Casillero del Diablo, returns this August with its fourth edition, featuring 11 award-winning movies curated by Ben Williams. The outdoor cinema event has grown from 5,000 attendees in 2013 to an expected 12,000-15,000 this year, with a focus on gourmet food and drinks. The 11 films include documentaries, classics, and cult favorites, and the event is geared towards adults aged 24-45. Held at Fort Canning Park, the event aims to recreate a unique cinematic experience under the stars.

site_title: A dangerous geo-strategic and geo-economic vacuum
summary: A recent surge in terrorist attacks, including those in Tel-Aviv, Orlando, Istanbul, Dhaka, and Baghdad, has been linked to radical Islamic groups, posing a geo-strategic threat. The UK's decision to exit the EU, or Brexit, has created a geo-economic vacuum, potentially encouraging other nations to follow suit and weakening globalisation. This shift challenges the liberal international order, which relies on the US as a global hegemon. The US's reluctance to exert its military power and liberalise global trade has created a strategic vacuum, allowing extremist groups to flourish, and may signal the end of its role as the global leader.

site_title: Italy's plan to shore up its banks could roil Europe
summary: Italy is facing a potential banking crisis that could roil Europe's $16 trillion economy, with the government needing $45 billion to shore up its banks burdened with bad loans. However, new European rules may prohibit such a bailout, forcing investors to absorb losses instead. This could lead to a significant hit to Italian households and potentially destabilize the financial system. European leaders are weighing the options, with some considering exemptions to the bailout rules, while others suggest a restructuring of the banking industry to prevent future problems.

site_title: Bitcoin's future hinges on mining powerhouse China
summary: Bitcoin's future is uncertain due to a capacity issue that needs to be resolved by the end of 2017. The cryptocurrency's network is limited by a pre-programmed cap on data processing, which could lead to transaction times increasing and undermining its 4,475% growth over the past five years. A simple coding tweak could fix the issue, but miners, software developers, and entrepreneurs have yet to form a consensus. Chinese miners, who control 70% of the world's bitcoin mining power, are crucial to finding a solution, as they have leveraged their access to cheap labor and electricity to outmaneuver global peers.

site_title: HSBC seeks to issue credit cards in China by end of the year
summary: HSBC aims to issue its own credit cards in China by the end of 2016, targeting the Pearl River Delta region with digitally-driven retail banking and wealth management services. The move is part of the bank's strategy to tap into rising online and mobile spending in the country. HSBC received regulatory approval earlier this year for its mainland offerings and plans to use the experience gained from its partnership with Bank of Communications to launch its own cards.

site_title: When the arts build bridges
summary: The George Town Festival in Penang, Malaysia, has seen substantial Singaporean participation and support for its seventh year. The festival has collaborated with Singapore artists, with the headline show "Pearl of the Eastern & Oriental" being performed by Singaporean duo Tan Kheng Hua and Lim Yu-Beng. This year's festival also includes a workshop led by Singaporean artist Sim Chi Yin, who has been researching her family history in Penang. Other notable performances include a talk by Larry Harvey, co-founder of Burning Man, and a dance production by Akram Khan. The festival highlights the shared history and culture between Penang and Singapore, and aims to build bridges between the two countries.

site_title: TSA fixes delays at US airports - for now
summary: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has successfully reduced security screening delays at US airports, with average wait times under 10 minutes over the July 4 holiday weekend. The agency credits expedited hiring of new security officers, increased overtime staffing, and the conversion of part-time to full-time positions, as well as airline support and new technology. However, experts warn that the solutions may be temporary, and the problem may recur, with David Swierenga stating that the TSA has not made substantive changes to procedures or manpower.

site_title: ECB mulls legal steps as Slovenia raids its central bank in bailout case
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi warned of potential legal steps against Slovenia after police raided the country's central bank in a probe into a 2013 bank bailout. The raid, which seized ECB information, infringes the EU's Protocol on Privileges and Immunities, Draghi said in letters to Slovenia's prosecutor general and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. Draghi called for the seizure to be remedied and said the ECB will explore legal remedies under Slovenian law.

site_title: Arbitration Centre praised for innovative changes made to rules
summary: Singapore's Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) has received praise for its innovative changes to its international arbitration rules, set to take effect in August. The revised rules aim to address concerns of delay and inefficiency in international arbitration, introducing features such as the early dismissal of claims or defences without legal merit. The changes also include provisions for multi-contract, multi-party arbitrations and streamlined emergency arbitration proceedings, aiming to provide a more efficient and expedient process for resolving international disputes.

site_title: DBS launches metal Visa payWave card for the affluent (Amended)
summary: DBS Bank launched the world's first metal Visa payWave card, the DBS Insignia Visa Infinite Card, available only by invitation to affluent members with a minimum annual income of S$500,000. The card offers 100,000 air miles, Priority Pass membership, and benefits such as complimentary hotel stays and access to exclusive clubs. The move aligns with the growing trend of affluent consumers embracing a cashless lifestyle, with 90% year-on-year growth in Visa payWave affluent users.

site_title: Deals worth S$120m for Keppel Shipyard
summary: Keppel Shipyard secured four contracts worth S$120 million from repeat customers. The contracts include the installation and integration of topside modules for a newbuild FPSO vessel, the fabrication of an internal turret mooring system, upgrading work for the pipelay vessel Castorone, and modification and upgrading of the FPSO vessel Ngujima-Yin. The shipyard's job scope for the Ngujima-Yin upgrade includes marine and hull life extension, installation of a customised water flood module, and modification of swivel system. The detailed engineering phase is expected to commence this month, with construction work scheduled to start in Q2 2018.

site_title: China faces innovation centre glut as top-down policy backfires
summary: China is facing a glut of innovation centres as local governments construct them in an effort to support creativity, despite a lack of entrepreneurs and startups moving in. Nearly 5,000 centres are set to open in the next five years, with occupancy rates of less than 40%. The centres often lack the necessary resources, expertise, and local market demand, leading to a buildup of debt and a risk of a bubble. China's top-down policy to drive innovation has backfired, leaving many of the centres as "white elephants".

site_title: Food Empire can't use 'Mc' or 'Mac' in EU, court rules
summary: Singapore-listed Food Empire has lost a trademark dispute with McDonald's in the European Union, with the General Court ruling in favor of the global fast-food chain. Food Empire's subsidiary Future Enterprises Pte Ltd had applied to register "MacCoffee" as an EU trademark, but was rejected. The court's decision prevents Food Empire from using "Mc" or "Mac" in trademark names for its foodstuff and beverages in the EU. The company's directors are disappointed with the ruling and plan to appeal the decision.

site_title: Crowdfunding catches on
summary: Singaporean entrepreneurs are turning to crowdfunding to get their businesses off the ground. Erwin Lian's Perfect Sketchbook project, which raised US$53,851 on Kickstarter, and Witching Hour Studios' Masquerada: Songs and Shadows, which exceeded its £45,000 goal on Kickstarter, are examples of successful local projects. However, not all successful projects translate into complete products, with some companies folding and contributors left with nothing. As a result, crowdfunding platforms are shifting their focus from funding to mentorship. The TinyMOS camera for astrophotography, which has raised over US$337,000 on Indiegogo, is an example of a project using crowdfunding as a marketing tool and market validation.

site_title: Scoot could be budget carrier with the world's longest route
summary: Scoot, a low-cost carrier subsidiary of Singapore Airlines Group, is set to launch services to Europe in the second quarter of 2017, potentially becoming the world's longest LCC route. Scoot will operate four 787-8 aircraft with crew bunks, taking over routes from its parent airline. The airline is expected to launch a route over 10,000km long, making it the first LCC to do so since AirAsia X suspended services in 2012. Scoot's European expansion is seen as a strategic move to establish itself as a long-haul airline, despite potential challenges to profitability.

site_title: Noble Group's shares and nil-paid rights hotly traded
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 10% to 18.4 Singapore cents, while its nil-paid rights declined 30% to 7.4 cents. The company's US$500 million one-for-one rights issue, announced on June 3, has seen its shares slide from 30 cents to a low of 15.9 cents. The rights issue is estimated to raise S$696.1 million in net proceeds, with most funds going towards working capital and debt repayment.

site_title: Sterling back above US$1.30 as sellers take breather
summary: Sterling rises 0.9% to above US$1.30 as investors book profits on bets against it, despite the UK's Brexit vote outlook remaining grim. The US dollar is 0.2% lower against the yen, while the Australian dollar falls after S&P downgrades its credit rating outlook. Investors are cautious about the yen's gains due to the risk of Bank of Japan intervention. The Bank of England prepares to ease monetary policy, potentially leading to further sterling decline.

site_title: Swiber expected to call S$75m four-year bonds
summary: SWIBER Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore marine counter, is expected to call its S$75 million of 7% four-year bonds before Thursday, July 7. The firm requested a trading halt on July 4, two days before its second bond deadline in 2016.

site_title: Star-studded thriller needs more firepower
summary: Hong Kong directors Longman Leung and Sunny Luk return with Cold War 2, the sequel to their 2012 hit. The film, starring Aaron Kwok and Eddie Peng, follows Police Commissioner Sean Lau as he tries to rescue his family from kidnappers. However, the plot is marred by confusion and excessive characters, leading to a convoluted storyline. Despite its flaws, the film delivers on style and dialogue, but its reliance on action over substance is criticized. The sequel is deemed an entertaining but frustrating watch, with a rating of C+.

images.alt_text: Deputy Police Commissioner MB Lee (Tony Leung) confronts senior counsel Oswald Kan (Chow Yun Fat) in Cold War 2. The plot twists and turns so much it gets confusing.

site_title: Australian banks seen facing inquiry after cliff-hanger election
summary: Australian banks, including Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and National Australia Bank, are likely to face a wide-ranging inquiry into mis-selling, misconduct, and market dominance concerns following the country's knife-edge election. Independent and small party lawmakers are pushing for a Royal Commission into the industry, which could lead to calls for the banks to be broken up if they control 80% of the country's lending.

site_title: Europe governments banking on confusion of strangers
summary: European governments and central banks are relying on the confusion of strangers to cover up inconsistencies in policymaking, following the UK's Brexit referendum. The UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, has forgotten his earlier threat of higher taxes and lower spending, while Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is now speaking of interest rate cuts. Meanwhile, the UK is set to replace Prime Minister David Cameron with a new leader, with Theresa May or Andrea Leadsom likely to take the position.

site_title: S&P cuts Australia's outlook on expected fiscal gridlock
summary: S&P Global Ratings has cut Australia's AAA credit rating outlook to negative, citing the country's potential fiscal gridlock and budget deficit. The agency warned that without forceful fiscal policy decisions, material government budget deficits may persist for several years. The rating change reflects Australia's decline in tax revenues amid a drop in commodity prices and a fall in mining investment. The nation's 10-year bond yield remains close to a record-low, and markets have appeared more relaxed despite the rating change.

site_title: As sugar finds its sweet spot, investors ask for how long?
summary: US raw sugar prices have more than doubled in less than a year, making it one of the best-performing commodity markets this year. This comes after a four-year bear market, with sugar's steepest bull run in years. The market's strong performance is attributed to factors such as reduced production and increased demand. The surge in sugar prices is also seen as a positive trend for investors, who are now questioning how long this trend will last.

site_title: DINING Bedrock Bar & Grill guest chef series
summary: Bedrock Bar & Grill in Singapore is hosting a guest chef series, "A Texas Meat Feast," featuring chef Jay McCarthy from the Cascabel Restaurant in San Antonio, Texas. The menu, available from July 8 to 10, includes a Tomahawk Steak and lobster mac & cheese. Desserts are also available, including a Bourbon Black Forest Tart and a Waffle Ice Cream Sandwich. Reservations can be made by calling 6238 0054 or visiting the restaurant's website.

site_title: Snapchat adds more trappings, lets users hang on to their snaps longer
summary: Snapchat introduces Memories, a feature allowing users to save and back up their snaps to the app's servers for longer periods. Users can designate snaps as "My Eyes Only" and save Stories to Memories. The feature, rolling out to iOS and Android users over the next month, will store snaps taken more than a day ago with a frame around them. Snapchat aims to broaden its audience beyond its traditional young demographic, while also adding more trappings of a traditional network, including advertising and sponsored content.

site_title: US airline stocks closer to biggest annual decline in five years
summary: US airline stocks are on track for their biggest annual decline in five years, with the Bloomberg US Airlines Index tumbling 26% in 2016. Rising fuel prices, increased labour costs, and a lack of capacity growth are contributing to the decline. Analysts at Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank have cut earnings estimates for major carriers, citing sustained declines in passenger revenue and a reluctance to trim capacity. The industry's net income is expected to peak and decline in 2017 and 2018, according to Deutsche Bank's forecast.

site_title: SPH Reit's Q3 DPU higher at 1.36 cents
summary: SPH Reit reported a 0.7% rise in distribution per unit for Q3, reaching 1.36 cents, driven by a 1.8% increase in net property income to S$40 million. Both Paragon and The Clementi Mall achieved 100% occupancy and positive rental reversion, with Paragon seeing a 4.9% rental uplift and The Clementi Mall recording a 4.5% increase. The Reit's asset enhancement initiatives, including decanting air handling units at Paragon, are progressing well.

site_title: Creating sustainable cities and turning them into cities of opportunity
summary: Tai Lee Siang, chairman of the World Green Building Council, emphasizes the need for sustainable cities, particularly in Asia, where over two-thirds of the world's population lives in urban areas. He aims to promote green buildings and urban spaces, encouraging governments, businesses, and residents to work together for a more livable and sustainable future. Lee Siang's priorities include increasing global membership, addressing funding and inertia challenges, and leveraging citizenry to drive change. He plans to grow the number of green buildings and structures worldwide through the WorldGBC's global network and promote green thinking among governments, businesses, and individuals.

site_title: SRX Property data differs from HDB flash figures
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore fell 0.6% in June 2016, according to SRX Property data, contradicting HDB's flash estimates of a 0.1% increase in the second quarter. Analysts attribute the discrepancy to SRX's figures not accounting for DIY transactions, which accounted for 24% of resale transactions in 2015. Despite the difference, experts expect minimal price drops for the year, with stability supporting buyer interest.

site_title: Temasek sees slower growth and bumpier path ahead
summary: Temasek Holdings expects slower growth and increased volatility in 2017, with a 5-in-6 chance of portfolio returns ranging from -21% to 32%. The firm is cautiously optimistic about US economic recovery, while China is seen transitioning to a sustainable growth path. Europe faces fundamental downside risks due to Brexit and regulatory uncertainty. In contrast, Singapore's ongoing economic reforms are expected to unlock stronger productivity growth. Temasek is focusing on emerging themes such as big data, robotics, and sustainable development.

site_title: China's Silk Road Fund in joint bid for Glencore mine
summary: China's Silk Road Fund is discussing a joint bid with China National Gold Group Corp for Glencore plc's gold mine in Kazakhstan, valued at approximately $2 billion. The joint offer may compete with other Chinese gold producers, following a 36% increase in mining acquisitions by Chinese companies this year. This comes as China Molybdenum Co and China National Gold have already made significant mining acquisitions in 2016, with a total value of $3.25 billion. The Silk Road Fund, a $40 billion investment pool, is exploring opportunities along the Silk Road trade routes.

site_title: Alibaba challenges Apple, Google with China-made Web car
summary: Alibaba is challenging Apple and Google with its China-made Web car, showcasing its YunOS operating system in a SAIC Motor Corp Roewe RX5 SUV model. The OS allows drivers to book parking, order coffee, and pay using Alipay, and Alibaba is in talks with carmakers to form alliances to use YunOS. The company sees the car as a "robot you communicate with on a daily basis," with the global connected car market projected to grow by 19% per year to $4.2 billion by 2021.

site_title: Samsung profit tops estimates on Galaxy S7 demand
summary: Samsung Electronics reported better-than-expected profit in the second quarter, driven by strong demand for its Galaxy S7 smartphones. Operating income rose to 8.1 trillion won, exceeding analyst estimates, and revenue reached 50 trillion won. The company's mobile devices business turned around, with the S7 model capitalizing on a lull in new iPhones from Apple. Profit margins were boosted, and shares rose 13% in 2016, marking the first annual increase in four years.

site_title: Northwave EC gets 240 e-applications for 358 units, Treasure Crest EC over-subscribed
summary: Northwave EC in Woodlands received 240 e-applications for 358 units, while Treasure Crest EC in Sengkang was over-subscribed with 800 e-applications for 504 units. Consultants attribute Northwave's lower subscription to weaker transport links and a mixed industrial-residential neighborhood. Treasure Crest's popularity is attributed to its spacious units, competitive pricing, and ideal location. Balloting for Northwave will be conducted this Saturday, offering a 5% discount for normal payment scheme buyers.

images.alt_text: Northwave (left) is a 10-minute walk to Sembawang MRT Station, whereas Treasure Crest is a shorter walk to Cheng Lim LRT Station and Sengkang MRT Station

site_title: Our Kind of Traitor passes muster as decent entertainment
summary: Our Kind of Traitor, a film adaptation of John Le Carré's novel, follows an ordinary college professor, Perry Makepiece, who gets caught up in international espionage after meeting a Russian mobster, Dimi. The story unfolds as Perry agrees to help Dimi, a high-profile money-launderer, to save his family from the mafia. As Perry delves deeper, he finds himself in a treacherous game of hide-and-seek with corrupt politicians and British intelligence. The film features nuanced performances by Ewan McGregor and Stellan Skarsgard, making it a decent entertainment for grown-ups.

site_title: Temasek returns -9% in FY2016 - its worst showing since 2009
summary: Temasek, a Singapore investment firm, reported a 9.02% decline in its net portfolio value to S$242 billion in FY2016, its first one-year negative return since 2009. The decline was mainly due to mark-to-market valuations of listed assets, particularly in China and financial services. However, the firm's investments in technology-leveraged companies, such as telecommunications, media, and technology, outperformed the rest of its portfolio. Temasek will continue to shift its portfolio towards technology, with a new office in San Francisco slated to open in September.

site_title: Swiss Bankers urge financial center alliance after Brexit: FT
summary: Swiss Bankers Association head Patrick Odier urged collaboration among the UK, Switzerland, Hong Kong, and Singapore to tackle EU regulation and policy issues post-Brexit. This alliance would facilitate discussions and solutions to challenges faced by the financial centers. The UK's exit from the EU has raised questions about its future status as a gateway to European business, affecting the global financial firms with bases in the country, including Swiss banks.

site_title: ShareInvestor launches upgraded mobile app
summary: ShareInvestor, a Singapore-based financial internet media company, has launched an upgraded version of its mobile app, ShareInvestor Mobile. The new app features real-time market information, business news, and dynamic tools to help investors manage their portfolios. The app offers access to multiple stock markets, a company database, and advanced technical analysis charts. Two versions are available, one free and one paid for registered subscribers. The upgrade aims to keep pace with new mobile devices and provide investors with timely investment decisions and portfolio management capabilities.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Local events and dining options are highlighted in the "City Buzz" section. Shaolin monks are performing a jaw-dropping stage spectacular at Theatre Shaolin, showcasing their acrobatic feats. The Art Apart Fair is also taking place at Isetan Wisma Atria, featuring art and furniture from North and South-east Asia. Chef's Table by Chef Stephan offers a unique dining experience with a changing menu each day, while Truffle Constellation at Stellar at 1-Altitude features an eight-course menu with truffles from Western Australia. A Texas Meat Feast is also being held at Bedrock Bar & Grill.

site_title: ISIS ideology took root amid political bickering
summary: Bangladesh has witnessed a surge in ISIS-inspired violence, with the recent attack on a Dhaka restaurant killing 22 people. The perpetrators, linked to Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen Bangladesh, were from the country's western-educated elite, exposing the government's failure to contain the spread of radical ideology. The attack is part of a growing trend of extremist groups in Bangladesh, with ties to Al Qaeda and Afghan Taliban. The government's response has been criticized for downplaying the presence of foreign militant organizations and prioritizing political opponents over terrorists.

site_title: A five-star Hotel experience
summary: A five-star Hotel production, a two-part play by W!ld Rice, premiered at Singapore Arts Festival last year and returned for a headlining encore season at Singapore Theatre Festival. The epic five-hour production, set in Singapore, explores a century of history through 40 characters and 11 acts, drawing parallels between past and present. The play won big at the M1-The Straits Times Life Theatre Awards, including Production of the Year, Best Ensemble, and Best Director. It showcases a unique perspective on Singapore, celebrating the everyday lives of ordinary people instead of famous historical figures.

site_title: Stocks drift lower on Brexit worries
summary: Singapore stocks closed 2.5 points lower on Thursday, July 7, 2016, due to Brexit-induced selling in European markets. Despite this, the local market's resilience can be attributed to its defensive quality, with financially sound companies and decent dividend yields. The Straits Times Index closed at 2,862.17, with turnover at 1.6 billion units worth S$1.2 billion. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong closed 1% higher, while Dow futures gained 28 points.

site_title: Sunday's election in Japan just might be as impactful as Brexit
summary: A Japanese parliamentary election on Sunday may have significant geopolitical implications, potentially altering the nation's stance on military force and revising its post-war Constitution. The ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and its allies aim to secure a two-thirds majority in the upper house to launch a national referendum on constitutional change. Analysts see this as a key test for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies and his long-held goal of revising the Constitution. The outcome could impact regional tensions with China and the US, and its effects on global financial markets remain uncertain.

site_title: Lum Chang MD and sons launch takeover offer for Ellipsiz
summary: Lum Chang Holdings, controlled by the Lum family, has launched a mandatory takeover offer for Ellipsiz, a semiconductor equipment provider. The offer price is S$0.38 per share, valuing Ellipsiz at S$63.5 million. The takeover was triggered after the family's vehicle, Bevrian Pte Ltd, acquired 7.93 million shares, giving them a 34.10% stake in the company. Bevrian intends to maintain Ellipsiz's existing business activities and listing status, with no plans for major changes.

site_title: Pairing wines with Asian cuisine
summary: A wine pairing dinner with Asian cuisine was held, featuring three wines: Champagne Pol Roger Sir Winston Churchill 1996, Château Rayas Chateauneuf-du-Pape 2004, and Bonnes Mares 2004 Grand Cru. The wines were chosen based on their good fruit ripeness, minimum or very ripe tannins, and good acidity. The pairings were deemed successful, with the Château Rayas working well with a short-rib curry and the Bonnes Mares complementing a chicken rice dish. The article concludes that selecting wines to accompany Asian cuisine is relatively straightforward, following basic guidelines of fruit ripeness, tannin levels, and acidity.

site_title: Boeing slows payments to suppliers as it accelerates cost-cutting
summary: Boeing is accelerating cost-cutting efforts, slowing payments to suppliers to up to 120 days, down from 30 days, to conserve cash and trim inventory. The company is also relying on suppliers to hold parts instead of maintaining its own inventory in factories. Boeing aims to remain competitive in a market where investors closely watch its cash flow, with CEO Dennis Muilenburg seeking to lift the company's profit margin to the mid-teens by 2020. This move follows a 2012 program that saw suppliers cut prices by 15%.

site_title: OECD employment levels recovering, but 'job quality is low'
summary: Employment levels in OECD countries are recovering, with employment levels expected to return to pre-crisis levels in 2017. However, the recovery is uneven, and unemployment remains high in some European countries. Many newly-created jobs are of low quality, and labor-market inequalities are high. The OECD urges governments and employers to address these issues by encouraging better use of skills in the workplace, which will improve job satisfaction and productivity while enabling employers to raise profitability and wages.

site_title: StanChart Holland Village branch robbed of S$30,000
summary: Standard Chartered's Holland Village branch in Singapore was robbed of approximately S$30,000 in cash. No injuries were reported, and the bank's employees and customers are safe. The bank immediately filed a police report and is cooperating with the investigation. A suspect matching the description of a Caucasian man wearing a grey hoodie and mustard pants is being questioned. The branch has been shut for police investigations.

site_title: Local telcos' H1 total returns average 7.3%
summary: Singapore's three largest telcos - Singtel, StarHub, and M1 - averaged a 7.3% total return for the first half of 2016, with an average dividend yield of 5%. Their one-year and three-year total returns are -1.8% and 15.3%, respectively. The companies maintained an average return on equity (ROE) of 69.6% and a price-earnings (P/E) ratio of 16.1.

site_title: Fed minutes suggest uncertain outlook over Brexit
summary: The Federal Reserve's June policy meeting minutes suggest uncertainty over the UK's vote to leave the EU, with policymakers deciding to hold off on interest rate hikes until they have a handle on the consequences. The minutes showed widespread unease over Brexit, with Fed governor Daniel Tarullo arguing for holding off on rate hikes until inflation turns decisively higher. The decision was made ahead of the June 23 referendum, which shocked investors and triggered global stock market losses. Anxieties remain, with global financial conditions tightening as investors anticipate a prolonged period of uncertainty.

site_title: US gives Taiwan US$1.5m from property bought by ex-leader's family
summary: The US has returned $1.5 million to Taiwan, which was obtained from the sale of US properties purchased with bribes paid to former Taiwan President Chen Shui-Bian's family. The bribes, worth approximately $6 million, were paid to Chen's wife Wu Shu-Jen in 2004. The properties were sold by the US government after a final forfeiture judgment was entered in 2012, and the proceeds were used to purchase two properties in Virginia and New York.

site_title: UK economy heading for marked slowdown after Q2 pick-up: NIESR
summary: The UK economy is expected to experience a significant slowdown after a strong second quarter, according to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR). The economy expanded 0.6% in Q2, but the Bank of England warned of a potential contraction in Q3 and Q4. This comes as businesses and consumers face uncertainty following the June 23 Brexit vote, with some surveys suggesting a quarterly growth rate of just 0.2%. The NIESR estimated the economy would be 1.0% smaller in 2017 and 2.3% smaller in 2018 if the UK leaves the EU.

site_title: Property circuit excited over 2 big deals for good reason
summary: High-profile investors, including sovereign wealth funds and ultra-high networth individuals, are seeking long-term capital safety in the Singapore office market amid uncertainty. The recent large office sales, such as Asia Square Tower 1 and Straits Trading Building, have sparked buzz and attracted big money. These investors are willing to accept thinner property yields, as they are not fettered by short-term investment hurdle rates. The wave of mega investors could lead to a compression of Singapore office property yields, with potential deal sizes exceeding S$100 million.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on strong labour market data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by strong private sector employment data and a drop in jobless claims, which pointed to a steady labor market ahead of the monthly payrolls report on Friday. The ADP national employment report showed 172,000 jobs added in June, beating economists' expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%, the S&P 500 gained 0.26%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.39%. Investors are watching for signs of the economy's health and the possible impact of the Brexit vote on quarterly earnings.

site_title: US proposes United, Delta, American airlines fly nonstop to Havana
summary: The US Transportation Department proposed eight airlines, including United, Delta, American, and JetBlue, to operate nonstop flights from US cities to Havana, Cuba, as early as this fall. The list also includes Alaska Air, Frontier, Southwest, and Spirit. The flights will connect cities with large Cuban-American populations, such as Atlanta, Miami, and New York City. The move comes a year after the US and Cuba re-established diplomatic relations, and is part of President Obama's foreign policy legacy. The flights will fill the 20 daily slots allowed between Havana and US cities.

site_title: US jobless claims tumble as private hiring holds steady
summary: US jobless claims dropped to a near three-month low, falling 16,000 to 254,000 in the week ending July 2. The four-week moving average of new claims also decreased, down nearly 14,000 from a year ago. Private sector hiring remained steady in June, with 172,000 jobs added, according to ADP. The job growth is expected to rebound in the official June jobs report, which is forecast to show 175,000 nonfarm payrolls and an unemployment rate rise to 4.8%.

site_title: UK banks spared downgrades by S&P in mass outlook cull
summary: Standard & Poor's cut the rating outlooks of major UK banks to negative, but did not downgrade them, following the Brexit vote. This decision comes after S&P stripped Britain of its top-notch credit rating last month. The rating agency believes the UK economy has entered a correction phase, driven by worsening imbalances and slowing credit growth. The move is seen as a relief to UK banks, which had feared full downgrades.

site_title: Mega urbanisation forum kicks into gear
summary: Singapore is hosting a 5-day mega urbanization forum, the Singapore International Water Week, World Cities Summit, and CleanEnviro Summit Singapore, drawing 20,000 participants from over 100 cities. The event aims to improve liveability, sustainability, and urban planning, with a focus on water and clean energy. Key leaders, including President Tony Tan, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, and Royal Dutch Shell chairman Charles Holliday, will attend. The event highlights the growing importance of urban solutions and sustainability in Singapore's economy, with a budget of S$900 million allocated to research in the sector over five years.

site_title: Four US investment banks vow to help London after Brexit vote
summary: Four US investment banks, JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and Morgan Stanley, have pledged to support London's financial sector following the UK's Brexit vote. The banks, along with Standard Chartered, will work together to help London retain its position as a global financial centre. No commitment was made to keep jobs in Britain, but the statement emphasized the importance of preserving London's passporting rights. The move aims to alleviate concerns of an exodus from the City of London.

site_title: TSH Corp to sell freehold industrial land and building for S$16.1m
summary: TSH Corp has entered a sale and purchase agreement to sell its freehold industrial land and building at 62 Burn Road, Singapore, for S$16.1 million. The property, which occupies about 1.8 million square feet, will be used to repay an existing bank loan and discharge a mortgage. The company will retain S$3.9 million from the sale proceeds for future use, but no specific plans have been announced. The sale is part of TSH Corp's efforts to optimize its asset utilization.

site_title: Big solar leaves rooftop systems in the dust
summary: Large-scale solar systems are expected to account for 70% of new solar added to the grid this year, surpassing rooftop installations. The cost of large-scale solar electricity is now comparable to and sometimes cheaper than natural gas-fired power, driven by economics rather than green mandates. Utility-scale solar has become more competitive, with prices as low as four US cents a kWh, making it a financially viable option for utilities and states without green power policies. This shift raises questions about the effectiveness of incentives for rooftop installations, which remain expensive and require hefty subsidies.

site_title: Singapore Airlines to allow passengers to bid for seat upgrades
summary: Singapore Airlines has introduced an online bidding system for seat upgrades, allowing select economy class passengers to bid for premium economy seats 7 days in advance. The airline will invite passengers based on dynamic criteria, and results will be known 40 hours before departure. This move aims to increase revenue from yields, which have reached a six-year low due to intense competition from low-cost carriers and Middle Eastern rivals.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounce from losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded in the first few minutes of trading, rising 0.54% to 20,606.68, after a two-day decline. The move was cautious amid concerns over the long-term impact of the UK's EU exit. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.26%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.10%. Investors remain cautious despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in US markets.

site_title: China issues guidelines to improve banks' risk management
summary: China's bank regulator has published new draft guidelines to improve banks' risk management systems. The guidelines require banks to set up comprehensive risk management systems to identify, quantify, evaluate, monitor, and control various risks. The draft document is open for public comments until August 6. This move aims to enhance the banking sector's ability to manage risks and improve financial stability.

site_title: Infidelity website Ashley Madison facing FTC probe, CEO apologises
summary: Avid Life Media, the parent company of infidelity dating site Ashley Madison, is under investigation by the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) amid a breach that exposed millions of users' personal details. CEO Rob Segal apologized for the incident, which cost the company over a quarter of its revenue. The company is spending millions to improve security and exploring payment options with more privacy. Avid faces class action lawsuits and allegations of using fake profiles to manipulate customers, and the FTC investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Philippine June annual inflation speeds up to 14-mth high of 1.9%
summary: The Philippine annual inflation rate accelerated to 1.9% in June, the highest in over a year, driven by increased costs of food, fuel, and school fees. This pace matched analysts' expectations but fell short of the central bank's target of 2-4% for the year. Core inflation, excluding volatile food and fuel items, rose to 1.9% from 1.6% in May. The steady inflation rate supports expectations that monetary policy will remain unchanged for the rest of the year.

site_title: COE premiums slip across the board
summary: COE premiums in Singapore have decreased across all categories, with Category A for cars below 1,600cc dropping from S$52,301 to S$52,301 and Category B for cars above 1,600cc falling from S$56,089 to S$56,089. Category C for goods vehicles and Cat D for motorcycles also saw decreases. Dealers attribute the decline to a lack of bookings and high prices, with some customers unwilling to purchase at current COE premiums. Experts link the decrease to a poor economic outlook and Brexit-related concerns.

images.alt_text: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums softened across the board on Thursday as bookings for new vehicles dried up, some dealers said.

site_title: UBS told to hand client info to French taxman
summary: Swiss banking giant UBS has been ordered to hand over client information to the French tax authorities, amid allegations it orchestrated a vast system of tax fraud in France. The French request followed data from 2006 to 2008, and UBS expressed concerns over the ambiguous legal grounds. The bank denies the accusations, stating its involvement has not been proven. The investigation is linked to a whistle-blower case and a probe into UBS's alleged dual accounts system, which allegedly hid capital movement between 2004 and 2012.

site_title: China shares pressured by sliding yuan but pull off lows
summary: China's stocks rose for the eighth straight day, gaining 0.3% to 3,216.80, despite the yuan falling to its lowest 5-1/2 year lows against the dollar. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.4% to 3,017.29 points. Analysts predict the market will consolidate gains around 3,000 points. The yuan's weakness is attributed to concerns over China's struggling exporters and potential further weakening by the central bank to boost exports.

site_title: Mobile news surges, newspapers fall further: US poll
summary: US poll reveals Americans are increasingly turning to mobile devices for news, with print newspapers losing ground. A Pew Research Center survey found 72% of Americans get news on a mobile device, up from 54% in 2013. Television remains a steady source of news, while mobile devices have become the primary source of news for many Americans, with 36% saying they "often" get news from a smartphone or tablet. This trend suggests a significant shift in the way people consume news in the US.

site_title: Chatbots: closing ranks
summary: Chatbots are becoming increasingly competitive as several major companies, including BT, are launching new platforms and offices focused on artificial intelligence and digital innovation. The Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) has launched an AI and Digital Innovation office to foster Design AI skills in students. Meanwhile, companies such as NIE, Amazon Web Services, BHP, Oracle, Grab, and PwC are setting up AI-focused innovation hubs in Singapore. Additionally, Lazada has invested $100 million in creator commerce through its LazAffiliate Programme. These developments highlight the growing importance of AI in various industries.

site_title: Asia investors are at risk from slide in London property prices
summary: Asia investors are at risk due to a decline in London property prices following the UK's EU vote. Commercial property values are expected to fall 10% over the next year, mainly in oversupplied central London. Asset managers have frozen withdrawals from real estate funds as investors rush to redeem their money. The uncertainty has prompted concerns about the long-term outlook for London's property market.

site_title: Global air passenger traffic demand up 4.6% in May: IATA
summary: Global air passenger traffic demand rose 4.6% in May, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). This slowdown from the start of the year is attributed to attacks in major cities and the fragile global economy. Capacity increased 5.5%, but load factor dropped 0.7 percentage points to 78.7%. IATA Director General Tony Tyler stated that the shocks of Istanbul and the Brexit vote make an early uptick in travel demand unlikely.

images.alt_text: Global demand for air travel rose 4.6 per cent in May, slowing from a strong start to the year, with attacks in major cities and the fragile global economy affecting travel demand, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) said on Thursday.

site_title: Temasek unit buys majority stake in Malaysia's Aurum Healthcare
summary: Temasek Holdings, through its unit Accuron Technologies Ltd, has acquired a majority stake in Malaysia-based Aurum Healthcare Sdn Bhd, which will be subsumed into Singapore-based Advanced Materials Technologies (AMT). The deal aims to expand AMT's manufacturing footprint in Malaysia and transform it into an integrated medical device outsourcing specialist. With the acquisition, AMT's manufacturing capabilities will expand to 140,000 sq ft, and the company plans to scale up and diversify in the fast-growing medtech outsourcing sector in Asia.

site_title: Carney's questionable commitment to rate cuts
summary: Mark Carney, the Bank of England governor, indicated in a speech after the UK's EU referendum that the economy will weaken and the bank is ready to cut interest rates to correct matters. This move appears to contradict his previous warnings about the UK's large external current account deficit, which would make rate cuts a risky policy response in the event of capital outflows and a weak currency. Carney's signal of potential interest rate cuts this summer raises concerns about his commitment to attaining the bank's inflation target and handling the economic uncertainty following the Brexit vote.

site_title: India's US$4 smartphone seems too good to be true
summary: India's Ringing Bells Pvt is set to launch the world's cheapest smartphone, the Freedom 251, priced at 251 rupees (S$5). The device boasts a quad-core processor and 4-inch screen, but experts say the company will lose money on each unit due to manufacturing costs. Managing director Mohit Goel plans to recoup losses through advertising and marketing deals. The launch has attracted scrutiny and protests from buyers, raising questions about the company's business model and ability to turn a profit.

site_title: Shell takes sacked UK workers overseas service tax breaks
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has changed its redundancy terms for UK workers to claim tax refunds on severance payments, reducing the amount of money workers will receive. The company is slashing 5,000 jobs due to low oil prices and its merger with BG Group. The change means Shell will claim tax reliefs on severance payments, rather than allowing employees to claim them themselves. This could result in significant savings for the company, with one example showing an employee receiving £68,500 after tax, down from £100,000.

site_title: Brexit puts London's offshore renminbi lead under threat
summary: Brexit has cast a shadow over London's status as the top offshore renminbi hub in Europe, with China reviewing its renminbi strategy for Europe. The UK's exit from the EU may lead to barriers for selling London-based renminbi products to European investors and restrictions on EU investors' ability to buy London-originated renminbi products. However, London's advantages in foreign-exchange trading, time zone, and language are expected to maintain its position as the leading offshore renminbi hub, with other European cities such as Luxembourg and Frankfurt gaining attention from China.

site_title: Four-seater models lower average age of Ferrari buyers
summary: Ferrari's four-seater models, the GTC4Lusso and California T, are helping to lower the average age of its buyers, from 55 to 45, by attracting younger customers. The four-seater GTC4Lusso, in particular, is used more often due to its practicality, with owners averaging 12,000 km per year. The California T is used as a daily car for 20% of its buyers, with two-thirds of owners having at least one passenger. Ferrari aims to target the 35-45 age group to spur sales growth, with Asia expected to account for 22% of sales in 2016.

images.alt_text: YOUNG AND SPORTY: Ferrari, Mr Knechtel (right) explains, wants to be recognised as 'the most exclusive sports car manufacturer'.

site_title: Seoul: Won takes a breather after rally, stocks up
summary: The South Korean won dropped 0.3% to 1,148.5 on Monday, snapping a four-session rally, as investors took a breather. The won had reached a near two-month high on Friday amid recovering appetite for riskier assets after the Brexit vote. Shares, however, edged higher, with the Kospi index up 0.4% at 1,994.59 points. Analysts expect the won to trade between 1,147 and 1,154, with concerns over Brexit and a weakened yuan keeping the currency under pressure.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OCBC Bank purchased 611,800 shares of Great Eastern Holdings for S$12.6 million, increasing its shareholding from 87.6% to 87.73%. Vashion Group plans a 9-for-1 rights issue to raise S$5.09 million. KrisEnergy CEO Keith Cameron will retire, with Jeffrey S Macdonald taking over as interim CEO. Ascendas Reit appointed Lim Hock San as an independent director, effective Friday.

site_title: Analysts see further boost to S-Reits amid Brexit fallout
summary: Analysts predict further growth for Singapore Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) amid the Brexit fallout and low federal fund rates, with a 5.7% rise since the UK referendum. Brokerages Religare and RHB expect S-Reits to continue performing well, citing their stable dividend distribution policies, lower volatility, and higher yield spreads. Analysts forecast a 10% upside for S-Reits in the near term, assuming no further compression in bond yields.

site_title: Singapore could partner IEA to do more: Iswaran
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran announced the country's potential partnership with the International Energy Agency (IEA) to host regular training sessions on low carbon technologies and energy efficiency in the region. Singapore supports the IEA's associate membership initiative and plans to work collaboratively with the agency to address growing energy consumption in Asia. The partnership aims to develop capabilities in emerging economies, including those in Asia, to set the foundations for their energy policies for the next few decades.

images.alt_text: LNG storage tanks at the Singapore LNG terminal on Jurong Island.
Mr Iswaran says that the adoption of natural gas as an alternative to more carbon-intensive fuels is the way forward.

site_title: 13 charged over deadly Istanbul aiport bombings: report
summary: Thirteen suspects, including 10 Turks, have been charged over the deadly Istanbul airport bombings that killed 45 people, including 19 foreigners. The Islamic State jihadist group is blamed for the attack. Turkish officials have arrested 29 people, including foreigners, and are investigating the strike's organiser, Akhmed Chatayev, who allegedly planned two deadly bombings in Istanbul this year. The bombings have had a significant impact on Turkey's tourism industry, with Germany warning its citizens to exercise caution when traveling to the country.

images.alt_text: Thirteen suspects, including 10 Turks, were charged Sunday over the Istanbul airport suicide bombings, the deadliest of several attacks to strike Turkey's biggest city this year, the Dogan news agency reported.
